preface.title: FOREWORD
preface.p: In the introduction to the Book of Genesis, note was taken of Ibn Ezra’s influence on biblical exegesis. However, Ibn Ezra was not only a great Bible commentator, he was also a profound thinker who greatly influenced Jewish philosophical and mystical thought. Hence, as we approach the conclusion of Ibn Ezra’s commentary on the Pentateuch a discussion of this commentary’s influence on the development of Jewish thought seems appropriate.

Moses Maimonides was beyond doubt the greatest medieval Jewish philosopher. Students of Jewish philosophy have noted a close affinity between the philosophical writings of Abraham Ibn Ezra and those of Moses Maimonides. Entire passages in Maimonides’ Guide for the Perplexed (translated by M. Friedlander, Dover Publishing Co., New York, 1956, reprint of the 1904 revised edition) appear to elaborate points made by Ibn Ezra.

Ibn Ezra believed that man’s uniqueness lies in his intellect. He tells us that “man’s intelligence is the angel which mediates between him and his God” (I.E., Vol. 1, Introduction, p. 10). Maimonides held a similar point of view (Guide, 1:1, p. 14; 3:51, p. 386).

Ibn Ezra held that the Torah is to be interpreted in accordance with the dictates of reason. He believed that “every precept, be it minor or major, must be weighed in the scale of one’s heart wherein the Eternal has planted some of his wisdom. Thus when there appears something in the Torah that is intellectually impossible to accept or contrary to the evidence of our senses, then we must search for a hidden meaning. This is so because intelligence is the basis of the Torah. The Torah was not given to ignoramuses” (I.E., Vol. 1, Introduction, p. 10).

Maimonides had an identical notion. In fact, one of his reasons for writing the Guide for the Perplexed was to interpret traditional Jewish teachings in accordance with the dictates of reason (Introduction to the Guide, p. 2). One of his methods of doing so is to attribute secret meanings to passages in the Bible, Talmud, and Midrash which contradict reason (Ibid., p. 3).

Ibn Ezra believed that there are secret interpretations of the Torah that are best kept from the common people and that it is necessary to write in such a way that only the initiated will understand. Thus he notes that there is a bird that cannot see on sunny days and is able to see only at night. In other words, some people are better kept in the dark, for they cannot comprehend the full truth (I.E., Vol. 1, Introduction, p. 14). Throughout his commentary Ibn Ezra hints at secrets, either by actually saying so or by such statements as and the intelligent will understand, or I cannot explain, or a secret (sod) is hidden here.

This is precisely the method chosen by Maimonides in the Guide. In a sentence reminiscent of Ibn Ezra’s parable of the bird that cannot see during the day, Maimonides writes that Scripture spoke in metaphors “in order that the educated may comprehend it according to the measure of their faculties and the feebleness of their apprehension, while the educated persons may take it in a different sense” (Guide, Introduction, p. 4).

According to Ibn Ezra man gains immortality by developing his soul. “If the soul grows wise it will share the secrets of the angels and will then cleave to God the Glorious” (I.E. on Ex. 3:15; see also Yesod Mora, 1). Maimonides had a similar notion (Guide, 3:8, p. 26; 3:54, p. 395).

According to the Talmud the expression dibberah torah kelashon bene adam (the Torah spoke in the language of man) is employed only in a halakhic sense. No laws are to be extended or derived from what appears to be biblical verbosity, as in the phrase hikaret yikaret (shall utterly be cut off) (Num. 15:31), or ish ish (any man) (Lev. 15:2), or ganev yigganev (but if it be stolen) (Ex. 22:11).

Ibn Ezra also applies the above to those parts of Scripture which speak of God in human terms. Thus in commenting on Gen. 1:26 (Vol. 1, p. 46,47) Ibn Ezra writes: “We know that the Torah spoke the language of man, for it was given to humans who speak and hear. Now a human being cannot speak of things above or below him without employing human terminology. Hence Scripture uses such terms as the mouth of the earth (Num. 16:30), the hand of the Jordan (Num. 13:29), and the head of the dust of the world” (Prov. 8:26).

Similarly in commenting on for in six days the Lord made heaven and earth and He ceased from work and rested on the seventh day, I.E. writes, ve-hatorah dibberah ke-lashon bene adam (the Torah spoke in the language of man) (I.E. on Ex. 31:17, Vol. 2, p. 652).

Maimonides follows suit in his commentary on the Mishnah (Introduction to Chapter 10 of Sanhedrin); in his Mishneh Torah (Hilkhot Yesode Ha-Torah, 1:9); and in the Guide for the Perplexed (1:26,27, pp. 35,36).

There are many aggadot in the Talmud which run counter to reason. Ibn Ezra claimed that many of these aggadot have a secret meaning. “There is a secret meaning to the midrashic statement to the effect that the world will exist for 6,000 years (I.E. on Gen. 1:15, Vol. 1, p. 33); as to the Midrash which states one (the sun) was not greater than the other (the moon), there is a secret meaning to it” (I.E. on Gen. 1:16, Vol. 1, p. 39). “The Rabbinic statement that Noah drank from his vineyard on the day he planted it is not to be taken literally” (I.E. on Gen. 9:20, Vol. 1, p. 127). “Our sages say that God showed Moses the knot of the tefillin. These words are correct. However, its meaning is not in accordance with that of the wise men of this generation who interpret the Rabbinic statement literally. On the contrary, this has a deeply hidden secret meaning” (I.E. on Ex. 33:21, Vol. 2, p. 693).

Maimonides similarly believed that many aggadot have a hidden meaning. In his introduction to the Guide he tells us that he refrained from writing a work explaining the aggadot because when a person who is both religious and well-educated reads them he will either take them literally and question the reasoning abilities of their author (which, according to Maimonides offers no challenge to faith), or he will assume that the passages in question has some secret meaning (Guide, Introduction, p. 5).
Speaking of God, Ibn Ezra writes: “Hu le-vado yode’a, veda’at ve-yadu’a (He is the knower, the content of His thought, and the object of His thought)” (Ex. 34:6).

This dictum is often quoted by Maimonides (Introduction to Tractate Avot; Hilkhot Yesode Ha-Torah 2:10). He also devoted an entire chapter of the Guide for the Perplexed (1:68) to explaining this concept.

The medieval Jewish philosophers were concerned with explaining the divine commandments. Saadiah Gaon divided the commandments into traditional (a-rational) commandments and rational commandments. Ibn Ezra disagreed with this differentiation. Believing that all the divine commandments are rational, he argues: “All of the commandments fall into one of the following two categories. One category consists of rational laws which God implanted into the minds of all intelligent human beings. There are many such commandments. The only one of the Ten Statements which does not fall into this category is the command to observe the Sabbath…The second category that the precepts fall into is that of ‘Hidden Commandments,’ that is, commandments for which the Torah does not reveal any reason. Far be it, far be it for one to even think that any of these commandments contradict reason. We must in all instances observe everything that God has commanded us, whether their secret has or has not been revealed to us…(we) must search for its meaning in the books of the wise men, of blessed memory…we must investigate and try to understand it with all our strength” (I.E. on Ex. 20:1, Vol. 2, pp. 407-409).
Maimonides accepted Ibn Ezra’s premise. He too asserts that all commandments of the Torah have a purpose and that their purposes can be discovered (Guide, 3:26, pp. 310-312).

However, Maimonides differs with some of the reasons which Ibn Ezra gave for the commandments. Ibn Ezra believed that some commandments, such as the ones concerning priestly garments and the temple service, have astrological or mystical import (I.E. on Ex. 25:40, Vol. 2, pp. 558-562; Ex. 20:5, Vol. 2, pp. 591-598). Maimonides disagreed. He gave a purely rational explanation for all the commandments.

Ibn Ezra held that ultimate religious development requires an ascetic life. “Note that most people are slaves to worldly lusts. The true king, the one who has a crown, the one who wears the royal diadem, is the person who is free from this lust” (I.E. on Num. 6:7, Vol. 4, p. 43). I.E. believed that Moses refrained from sexual relations with his wife because of his spirituality (I.E. on Num. 12:1, Vol. 4, p. 94, and notes thereto). Maimonides had a similar notion (Guide, 3:8, p. 263).
Ibn Ezra considered man to be a microcosm (olam katan) (Ibn Ezra on Gen. 1:26). Maimonides agreed with this concept (Guide, 1:72, pp. 113-119).
It is impossible to say how much Maimonides actually took from Ibn Ezra. However, there can be no doubt that the influence was substantial.

The writings of Ibn Ezra served as basic texts for many Jewish scholars. Leon Jehuda Mosconi, who wrote a supercommentary on Ibn Ezra’s commentary on the Pentateuch (between 1362 and 1370), noted that he was aware of thirty supercommentaries on Ibn Ezra’s works. Solomon Delmedigo of Candia (1591-1655) similarly reported seeing some twenty-four commentaries on Ibn Ezra in Constantinople.

Ibn Ezra’s thinking not only influenced Jewish philosophers, it also affected mystical trends of Jewish thought. The writings of Ibn Ezra influenced the Haside Ashkenaz, the Kabbalists [I. Tishby, The Wisdom of the Zohar (Hebrew), Israel, 1957, pp. 90,91], and the Hasidic movement.

Ibn Ezra taught that God is one. He is the creator of all. He is all. According to Ibn Ezra, God’s relationship to the world is comparable to the relationship of the number “one,” which is the first all numbers and is found in all numbers (I.E. on Ex. 33:21, Vol. 2, p. 695). Similarly, the world emanated from God, and from this aspect God can be said to be all. The Hasidic movement has a similar belief. Hasidic doctrine stresses that there is no place devoid of God’s presence (let atar panuy mineh) (Sheneyur Zalman of Ladi, Tanya, 22; Iggeret Ha-Rav, 1:218).

Ibn Ezra held that the true religious life consists in directing one’s thoughts to God and cleaving to God. In his commentary on Num. 20:8 he writes, “When the part (man) knows the All (God), he cleaves (yidbak) to the All and creates signs and wonders with the help of the All.” I.E. believed that cleaving to God will ultimately lead to eternal life (Deut. 11:22). This is the purpose of the commandments. Thus Ibn Ezra writes: “The intelligent man will…isolate himself for the purpose of studying and mediating upon God’s law and observing the Lord’s precepts…His soul will cleave to God and enjoy the fullness of the joy of God’s presence…”(Yesod Mora, Chapter 7).

The above came to be known as the practice of devekut (cleaving to God). The concept of devekut is a prime element in Jewish mystical thought. Rabbi Jehiel Michal of Zlotchov describes the experience of devekut as follows: “A man’s heart should be constantly in dread and awe of God and that the love of God should burn always in his heart…All man’s psychological faculties [must be devoted to] clear and pure thoughts on God constantly, and in separation from every pleasure” (Derekh Emet quoted in Hasidic Prayer by Louis Jacobs, pp. 20,21). According to the great eighteenth-century kabbalist Rabbi Moshe Chaim Luzzato, devekut means “directing oneself to God. It means recognizing God every day and finding ways to understand His presence in the world. This could include the study of holy books. This could take the form of prayer or meditation” (Gila Nievwenholzon-Gerzoni, The Works of Unification and Devekut in the Writings of Moshe Chaim Luzzato, p. 7). It is noteworthy that the Hasidic movement, which would be expected to be critical of Ibn Ezra, actually had a positive attitude toward him. This was because they felt a special affinity for Ibn Ezra’s spiritual side. Thus Rabbi Simchah Bunim of Peshischa is reported to have said that he could not understand how Ibn Ezra was able to remain alive here on earth in view of his great piety and fear of God (M.H. Cherez, Commentary on Ibn Ezra, Gen. p. 9). The leader of Chabad, Rabbi Yosef Yitzchak, reports that it is traditional among the Chabad Chasidim to alternate yearly the study of the weekly Torah portions between Rashi and Ibn Ezra, Rashi and Nahmanides, and Rashi and the Or Ha-Chayyim.

Rabbi Pinchus of Koretz greatly loved Ibn Ezra’s commentaries. He argued that Ibn Ezra had the soul of a tanna, a teacher of the Mishnah, and hence had the authority to disagree with Rabbinic sages. Rabbi Pinchus was careful to chant Ibn Ezra’s Sabbath song, “If I keep the Sabbath, God will keep me,” every Friday night (Isaac Weiss, Elef Katav, Bene Brak, 1997, #481).

Baruch Spinoza is considered the father of modem Biblical criticism. Spinoza did not believe that Moses was the author of the Pentateuch. He claimed that Ibn Ezra had a similar belief. Spinoza writes:

In order to treat the subject methodically, I will begin with the received opinions concerning the true authors of the sacred books, and in the first place speak of the author of the Pentateuch, who is almost universally supposed to have been Moses. The Pharisees are so firmly convinced of his identity, that they account as a heretic anyone who differs from them on the subject. Wherefore, Aben Ezra, a man of an enlightened intelligence, and no small learning, who was the first, so far as I know, to treat of this opinion, dared not express his meaning openly, but confined himself to dark hints which I shall not scruple to elucidate, thus throwing full light on the subject (A Logico-Political treatise, Chapter 7).
Was Spinoza correct?

In his commentary on the Pentateuch, I.E. hints that there are verses or parts of verses in the Pentateuch which are post-Mosaic. Thus in commenting on And the Canaanite was then in the land (Gen. 12:6), which implies that the Canaanites were no longer in the land when this part of the verse was written, I.E. notes, “It is possible that the Canaanites seized the land from some other tribe at that time. Should this interpretation be incorrect, then there is a secret meaning to the text. Let the one who understands it remain silent.”

Commenting on Deut. 1:1, Ibn Ezra writes, “If you will understand the secret of the twelve, and of And Moses wrote (Deut. 31:22); And the Canaanite was then in the land (Gen. 12:6); as it is said to this day. In the mount where the Lord is seen (Gen. 22:14); and behold, his bedstead was a bedstead of iron (Deut. 3:11), you will recognize the truth [concerning the first five verses of Deuteronomy as well].”

Ibn Ezra’s point is that the last twelve verses of Deuteronomy, which describe the death of Moses, were not written by Moses. The same applies to Deut. 3:11, for Moses would not say, behold, his bedstead was a bedstead of iron; is it not in Rabbah of the children of Amon, to the Israelites of his generation, for he had no need to tell the people of his generation that Og’s great height could be verified by the size of his bed. The people whom Moses was addressing were the very ones who fought against Og. They knew of Og’s height. Hence this verse must have been written some time after Moses’ generation had passed away. I.E. similarly believed that as it is said to this day: In the mount where the Lord is seen was not written by Moses, for Mount Moriah was not a place of pilgrimage in the days of Moses. Ibn Ezra argues that just as these words were not written by Moses, neither were the first five verses in Deuteronomy.

According to Talmudic tradition the entire Pentateuch was written by Moses (Baba Batra 15a). According to the eighth and ninth of Maimonides’ thirteen principles of Judaism, a Jew is obligated to believe that the entire Torah which we now possess was given by God to Moses, that this Torah was dictated by God to Moses, and that nothing is to be added to it or subtracted from it (Sanhedrin, Commentary on the Mishnah, Introduction to Chapter 11). Despite this, there are Rabbinic precedents for Ibn Ezra’s assertion that the Torah contains post-Mosaic glosses. Some sages are of the opinion that the last eight verses of Deuteronomy were added to the Pentateuch by Joshua (Baba Batra 15a). Furthermore, Rabbinic literature speaks of tikkune soferim, editorial changes in the Torah made by the scribes.

We thus read in the Midrash Beresheth Rabba 49:12: “And the men turned from thence, and went toward Sodom; but Abraham stood yet before the Lord (Gen. 18:22). Rabbi Simon said: This is a scribal emendation (tikkun soferim), for the Divine presence waited for Abraham.”

In other words, the original reading of the text was claimed to be: And the men turned from thence, and went toward Sodom; but the Lord stood yet before Abraham. However, out of respect for God the scribes changed the text so that our Bible reads: but Abraham stood yet before the Lord.

Midrash Tanchumah, Beshalach 16 states that the original reading of And if Thou deal thus with me, kill me, I pray Thee, out of hand, if I have found favor in Thy sight; and let me not look upon my wretchedness (Num. 11:15) was: And if Thou deal thus with me, kill me, I pray Thee, out of hand, if I have found favor in Thy sight; and let me not see Thy (God’s) wretchedness.

Midrash Tanchumah, Beshalach 16 similarly states that the original reading of one…of whom the flesh is half consumed when he cometh out of his mother’s womb (Num. 12:12) was, half of our flesh was consumed when we cometh out of our mother’s womb.

According to Tanchumah, Beshalach 16, the men of the Great Assembly were responsible for the tikkune soferim. Some scholars cite other Rabbinic sources that credit Ezra with these textual changes (tikkune soferim) (Marc Shapiro, Torah U-Maddah Journal, Vol. 4, 1993, p. 199).

It should also be noted that I.E. was not the only medieval rabbi who believed that there are some glosses or slight changes in the text of the Torah. Thus Rabbi David Kimchi (c. 1160-1235) notes that the word Dan in Gen. 14:14 is post-Mosaic. He argues that the original reading of Gen. 14:14 was “and pursued as far as Leshem.” Rabbi Kimchi maintains that after the tribe of Dan conquered the city of Leshem and changed its name to Dan (Josh. 19:47), the reading of Gen. 14:14 was changed to read “and pursued as far as Dan” as in our texts of Scripture (Radak on Gen. 14:14).

Others went much further than I.E. Rabbi Judah Ha-Hasid of Regensburg (d. 1217), the author of the Sefer Hasidim and one of the Tosafists, believes that the clause And he set Ephraim before Manasseh (Gen. 48:20) is not Mosiac. He believes that it was inserted in the verse by Joshua or by a member of the Great Assembly. According to Rabbi Judah the meaning of And he set Ephraim before Manasseh is not that Jacob set Ephraim before Manasseh but that Moses placed Ephraim before Manasseh when they marched in the wilderness (Num. 10:22,23). (See Ben Zion Katz, Jewish Bible Quarterly, Vol. 25, No. 1, 1997, p. 23).

Rabbi Judah believes that Psalm 136 originally followed Num. 21:18 and that King David removed it from the Book of Numbers and inserted it into Psalms. He similarly believes that David removed all other anonymous psalms composed by Moses from the “Chumash (Pentateuch)” and placed them in the Book of Psalms [Ibid., p. 26; see also Israel Ta Shema in Ma-she-hu Al Bikkoret Ha-Mikra Be-Ashkenaz Be-yeme Ha-Benayim, in The Bible in The Light of Its Interpreters (Hebrew), Jerusalem, 1994].

Rabbi Judah also believes that the men of the Great Assembly inserted verses 31-39 into Chapter 36 of Genesis (Katz, p. 29). It should be noted that I.E. suggested that a commentary containing a similar comment be burned. (See I.E. on Gen. 36:31, Vol. 1, p. 341).

It is noteworthy that Maimonides’ position on the text of the Pentateuch did not prevent him from charging his son not to spend time on any other commentaries save those of Ibn Ezra, “which alone are meaningful and profitable to all who study them with intelligence, understanding and deep insight.” (I.E., Vol. 1, Preface, p. VIII). (However, there are those who believe that Maimonides’ charge to his son is apocryphal.) Ibn Ezra’s position on post-mosaic glosses in the Pentateuch did not prevent Rabbi Maimonides’ son from studying Ibn Ezra’s works and constantly quoting him in his commentary.

Furthermore, Rabbi David Ha-Nagid, a direct descendant of Maimonides, asked Rabbi Joseph ben Eliezer (fourteenth century) to explain to him the secrets at which Ibn Ezra hints. In explaining Ibn Ezra’s position on post-Mosaic glosses in the Torah, Rabbi Joseph writes: “Since we must believe in tradition and in the words of prophecy what difference does it make to me whether Moses wrote it or another prophet wrote it since it is all true and it is prophetic. If you say, does not the Torah state, Ye shall not add [unto the word which I command you] (Deut. 4:2), the answer is: Rabbi Abraham [Ibn Ezra] wrote…that words are like bodies and their meanings are like souls…(Ex. 20:1). Furthermore, Ye shall not add only applies to the commandments…not to words. (Tzoffnat Pane’ach) on Gen. 12:6 as quoted by M.E. Stem, Kokheve Ya’akov, No. 27, Vienna, 1862, pp. 33,34).

It is worthy of note that Nachmanides, who often took issue with I.E. and who believed that the text of the Torah preceded the creation of the world (see C.B. Chavel, Nachmanides’ Introduction to the Pentateuch, 1959, p. 2), never condemned I.E.’s hints of post-Mosaic writings in the Torah.

Normative orthodoxy ultimately accepted Maimonides’ opinion. They argued that the tikkune soferim do not refer to actual changes in the text of the Bible. They claim that what the midrash means by tikkune soferim is that Moses employed euphemisms (Rabbi Joseph Albo, Sefer Ha-Ikkarim, translated by I. Husik, Philadelphia, 1930, Vol. 3, pp. 189-200). Thus Rabbi Shabbatai Bass (1641-1718) quotes Rabbi Solomon ben Adrat (1235-1319) as saying that the term tikkune soferim “does not, God forbid, intend to teach that they [the scribes] added or addended even one letter to Scripture” (Sifte Chachamim on Gen. 18:22). Rabbi Joseph Albo stated the same (Ibid.).

It should be noted that I.E. himself did not believe that there were any tikkune soferim in Scripture. However, he based his opinion on exegetical grounds. He wrote, “one who correctly interprets the Torah does not need to assume any scribal emendations (tikunne soferim)” (I.E., Vol. I, Introduction, p. 18).

Contemporary orthodox authorities claim that citations in I.E., Radak, Rabbi Judah Ha-Hasid, and others are misinterpretations, forgeries, or glosses inserted in the commentaries by erring students (see Rabbi Moshe Feinstein, Iggerot Moshe, Orach Chayyim, Part 4, Bene Berak, 1981, pp. 358-361). They believe that the whole issue should be ignored.

While it is true that one can argue that I.E. opened the door to biblical criticism by going somewhat further than the Talmud, it is a far cry from I.E., who added some six small emendations to those of the Talmud and Midrash, to Spinoza and to biblical criticism that questions the entire Mosaic authorship of the Pentateuch. Spinoza and his followers totally misrepresented the views of I.E.

Others projected their own conflicts onto Ibn Ezra. Thus Zalmen Shazar, the late president of Israel, claimed that Ibn Ezra led a double life, putting on a facade of piety while secretly harboring doubts with regard to certain elements in the Rabbinic tradition. Shazar, like Spinoza, considered Ibn Ezra to have been one of the forerunners of modern biblical criticism. He believed that Ibn Ezra suffered great emotional stress because he could not openly express his beliefs. Shazar hints that Ibn Ezra’s cynicism can be traced to this inner conflict. (M. Soloweitschik and S. Rubasscheffs, Toledot Bikoret HaMikra, Berlin, 1935, pp. 42-50).

Abraham Geiger had a similar notion. Anticipating Freud, he claimed that Ibn Ezra often poured invective on heretics because deep down he agreed with them (I.E. Twersky, Rabbi Abraham Ibn Ezra, Studies in the Writings of a Twelfth-Century Jewish Polymath, p. 139).
Michael Creizenbach (1789-1842) of Frankfurt, a nineteenthcentury Reform rabbi and Ibn Ezra scholar, considered Ibn Ezra a kindred spirit and a precursor of Reform Judaism (Twersky, Ibid., p. 136).

The fact of the matter is that Ibn Ezra was a pious and believing Jew. In fact, Ibn Ezra taught that if faith is lacking, religious practice is meaningless. He emphasized that the Rabbinic tradition is true and is to be followed. What he did was to show us that we should place Rabbinic interpretation and the plain reading of the text in their proper prospective. Ibn Ezra was no more responsible for the misinterpretation of his work than the prophet Isaiah was for the Christian misinterpretation of Is: 7:14.

Rabbi Johanan ben Zakkai compared his student Rabbi Eleazar ben Arakh to a flowing spring (Avot 2:11). The same may be said of Rabbi Abraham Ibn Ezra. He has been a fount of learning and a source of intellectual inspiration from the twelfth century to our own day. There is no doubt that he will do the same for coming generations.
H. Norman Strickman
Touro College
September 11, 2001

chapter.title: CHAPTER 1
chapter.p: In the name of the one who speaks righteousness
and declares things that are right1
I will explain the Torah portion which begins
with These Are The Words.

Some say that the meaning of eleven days’ journey from Horeb…by the way of mount Seir (v. 2) is: Look. They traveled for forty years in the wilderness.2 This is the meaning of And it came to pass in the fortieth year (v. 3).3 However, they err, for Israel came up to Kadesh-barnea in the second year.4 Actually, And it came to pass in the fortieth year is connected to that Moses spoke5 (v. 3).

I believe that These are the words (v. 1) refers to the precepts recorded in the Torah portions Re’ah Anokhi,6 Shoftim,7 Ki Tetze,8 and Ve-hayah Ki Tavo,9 which were already spoken by Moses when they were in the wilderness. Moses spoke (v. 1) should be read as if written twice.10 This means Moses spoke,11 in the wilderness, in the Arabah, and in Suph from the day that they journeyed from Sinai.12

1. BETWEEN PARAN AND TOPHEL, AND LABAN, AND HAZEROTH, AND DI-ZAHAB. Places not mentioned in the Torah portion These Are the Stages13 (Num. 33:1). On the other hand, they might have been mentioned14 under other names, for, observe, Senir15 has three names.16 There are many other such instances.
2. IT IS ELEVEN DAYS’ JOURNEY. This means that Moses spoke these things17 in those eleven days.

FROM HOREB. That they went from Horeb to Kadeshbarnea. I have already told18 you that the spies went out from Kadesh-barnea. After God swore that they would not enter the land,19 no new commandment was given to them.20 No new commandment was revealed until the fortieth year. We find the aforementioned to be so.21 Took Moses upon him to expound this law (v. 5) is proof of this. Moses expounded the laws22 which he had stated between Paran and Tophel, for most of the commandments are in this book.23 According unto all that the Lord had given him in commandment unto them (v. 3), refers to the precepts given beyond the Jordan; in the wilderness, in the Arabah (v. 1).24

If you understand the secret of the twelve25 and also that of So Moses wrote (Deut. 31:22);26 And the Canaanite was then in the Land (Gen. 12:6);27 In the mount where the Lord is seen (Gen. 22:14);28 and behold, his bedstead was a bedstead of iron (Deut. 3:11);29 then you will recognize the truth.30

Some say that Moses died on the first day of Shevat.31 Scripture states that Israel mourned thirty days (Deut. 34:8). They spent six Sabbaths there.32 They offer proof from that selfsame day (Deut. 32:48), i.e., that Moses read this book before all of Israel in one day and then died on that very day.33 However, this is no proof, for that selfsame day refers to the song.34 Look! Scripture states, thou art to pass over the Jordan this day (Deut. 9:1).35
3. IN THE ELEVENTH MONTH. I have explained the meaning of ashte asar (eleven) in my comments on the Torah portion Nasso.36

5. TOOK MOSES UPON HIM TO EXPLAIN. Ho’il (took upon himself) and be’er (to explain) are two verbs in the perfect attached to each other without a connective vav.37 We find the same in chamak avar (had turned away, and was gone) (Cant. 5:6).

Look! Moses began to explain to the children who were born in the wilderness what happened to their fathers. He related to them all the commandments. They would also hear from the mouth of the faithful messenger the Ten Statements which their fathers heard from God.
6. HOREB. This is Sinai,38 as I have previously noted.
7. TURN YOU. Leave this place.
AND TAKE YOUR JOURNEY. It is the style of Scripture to say, u-se’u lakhem39 (and take your journey). Compare, lekh lekha40 (get thee out) (Gen.2:1).
9. I AM NOT ABLE TO BEAR YOU MYSELF ALONE. Its meaning is similar to thou art not able to perform it alone (Ex. 18:18).41
10. HATH MULTIPLIED YOU. In Egypt, and the blessing which your father blessed you was fulfilled.
[AS THE STARS OF HEAVEN.] This is a metaphor.
[11. A THOUSAND TIMES.] The word pe’amim (times) comes with elef (a thousand)42 and with me’ah (a hundred).43 The reverse is the case in Arabic.44
12. YOUR CUMBRANCE. Torchakhem (your cumbrance) is related to the word torach (burden) in They are a burden unto me (Is. 1:14).45 Your cumbrance refers to teaching the commandments to the simple.
AND YOUR BURDEN. They demanded bread, water, and meat. Compare, that Thou layest the burden of all this people upon me (Num. 11:11).
AND YOUR STRIFE. One with another.
13. GET YOU. The word havu (get) is irregular. Its heh46 should have been vocalized with a sheva na and a pattach.47
AND FULL OF KNOWLEDGE.48 Men who were known, men whom all recognized.
15. CAPTAINS OF THOUSANDS. I have already explained this.49

16. HEAR. Shamo’a (hear) is an infinitive. It is like the word zakhor (remember) in Remember the sabbath day (Ex. 20:8).50 Shamo’a is short for shamo’a shimu (you shall surely hear) or shimu shamo’a (you shall surely hear).51
THE STRANGER THAT IS WITH HIM. I have already explained the meaning of the term ger (stranger).52
17. RESPECT PERSONS IN JUDGMENT.53 To force judgment in favor of the person whom he [the judge] recognizes.
18. WHICH YE SHOULD DO. The reference is to the statutes and laws which he [Moses] taught them.
19. ALL THAT GREAT AND DREADFUL WILDERNESS. This is what the eleven day’s journey (v. 2) refers to.

[THE HILL-COUNTRY OF THE AMORITES.54] For Scripture states, [And the Amorites, that dwell in that hill-country, came out against you…] and beat you down in Seir, even unto Hormah (Deut. 1:44).55 This56 means that we should go out toward the hill country of the Amorites.57
21. TAKE POSSESSION. Resh (take possession) is vocalized like the word shev (sit).58 Resh is related to the word yerushah (possession).
DISMAYED. Techat (dismayed) is similar59 to the word yiddal (shall be made thin) in That the glory of Jacob shall be made thin (Is. 17:4).60 Techat comes from a double root.

22. THAT THEY MAY SEARCH THE LAND FOR US. Veyachperu (that they may search) is similar61 to la-chepor (to search out) in to search out all the land (Josh. 2:3). One who digs (chofer) searches for that which is hidden.62
BY WHICH WE MUST GO UP. At first.63
23. AND THE THING PLEASED ME WELL. Because you all assented to this.
25. AND BROUGHT IT DOWN. Moses said this because of the height of the tree.64 Actually, however, he said this because they65 were in the south.66

27. AND YE MURMURED. Va-teragenu (and ye murmured) is similar to rogenim (murmur) in And they that murmur shall learn instruction (Is. 29:24). Teragenu (murmured) is in the nifal. Compare, al te’atzevu67 (be not grieved).
29. DREAD NOT. Lo ta’artzun means dread not. Ta’artzun is related to the word ma’aritzekhem (your dread) in and let him be your dread (Is. 8:13). It means the breaking of the heart by fear.68
30. HE SHALL FIGHT FOR YOU. Lakhem means for you.69
33. TO PITCH YOUR TENTS. La-chanotekhem (to pitch your tents) is not a transitive verb,70 for we do not find this form to be transitive.
TO SHOW YOU. La-re’otekhem (to show you) is vocalized with a pattach to show that the letter heh, which is placed before the direct object71 (le-hare’otekhem) is missing.
36. SAVE. The yod in zulati (save) is superfluous, for the word is found without the yod.72
AND TO HIM WILL I GIVE THE LAND THAT HE HATH TRODDEN UPON. The reference is to Hebron.73

37. [ALSO THE LORD WAS ANGRY WITH ME.] I have already shown you74 that the nun of the word appo (his anger) (Gen. 39:19) is swallowed by the peh.75 However, it is present in the Aramaic.76 Furthermore, appo is also related to the word anafta77 (thou was angry) in For though Thou was angry with me (Is. 12:1) and hitannaf (was angry)78 in Also the Lord was angry with me. Moses mentions Caleb first, then Joshua.79 I have already explained why.80
38. WHO STANDETH BEFORE THEE. This is his minister (Ex. 24:13; Num. 11:28).81
39. THAT THIS DAY HAVE NO KNOWLEDGE. That day.82
OF GOOD OR EVIL. Scripture speaks of the majority.83

41. AND DEEMED IT A LIGHT THING. The meaning of va-tahinu (and deemed it a light thing) is, and you said behold (hen).84 Do not ask how a verb85 can be derived from a word that is connected to another word,86 for we find the same with al.87 The same is true, as I have explained,88 of the word pen (lest), for we find the word afunah (I am distracted) (Ps. 88:16).89
Others say that va-tahinu is related to the word hin.90 Its meaning is a measure.91 However, this is far-fetched.
44. AND THE AMORITES…CAME OUT. The reference, as I have explained, is to the Canaanites.92
AS BEES DO. For they immediately chase after and bite whoever touches their abode.
AND BEAT YOU DOWN. I have explained the meaning of va-yakketu (and beat you down).93 It is related to the word ve-khatoti (and I will beat to pieces) (Ps. 99:24).94
UNTO HORMAH. Hormah is either the name of a place or an infinitive.95
46. SO YE ABODE IN KADESH. Kadesh-barnea.96

MANY DAYS, ACCORDING UNTO THE DAYS THAT YE ABODE THERE. In spying out the land. If one should argue, the spies alone abode there.97 [The answer is:] Scripture similarly reads, After the number of days in which ye spied out the land (Num. 14:34).98
chapter.ftnote: 2 In other words, the meaning of eleven days’ journey from Horeb unto Kadesh-barnea…by the way of mount Seir (v. 2) is, that it took them 40 years to make a journey that normally takes eleven days.
3 They came to Kadesh-barnea in the fortieth year. Verse 3 explains verse 2.

4 Moses sent out the spies in the second year following the Exodus. He sent out the spies from Kadesh-barnea. See Num. 32:8. It should be noted that Num. 13:3 identifies the place from which the spies departed as the wilderness of Paran. The commentaries explain that Kadesh-barnea is at the edge of the wilderness of Paran. See Weiser.
5 Not to Kadesh-barnea.

10 Verse 1 is to be interpreted as if written: These are the words which Moses spoke unto all Israel beyond the Jordan. He spoke these words in the wilderness, in the Arabah, etc. He spoke them on the eleven days’ journey from Horeb unto Kadesh-barnea.
11 These precepts.

12 I.E. interprets verse 1-3 as follows: These precepts, which Moses recorded in the Book of Deuteronomy beyond the Jordan, were first delivered by Moses in the wilderness between Horeb and Kadesh-barnea.
13 Wherein Moses records the journeys of the children of Israel in the wilderness.
14 There.
15 A mountain in northern Israel. See Deut. 3:9
16 It is also known as Hermon and Sirion. See Deut. 3:89.
17 These words of the Torah repeated by Moses.
18 I.E. is referring to his comments above.
20 See I.E. on Num. 20:1 (Vol. 4, p. 157).
21 The Torah does not record any commandments or prophetic utterances during this period. See I.E. on Num. 20:1 (Vol. 4, p. 157).
22 For that is what this law refers to.
23 The Book of Deuteronomy.

24 According to I.E., Moses spoke… (v. 3) is to be interpreted as: Moses spoke… according unto all that the Lord had given him in commandment unto them beyond the Jordan; in the wilderness, in the Arabah, and in all the other places mentioned earlier in the eleven days’ journey from Horeb to Kadesh-barnea.
25 The last twelve verses of the Torah. According to I.E. the last twelve verses of the Torah were not written by Moses, for they record the death of Moses.
26 I.E. believes that Moses did not write this verse.

27 I.E. believes that Moses did not write this verse, for Scripture implies that the Canaanite was then in the land but not at the time that this verse was written. See I.E. on Gen.12:6 and the notes thereto (Vol. 1, p. 151).

28 The reference is to Mount Moriah. However, in the days of Moses the temple had not yet been built. Thus Moses would not have said, In the mount where the Lord is seen. Hence this verse was inserted in the Torah at a later date.

29 The reference is to the bed of Og, king of Bashan, slain by Moses. I.E. believes that Moses would not have had to prove the height of the king by pointing to his bed, for all of Israel then knew of his height. Hence the verse is post-Mosaic.

30 That the first five verses of this book were not composed by Moses but at a later period. I.E. hints at the above because he did not want people to generalize and assume that there are other post-Mosaic additions in the Pentateuch. See I.E. on Gen. 36:31, “…Yitzchaki claims in his book that this chapter was composed during the reign of King Jehosaphat…Far be it for one to believe that our chapter was written in the days of Jehosaphat as Yitzchaki maintains. Indeed his book is fit to be burned” (Vol. 1, p. 341).
31 This opinion holds that Moses died on the very day that he explained the Torah to Israel, namely, the first day of Shevat (v. 3).

32 In the land of Moab following the death of Moses. Israel mourned Moses for 30 days (Deut. 34:8). The period of mourning concluded on the first of Adar. Israel crossed the Jordan on the tenth day of Nisan (Josh. 4:19). There are six Sabbaths between the first of Adar and the tenth day of Nisan. It should be noted that some manuscripts read: “Some say that Moses died on the first day of Adar. Scripture states that Israel mourned thirty days (Num. 34:8). They spent two Sabbaths there.” According to this opinion Moses reviewed the Torah for thirty days, and that selfsame day refers to the day that Moses finished reviewing the Torah. If this was the case, then two Sabbaths remained from the end of the period of Moses’ mourning and the tenth of Nisan. Both of these opinions take issue with Rabbinic tradition, which believes that Moses died on the seventh of Adar. According to Weiser the opinions quoted and rejected by I.E. are those of the Karaites. It is worth noting that I.E. does not quote the Rabbinic opinion.
33 They believe that that selfsame day refers to the day that Moses repeated the Torah to all of Israel.
34 The day on which Moses recited the song that opens with the words ha’azinu (give ear) (Deut. 32:1-43).

35 Israel did not cross the Jordan on the day that Moses uttered Deut. 9:1, for Scripture tells us that Israel crossed into Canaan after the death of Moses. We thus see that the term “that day” is not to be taken literally, but means at that time. The same applies to that selfsame day.
36 See I.E. on Num. 7:72 (Vol. 4, p. 54).

37 Two verbs usually are connected with a vav. Hence I.E.’s comments. According to I.E., ho’il moshe be’er (took Moses upon himself to expound) is to be explained as if written, ho’il moshe u-ve’er (Moses began and explained).
38 See I.E.’s short commentary on Ex. 3:1.
39 U-se’u lakhem literally means, and journey for yourselves. Hence I.E.’s comment.
40 Literally, go to you.
41 In other words, the meaning of our verse is, I am not able to do it alone.
42 The word elef precedes the word pe’amim.
43 We also come across the phrase me’ah pe’amim (a hundred times).
44 The Arabic word for times comes before the number.
45 They come from the same root and have a similar meaning.
46 Which is vocalized with a kamatz.
47 Beneath the heh. See I.E. on Gen. 11:4; 47:16, and the notes thereto (Vol. 1, pp. 139,140, 408).
48 Hebrew, vi-yedu’im (literally, and known). Hence I.E.’s comment.
50 Zakhor is an infinitive.

51 The word shamo’a literally means to hear. This makes no sense here. Thus I.E. believes that it is short for shamo’a shimu or shimu shamo’a (you shall hear), for it is good Hebrew style to combine a conjugated verb with an infinitive for purposes of emphasis.
52 See I.E. on Gen. 15:13 (Vol. 1, p. 173).
53 Literally, you shall not recognize faces. Hence I.E.’s comment.
54 Literally, the mountain of the Amorites.

55 Deut. 1:2 notes that Kadesh-barnea is eleven days’ journey from Horeb via Mount Seir. However, our verse (according to I.E.’s interpretation) tells us that it is eleven days’ journey from Horeb to Kadesh-barnea via the mountain of the Amorites. Therefore I.E. points out that Deut. 1:44 indicates that mount Seir and the mountain of the Amorites are next to each other.
56 The clause as the Lord our God commanded us.
57 As the Lord our God commanded us refers to the charge in verse 7 to march towards the Promised Land, namely, turn you, and take your journey, and go to the hill-country of the Amorites…
58 Both words are peh yods. Resh comes from the root yod, resh, shin. Shev comes from the root yod, shin, bet.
59 In vocalization.
60 Both words come from a double root and are similarly vocalized, except that in techat the chirik changes to tzereh because of the chet.
61 In meaning.
62 Ve-yachperu (that they may search) and la-chepor (to search out) come from the root chet, peh, resh, which means to dig. Hence I.E.’s comment.
63 For strategic purposes (Weiser).
64 In other words, the meaning of and brought it down unto us is, and they brought the fruit down from tree and delivered it to us.
65 Israel.
66 South of the Land of Israel (See I.E. on Num. 13:17, Vol. 4, p. 102). In other words, and brought it down unto us means: and brought the fruit to us from the north.
67 Which is in the nifal.
68 Ta’artzun comes from the root ayin, resh, tzadi, which means to break. Thus lo ta’artzun literally means do not be broken. Hence I.E.’s comment.
69 Lakhem literally means to you. Hence I.E.’s comment.

70 It does not mean to cause you to pitch your tents but to pitch your tents. Thus our verse should be rendered: to seek you out a place to pitch your tents, not to seek you out a place to cause you to pitch your tents [there].
71 This is probably a scribal error for the missing heh is the heh of the hifil.
72 Zulat. See II Kings 24:14.
73 See I. E. on Num. 13:22 (Vol. 4, p. 103).
74 See I.E.’s comments on Ex. 2:2 (Vol. 2, p. 32).
75 The root of appo is alef, nun, peh. In appo the nun drops out and a dagesh is placed in the peh.
76 Cf. anpa, anpin (Krinsky).
77 From the root alef, nun, peh.
78 From the root alef, nun, peh.
79 Moses mentions Caleb before Joshua.
80 Caleb is mentioned first because he quieted the people. See I.E. on Num. 14:24,30 (Vol. 4, pp. 111,113).
81 The one who standeth before thee means the one who stands before you to serve you (Krinsky).
82 This day refers to the day that God meted out the punishment to the generation that exited Egypt, not to the day that Moses reviewed the Torah.
83 Of their children. According to I.E. a person comes to the knowledge of good and evil at the age of puberty. See I.E. on Gen. 3:6 (Vol. 1, p. 68).
84 That is, Behold, we are here (hinnennu), and will go up unto the place which the Lord hath promised (Num. 14:40).
85 The word va-tahinu.
86 That is, to an adverb or preposition. See Weiser.
87 The word alah (went up) is derived from al (on).
88 In his commentary on Ps. 88:16.
89 Afunah is derived from the word pen.
90 A liquid measure. See Num. 28:5.
91 According to this interpretation the meaning of va-tahinu is, they measured; i.e., they were ready to measure the mountain, that is, to take the mountain (Sarim).

92 See I.E. on Num. 14:25 (Vol. 4, p. 112). Num. 14:45 tells us that it was the Canaanites who attacked the Israelites and beat them down, even unto Hormah. Hence I.E.’s comment. The Amorites were a branch of the Canaanite people. See I.E. on Gen. 15:16 (Vol. 1, p. 175).
93 See I.E. on Num. 14:45 (Vol. 4, p. 115).
94 Both words come from the root caf, tav, tav.
95 Meaning unto destruction, that is, until they defeated them. See I.E. on Num. 14:45 (Vol. 4, p. 115).
96 There was a city in the land of Moab called Kadesh. Hence I.E.’s comment.
97 That is, in Canaan. How then can Scripture say that Israel spent 40 days in Canaan?
98 Num. 14:31 attributes the spying out of the land to all of the Israelites. So too here.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 2
chapter.p: 5. CONTEND NOT WITH THEM. The word titgaru (contend) is similar to the word yigareh (strife) in stirreth up strife (Prov. 28:25). It means to disturb and err.1

6. YE SHALL PURCHASE FOOD OF THEM. If they want to sell.2 Some say that our clause is to be read as a question. It means that Israel had no need for food and drink in these past years. For the Lord thy God hath blessed thee (v. 7) is proof.
9. I HAVE GIVEN AR. Of Moab.3 It is possible that Sihon took Ar4 and that it returned to Maob at the end.5
10. THE EMIM. I have previously explained the meaning of Emim.6 Scripture tells us that Moab took Ar from the Emim.
11. REPHAIM. I have previously explained its meaning.7
12. THE HORITES. They are the sons of Seir the Horite (Gen. 36:20).
15. TO DISCOMFIT THEM. Le-hummam (to discomfit them) is a kal. It comes from a double root.8

16. SO IT CAME TO PASS, WHEN ALL THE MEN OF WAR WERE CONSUMED. Our verse is connected to that the Lord spoke unto me saying (v. 17).9 It is similar to And it came to pass, when Moses had made an end of writing (Deut. 31:24)10 and And it came to pass on the day when the Lord spoke (Ex. 6:28).11 There are many other such cases. It means,12 And it came to pass when they13 were consumed, God said that we are about to pass over the border of Ar.
19. AND WHEN THOU COMEST NIGH OVER AGAINST THE CHILDREN OF AMMON. The meaning of ve-karavta is, when you come close to them.14
HARASS THEM NOT. Tetzurem (harass) comes from a double root.15
NOR CONTEND WITH THEM. Titgar (contend) is in the hitpa’el. Its root ends in a heh.16
20. ZAMZUMMIM. A foreign term which was Hebraized.17 Compare, ha-achashdarpenim (the satraps) (Esth. 8:9).18
21. BUT THE LORD DESTROYED THEM. Scripture relates that God destroyed a people on behalf of the Moabites19 and gave them the land as an inheritance, as he did with Mount Seir on behalf of Esau.

23. [AS FAR AS GAZA.] Scripture reads as far as Gaza because Gaza belonged to the Philistines and there already was a covenant between Abraham and Abimelech, namely, that thou wilt not deal falsely with me, nor with my son, nor with my son’s son (Gen. 21:23).20 Scripture relates that the Avvim took Gaza.21
24. BEGIN TO POSSESS IT. The word rash (possess) comes from the word yerushah (possession).22
26. OUT OF THE WILDERNESS OF KEDEMOTH. I believe that the wilderness of Kedemoth is the same as the place called the wilderness to Mattanah (Num. 21:18).
27. THE HIGHWAY. The well-known highway.23
28. THOU SHALT SELL ME FOOD FOR MONEY, THAT I MAY EAT. If I need to.24

29. AS THE CHILDREN OF ESAU…AND THE MOABITES THAT DWELL IN AR DID UNTO ME. Some say that did unto me refers to thou shalt sell me food for money.25 If this is so, then what will they do with the inhabitants of Ar who were Moabites,26 about whom Scripture writes, because they met you not with bread and with water in the way (Deut. 23:5)?27 They were compelled to offer this interpretation28 because the king of the Edomites said, Thou shalt not pass through me (Ex. 20:18).

I believe that Israel’s request refers to, I will go along by the highway (v. 27)29 as the children of Esau did, for Israel went around Mount Seir by the highway. Indeed, Scripture reads, Ye are to pass through the border of your brethren the children of Esau, that dwell in Seir (v. 4). However, the king, that is, the king of Edom, did not allow them to pass through his country, which was near Canaan. Israel therefore passed by Ar, as Scripture records (v. 18).
Others say that they30 did not meet the Israelites31 but the Israelites bought32 from them.

31. I HAVE BEGUN. The heh of hachilloti (I have begun), which is the heh of the form,33 is vocalized with a pattach34 because of the guttural.35 Compare, ha’irotihu (roused him)36 in I have roused him up in victory (Is. 45:13).
33. AND WE SMOTE. The root nun is missing in the word va-nakh (and we smote).37
34. THE MEN. Metim (men) means people.
36. TOO HIGH. Sagevah (too high) is related to the word venisgav (shall be exalted) in And the Lord alone shall be exalted (Is. 2:11).
37. TO THE LAND OF THE CHILDREN OF AMMON. Which, as I have noted,38 is today in their hands.
ALL THE SIDE. The word yad (side) means place.39 Compare, yad (side) in by the side of the Jordan (Num. 13:29).
chapter.ftnote: 1 Strife is caused by disturbance and distance from that which is normal.
2 We will not demand that they sell food to us.
3 Ar is a Moabite city (Num. 21:28).
4 As is related in Num. 21:28.
5 At the end of the war between Sihon and Moab. I.E. comments thus because our verse speaks of Ar as belonging to the children of Lot, i.e., the Moabites.
6 See I.E. on Gen. 14:5 (Vol. 1, p. 105).
8 Its root is heh, mem, mem.
9 Even though, according to the massorah, they are in two sections.
10 This verse is connected to the verse which follows even though the next verse appears to belong in a new paragraph (Weiser).
11 This verse is connected to the verse which follows even though, according to the massorah, they do not form one section. See I.E. on Ex. 6:28 (Vol. 2, p. 141).
12 The meaning of verses 16 and 17.
13 All the men of war, those of the age of going to war among the generation that left Egypt.
14 In other words, the vav here has the meaning of when, not that of and.
15 Tzadi, resh, resh.
16 Its root is gimel, resh, heh.
17 The ending (im) is Hebrew. However, the basic word is not Hebrew.
18 Which is Persian in origin.
19 In other words, before them means on behalf of the Moabites. The previous verse mentions the Amonites. Hence I.E. points out that them in our verse refers to the Moabites.
20 Hence Israel would not be permitted to take Gaza.

21 From the original inhabitants. It was with the Avvim (a Philistine tribe) that Abraham made the treaty recorded in Gen. 21:23. However, the Kaftorim (a different Philistine tribe) displaced the Avvim. The treaty which Abraham made did not apply to this tribe. See Rashi. Israel was henceforth permitted to take Gaza.
22 Its root is yod, resh, shin. There is no yod in rash. Hence I.E.’s comment.
23 The pattach beneath the bet of ba-derekh (at the highway) indicates the definite article.
24 Israel was fed by the manna. Therefore it did not commit itself to buy food from Sihon.
25 For the children of Esau did not permit the Israelites to pass through their lands.
26 Verse 18.
27 The meaning of which is, they did not sell you bread or water.
28 That did unto me refers to thou shalt sell me food for money.
29 Israel asked Sihon to permit them to go on the highway.
30 The Ammonites and Moabites.
31 With bread and water.
32 Bread and water.
33 The hifil form.
34 Rather than with a chataf pattach.
35 The chet.
36 Which is vocalized with a pattach rather than with a chataf pattach because of the guttural, the ayin.
37 From the root nun, caf, heh. The nun in va-nakkeh is a prefix.
39 The literal meaning of yad is hand. Hence I.E.’s comment.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 3
chapter.p: 3. NONE WAS LEFT TO HIM.1 Each of the Israelites [left none to him].2 Hishir is in the perfect.
4. THE REGION OF ARGOB. The words of the Aramaic translator3 are known.4

Some say that Argob is the name of a person who possessed this region as an inheritance from his father. Some go far afield and say that the alef of Argob is superfluous and that Argob is related to the word regavim (clods) in And the clods cleave fast together (Job 38:38).5

11. AFTER THE CUBIT OF A MAN. After the cubit of a normal person. Observe, Og was double in size.6 It is unlikely that the Torah is speaking of Og’s cubit,7 for if this were so, then what is Scripture trying to teach?8 Furthermore, he would not have the image of a person at all.9
14. JAIR THE SON OF MANASSEH. I have already explained that he came from the tribe of Judah.10
THE GESHURITES AND THE MAACATHITES. Two nations.
15. TO MACHIR. This was explained.11
16. THE MIDDLE OF THE VALLEY FOR A BORDER.12 The word u-gevul (for a border)13 is be rendered, and its border.14 So too u-gevul (the border thereof) in the Jordan being the border thereof (v. 17).15

18. AND I COMMANDED YOU. Moses speaks to the children of Gad and Reuben.16 He uses the term you, not them,17 because they are included among the Israelites. The reverse is true with, that Moses commanded the Levites…Take this book of the law…For I know thy rebellion (Deut. 31:25-27).18 Moses did not address the Levites.19 On the contrary, he spoke to all of Israel.20 He addressed the Levites21 because they are included in all of Israel.

23. The meaning of va-etchannan (and I besought) is, and I had already besought.22 When Moses mentioned Joshua and said, And I commanded Joshua, etc. (v. 21) because I am not passing over with you, he had already asked the Lord to be allowed to pass over with the Israelites; for God’s greatness is unsearchable (Ps. 145:3) and They are new every morning; Great is Thy faithfulness (Lam. 3:23).23
24. THOU HAST BEGUN. The wisest of the wise24 said: Thou hast begun to show Thy servant Thy greatness, in heaven and on earth,25 i.e., the manner in which You conduct the world.
AND THY STRONG HAND. Via the signs performed through Moses so that the world learned that there is no God but the Lord. The meaning of El26 (God) is mighty.
IN HEAVEN. Wherein are the angels and the hosts.27
OR ON EARTH. Wherein are the beasts and human beings.
ACCORDING TO THY WORKS. All of which are governed by wisdom.
MIGHTY. In ability.28
This section was written to instill a love of the Land of Israel. If they love the land, they will observe God’s commandments so that they will not be exiled from the land.
27. GET THEE UP INTO THE TOP OF PISGAH. The reference is to the valley that is in the field of Moab, the top of Pisgah.29

29. SO WE ABODE IN THE VALLEY. The meaning is, and we had already stayed in this valley, which is the top of Pisgah,30 for from there31 they journeyed to the plains of Moab.32 The valley is in the mountains of Abarim, for the latter is clearly stated.33
Moses now commenced to speak about the commandments. He began with idol worship because they were near Bethpeor.34
chapter.ftnote: 1 Hebrew, hishir (he [Israel] left him).

2 Hishir (none was left) is in the singular. Thus our verse literally reads, and we smote him until he left him with no one remaining. I.E. renders this, and we smote him until each one of the Israelites left him no one standing.
3 Onkelos.
4 Onkelos renders chevel as tarchona, i.e., Trachonites. Trachonites is a district on the Golan heights.
5 They render chevel Argob as the district of clods.

6 Og was double the size of a normal person. I Sam. 17:4 tells us that Goliath’s height was six cubits and a span. This is about twice the height of a normal person. Goliath was of the Rephaim (I Chron. 20: 4-8), as was Og. Hence I.E.’s reasoning (Weiser).
7 According to Rashi, Scripture speaks of Og’s cubit when it describes his bed.
8 Since we do not know Og’s span, Scripture’s statement that Og’s bed was nine cubits long and four cubits wide is meaningless.
9 If we assume that Og’s span was twice that of a normal person, then his bed indicates that Og’s dimensions were way beyond that of a human being. I.E. did not believe that such giants existed.
10 See I.E. on Num. 32:41 (Vol. 4, p. 254).
11 It means to the children of Machir. See I.E. on Num. 32:40 (Vol. 4, p. 254).
12 Literally, the middle of the valley and border.
13 Literally, and border.
14 According to I.E. our clause should be rendered, the middle of the valley and its border.
15 Literally, the Jordan and boundary. I.E. believes that this should be rendered, the Jordan and its boundary.
16 Even though he was addressing all the Israelites.
17 Since Moses spoke to Israel, he should have used the term them when referring to Reuben and Gad.
18 Here Moses is addressing the Levites, but part of what he says is directed to Israel.
19 When he said, For I know thy rebellion…
20 When he said, For I know thy rebellion…

21 The point is that some of what Moses said when he spoke to the Levites was directed specifically at the Levites, but the rest was directed to all of Israel. Moses could address Israel while speaking to the Levites because the Levites are part of Israel.
22 Before charging Joshua. He would not beseech God to pass over the Jordan after telling Joshua that he would lead Israel into Canaan.
23 Hence Moses thought that God might relent and permit him to enter Canaan.
24 Moses.
25 I.E.’s paraphrase of the second part of our verse.
26 The term for God in our verse.
27 The stars.
28 God has the might to execute His will.
29 See I.E. on Num. 21:18 (Vol. 4, p. 172).
30 Before coming to the plains of Maob, where they presently were.
31 Mount Abiram.
32 Where they now were.
33 And they journeyed from the mountains of Abarim, and pitched in the plains of Moab (Num. 33:48).
34 Where Israel worshipped Baal of Peor. See Num. 25:3.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 4
chapter.p: 1. WHICH I TEACH YOU, TO DO THEM. The main purpose of study is the observance of the commandments.
THAT YE MAY LIVE. For those who worshipped pe’or were destroyed.1

AND POSSESS. The middle root letter of the verb vi-yerishtem (and possess)2 is vocalized with a chirik because the yod is silenced and made invisible by the chirik beneath the vav.3 There is no other word that is similarly vocalized.
2. YE SHALL NOT ADD. On your own4 and think that it is in the service of God. You shall similarly not diminish.5
Now, my6 statement that ye may live does not require witnesses, for Your eyes have seen… (v. 3).7
3. IN BAAL-PEOR. Be-va’al pe’or (in Baal-peor) means because of Baal-peor.8 There are many such instances.9 Whoever did not worship Baal-peor is alive.

5. [I HAVE TAUGHT YOU.] Moses states, I have taught you, after saying which I teach you (v. 1), because he wants to add, even as the Lord my God commanded me. The meaning of our verse is, the precepts which I taught you are God’s commandments, which you should observe in the land that God will give you for a possession. Furthermore, the commandments are your glory over the nations.

[6. YOUR WISDOM AND YOUR UNDERSTANDING IN THE SIGHT OF THE PEOPLES.] Because an intelligent person can understand the basis of all the commandments. An intelligent person can ascertain the reason why they were given.

7. FOR WHAT GREAT NATION IS THERE. That has God so near in that He always answers him in all that he intelligently10 requests of Him. Furthermore, unlike Israel there is no great nation that has statutes and ordinances that reason tells us are righteous.
A great nation means, great in intelligent people who fear the Lord.
9. ONLY TAKE HEED TO THYSELF. Its meaning is, should you forget everything, do not forget the day that you stood at Sinai.
WHICH THINE EYES SAW. The reference is to And all the people perceived the thunderings, and the lightnings (Ex. 20:15).
10. [ALL THE DAYS THAT THEY LIVE UPON THE EARTH.] Scripture says this because God knows that they can not properly observe His commandments when they are in countries where others rule over them.11
11. UNTO THE HEART OF HEAVEN. The middle of heaven.12 Scripture speaks of those who look up. The heart of the sea (Ex. 15:8) is similar.13
12. ONLY A VOICE. Which you heard,14 for the voice is not visible to the eye.15 I have already explained the meaning of And all the people saw the sounds16 (Ex. 20:15).17
14. [COMMANDED ME AT THAT TIME.] For God told Moses all the statutes and ordinances at Sinai. However, Moses related them to Israel in the second year18 and again in the fortieth year.19

[Moses tells the Israelites:] Since you saw no form (v. 12) take ye therefore good heed unto yourselves (v. 15) lest you corrapt what you saw (v. 16), that is, lest you corrupt the truth20 or your ways.21
16. A GRAVEN IMAGE. The word pesel (graven image) refers to an object that has been fashioned.22 Compare, va-yifselu (did fashion) in And Solomon’s builders…did fashion them (I Kings 5:32).

MALE OR FEMALE. Worshipped by some well-known nations. There are also nations that bow down and worship any beast that they meet at the beginning of their day in order to bring down a power from on high; for example, they worship the scorpion23 if they want someone bitten. The same applies to the remaining forty-seven forms.24
19. THE SUN AND THE MOON. Which are the great lights.25

After mentioning the stars, Scripture goes on to use a general term, namely, even all the host of heaven. All the hosts of heaven refers to the planets,26 which are light-giving stars, and all the constellations and forms.27
THOU BE DRAWN AWAY.28 You will, as it were, slip and fall.

WHICH THE LORD THY GOD HATH ALLOTTED. It has been empirically established that each and every nation has a specific star and constellation. Every city similarly has its own constellation. God raised Israel to a very high level in that God, and not any star, is Israel’s guide.29 Israel is thus God’s portion.

21. [NOW THE LORD WAS ANGERED WITH ME.] Moses says this because he had stated earlier, But you hath the Lord taken and brought forth…to be unto Him a people of inheritance (v. 20) in the land, so that you will serve Him. However, I will not share in this good.
FOR YOUR SAKES. You were the cause of my not entering the land. I have already explained this.30

23. TAKE HEED UNTO YOURSELVES…AND MAKE YOU A GRAVEN IMAGE. Moses had previously said something to this effect.31 He repeated himself because he wanted to add, For the Lord thy God is a devouring fire (v. 24). Hence32 I command you to [take heed unto yourselves…].
EVEN THE LIKENESS OF ANY THING. Temunat kol33 is to be rendered as the likeness of anything.34

WHICH THE LORD THY GOD HATH FORBIDDEN THEE. Asher tzivvekha (hath forbidden thee) is to be rendered as He commanded thee.35 Or tzivvekha may be interpreted: which He commanded you not to make.36 Compare, I will also command (atzavveh) the clouds (from raining rain upon it)37 (Is. 5:6).38 Some say that the reference39 is to the likeness of the stars.40 However, this appears to me to be far-fetched.
24. A DEVOURING FIRE. There is no kaf with the meaning of like prefixed to the word esh (fire). The meaning of esh okhlah hu (a devouring fire) is, like a devouring fire.41
A JEALOUS GOD. With regard to idol worship. His jealousy devours like fire, which does not leave root or branch.
25. WHEN THOU SHALT BEGET CHILDREN. Moses first tells the Israelites that the Lord God is a jealous God. He then tells them what will happen to them if they make an image.
AND YOU SHALL DEAL CORRUPTLY. With regard to the rest of the commandments such as to murder or to commit adultery.

26. I CALL HEAVEN AND EARTH TO WITNESS AGAINST YOU THIS DAY. Some say the witness of heaven and earth refers to the angels and the human beings.42 Others say that the reference is to the rain, as in and I will make your heaven as iron, and your earth as brass43 (Lev. 26:19). However, it appears to me that heaven and earth are witnesses, and the Israelites and their children will always see them, for they are everlasting, as in as the days of the heavens above the earth44 (Deut. 11:21). Hear, O ye mountains, the Lord’s controversy (Micah 6:2); and Behold, this stone shall be a witness against us (Josh. 24:27) are similar.45 Should one dispute this on the basis of For the heavens shall vanish like smoke46 (Is. 51:6) and the like,47 [then I respond] the one who makes this argument is awake but his heart sleeps.48
YE SHALL SOON UTTERLY PERISH. The word tovedun (ye shall utterly perish)49 is similar to tilmedun50 (that you may teach).51 The word52 is so vocalized53 because it is not in the construct.54
27. FEW IN NUMBER. I have already explained the meaning of mete (few).55

28. WHICH NEITHER SEE, NOR HEAR. Scripture mentions the four senses.56 It is unnecessary to mention the fifth57 because it is thicker58 than the others.59 Furthermore, it is the root of the life of the body.60 Do not be amazed at the terms u-vikashtem (but…ye will seek) and u-matzata (and thou shalt find)61 for Scripture speaks to many, to an entire nation, or to one person.62
29. WITH ALL THY HEART. I will explain this later.63
[31.] HE WILL NOT FAIL THEE. Yarpekha (fail thee) is the opposite of strengthen thee.64
32. FOR ASK NOW OF THE DAYS PAST. She’al na means ask now.65
SINCE THE DAY. The lamed of le-min (since) is superfluous.66 There are many such examples.67 On the other hand, it may be there for literary purposes.68
AND FROM THE ONE END OF HEAVEN. Heaven, as I have explained, refers to the air,69 which has ends.70
WHETHER THERE HATH BEEN. In his days.
OR HATH BEEN HEARD LIKE IT. The reference being to Did ever a people hear…(v. 33).
34. OR HATH GOD ASSAYED. Some say that Elohim (God) does not refer to the Lord.71 Heaven forbid. It most certainly refers to God.
ASSAYED. Scripture employs human language so that those who hear will understand.
BY TRIALS. This is a general term.72 Or it refers to trials done via signs.73 Compare, and did the signs in the sight of the people (Ex. 4:30).
AND BY WONDERS. The ten plagues. Scripture states, and Moses and Aaron did all these wonders (Ex. 11:10).
AND BY WAR. The reference is most probably to the killing of the first-born and to the punishments meted out to the gods of Egypt.74
AND BY A MIGHTY HAND. The reference is to Israel’s departure by high hand.75
The outstretched arm refers to the pillar of fire and the pillar of cloud.
AND BY GREAT TERRORS. The drowning of Pharaoh and his army along with the splitting of the sea on behalf of Israel.
IN EGYPT. To the people of Egypt.
35. IT WAS SHOWN. Horeta (it was shown) is a hofal. The meaning of our clause is, God showed you all this so that you will know that He alone is God.

[THERE IS NONE ELSE.] This is to be understood according to the hint which I gave in my commentary on Koheleth on the verse that reads, for one higher than the high (Eccles. 5:7).76 Hence Scripture reads, There is none else.77

[GOD.] I have explained the meaning of Elohim (God) in the Torah portion And Jethro Heard.78 Scripture states, And God (Elohim) spoke (Ex. 20:1); and God (Elohim) answered him by a voice (Ex. 19:19); God (Elohim) is come (Ex. 20:17); where God (Elohim) was (Ex. 20:18); for Elohim (God) was the speaker.79 [I quoted these verses] because there are some who do not understand when one is being brief.80 It is a deep secret.81

36. THAT HE MIGHT INSTRUCT82 THEE. He made thee to hear Him so that you would fear Him.83 This is borne out when Israel said, but let not God speak with us, lest we die (Ex. 20:16). Look, you feared because of what your eyes saw and your ears heard. There was another reason why God made you hear His voice. He did so because He loved your fathers (v. 37), your fathers being three.84
37. AND CHOSE THEIR SEED. Be-zaro (their seed)85 alludes to Jacob. If Scripture had read be-zaram (their seed), then the eight nations86 would have been included with us.
AND BROUGHT THEE OUT WITH HIS PRESENCE. Befanav (with His presence)87 means with His anger.88 He was angry at Egypt.
Others say that panav (presence) here is similar to panav (presence) in And the angel of His presence saved them (Is. 63:9).89
However, I believe that panav (presence) here is similar to panekha (thine own person) in and thou go to battle in thy own person (Josh. 17:11).90

38. AS IT IS THIS DAY. Close to this day.91 However, it really alludes to their possession of the land of the two Amorite kings, for Reuben, Gad, and the half tribe of Manasseh are called Israel.92 Scripture similarly reads, as Israel did unto the land of his possession (Deut. 2:12). The reference is not to the future, as many explain.93 Proof of the latter is the fact that the psalm which opens with the words, O give thanks unto the Lord, for He is good (Ps. 136) reads, To Him that smote great kings (Ps. 136:17). Now the psalm only mentions Sihon94 and Og95 (Ps. 136:19,20). The psalm says, And gave their land for a heritage…Even a heritage unto Israel96 (Ps. 136:21,22).

After stating that the Lord, He is God; there is none else beside Him (v. 35), Moses explains why by giving a very valuable reason. He begins with what the eye sees97 and goes on to logic and the wisdom of the heart.98 He says, Know that the Lord alone is God in the heavens above, that is, in the heavens which are above human beings99 and upon the earth which is under people. And thy heaven that is over thy head shall be brass [and the earth that is under thee shall be iron] (Deut. 28:23) is proof that this interpretation100 is correct.

Now that you have seen the terrors, you shall place in your heart the conviction that you are obligated to observe God’s commandments.101 The observance of God’s precepts will also go well with you and with your children after you.102
41. THEN MOSES SEPARATED. This means, on the day that Moses separated these cities, he spoke the words of the covenant.103
46. BEYOND THE JORDAN, IN THE VALLEY. The reference is to Mount Abarim before Israel journeyed to the plains of Moab,104 even though Mount Abarim is in the land of Moab.105
chapter.ftnote: 1 Verse 3. For the incident of Baal-peor, see Num. 25:1-9.
2 The resh. The root of vi-yerishtem is yod, resh, shin.
3 According to the rules of Hebrew grammar the word should be vocalized vi-yerashtem. Hence I.E.’s comment.
4 According to Rabbi Judah Ha-Levi, the Chief Bet Din may add laws to the Judaic code. The individual may not. I.E. seems to take the same position.
5 From God’s commandments.
6 Moses.
7 That God destroyed those who worshipped Baal-peor, but those who remained faithful to the Lord are alive today (v. 4).
8 The bet here has the meaning of because rather than in. I.E. renders our clause as: your eyes have seen what the Lord did because of Baal-peor.
9 Where the bet here has the meaning of because.
10 Hebrew, be-chokhmah. I.E. adds be-chokhmah to indicate that God responds only to intelligent requests. The word be-chokhmah is not found in Vat. Ebr. 28.
11 I.E. explains earth (adamah) as referring to the Land of Israel, as in Deut. 11:21.

12 The heart lies in the middle of the body. Hence heart is used in the sense of middle. See I.E. on Ex. 15:8 (Vol. 2, p. 299). When a person looks straight up, it appears to him that he is staring at the middle of the sky.
13 It means the middle of the sea. See above note.
14 Only a voice is short for you only heard a voice.
15 Hence this interpretation.
16 Translated literally.
17 Scripture interchanges the way the senses are referred to because they are all perceived in one central place. See I.E. on Gen. 42:1 (Vol. 1, p. 386). Hence Scripture uses the term saw for heard.
18 That is, from the time of the revelation at Sinai until they sent out the spies to Canaan in the second year.
20 To claim that you saw an image.
21 You make an image.
22 Hebrew, niktzav (literally, cut).
23 Which has the form of the constellation Scorpio.
24 There are 48 forms in heaven. Since I.E. already mentioned Scorpio, there are 47 remaining forms.
26 Literally, moving stars.
27 Which appear in heaven (Weiser).
28 Hebrew, ve-nidachta (literally, and you will slip). Hence I.E.’s comment.
29 Literally, advisor.
30 How Israel was the cause of Moses’ not entering the Land of Israel. See I.E. on Num. 20:8 (Vol. 4, p. 159).
31 Verses 14 and 15.
32 Moses repeats himself because he wants to add: Since the Lord Your God is a devouring fire, take heed to yourself and do not worship idols.
33 Literally, the likeness of all.
34 In other words, kol is short for kol davar (all things, i.e., any thing).

35 Asher tzivvekha (hath forbidden thee) literally reads, which He has commanded you. However, it cannot have this meaning here for then our verse would read: and make you a graven image, even the likeness of anything which the Lord your God has commanded you. Hence I.E. comments that asher tzivvekha is to be read, ka’asher tzivvekha. In other words, it is to be interpreted as, which the Lord your God had commanded.
36 In other words, commanded has the meaning of prohibited.
37 Translated literally.
38 Here too the word command has the meaning of prohibit.
39 That is, temunat kol (likeness of anything) refers to the making of an image of the stars.
40 For Deut. 5:8 speaks of kol temunah asher ba-shamayim mi-ma’al (even any manner of likeness, of anything that is in heaven above).

41 In other words, esh okhlah hu (a devouring fire) should be interpreted as if written, ke-esh okhlah hu (like a devouring fire). I.E. notes this lest anyone take our text to imply any corporeality in God.
42 In other words, I call heaven and earth to witness against you means I call the angels in heaven and the inhabitants of earth to witness against you.
43 As a result of lack of rain.
44 As the days of the heavens above the earth means eternally.
45 To heaven and earth bearing witness.
46 Which implies that the heavens are not eternal.
47 Other similar verses.
48 He does not understand the true meaning of the verse, for it is not to be taken literally.
49 The usual form of the word is tovedu. Hence I.E.’s comment.
50 The correct reading is yilmedun (v. 10). Tilmedun is not found in Scripture. See Weiser.
51 The usual form of the word is yilmedu.
52 Tovedun.
53 With a tzere rather than a sheva beneath the bet as in yilmedun.
54 If the word was closely connected to that which follows then it would have been vocalized with a sheva. Compare te’abbedun (ye shall surely destroy) (Deut. 12:2) (Krinsky).
55 Mete (few) means men of. Anything that can be numbered is deemed a few. See I.E. on Gen. 34:30 (Vol. 1, p. 330).
56 Seeing, hearing, tasting, and smelling.
57 The sense of touch.
58 Coarser.
59 The other senses are of a higher order. In other words, Scripture speaks only of the specialized senses.
60 It is spread all over the body. All parts of the body are sensitive to touch.
61 U-vikashtem (but…ye will seek) is plural. U-matzata (and thou shalt find) is singular. We would expect Scripture to be consistent.
62 Hence it employs both the singular and the plural.
63 The observance of the commandments is contingent on the perfection of the heart. See I.E. on Deut. 30:10.
64 Thus yarpekha (fail thee) means will cause you to weaken.
65 In other words, na means now. See I.E. on Gen. 12:11 (Vol 1, p. 154).
66 Le-min literally means to-from. Hence I.E.’s comment that le-min is to be interpreted as if written from (or since).
67 Of Scripture’s use of superfluous letters. See Vol. 1, p. XVII.
68 Perhaps to rhyme with le-yamim, le-miktzeh, and other lameds in our verse.
69 The firmament.

70 At the point where the firmament appears to merge with the sea. See I.E. on Gen. 1:6 and the notes thereto (Vol. 1, p. 34). From this it appears that the correct reading in I.E. on Gen. 1:6, is, as was stated, ketzot ha-shamayim rather than ketzot ha-shemesh.
71 It refers to any god.
72 It refers to all sorts of trials.
73 In other words, it refers to signs which were brought by God in bringing the children of Israel out of Egypt.
74 See I.E. on Ex. 12:12.
75 Confidently and fearlessly. See Ex. 14:8.
76 I.E. there explains that the verse alludes to a hierarchy of 55 powers in heaven.
77 That is, God is the ultimate power.
79 Hence Scripture describes God as speaking.
80 Hence one quote would be insufficient.

81 Why Scripture refers to God by the term Elohim. I.E. on Gen. 1:1 (Vol. 1, p. 26) explains that Elohim means angels and that God is referred to as Elohim because God works through the angels. I.E. seems to imply that God revealed himself on Sinai through angels rather than through His own essence.
82 Hebrew, le-yassereka (literally, to discipline you).
83 I.E. interprets le-yassereka as to put God’s fear in you. Hence his interpretation.
84 In other words, thy fathers (v. 37) refers to Abraham, Isaac and Jacob.
85 Literally, his seed.
86 The six nations descended from Keturah the concubine of Abraham (Gen. 25:2), the descendants of Ishmael, and the descendants of Esau.
87 Literally, with His face.
88 See I.E. on Lev. 26:17.
89 I.E. explains this verse as follows: And the angel which He sent with His mouth (the mouth is in the face) saved them; that is, God commanded an angel to save them.
90 In other words, panav is to be rendered presence. See I.E. on Ex. 33:14 (Vol. 2, p. 688).
91 In the near future. I.E. comments thus because Israel had not as yet possessed the Land of Israel.
92 They are part of the people of Israel. Hence if they possessed their land, Moses could speak to all of Israel that they already possessed the land of mighty nations.
93 But rather to the land possessed by Reuben, Gad and half of the tribe of Manasseh.
94 King of the Amorites who dwelled in Transjordan
95 King of Bashan.
96 Even though their land was given to the above-mentioned two and a half tribes.
97 Unto thee it was shown (v. 35).
98 That thou mightest know. I.E.’s point is that Unto thee it was shown, that thou mightest know means what you saw with your eyes convinced your mind that the Lord alone is God.
99 The layer of air. I.E. distinguished between the Heaven of Heavens (the place of the stars and planets) and the firmament. See I.E. on Gen. 1:1 (Vol. 1, p. 21).
100 That heaven refers to the firmament and not to the Heaven of Heavens.
101 Verse 40.
102 Verse 40.
103 The Decalogue, which follows in chapter 5.
104 See I.E. on Deut. 3:29.
105 For it lies in a different district.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 5
chapter.p: 1. AND MOSES CALLED UNTO ALL ISRAEL. As I have explained,1 to make the children hear the words of the covenant.2
2. IN HOREB. This is Sinai.3
3. THE LORD MADE NOT THIS COVENANT WITH OUR FATHERS. Alone.4

BUT WITH US, EVEN US. The meaning of ittanu5 (even us) is, but also with us.6 It is similar to thy name shall not be called any more Jacob (Gen. 35:10).7 Or it means the Lord did not make a covenant with our fathers who were in Egypt but only with us,8 for there were many in the camp who heard the covenant from the mouth of God.9 Moses therefore said even us, those who are here, and are alive. Moses’ words, with you (v. 4) and [I stood] between [the Lord] and you (v. 5) is proof of the correctness of this interpretation.

4. FACE TO FACE. Without an intermediary.10 This means I spoke to you, although you did not see Me. The metaphor used in our verse is that of a person who speaks to another person face to face even though the person being spoken to does not see that speaker.11
5. I STOOD BETWEEN THE LORD AND YOU. I have already explained this.12
FOR YE WERE AFRAID BECAUSE OF THE FIRE. Even though you did not go up the mountain.

[SAYING.] The word saying is connected to the previous verse.
