Its meaning is, The Lord spoke with you face to face…out of the midst of the fire (v. 4) saying.13 It is possible that I stood between the Lord and you means I stood between the Lord and you after the revelation at Sinai. Its meaning is, God spoke with you face to face [at Sinai] and from that day on I stood between the Lord and you because you were afraid,14 as Moses goes on to explain.
AND WENT NOT UP INTO THE MOUNT. When I went up. Compare, but Moses drew near unto the thick darkness (Ex. 20:18).

Do not pay attention to the fact that the word saying is far removed [from the end of verse 4],15 for there are many such instances.16 The speaker17 did not separate the verses and sections.18 Also do not pay attention to the words,19 for they are like bodies and their meanings are like souls.20 One who cuts with two similar tools produces the same result. Scripture therefore interchanges shav (false)21 (v. 17) and sheker (false) (Ex. 20:13),22 as these terms are brothers.23 All lies are vanity. I have already explained that the word zakhor (remember) (v. 8) means the same as shamor (keep).24 Moses adds,25 as the Lord thy God commanded thee (v. 12). It means, when you stood around Mount Sinai.26
14. NOR THINE OX, NOR THINE ASS, NOR ANY OF THY CATTLE. A particular followed by a general term.27 At first28 only the general term is used. Both say the same.29

THAT…MAY REST. Scripture here adds the explanation of the law regarding the man-servant and the maid-servant,30 namely, And thou shalt remember that thou was a servant.31 Now God gave rest to your servant. Therefore the Lord your God commanded [thee] to do this on the Sabbath day refers to giving rest to one’s servant.32
Some say33 that a servant does not rest.34 Now God took you out of slavery and commanded you to rest so that you will remember that you were a slave.35
In the commandment that begins with the word Honor (v. 16),36 Scripture goes on to say, as the Lord thy God commanded thee. This is to be understood in line with my interpretation.37
16. AND THAT IT MAY GO WELL WITH THEE. Some say that this alludes to the world to come. I will allude to the secret of the world to come in my comments on I kill, and I make alive (Deut. 32:39).
THY DAYS. Scripture goes on to explain that they will be good days.38

Know that all the early sages are of the opinion that I am (v. 6) is the first statement39 even though there is room to ask why the one who separated the statements did not separate Thou shalt have no other gods (v. 7).40
I have already explained the Ten Statements,41 relying on their opinion.42

However, I believe that the statement I am is not part of the Ten Statements, for the meaning of I am is, I am the one who commands. I am is the basis of the commandments, as I have explained previously.43

The word chamad (coveted) has two meanings in Hebrew.44 One is to rob, to extort, to take someone’s property by force and compulsion. This is the meaning of the word in neither shall any man covet (yachmod) thy land45 (Ex. 34:24). For if this is not its meaning, then the land is bad. But Scripture only comes to praise the land. The second meeting is to desire in the heart without acting.46

Now, Neither shalt thou covet thy neighbor’s house (Ex. 20:14) is the ninth statement, and thou shalt not covet thy neighbor’s wife (Ibid.) is the tenth statement.47 According to this interpretation, thy neighbor’s house and thy neighbor’s wife are connected to each other.48 On the other hand, thy neighbor’s house might be a general rule.49 The fact that Moses in this book [Deuteronomy] in which he explains the Torah, employs ve-lo50 titavveh (neither shalt thou covet) (v. 18) in place of lo tachmod (thou shalt not covet) (Ex. 20:14) is proof of this.51

Many say that one cannot sin with one’s thoughts and there is no reward and punishment for what one thinks. However, one can refute them by quoting many verses. I will not prolong my argument. I will merely point to the following: A heart that deviseth wicked thoughts (Prov. 6:18); thou didst well that it was in thy heart (II Chron. 6:8); And to them that are upright in their hearts (Ps. 125:4). Moses at the end52 said, in thy mouth, and in thy heart, that thou mayest do it (Deut. 30:14). The main purpose of the mitzvot is to perfect the heart. Most of them serve as a memorial.53 The distinction made between a sin committed deliberately and one committed inadvertently should convince them.54
19. THESE WORDS. Its meaning is, these Ten Statements and not the words which follow them.55
A GREAT VOICE. They never heard one like it.
AND IT WENT ON NO MORE. This occurred only one time. Observe, Scripture explains why the voice went on no more, namely, And it came to pass, when ye heard…(v. 20).
21. HIS GLORY. The appearance of fire.
AND HIS GREATNESS. The voices, the lightning, and the sound of the shofar.
AND…HIS VOICE. The Ten Statements. There is one opinion that God only uttered I am (v. 6).56
23. THE VOICE OF THE LIVING GOD. Elohim (God), as I have explained,57 is in the plural.
I believe that Scripture uses the term living to differentiate between God58 and the heavenly host,59 for the heavenly host does not move by its own power.60
24. AND THOU SHALT SPEAK UNTO US ALL. The word at (thou)61 is similar to the word at (thou) in And if Thou62 (at) deal thus with me (Num. 11:15). It is explained there.63
25. THEY HAVE WELL SAID. Hetivu (they have well) is a verb in the perfect. It comes from a root in which only two letters are sounded.64
26. OH THAT. Scripture does not say mi yitten li (oh that I) but rather mi yitten la-hem (oh that they).65 The word la-hem (they) thus follows ve-hayah levavam zeh (such a heart as this).66

Note, God’s decrees are the source of all actions and movements.67 The power and nature of all that is found beneath the heavens is determined by the arrangement of the heavenly bodies. These are connected to the roots below.68 The same applies to the compounds.69 All things similarly depend on the movements of the heavenly bodies day by day and time by time, for there is always a change,70 as the author of the Sefer Yetizrah explained.71 The parts72 receive73 from the categories74 according to their nature.75 It is due to the power of the “categories” that they76 can make some small changes in nature.77 This is the meaning of and the Lord hardened Pharaoh’s heart (Ex. 11:10).78 In another place, Scripture states, and hardened his heart, he and his servants (Ex. 9:34).79 It is all true. Scripture therefore states, O Lord, I know that man’s way is not his own (Jer. 10:23). It similarly states, O Lord, why dost Thou make us to err from Thy ways (Jer. 63:17). Moses said, therefore choose life (Deut. 30:19).80
Now, since God does not withhold good,81 He loves to do good. Scripture employs human language when it says, Oh that.82
27. GO SAY TO THEM. Moses was to go down.83

28. STAND THOU HERE BY ME. Moses was to return.84 Scripture similarly states, and I will speak unto thee all the commandment, and the statutes, and the ordinances. It is thus clear that most of the Torah was told to Moses at Sinai. However, Moses transmitted it in the wilderness of Sinai. I believe that he did so in the eleven days that they traveled from Sinai.85
29. YE SHALL OBSERVE TO DO. Scripture states this86 in order to add, and ye shall not turn aside to the right hand or to the left.

30. IN ALL THE WAY. This explains to the right hand or to the left.87 The main purpose of this commandment88 and the statutes and ordinances is that you, your son, and your son’s son fear the Lord. Faith of the heart is the basis of the commandments. When you fear God, you are fulfilling your destiny as a person. Man, as is noted by Koheleth, was created for this very reason.89 Furthermore, your days will be prolonged with everyone90 on the land and for the individual,91 in the world to come.92
chapter.ftnote: 1 See I.E. on Deut. 1:5.
2 The Decalogue.
3 Horeb is another name for Sinai.
4 But also with us.
5 Literally, with us.

6 Our verse literally reads: The Lord made not this covenant with our fathers, but with us (ittanu). I.E. believes that this should be interpreted: The Lord made not this covenant with our fathers alone, but also with us. In other words, ittanu (us) should be interpreted as if written gam (also) ittanu.
7 Thy name shall not be called any more Jacob should be read as if written, Thy name shall not be called any more only Jacob. See I.E. on Gen. 35:10 (Vol. 1, p. 332).
8 In this case, no words have to be added to our verse and the clause is to be taken literally; i.e., the Lord made not this covenant with our fathers, but with us.
9 The tribe of Levi and those who were under twenty when Moses sent out the spies to Canaan.
10 Face to face is not to be taken literally, for God has no face.
11 This would be the case when the speaker and the addressed would be in a pitch dark room. I.E.’s point is that Moses received a clear message.
12 Moses could say this because “for there were many in the camp who heard the covenant from the mouth of God.” See I.E. on verse 3.
13 I am the Lord thy God, etc.
14 Of the fire.
15 In other words, do not be surprised that the last word in verse 5 is to be interpreted as the conclusion of verse 4.
16 Where a word is not connected to what immediately precedes it.
17 Moses.
18 This was done later. I.E. apparently takes issues with those who believe that the arrangement of the verses and chapters of the Torah is from Sinai.
19 The difference in wording between the Decalogue in Deuteronomy and that in Exodus. I.E. discusses these differences in his commentary on the latter. See I.E. on Ex. 20:1 (Vol. 2, pp. 394-406).
20 In other words, it is the ideas and not the exact wording that matters. See I.E. on Ex. 20:1 (Vol. 2, pp. 394-406).
21 Literally, vain.
22 Ex. 20:13 reads: Thou shalt not bear false witness (ed shaker). Deut. 5:17 reads: Neither shalt thou bear false/vain witness (ed shav).
23 They convey the same meaning.
24 Ex. 20:8 reads: Remember (zakhor) the sabbath day to keep it holy. Deut. 5:12 reads: Remember (shamor) the sabbath day to keep it holy. Hence I.E.’s comment.
25 When repeating the commandment in Deuteronomy to observe the Sabbath. As the Lord thy God commanded thee is not found in Exodus. Hence I.E.’s comment.
26 The meaning of as the Lord thy God commanded thee is keep the Sabbath as God commanded you at Sinai when he revealed the Decalogue.
27 Ox and ass are particulars. Cattle is the general term.
28 In the first version of the Decalogue. The parallel verse in Ex. 20:10 reads: nor thy cattle. Ox and ass are not mentioned.
29 Both versions state the same idea.
30 Why they are to rest on the Sabbath.
31 This explanation is not found in the parallel verse in Exodus.
32 I.E.’s paraphrase of therefore the Lord thy God commanded thee to keep the sabbath day.
33 Some offer another meaning for And thou shalt remember that thou was a servant.
34 The Jews in Egypt did not have any rest.

35 According to this interpretation, it is not a reason for giving the servant rest but it is a reason why the Israelite himself must rest. He must do so because his rest will remind him that he was a slave and that God freed him.
36 Honor thy father and thy mother.
37 On verse 5. There I.E. comments that as the Lord thy God commanded thee (v. 12) means as the Lord thy God commanded thee when you stood around Mount Sinai. Similarly, here.
38 And that it may be well with thee elaborates on that thy days may be long; i.e., your long days will be good days.
39 Contra I.E. who believes that the Decalogue begins with v. 7.

40 From I am. The Decalogue is divided into ten sections in the massoretic edition of the Torah. Each of these sections is devoted to a particular statement. Now, if I am is an independent statement, it should form an independent section. However, it does not. Hence I am seems to be an introduction to that which follows. We have followed Vat. Ebr. 38 which reads lo hifsik.
41 And noted that I am is the first of the Ten Statements. See I.E.’s comments on Ex. 20:1 in both the long and the short commentary. See Vol. 2, pp. 401-404.
42 On the opinion of the early sages.

43 “I am includes all precepts directed at the heart, tongue, and human deeds. For one who does not believe in his heart that God exists has no reason to be obligated to observe any commandments” (I.E., Vol. 2, p. 415).
44 I.E. is commenting on verse 18, which reads: ve-lo tachmod (neither shalt thou covet).

45 If neither shall any man covet (yachmod) thy land means no one shall desire your land, then the Land of Israel would be an undesirable land. Hence the meaning of neither shall any man covet (yachmod) thy land must be no one will take your land.
46 On the desire.

47 This interpretation does not count I am as the first statement of the Decalogue. Therefore, it counts Neither shalt thou covet thy neighbor’s house and thou shalt not covet thy neighbor’s wife as two separate statements.

48 That is, they have a similar meaning even though they form two separate statements. Hence Scripture can invert these statements. I.E. comments thus because in Exodus the prohibition against coveting thy neighbor’s house precedes thou shalt not covet thy neighbor’s wife, while the reverse is true in Deuteronomy (Weiser).

49 In other words, Neither shalt thou covet thy neighbor’s house is the tenth statement. Scripture first states the general rule and then goes into detail; that is, Neither…thy neighbor’s house includes your neighbor’s wife, servant, ox, ass, and all that he owns. According to this interpretation, I am is the first statement and Neither shalt thou covet thy neighbor’s house is the tenth.
50 I.E, lo.
51 That Neither shalt thou covet thy neighbor’s house is a general statement, for Moses explains it by using a different term in Deuteronomy.
52 Of his review of the commandments.

53 They remind the heart what it is to believe. See The Secret of Torah, A Translation of Ibn Ezra’s Yesod Mora, translated by H. Norman Strickman, Jason Aaronson, 1995, p. 78: “Some commandments serve as reminders of the fundamental precepts. For example, the Sabbath commemorates creation. Likewise, not permitting one’s slave to work on the Sabbath recalls the Exodus from Egypt. Similarly, the Pascal lamb, the matzot, the bitter herbs, the sukkah, the mezuzah, and the tefillin worn on the hand and head. Likewise, the tzitzit.”
54 That one can sin with one’s thought, for one who sins deliberately is punished while one who sins inadvertently is not.
55 In the Torah.

56 If the reference is to a Rabbinic sage, then “that God only uttered I am” is short for, that God only uttered I am and Thou shalt have no… See I.E. on Ex. 20:1 (Vol. 2, p. 393). Also see Horiyot 8a.
57 See I.E. on Gen. 1:1 (Vol. 1, p. 24).
58 God is the prime mover of the universe.
59 The stars and planets are moved by God. They do not move on their own.
60 As God is the source of its movement.
61 At (you) is a feminine pronoun.
62 God.
63 There I.E. explains that at can be used in the masculine.
64 Its root is tet, vav, bet.
65 In other words, the object of mi yitten is Israel not God.

66 Our verse reads, mi yitten ve-hayah levavam zeh la-hem (oh that they). This literally reads, Oh that such a heart as this to them. I.E. believes that this should be read as if written, mi yitten la-hem ve-hayah levavam zeh lahem (oh that they had such a heart as this).
67 In heaven and on earth. In other words, God is the first cause of everything.
68 The root of all things, every element on earth, is influenced by a heavenly source.
69 To all things that are compounds of the four elements.
70 Everything on earth is in a state of flux. “It is because of the heavenly motions that change comes to all things born of the earth, be they metal, plants, or living beings” (Yesod Mora, p. 173).
71 The Book of Creation is a mystical work composed between the third and sixth centuries either in the Land of Israel or in Babylonia.
72 The particular (individual items) of each category.
73 Sustenance.

74 According to I.E. the hosts of heaven are in charge of the categories, which are eternal. Everything belongs to its own category, i.e., human beings, animals, plants, etc. See I.E. on Ex. 33:21 (Vol. 2, p. 698), “Note, all plants, all that live on the earth, all fowl, cattle…and human beings are tied to the 48 forms of the sphere.”

75 The categories are eternal. They influence their parts on earth. For example, life is a category. Different creatures have different life spans based on their nature. The heavenly apparatus which influences life will thus provide life to a creature according to its unique nature.
76 Human beings.
77 By mastering the science of the categories man can save himself from what the stars have decreed. See I.E. on Ex. 33:21, Vol. 2, pp. 691-692.
78 Pharaoh was born with a “hard heart.”
79 Pharaoh choose not to develop his soul.

80 For man has free will to improve and develop his soul. According to I.E. a person is born with certain personality traits. Some of these traits may be evil. God may thus be said to determine man’s behavior. However, man has it in his power to overcome these evil traits. Thus man has free will. See I.E. on Ex. 7:3 (Vol. 2, p. 145) and the notes thereto.

81 From the deserving. God has so arranged the world that good will automatically befall the person who leads a good life. God will not interfere with nature and prevent good from descending upon that person.
82 Moses spoke as people normally do when he said, Oh that…
83 From Mount Sinai and tell the people to return to their tents.
84 After telling the people to return to their tents, Moses was to return to Mount Sinai.
85 To Kadesh-barnea. See I.E. on Deut. 1:2.
86 Our verse seems to be repeating verse 29. Hence I.E.’s comment.
87 In the previous verse.
88 That is, these commandments. I.E. employs a collective noun.
89 See Eccles. 12:13, Fear God, and keep His commandments; for this is the whole man.
90 With your fellow Israelites.
91 The select few who are worthy of enjoying the world to come.
92 Some editions have “in this world.” However, this rendering appears incorrect, for what difference is there between “on the land” and “in this world”?

chapter.title: CHAPTER 6
chapter.p: 3. AND OBSERVE TO DO IT. Behold. I command you to observe that it may be well with you.
A LAND FLOWING WITH MILK AND HONEY. This is connected to to possess it (v. I).1 Now, it is far from it,2 or it is missing a bet,3 as in that was found in the house of the Lord (II Kings 12:11).4

[4. HEAR O ISRAEL: THE LORD (YHVH) OUR GOD, THE LORD (YHVH) IS ONE.] That which the ancients, of blessed memory, transmitted regarding the reading of the shema is true,5 and there is no need for further investigation.

Note that the glorious name (YHVH) is a noun.6 This being the case, why is it said a second time?7 The answer is that Adam is a noun. Adam is also an adjective, and not a noun,8 even though9 he was called after the very earth. The same is true of the name YHVH.10 The fact that YHVH is connected to tzeva’ot (hosts)11 is proof.12
On the other hand, the term Elohenu (our God) might be the object.13 The name YHVH was repeated in order to state YHVH echad (the Lord is one) the meaning of which is, only YHVH.14

There are many proofs that YHVH alone is God.15 The verse that states, In that day shall the Lord be One (echad)16 (Zech. 14:9), speaks of men’s thoughts.17 In my opinion, the word one18 is connected to the word king, for Scripture writes: And the Lord shall be King over all the earth; In that day shall the Lord alone be King and His name one (Zech. 14:9).19 The latter is similar in meaning to For then will I turn to the peoples, A pure language, That they may all call upon the name of the Lord (Zeph. 3:9}. Behold, all the nations will speak one language. The name of the Lord will therefore be one.
5. AND THOU SHALT LOVE. Since we have no other god aside from the Lord, you are obligated to love Him, for we have no other god.20

WITH ALL THY HEART, AND WITH ALL THY SOUL. The heart refers to knowledge. It is another term for the spirit of intelligence,21 for the heart is its first residence.22 The same applies to wise-hearted (Ex. 36:1) and to He that getteth a heart (Prov. 19:8).23
THY SOUL.24 The reference is to the spirit, which is in the body.25 It is the spirit which lusts.26 Its power is manifest in the liver.

THY MIGHT. The meaning of me’odekha (thy might) is very very much.27 It means that you should love Him to the utmost in any way that you are able. Your heart should be totally committed to the love of God.

[6.] AND THESE WORDS…SHALL BE. Those who deny the Rabbinic tradition28 say that the reference is to the Decalogue, and that it is in reference to the Decalogue that Scripture states, And thou shalt write them upon the door-posts (v. 9). However, the truth is that and these words…shall be refers to all of the commandments.
7. AND THOU SHALT TEACH THEM. Ve-shinantam (and thou shalt teach them) is related to the word shanun (sharp) in and a sharp arrow (Prov. 25:18). The method of sharpening an arrow is well known.29

Observe. Our verse teaches that the main purpose of man is to serve God.30 God’s service consists in recognizing God’s works.31 However, the transmitters of tradition taught that [our verse] refers to the time of reading the shema.32 We all rely on them.
WHEN THOU SITTEST. This is connected to and shalt talk of them.33

AND WHEN THOU LIEST DOWN. To sleep, for one is not obligated to observe the commandments when one sleeps.34 Behold, the meaning of our verse is, And thou shalt talk of them verbally and in your heart.
8. AND THOU SHALT BIND THEM FOR A SIGN UPON THY HAND. This has been explained.35

AND THEY SHALL BE FOR FRONTLETS. The word totafot (frontlets) is not found elsewhere in Scripture. Those who dispute the Rabbinic tradition36 say that totafot is related to the word ve-hatef (and preach) in and preach toward the South (Ezek. 21:2). This is impossible, for the root of hattef is nun, tet, peh. However, there are two tets ands no nun in totafot.

[9.] AND THOU SHALT WRITE THEM. They37 also said that its meaning38 is Bind them (Prov. 6:8).39 Now since our fathers received the truth, we will forsake those who employ their heart to invent things.
11. ALL GOOD THINGS. The word tuv (good) is vocalized with a shuruk in place of a cholam,40 for these vowels interchange and tuv is not in the construct.41
[12. OUT OF THE HOUSE OF BONDAGE.] Where you did not possess cities and houses that are full.
13. THOU SHALT FEAR. You shall not violate any of the negative commandments.
SHALT THOU SERVE. By observing the positive commandments.

AND BY HIS NAME SHALT THOU SWEAR. And not by the name of another god when you affirm anything or make a covenant. Similarly, Every tongue shall swear42 (Is. 45:23). You shall swear only the truth. The meaning of our verse is, you shall have no other god to swear by his name. You shall only swear by the name of the Lord. Scripture therefore afterwards reads, Ye shall not go after other gods (v. 14), and ye shall not try the Lord your God (v. 16).

16. IN MASSAH. Massah is the name of a place mentioned earlier, And the name of the place was called Massah (Ex. 17:7). The bet which is prefixed to Massah is vocalized with a pattach43 like the bet prefixed to karkor in Now Zebah and Zalmona were in Karkor44 (Jud. 8:10), and the bet placed before Telaim in And numbered them in Telaim45 (I Sam. 15:4). I explained it46 there.
Massah was so called because Israel said, Is the Lord among us (Ex. 17:7).47 If He is, then we will serve Him.

[Moses told Israel:] you have no need to test God. All you have to do is observe His commandments. If you do what is good in His sight, the Lord will do to you all that is good for you and will thrust out all of your enemies.
19. TO THRUST OUT. The heh in la-hadof (to thrust out) is a root letter, as the word hadofo (cast it upon him) (Num. 35:22) proves.
20. WHAT MEAN THE TESTIMONIES. It means, Why, out of all people, is this burden placed upon us?48

[21.] THEN THOU SHALT SAY. For God redeemed us from the house of bondage. Now, God did us this good. We are obligated to fear His name49 because we have recognized that He did good to us in the past. He will do good for us in the future to keep us alive, for His commandments are life unto those that find them (Prov. 4:22).

25. AND IT SHALL BE RIGHTEOUSNESS UNTO US. Some say that this verse hints at the reward in the world to come for the observance of the commandments.50 However, according to the plain meaning of the text, our verse teaches that following God’s will is the righteous thing to do, for He is our Master. I believe that the correct meaning is, all the nations shall see that we are righteous when we keep God’s commandments and statutes, which Scripture clearly states are righteous.51
chapter.ftnote: 1 A land flowing with milk and honey is connected to the end of the first verse.
2 A land flowing with milk and honey concludes the first verse even though it is some distance from it.

3 In other words, eretz (a land) is to be read as if written be-eretz (in a land). In this case, the clause reads, in a land flowing with milk and honey, and is connected to that it may be well with thee, and that you may increase mightily.

4 The verse literally reads, that was found house of the Lord. The latter is to be read as if written, that was found in the house of the Lord. In other words, bet Adonai is to be read as if written be-vet Adonai.
5 According to Rabbinic tradition there is a biblical command to recite Hear (shema), O Israel, morning and evening.
6 A proper noun.

7 Why repeat the proper noun? Scripture should have read, Hear, O Israel, the Lord (YHVH) our God is one. It should be noted that I.E. comments elsewhere that it is biblical style to repeat nouns in the same verse. See I.E. on Gen. 19:24, (Vol. 1, p. 208) and on Ps. 1:2.
8 In other words, the name Adam is at times a proper name and at other times an adjective.

9 “Even though” seems out of place. Some suggest omitting it. In this case, our text reads: Adam is also an adjective and not a noun, [for] he was called after the very earth. In other words, Adam as an adjective means the one who was created out of the earth. See I.E. on Gen. 2:8 (Vol. 1, p. 53). Adam is derived from the word used for ground (adamah).
10 It is employed both as a proper noun and as an adjective. See I.E. on Ex. 3:15 (Vol. 2, pp. 67,68).
11Adonai tzeva’ot (the Lord of hosts) (Is. 1:9).
12 For Adonai is in the construct with tzeva’ot, whereas a proper name cannot come in the construct. See I.E. on Ex. 3:15 (Vol. 2, p. 65).
13 In other words, the main purpose of the verse is to teach us that YHVH is our God.
14 After Scripture tells us that YHVH is our God, it goes on to say that only YHVH is our God.
15 The medieval Jewish philosophers proved that there can be only one God.
16 I.E. renders this, In that day shall the Lord alone be God.
17 Actually, the Lord alone is God today also. However, in contemporary times there are many people who worship other gods.
18 In Zech. 14:9.

19 Zech. 14:9 reads: And the Lord shall be King over all the earth; In that day shall the Lord be One, and His name one. I.E.’s interpretation eliminates the implication that today there are more gods than YHVH, for it speaks of all people recognizing one king, i.e., the Lord.
20 I.E. repeats himself for purposes of emphasis. It is also possible that we have a conflation of two different manuscripts.
21 The rational soul.

22 See I.E. on Gen. 1:1 (Vol. 1, p. 25): “Speech is called safah (lip) because it is seen to come from the lips. Similarly, man’s highest soul is called heart (lev)…because the heart is its first resting place.”
23 Translated literally.
24 Hebrew, nafshekha.
25 I.E. believed that man has three souls; vegetative (nefesh), animal (ru’ach), and rational (neshamah). See Vol. 1, p. xiii; also The Secret of the Torah, p. 96.
26 The nefesh.
27 The word me’od means much. Thus me’odekha (your might) literally means your much. Hence I.E.’s comment.
28 The Karaites.
29 It is sharpened by consistent filing. Similarly, the words of the Torah must consistently be drilled into a child (Weiser).
30 By studying the Torah at all times. See next note.

31Prima facie, the reference is to the study of the Torah (see Weiser). However, it should be noted that in I.E., study of God’s works usually refers to the study of the sciences. Thus I.E. writes: “When one masters astronomy and the circuits of the [sun and. moon], he comes to know the works of God the glorious” (The Secret of the Torah, p. 21). Perhaps I.E. is alluding here to his belief that the Torah cannot be fully understood unless it is interpreted in light of the studies of science (see The Secret of the Torah, pp. 33,34).

32 According to the sages when thou liest down means that we should read the shema at night, and when thou risest up refers to the reading of the shema in the morning. See chapter 1 of Mishnah Berakhot.

33 That is, our verse should be read, And thou shalt teach them diligently unto thy children, and shalt talk of them when thou sittest in thy house, not And thou shalt teach them diligently unto thy children, and shalt talk of them.
34 Thus and when thou liest down can’t be taken to mean when you sleep.

36 The Karaites. However, in his commentary on Exodus, I.E. does not identify this opinion as being heretical. He merely notes that “others say” that totafot is related to the word ve-hatef (and preach). Actually this opinion was quoted by Rashi in the name of Menachem ben Saruk, who, far from being a heretic, was an accepted tenth-century grammarian and Bible commentator. See I.E. on Ex. 13:16 (Vol. 2, p. 266).
37 Those who dispute the Rabbinic tradition.
38 The meaning of and thou shalt bind them. However, see I.E. on Ex. 13:9, (Vol. 2, pp. 261,262).
39 That is, Bind them continually upon thy heart (Prov. 6:8). The latter verse is symbolic. So too ours.
40 The usual word for good is tov.
41 Tuv is the normal vocalization for the word in the construct.
42 When affirming anything or making a covenant.
43 Our verse reads ba-massah (in Massah). The usual way to say in Massah is be-massah.
44 Hebrew, ba-karkor.
45 Hebrew, ba-talaim.
46 The reason for the irregular vocalization. We do not know how I.E. explained the latter, for his commentary on Judges has been lost.
47 Massah comes from the root nun, sin, heh. The latter means to test.
48 That is, the import of our verse is, Why out of all people is the burden of observing these testimonies placed upon us?
49 In the present.
50 See Targum Jonathan: And merit will be kept for us for the world to come.
51 See Deut. 4:8.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 7
chapter.p: 1. AND SHALL CAST OUT. The nun in ve-nashal (and shall cast out) is a root letter. It is related to the word yishal (shall drop off)1 in for thine olives shall drop off (Deut. 28:40).
4. FOR HE WILL TURN AWAY THY SON. The reference2 is to “his son” mentioned earlier.3 That is, do not give your daughter to his son4 or do not take the daughter5 mentioned.6
5. BUT THUS. Ki im ko ta’asu la-ham means but thus7 shall ye deal with them8 because thou art a holy people (v. 6) and should not defile yourself with pagan images drawn on pillars, or with asherim.9

6. HIS OWN TREASURE. I have already explained the meaning of the word segullah (treasure).10 It means a desirable thing to which nothing comparable is to be found any-where. Segullat (treasure)11 in and treasure such as kings…have as their own (Eccles. 2:8) is similar.
7. SET HIS LOVE UPON YOU, NOR CHOOSE YOU. You and not anyone else.
8. AND BECAUSE HE WOULD KEEP. U-mi-shomro (and because he would keep) is an infinitive.

9. HE IS GOD. This means this is truly the God who has the power and is faithful. And is faithful refers to the oath which God took. Scripture says that God is powerful and faithful, because there are others who are faithful but lack the power to keep their oaths and others who are powerful but are unfaithful.
WHO KEEPETH COVENANT AND MERCY WITH THEM THAT LOVE HIM. There are none higher then they.12
AND KEEP HIS COMMANDMENTS. After them.13 Or its meaning is, them that love Him in their hearts, they are the ones who keep His commandments verbally and in practice.

TO A THOUSAND GENERATIONS. The one who says that the sphere of the constellations14 completes its cycle at the end of thirty-six thousand years15 errs, for we find it moving one degree in seventy years.16 The meaning of a thousand is, endless.17
10. AND REPAYETH THEM THAT HATE HIM…TO DESTROY THEM.18 To destroy each individual that hates Him.19 Compare, But righteous people is secure as a young lion20 (Prov. 28:1).21

TO THEIR FACE. Be-fanav (to their face) means to him.22 Others say that el panav (their face) has the meaning of befanav, that is, because of His anger.23 Its means that God will repay the wicked because they hated the truth.24

TO DESTROY THEM; HE WILL NOT BE SLACK TO HIM THAT HATETH HIM. Some say that the meaning of our verse is that God rewards the wicked for his good deeds in this world and does not wait to reward him in the world to come.25 However, it appears to me that our verse contrasts the righteous26 who will exist27 for a thousand generations with the wicked28 who will be destroyed. Scripture reads, He will not be slack because the wicked person thinks that his son or grandson shall live,29 as in [visiting the iniquity of the fathers] upon the children, and upon the children’s children (Ex. 33:7).30
11. THOU SHALT THEREFORE KEEP. It means as God keeps the covenant so shall you keep His commandments.
12. BECAUSE. Ekev (because) has the same meaning as ekev (reward) in For ever, reward31 (Ps. 119:112). It means the reward which will be given at the end.

The meaning of who keepeth covenant in the previous verse (v. 9) is that God kept the covenant with Abraham. If you will be among those that love Him, then He will continue to keep the covenant.32 If you will be among those who love Him, then He will love thee, and bless thee, and multiply thee (v. 13). This is the meaning of the covenant and the mercy (v. 12).
13. THY BODY. Thy children.33 Bitnekha (thy body)34 is a euphemism.35
AND THE FRUIT OF THY LAND. Scripture mentions com, wine, and oil because they are the most important foods.
THE INCREASE. I have already explained the meaning of shegar (the increase of).36
THY KINE. The word alafekha (thy kine) is similar to the word alufenu (oxen) in Whose oxen are well laden (Ps. 144:14).
AND THE YOUNG OF. Ashterot (and the young of) means and the flocks of.

There was a great commentator in Spain37 who explained why the Hebrews referred to cattle as alef38 and to sheep and goats as ashterot. He similarly explained the ba’alim and the ashtaroth (Jud. 10:6) as referring to the lord of the flowering constellation39 and that of the tenth.40

Scripture goes on to say God will not only bless the fruit of your body but there will not be a barren male, that is, one whose seed is infertile, among you or among your cattle. Furthermore, you will be healthy and avoid all sorts of well-known illnesses which normally befall people. You will similarly avoid abnormal, evil diseases.41
16. AND THOU SHALT CONSUME. This is a commandment to consume them as one consumes bread, as thine eye shall not pity them proves.
FOR THAT WILL BE A SNARE UNTO THEE. The reference is to each one of their gods.42
20. THE HORNET. Ha-tzirah (the hornet) refers to an illness which afflicts the body. It is related to the word tzara’at (leprosy).
21. THOU SHALT NOT BE AFFRIGHTED AT THEM. Only fear the Lord, who is great and awful.

[22. LEST THE BEASTS OF THE FIELD INCREASE UPON THEE.] The Gaon says that this is a sign regarding the time that they shall be victorious over them.43 There is no need for the Gaon’s interpretation.44 I have already explained it.

24. THOU HAST DESTROYED THEM. Hishmidekha (thou has destroyed them) is an infinitive even though it is vocalized with a chirik.45 The word hishir46 (left him remaining) in until there was none left him remaining (Num. 22:35) is most likely similar to it. The word otam (them), which is the object,47 proves that hishmidekha is an infinitive.48
[25. THE SILVER OR THE GOLD THAT IS ON THEM.] Alehem is to be rendered, that is on them. Or the meaning of our clause is, you shall not take money to leave them.49
SNARED. The vav in tivvakesh (snared) is in place of a yod.50 Compare, yakoshti51 lakh (I have laid a snare for thee).
chapter.ftnote: 1 Which comes from the root nun, shin, lamed.
2 That is, He will turn away.
3 In the previous verse.
4 The son of the Canaanites mentioned in the previous verse will turn aside your son, that is, his brother-in-law, from following the Lord.
5 Of the Canaanite.
6 In the previous verse, for she too will turn your son away from Me. For other interpretations, see Krinsky, Meijler, and Filwarg.
7 In other words, ki im, means but thus. Ki literally means but, for, when; im means if. Thus ki im literally means but if. Hence I.E.’s comment that ki im should be rendered but thus.
8 You shall destroy their images.
9 Sacred trees (Rashi).
10 See I.E. on Ex. 19:5 (Vol. 2, p. 375).
11 Literally, treasure of.
12 That love God.
13 The future generations. God’s oath is conditional upon their keeping of His commandments.
14 Which contains 360 degrees and moves one degree in 100 years.

15 After which this world ends (Krinsky). According to this interpretation God says that he will keep his oath until the end of time. This interpretation says that a generation lasts for 36 years and a thousand generations is 36,000 years.
16 Thus it completes its cycle once in 25,200 years.
17 A thousand generations means endless generations.
18 Hebrew, le-ha’avido, (literally, to destroy him).
19 Hence the combination of the singular with the plural. See Vol. 1, p. XVII.
20 Translated literally.
21 Each one of the righteous people is secure as a young lion. Here too we have a combination of the singular with the plural.
22 To the previous person. Face is not to be taken literally.
23 In other words, panav is to be rendered His anger. See I.E. on Deut. 4:37.
24 And thereby angered God.
25 See Erubin, 22a; Onkelos and Rashi.
26 Literally, ones who love God.
27 By living on through their children.
28 Literally, ones who hate Him.
29 And receive the punishment due him.
30 Hence the Torah states that the wicked themselves shall receive the punishment due them.
31 Translated according to I.E.
32 In other words, the meaning of that the Lord thy God shall keep with thee the covenant in our verse is, God will continue to keep the covenant if you love him.
33 That is, the fruit of thy body means your children.
34 Literally, your belly.
35 For the sexual organ.
36 I.E. renders it as flock in his short commentary on Ex. 13:12. See also his long commentary on Ex. 13:12 (Vol. 2, p. 263).
37 I.E. does not identify the commentator.
38 As in alafekha (thy kine) and in alufenu (oxen).

39 The planet which rules over “the ascent, the zodiacal sign appearing on the eastern horizon at a certain moment” (I. Efros, Studies in Medieval Jewish Philosophy, p. 202). This constellation is the first (alef) in the sky and its ruling planet, its lord (ba’al) was believed to have a powerful affect on fertility.
40 The tenth constellation, Capricorn, which rules during the months of tevet, shevat, and adar when most of the sheep and cattle are born.
41 Hence the mention of the diseases of Egypt.

42 Our verse literally reads, “Neither shalt thou serve their gods; for he will be a snare unto thee.” To be consistent, our verse should have read, neither shalt thou serve their gods; for they will be a snare unto thee. Hence I. E.’s interpretation.

43 When Israel will so increase that there will be no danger that the beasts of the field will overwhelm them, then they will know that it is time to drive out the Canaanites. See I.E. on Ex. 23:29 (Vol. 2, p. 519).

44 For the meaning of our verse is that God will not drive out the Cananites in one year because the Land of Israel was too large for those who left Egypt to settle all of it. See I.E. on Ex. 23:29 (Vol. 2, p. 519).
45 Rather than with a pattach beneath the heh. Hishmidekha is a hifil. In such cases the heh is normally vocalized with a pattach in the infinitive. Compare, hashmid.
46 Which is a hifil.
47 Of hishmidekha.
48 Hishmidekha is a third person (hishmid) plus the second person pronoun. Its meaning is, he destroyed you. However, with the word otam following, it is an infinitive, meaning you destroy them.
49 In this case, alehem means for them, and the meaning of our clause is, you shall not take a bribe of money to leave them alone.
50 The root of tivvakesh is yod, kof, shin.
51 The root of yakoshti is yod, kof, shin.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 8
chapter.p: 1. ALL THE COMMANDMENT. This means, if you want to keep the commandments so that you may live then remember all the way (v. 2).1
2. THAT HE MIGHT AFFLICT THEE, TO PROVE THEE. I have already explained it.2
3. AND HE AFFLICTED THEE. On the way.

AND SUFFERED THEE TO HUNGER. Before the coming of the manna.3 Or via the manna itself, for it was light and did not satisfy their heart’s desire.4 However, this is not so.5 It most probably refers to other desires.6

KNOW. Yade’un (know) is spelled with a nun.7 So too the word tzakun (poured out)8 in Silently they poured out a prayer (Is. 26:16) and va-yachanun (and they pitched)9 in and they pitched on the other side of the Arnon (Jud. 11:18).
THAT HE MIGHT MAKE THEE KNOW. Hodi’akha10(make thee know) is an infinitive.
BREAD. Which people always eat.

EVERY THING THAT PROCEEDETH OUT OF THE MOUTH OF THE LORD. It means that which God has decreed. Compare, As the word went out of the king’s mouth (Esth. 7:8). The meaning of our verse is, man does not live by bread alone but by the power,11 or with the power, which comes from on high12 by the command of God. This is the meaning of that proceedeth out of the mouth of the Lord. The fact that you did not eat bread and you lived is proof of this.
4. THY RAIMENT. Some say via a miracle. Others say that the Israelites brought out many garments from Egypt.13 However, it is most likely the nature of manna not to produce sweat.14

NEITHER…SWELL. The word batzekah (swell) is related to the word batzek (dough)15 in And they baked…the dough (Ex. 12:39). It is usual for the feet of a wayfarer who walks great distances to swell. It is possible that God gave the Israelites strength or that he led them slowly.16

5. AND THOU SHALT CONSIDER IN THY HEART.17 You shall know by believing in your heart.18 The latter is what counts most.19 God will reward you by bringing you into the good land, because you obeyed the God who chastens you. You obeyed God even though in order to chasten you, He afflicted you with thirst and made you suffer hunger.
8. A LAND OF WHEAT. Moses makes mention of the foods which produce blood.20
AND HONEY. I have already explained this.21
9. SCARCENESS. Be-miskenut (scarceness) means in poverty and impoverishment. Compare, misken (poor) in a poor and wise child (Eccles. 4:13).
13. MULTIPLY. The yod in yirbeyun (multiply) is in place of a heh.22 This is not the opinion of Rabbi Mosheh Ha-Kohen the Spaniard.23

14. THEN THY HEART BE LIFTED UP. And you will forget that you were a slave and your heart was downcast. You will forget the affliction and the hunger which you experienced in the wilderness and even so the Lord sustained you.24
15. WILDERNESS. The word midbar (wilderness) is to be read as if written twice, that is, through the great wilderness in length and width and [through] a dreadful wilderness of fiery serpents.25
OF FLINT. Tzur ha-chalamish (the rock of flint) means the mighty rock.

17. THIS WEALTH. Chayil means wealth. Compare, the word chelam (their wealth) in And leave their wealth to others (Ps. 49:11). Chelam refers to that which they acquired by their efforts and strength.26
18. BUT THOU SHALT REMEMBER. This means if the thought My power and the might of my hand hath gotten me this wealth should enter your mind, then remember the One who gives you power.
20. BECAUSE. The word ekev (because) refers to payment at the end. It refers both to reward27 and to punishment.
chapter.ftnote: 1 In other words, verse 1 and 2 are not independent statements. Furthermore, ve-zakharta (and thou shalt remember) is to be rendered, then thou shalt remember.

2 How to understand “to prove thee.” The point is, since God knows the future, what point is there in testing people. I.E. explains divine tests in his comments on the “binding of Isaac.” He writes, “The reason God tested Abraham was to reward him.” See I.E. on Gen. 22:1 (Vol. 1, pp. 221-223).
3 Before the manna descended, Israel suffered hunger. See Ex. 16:3.
4 See Num. 21:5.
5 For Moses goes on to speak positively of the manna in verse 3.
6 Which they could not fulfill in the wilderness (Weiser).
7 The usual form of this word is yade’u.
8 The usual form of the word is yatzeku. Be that as it may, the nun is not part of the normal form of this word. See I.E. on Is. 26:16.
9 The usual form of the word is va-yachanu.
10 Hodi’a plus a pronominal suffix.

11 In the nature of the food. In other words, God created the world in such a way that man can exist on all types of food. For I.E.’s use of the word “power” in the sense of nature, see I.E. on Deut. 5:26.

12 See I.E. on Deut. 5:26: “The power and nature of all that is found beneath the heavens is determined by the upper arrangement.” According to I.E.’s first comment, everything that proceedeth out of the mouth of the Lord refers to the power to nourish which God placed in all foodstuffs. According to the second interpretation the verse refers to divine providence. The latter was demonstrated by the manna which came from on high.
13 The meaning of our clause is that they always had garments to wear.
14 Hence their garments waxed not old upon them.
15 Dough swells.
16 Hence their feet did not swell.
17 Literally, you shall know in your heart. Hence I.E.’s interpretation.
18 What you claim to know should be what your heart believes.
19 True belief. I.E. says, “If belief is lacking, then the observance of the commandments is meaningless and serves no purpose” (The Secret of the Torah, p. 91).
20 I.E. believed that the seven types of food mentioned in our verse increase the blood supply.
21 See I.E. on Lev. 2:11.
22 For the root of yirbeyun is resh, bet, heh. Compare the word yirbeh (multiplied) later on in the verse.
23 Who believes that the yod in yirbeyun is a root letter.
24 Even though you were insignificant, God took pity on you.

25 Our verse literally reads: who led thee through the wilderness and the dreadful wherein were serpents, fiery serpents. I.E. believes that our verse should be interpreted as if written, who led thee through the wilderness, a dreadful wilderness, wherein were serpents, fiery serpents, etc.
26 Chayil means strength. Hence I.E. explains that it also refers to that which a person acquires by his efforts.
27 See I.E. on Deut. 7:12.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 9
chapter.p: 1. THOU ART TO PASS OVER THE JORDAN THIS DAY. At this time.1 Or it means, imagine that you are passing over today.
3. AS A DEVOURING FIRE. Quickly.2 Scripture therefore goes on to say quickly3.
7. IN THE WILDERNESS. After they journeyed from Horeb.4 The lamed prefixed to le-min (from)5 in le-min ha-yom (from the day) is superfluous. There are many such instances.6
10. FINGER. This has already been explained.7
11. AT THE END.8 At the end or the beginning of the fortieth day.9 Look. This verse shows that the golden calf was made on the day that the tablets were given to Moses.10
18. AND I FELL DOWN. The reference is to Moses’ statement, and now I will go up unto the Lord (Ex. 32:30).11 The meaning of and now I fell down is, I fell with my face to the ground.12

19. THAT TIME ALSO. For he had previously prayed for Israel when they were at the sea.13 Wherefore criest thou unto me (Ex. 14:15) is proof of the latter. Furthermore, Scripture states, and he cried unto the Lord; and the Lord showed him a tree (Ex. 15:25).
21. AND I TOOK YOUR SIN. The calf is referred to by the term sin. Hence Moses goes on to explain and says, the calf.
AND BEAT IT. Into fine dust like the dust of the ground.14

22. AND AT TABERAH. Taberah is probably the name of a place. Israel camped there for but one day. Therefore Scripture does not mention it15 in the Torah portion Elleh Mase (These Are the Stages) (Num. 33:1).16 It is one of the thirty journeys that Israel traveled from Mount Sinai until they came to Kibroth-hattaavah (Num. 33:17),17 as I explained.18

The reason Scripture connects Taberah with Massah19 is that the people were as murmurers (Num. 11:1);20 that is, they tested God.21 Scripture mentions Taberah before Massah22 because nothing happened to Israel at Massah.23

Some say that Amalek came24 because Israel tested God.25 Scripture therefore mentions26 the burning of God’s fire among them,27 Amalek’s smiting of Israel’s hindmost,28 and the smiting of those who lusted.29 Scripture mentions the most severe punishments first.30
Some say that Taberah and Massah are one and the same place.31 It is like From the top of Senir and Hermon (Cant. 4:8).32 However, my interpretation is correct.
23. YE BELIEVED HIM NOT. In your hearts.
NOR HEARKENED. In deed.
Moses then goes back to describe the prayer which he offered.33

29. THY PEOPLE AND THINE INHERITANCE. Because of their fathers.34 The meaning of Thy people is, it is well known that they are thy people, for You took them out35 by Your great power, which You demonstrated to the world.
chapter.ftnote: 1 That is, soon. Israel did not pass over the Jordan the day that Moses spoke to them. Hence I.E.’s comment.
2 When God destroys his enemies he does so quickly.
3 Scripture therefore goes on to say, so shalt thou drive them out, and make them to perish quickly.
4 For Moses goes on to castigate them in the next verse for the sins they committed in Horeb.
5 Le-min literally means “to from.” Hence I.E.’s comment.
6 Of superfluous letters in Scripture. See Vol. 1, p. XVII.
7 See I.E. on Ex. 31:18 (Vol. 2, p. 654), “Scripture’s statement, with the finger of God is an anthropomorphism.” The Torah employs such language so that those who hear its words will understand.
8 Hebrew, mi-ketz.
9 According to I.E. the word mi-ketz sometimes means at the beginning and sometimes at the end. See I.E. on Num. 13:25 (Vol. 4, pp. 104,105).
10 For God told Moses about the calf on the day He gave Moses the tablets. I.E. assumes that had the calf been made a few days earlier, God would then have told Moses to descend from the mountain.
11 The full text of the clause (Ex. 32:30) is, and now I will go up unto the Lord, peradventure I shall make atonement for your sin.
12 That is, I fell on my face in prayer.
13 Hence Moses says that he also prayed for Israel when they made the golden calf.

14 Our verse literally reads, until it was fine to dust (le-afar). I.E. explains that le-afar (to dust) should be interpreted as ke-afar (as dust) and our text interpreted, until it was as fine as dust (Weiser).
15 So Vat. Ebr. 38. The printed texts read “them,” in place of “it.”
16 Wherein the journeys of the children of Israel in the wilderness are recorded.
17 Which is located in Kadesh-barnea.
18 That Israel journeyed from Sinai to Kadesh-barnea (Sarim). See I.E. on Deut. 1:2.

19 Israel tested God at Massah after crossing the Red Sea. See Ex. 17:7. The incident at Taberah [where Israel murmured against God and God punished them by fire (Num. 11:3)] occurred more than a year later, after Israel had journeyed from Mount Sinai.
20 In Taberah.
21 Which is what they did at Massah. Hence Taberah and Massah are mentioned back to back.
22 Even though Israel’s camping at Massah came before Taberah.
23 Israel was not punished for testing God in Massah. They were punished at Taberah.
24 To Rephidim and attacked Israel.
25 In Rephidim. Thus Israel was punished for testing God at Massah. See Ex. 17:1-7.
26 That is, mentions the places where the following punishments took place.
27 At Taberah.
28 At Massah.
29 At Kibroth-hattaavah.
30 Hence Taberah comes before Massah.
31 Hence Taberah is not mentioned among Israel’s journeys in the Torah portion Elleh Mase (These Are the Stages) (Num. 33:1).
32 Senir and Hermon are one and the same place. See Deut. 3:9.

33 After mentioning the sins Israel committed following the making of the golden calf in verses 22-24 and castigating them in verse 24, Moses goes back to the incident of the golden calf which he mentioned earlier and describes the prayer which he offered on behalf of Israel.
34 The patriarchs.
35 Of Egypt.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 10
chapter.p: 1. AT THAT TIME. During the forty days that are mentioned.1

AN ARK OF WOOD. The transmitters of tradition,2 of blessed memory, said that Moses first3 made another ark.4 Proof of the latter is, So I made an ark (v. 3), which is followed by and hewed two tables of stone (v. 3) and put the tables in the ark which I had made (v. 5). Now their minds are superior to our minds, for it appears to us5 that And the glory of the Lord abode (Ex. 24:16) is connected with the glory which the elders saw (Ex. 24:10).6 We do not know when Moses ascended,7 for according to the plain meaning of the text it appears that Moses fasted for only eighty days,8 for the meaning of Now I stayed in the mount (v. 10) repeats what was said earlier.9 It means when I stayed on the mountain during those forty days10 God listened to me and said, Arise, go before the people (v. 11), the reference being to And now go, lead the people (Ex. 32:34). The making of the ark of wood (v. 3) was thus by command.11 It refers to the ark made by Bezalel.12

3. SO I MADE AN ARK. By command.13 The meaning of And Moses assembled (Ex. 35:1) should be interpreted, and Moses had assembled.14 I have already shown you many such instances.15 All of this is necessitated16 by Scripture’s statement, and there they are, as the Lord commanded me (v. 5).17 This18 is what And thou shalt put into the ark the testimony (Ex. 25:16) refers to. It is also possible that it19 refers to and make thee an ark of wood.20 The tradition of the sages shall triumph.

6. AND THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL JOURNEYED FROM BEEROTH-BENEJAAKAN TO MOSERAH; THERE AARON DIED. This verse is placed here21 because Moses said, And I prayed for Aaron also the same time (Deut. 9:20).22 Moses indicated that Aaron did not die until the fortieth year (Num. 33:38).23 Moses’ statement, At that time the Lord separated the tribe of Levi (v. 8), which took place at Mount Sinai24 as I explained in the Torah portion which opens with And The Lord Spoke (Num. 1:1),25 is proof that this is its meaning.26

The early authorities27 tell us that Israel backtracked.28 However, what shall we do with the clause, there Aaron died, and there he was buried?29 Rabbi Isaac ibn Giat the Spaniard,30 of blessed memory, says that the meaning of sham (there) is then.31 He says that mi-sham (from thence) in misham ro’eh (from thence, from the shepherd) (Gen. 49:24) is similar. There is no need for this interpretation. On the contrary, I believe that Beeroth-benejaakan is not to be identified with Bene-jaakkan; neither is Moserah the same as Moserot (Num. 33:31).32 In reality Kadesh33 is called the wilderness of Beeroth-benejaakan, and the wilderness of Mount Hor is called Moserah.34 There are many such examples.35 Do you not see that Scripture says the wilderness of Shur (Ex. 15:22)? However, in another place Scripture refers to it as the wilderness of Etam (Num. 33:18).36

[7.] FROM THENCE THEY JOURNEYED UNTO GUDGOD. The latter is not to be identified with Hor-haggidgad (Num. 33:32).37 On the contrary, it is a general term for Zalmonah and also for Punon and Oboth (Num. 33:43,44).38

[TO JOTBAH.] Jotbah is the place that is also called Beer,39 for Scripture reads, And from thence to Beer (Num. 21:16). This is what a land of brooks of water (v. 7) refers to, for the nobles of the people dug it with their staves and water came forth (Num. 21:18). This verse, namely, From thence they journeyed unto Gudgod is connected to and Eleazar…ministered (v. 6).40

Now, I have already explained to you that Israel did not offer sacrifices after they journeyed from Mount Sinai.41 It is possible that they offered them when they came to Zalmonah42 and Punon and that the beginning of Eleazar’s service as high priest started in those places on Rosh Ha-Shanah.43 He ministered in a place called Beer44 on Yom Kippur.45 The meaning of our verses46 thus is, And Eleazar ministered when they came to such and such a place.47 Why did Eleazar minister? Because when Israel worshipped the calf, God separated the tribe of Levi to carry the ark and to stand before the Lord.48
8. TO MINISTER UNTO HIM. The sons of Levi with the sons of Aaron.49
AND TO BLESS IN HIS NAME. For Eleazar lifted up his hands.50
9. THE LORD IS HIS INHERITANCE. Its meaning is the same as O Lord, the portion of mine inheritance and of my cup (Ps. 16:5). It refers to serving God by learning His ways.51
10. NOW I STAYED IN THE MOUNT. I have already explained this.52
11. CAUSING THEM TO SET FORWARD. Massa (causing to set forward) is an infinitive.
15. AND HE CHOSE THEIR SEED. Their seed being you.53 This is the meaning of even you.

16. CIRCUMCISE THEREFORE THE FORESKIN OF YOUR HEART. The reference is to separation from lusts, which are as gross and leaden as a foreskin. It is also possible that it refers to cleansing the heart until one understands the truth.
STIFFNECKED. I have already explained the meaning of this term.54 Furthermore, he earlier said, for thou art a stiffnecked people (Deut. 9:6).
17. GOD OF GODS. I have already explained this.55
LORD OF LORDS. For they are on various high levels,56 as in and there are higher than they (Eccles. 8:7). The one who knows these measures57 is of circumcised heart.58

18. HE DOTH EXECUTE JUSTICE. Even though He is exalted, He executes justice on behalf of the orphan and widow who have no one to help them, as in a father of the fatherless and a judge of the widows (Ps. 68:6). He similarly loves the stranger and sustains him when he59 relies on Him. Now, since God loves the stranger, you too are obligated to love him.
20. THOU SHALT FEAR THE LORD THY GOD. You shall not violate the negative commandments.
HIM SHALT THOU SERVE. By observing the positive commandments.
AND TO HIM SHALT THOU CLEAVE. With your heart.
AND BY HIS NAME SHALT THOU SWEAR. With your mouth60 as Scripture explains.61
21. HE IS THY GLORY. Its meaning is, you should glorify yourself in Him, for He did these tremendous things for you.
22. WITH THREE SCORE AND TEN. I have already explained this.62
chapter.ftnote: 1 In Deut. 9:5.
2 The Talmudic sages.
3 Before ascending Mount Sinai to receive the second tablets. See Tanchuma, Ex. 1:10, and Rashi.

4 That is, other than the one later made by Bezalel. Thus the ark mentioned in our verse is not to be identified with the ark made by Bezalel which was placed in the Holy of Holies (Ex. 25:1-22; 37:1-9). The sages believed that God gave Moses the second pair of tablets at the end of 80 days and that Moses made an ark to hold them temporarily. See Rashi on our verse.
5 Contrary to their opinion.

6 Ex 24:16-18 reads: And the glory of the Lord abode upon mount Sinai, and the cloud covered it six days; and the seventh day He called unto Moses out of the midst of the cloud…And Moses entered in the midst of the cloud, and went up into the mount; and Moses was in the mount forty days and forty nights. According to the rabbis this verse relates to the giving of Torah (see Rashi on Ex. 24:16). Also, according to the rabbis, the forty days which this verse states Moses spent on the mountain starts with the seventh of Sivan. There are 120 days between that day and Yom Kippur when, according to Rabbinic tradition, Moses descended with the second pair of tablets. Moses thus spent 120 days on Mount Sinai. See Pirke de-Rabbi Eliezer, chapter 46. I.E. disagrees. He believes that the plain meaning of the text does not allow one to conclude that Moses spent 120 days on Mount Sinai. The text merely says that the elders of Israel ascended Mount Sinai and had a vision of God (Ex. 24:1-12). It does not say which day they descended. Following this vision the cloud covered the mountain for seven days, after which God called Moses to ascend the mountain for 40 days. We thus do no know what day Moses ascended the mountain, and therefore, cannot calculate 120 days between revelation and Yom Kippur. Thus Moses did not necessarily spend 120 days on Mount Sinai.
7 To receive the tablets.

8 According to the rabbis, Now I stayed in the mount, as the first time forty days and forty nights is not a repetition of Deut. 9:25 but speaks of an additional 40 days. Furthermore, as the first time forty days and forty nights indicates that as he fasted the first time, so did he now.
9 In Deut. 9:25.
10 Mentioned in Deut. 9:25.
11 So I made an ark of wood is to be interpreted, I commanded that an ark of wood be made.
13 By commanding Bezalel to make it.

14 Ex. 35:1 tells us that Moses gathered the people and told them to make the tabernacle and its furniture, the ark included. Ex. 35 follows the account of the giving of the second tablets, which is recorded in Ex. 34. Now, since I.E. believes that the ark spoken of in our chapter is to be identified with the ark made by Bezalel, he interprets And Moses assembled as And Moses had assembled Israel; that is, Moses gathered Israel and commanded them to make the tabernacle before he ascended Mount Sinai a second time to receive the second tablets.
15 Where a perfect is to be taken as a pluperfect. See Vol. 1, p. XVI.
16 I.E.’s interpretation.
17 This indicates that our verse deals with the ark in which the tablets were placed permanently; the ark in which Moses placed the tablets.
18 As the Lord commanded me.
19 As the Lord commanded me (v. 5).
20 In other words, verse 5 does not refer to the command recorded in Ex. 25:16. It thus does not speak of the ark made by Bezalel. Therefore our verse does not contradict the Rabbinic tradition.
21 Amidst the account of the golden calf.
22 Saying, And I prayed for Aaron also at that time, Moses indicated that Aaron did not go along with those who worshipped the calf.
23 And not after the incident of the golden calf, for God accepted Moses’ prayer.
24 Not after the death of Aaron.
25 See I.E. on Num. 3:1.
26 That our verse is a parenthetical statement.
27 The rabbis of the Talmud.

28 According to Num. 20:22-29, Aaron died at Mount Hor, not at Moserah. Furthermore, Num. 33:31 tells us that Israel journeyed from Moseroth to Bene-jaakan. The rabbis identify Bene-jaakan with Beeroth-benejaakan and Moserah with Moseroth. Additionally, the rabbis identify Hor-haggidgad (Num. 33:32) with Gudgod (v. 7). Thus according to the rabbis, verses 6 and 7 contradict Num. 33:31,32. The rabbis solve the contradictions by saying that Israel backtracked from Mount Hor to Moserah. See Rashi: “Moses reproved Israel saying that when Aaron died on Mount Hor at the end of 40 years and the clouds of glory departed you feared war with the king of Arad, and you appointed a leader that you might return to Egypt, and you turned backwards 8 stages unto Bene-jaakan and from there to Moserah. There the sons of Levi fought with you, and they slew some of you, and you some of them, until they forced you back on the road along which you had retreated. From Moserah you returned to Gudgod, (Num. 33:33), that is identical with Hor-haggidgad (v. 8).” Also, see Yerushalmi Sotah, chapter 1, Hal. 10; Yoma, Chap 1, Hal. 1; Seder Olam, chapter 9.
29 Which indicates that Aaron died and was buried at Moserah.
30 An eleventh-twelfth century scholar. He was a student of Rabbi Samuel Ha-Nagid and the teacher of Rabbi Moses ibn Ezra.
31 At that time.
32 Thus our verse does not contradict Num. 33:31.
33 Not Bene-jaakan, for Num. 33:37 relates that Israel journeyed from Kadesh to Mount Hor.
34 Hence our verse does not contradict Num. 20:22-29.
35 Where a place has two names and Scripture refers to it in one place by one name and in another place by another name.
37 To which Israel journeyed from Bene-jaakkan.
38 Numbers tells us that Israel journeyed from Mount Hor to Zalmonah, Punon and Oboth (Num. 33:43,44).
39 Hebrew, be’er (well). It is not to be identified with Jotbah in Num. 33:33 to which Israel journeyed from Hor-haggidgad.
40 In other words, Israel did not backtrack after Aaron’s death, for the journey to Gudgod, took place after Aaron died. See note 28.

42 According to I.E. on verse 7, Gudgod is a general name for Zalmonah and Punon. Now, since From thence they journeyed unto Gudgod is connected to and Eleazar… it follows that Eleazar started to serve as high priest there.

43 Aaron died on the first day of the fifth month (Num. 33:39). Moses waited until the new year began, on the first day of the seventh month, for Eleazar to begin serving as kohen gadol (high priest).
44 Or Jotbah.
45 Hence Gudgod and Jotbah are mentioned after and Eleazar…ministered. In other words, verses 6 and 7 are to be interpreted, and Eleazar ministered in Gudgod and in Jotbah.
46 Verse 6 and 7.
47 Namely, in Gudgod and in Jotbah.
48 At that time the Lord separated the tribe of Levi does not refer to when Israel came to Jotbah but rather to what happened at Sinai (v. 8).
49 Our verse refers to the entire tribe.
50 When offering the priestly blessing. This part of the verse applies only to the kohanim. Eleazar is mentioned for he is the kohen who did the blessing at that time.
51 See I.E. on Deut. 6:7 and the notes thereto.
52 See I.E. on verse 1.
53 Who stand before me.
54 See I.E. on Ex. 32:9 (Vol. 2, p. 665).
55 See I.E. on Gen. 1:1 (Vol. 1, p. 26). According to I.E. the term elohim means angels. Elohe elohim means God who is above the angels [the hosts].
56 Hence the term lords. The angels are on various levels.
57 That is, the one who knows the various heavenly levels.
58 For he knows the ways of God.
59 The stranger.
60 Alone. No other act has to accompany the oath (Sarim).
61 Num. 30:7 refers to an oath as the clear utterance of the lips (Krinsky).

62 See I.E. on Gen. 46:23 (Vol. 1, pp. 403-406). There I.E notes that Jacob is included among the 70, for if we do not count Jacob among the 70, then the number of those who descended into Egypt comes to 69. Most printed editions conclude with what we have as I.E.’s comment on 11:1.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 11
chapter.p: [1. THEREFORE THOU SHALT LOVE THE LORD.] Since the Lord multiplied you, you are obligated to love Him. Our verse adds always.1

2. I SPEAK NOT WITH YOUR CHILDREN THAT HAVE NOT KNOWN. The answer is2, but your eyes have seen (v. 7).3 It4 means these wonders are not future phenomena which your children shall see. On the contrary, you yourselves have witnessed them.
HIS GREATNESS, HIS MIGHTY HAND, AND HIS OUTSTRETCHED ARM. In taking you out of Egypt.
3. AND HIS SIGNS, AND HIS WORKS. Unto Pharaoh, for he was most important.5
4. HE MADE…TO OVERFLOW. The word hetzif (made to overflow) is related to the word tzafu (flowed)6 in Waters flowed over my head (Lam. 3:54).
DESTROYED THEM. Its meaning is, their children did not arise in their place to be like them.7
5. AND WHAT HE DID UNTO YOU IN THE WILDERNESS. The reference is to the manna.
6. AND THEIR HOUSEHOLDS.8 The reference is to their wives and to their children.
AND EVERY LIVING SUBSTANCE. Yekum (substance) is an all-inclusive term.9
THAT FOLLOWED THEM. Be-raglehem (that followed them) means because of them.10 On the other hand, the term may be taken literally.11
Since you have seen all of this,12 take heed so that you observe God’s commandments.13
8. AND POSSESS. The resh in vi-yerishtem (and possess) is vocalized with a chirik14 because the vav15 is vocalized with a chirik.

10. FOR THE LAND. Here is another reason why you are obligated to observe God’s commandments. The land is not like the land of Egypt. On the contrary, the land needs God to keep His eye on it.16 The meaning of our verse can be understood with the following parable. The Lord will act like a person who sees all that the land needs and will give everything in its time.
12. FROM THE BEGINNING. Me-reshit (from the beginning) is spelled without an alef.17 There are many such instances.18

Scripture therefore19 goes on to say, And it shall come to pass (v. 13); and I will give the rain of your land in its season (v. 14).20 This is what Scripture means by the eyes of the Lord are always upon it.21
14. THE FORMER RAIN. The word yoreh (former rain) refers to rain which indicates22 a good year. It comes at the beginning of the year.23
AND THE LATTER RAIN. The meaning of malkosh (the latter rain) is known.24
15. AND THOU SHALT EAT AND BE SATISFIED. This refers to thy corn, and thy wine (v. 14), not to that which comes immediately before it25 namely, grass in thy fields.
17. HER FRUIT. I have previously explained the meaning of yevulah (her fruit).26
AND YE PERISH QUICKLY. They will be exiled from the land like those who perish in hunger.27 Now, since the land is good, you are therefore obligated to take these words to heart.28

18. FOR FRONTLETS. Its meaning has been explained.29 If you will take My words to heart, you will not be exiled from the land, and your days upon the land shall be as long as the days of the heaven above the earth.

22. FOR IF YE SHALL DILIGENTLY KEEP. The meaning of our verse is: I told you that you will quickly be driven from the good land.30 Know that you will not initially enter the land, and you will not be victorious if you do not keep the commandments of God.31
TO LOVE. With your heart.
TO WALK IN ALL HIS WAYS. Not to change or overturn.32
AND TO CLEAVE UNTO HIM. Ultimately.33 This is a great secret.34
26. BEHOLD. Moses speaks to each individual.35

27. THE BLESSING, IF YE SHALL HEARKEN. For if you hearken, behold, you are blessed.36 A blessing means an addition of the good.37 A curse means a diminution.38 The word kelalah (curse) is related to the word kallah (light).39
29. THAT THOU SHALT SET THE BLESSING. Verbally,40 as in and he shall put them41 upon the head of the goat (Lev. 16:21).42
30. BEYOND THE JORDAN. To one standing on the side of the wilderness.43
BEHIND THE WAY OF THE GOING DOWN OF THE SUN. This means when you follow the western road you will find them.44
IN THE LAND OF THE CANAANITES THAT DWELL IN THE ARABAH. For there are Canaanites who dwell in the mountain.45

OVER AGAINST GILGAL. The mountains are long.46 Look. Moses specified the place47 by command. Over against Gilgal is similar to and pursued as far as Dan (Gen. 14:14).48 It is possible that it was prophetically stated,49 or we are dealing with two names.50
OVER AGAINST. The word mul means over against.
BESIDE THE TEREBINTHS OF MOREH. This is the same place as mentioned in the days of Abraham.51
Scripture will later on state the blessings and the curses.
31. FOR YE ARE TO PASS OVER. This means, thus shall you commence to do and the land will be yours eternally for an inheritance.
chapter.ftnote: 1 Thus our verse does not merely repeat Deut. 10:12.
2 The question raised by our verse is, “If God did not speak with their children, to whom was He speaking?”

3 In other words, verse 7 concludes the thought raised in our verse. I.E.’s point is that our verse is to be understood, I speak not with your children…but with you whose eyes have seen the great deeds that God wrought.
4 …but your eyes have seen (v. 7).
5 Our verse mentions Pharaoh, either because he was the most important Egyptian or because he was the main source of Israel’s trouble (Weiser).
6 From the root tzadi, vav, feh.

7 Our verse tells us that God destroyed the Egyptians unto this day. However, the Egyptians were not wiped off the face of the earth. Hence I.E.’s interpretation that the meaning of our verse is, God destroyed the type of Egyptians who enslaved and pursued the Israelites.
8 Literally, and their houses.
9 Yekum usually applies to living creatures. I.E. points out that here it applies to all sorts of property.
10 Be-raglehem literally means at their feet. Hence I.E.’s comment.
11 That is, those who walked in their footsteps, that is, those that followed them.
12 The acts of God described in verses 1-6.
13 I.E.’s paraphrase of verses 7 and 8.
14 Rather than with a pattach. Vi-yerishtem is the word yerashtem plus the conversive vav. Thus our word should have read vi-yerashtem. Hence I.E.’s comment.
15 Of vi-rishtem.
16 The land requires God’s supervision.
17 The world reshit is usually spelled with an alef.
18 Where a silent alef is dropped.
19 That is, because the land requires God’s supervision.

20 That is, Scripture states that God will give rain in its season if Israel observes God’s laws, because the land requires God’s supervision. God will care for the land if Israel observes His commandments.
21 It means that God looks upon the land to see whether the inhabitants are observing His laws.
22 The word yoreh literally means to show or teach.
23 The early rain is an indicator of an abundance of rain.
24 If yoreh refers to the early rain, then malkosh must refer to the later rain.
25 Literally, near it.
26 See I.E. on Lev. 26:4.
27 In other words, you will be driven from the land by hunger.
28 So that you are not exiled from the land.
29 See I.E. on Deut. 6:8.
30 If you worship idols.

31 The section dealing with exile from the land precedes our section. Scripture in effect says: not only will you be exiled from the land if in the future you worship idols, but if you do so now, you will not even be permitted to enter the land.
32 God’s laws.
33 When the soul leaves the body.

34 According to I.E. cleaving to God entails leading a life wherein one strictly observes God’s commandments, masters the sciences, learns about the throne of glory, and masters the secret of the chariot seen by Ezekiel. See The Secret of the Torah, p. 143.
35 The word re’eh (behold) is in the singular. That which follows is in the plural. Hence I.E.’s comment.
36 If you observe the commandments, you will automatically be blessed.
37 Such as children, wealth, strength, health, and the like. See I.E. on Gen. 2:3 (Vol. 1, p. 50).
38 Of the good. See I.E. on Gen. 3:14 and the notes thereto (Vol. 1, p. 70).
39 When one is cursed, the good which he has is taken away. He is therefore “lighter.”
40 Set the blessing means utter the blessings.
41 The sins of Israel.
42 One cannot put sins on a goat. Hence it means to confess the sins over the goat.

43 The eastern bank of the Jordan, where Israel presently was. Beyond the Jordan generally applies to the eastern bank of the Jordan. I.E. points out that here it applies to the western bank of the Jordan. It is also called beyond the Jordan to one standing on the eastern bank, which contains the wilderness.
44 The mountains.
45 Hence Scripture delineates which group of Canaanites it speaks of.
46 Hence Scripture delineates which part of the mountain is to be involved in the ritual.
47 Of the ritual.

48 Gilgal received its name in the days of Joshua. See Josh. 5:9. The question thus arises how could Moses employ a name which was not in existence during his lifetime. Hence I.E. points out that our verse is similar to Gen. 14:14. There, Scripture uses the term Dan with regard to an episode in the life of Abraham, even though the place could not have had this name in Abraham’s time, for Dan was named after the son of Jacob.
49 That Moses used the name Gilgal prophetically.
50 Two places with the same name. Gilgal in Josh. 5:9 is not the same as the Gilgal mentioned in our verse. The same would apply to Dan in Gen. 14:14.
51 See Gen. 12:6.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 12
chapter.p: 2. YE SHALL SURELY DESTROY ALL THE PLACES…THEIR GODS. Rabbi Jonah the grammarian says that et elohehem (their gods) is lacking a vav, for the meaning of the phrase is, and their gods.1 However, he contributes nothing.2 Et elohehem is most certainly connected to asher avedu sham (wherein they served).3
EVERY LEAFY TREE. The words ra’anan (leafy) and sha’anan (at peace) are always spelled with two nuns.4 The meaning of ra’anan is wet.5
3. THEIR ASHERIM. Asherim are trees.
AND YE SHALL DESTROY THEIR NAME. So that they not be mentioned.
4. YE SHALL NOT DO SO. This means do not sacrifice on the hills and the mountains. Do so only in the place where the Lord shall put His name.
5. TO PUT HIS NAME THERE. Compare, Where I cause My name to be mentioned (Ex. 20:21).
EVEN UNTO HIS HABITATIONS SHALL YE SEEK. The reference is to the land, that is, to the place where God’s glory dwells.6
7. AND THERE YE SHALL EAT. The kohanim and the Levites.7

8. YE SHALL NOT DO AFTER ALL THAT WE DO HERE THIS DAY. Scripture states this because they were journeying from station to station.8 After Aaron’s death some would sacrifice a burnt offering in any one of the stations that he desired to do so.9 Some would present the first-born of the flock. Others did not, for the commandment10 is contingent upon the Land of Israel.11 However, this is not my opinion. Its meaning,12 rather, is that not all of them feared God. Now, Moses said “we”13 because, as Scripture clearly states, he made the many commandments regarding the burnt offering contingent upon the Land of Israel.14

[9. TO THE REST.] So that they and their children do not have to travel.15 This is the meaning of inheritance.16 However, actually the meaning of the rest is, and giveth you rest (v. 10),17 and the inheritance refers to so that ye dwell in safety (v. 10).18
11. AND ALL YOUR CHOICE VOWS. The commandment requires that offerings made by vows be brought from the choicest.19 Behold, another addition, namely, And ye shall rejoice20 (v. 12).

[12.] AND THE LEVITE. You are obligated to make the Levite happy, for he does not have an inheritance as you do. Scripture repeats in every place that thou seest21 (v. 13) because it wants to exclude meat eaten out of desire.22 Scripture states the unclean and the clean (v. 15) with regard to meat eaten out of desire because peace offerings are sacred and one who eats sacred meat in a state of impurity incurs the penalty of excision.23

15. AS OF THE GAZELLE, AND AS OF THE HART. Which are not offered on the altar. The fat of the gazelle and also that of the hart, is permitted. Look, this is proof of my words.24 However, we rely on the tradition of our fathers.25
17. THOU MAYEST NOT EAT WITHIN THY GATES THE TITHE OF THY CORN. Moses speaks to the Levites.26 According to many he also speaks to the Israelites regarding the second tithe.27

OR THE FIRSTLINGS OF THY HERD OR OF THY FLOCK. Moses speaks to the kohanim,28 for the Levites and also the kohanim are included among the Israelites.29 Compare, And I commanded you (Deut. 3:18) wherein Moses speaks to two and a half tribes. Similarly, Moses speaks to Israel when he says, the first-born of man shalt thou surely redeem (Num. 18:15), which means the one who is obligated to redeem.30 Similarly, Thou mayest not eat within thy gates31 and but thou shalt eat them before the Lord thy God (v. 18) refer to the one who is obligated to eat.32

The heretics33 say that there are two sorts of first-born. One is the first to break out of its mother’s womb. The second is the first-born of the flock.34 There is no need to respond to their nonsense. There are also others who say that if an Israelite is in the chosen place, then he eats the first-born and the tithe. However, this is the reverse of what Scripture says.35

[20.
