BECAUSE THY SOUL DESIRETH TO EAT FLESH.] This means, if your soul desires to eat flesh.36 Moses already mentioned this.37 He repeats himself in order to add, If the place…be too far from thee (v. 21).38 Furthermore, this verse speaks of a place that is not part of the land of Canaan.39 Its law is the same as the law within your gates.40
23. FOR THE BLOOD IS THE LIFE. I have explained this previously.41

25. THAT IT MAY GO WELL WITH THEE. A person should not eat the soul [blood] of an animal for it will harm his soul.42 Also, one’s soul and form are in the image of the father.43 Scripture therefore states, and with thy children after thee.44
26. ONLY THY HOLY THINGS. Burnt offerings, peace offerings, and vow offerings.
THOU SHALT TAKE.45 This means bring them46 to the chosen place.

27. AND THOU SHALT EAT THE FLESH. Moses speaks to the kohen concerning47 a first-born, a sin offering, a guilt offering, or the shoulder or breast.48 If the kohen eats from a peace offering, the major part belongs to the Israelite.49
[28. OBSERVE AND HEAR.] Observe and hear means, observe and hear the law regarding the blood which is to be poured on the altar.
29. WHEN THE LORD…SHALL CUT OFF. This section50 also is connected to When the Lord…shall enlarge thy border (v. 20), for if Israel does not conquer the nations, God will not enlarge Israel’s border.
[30. AND THAT…NOT.] U-fen (and that…not) introduces an abridged clause. So that you will follow their practices [has been omitted].51

EVEN SO WILL I DO LIKEWISE. In the service of the Lord, and you will think that you are doing good. You shall not act in this manner, for God despises all their ways. For even their sons…do they burn in the fire to their gods is proof of the latter. That which I commanded you, that shall you observe to do.52
chapter.ftnote: 1 Rabbi Jonah maintains that our verse should be read: Ye shall surely destroy all the places wherein the nations that ye are to dispossess served, “and” their gods. He interprets this as meaning, You shall surely destroy all the places wherein the nations that you are to dispossess worshipped. You shall also destroy their gods.
2 For as I.E. goes on to note, et elohehem is connected to asher avedu sham (wherein they served).
3 For our text reads, et elohehem (their gods) not ve-et elohehem (and their gods). I.E. feels that there is no reason to interpret et as if written ve-et.

4 I.E. apparently believed that the root of sha’anan is shin, alef, nun and that of ra’anan is resh, ayin, nun. Hence he points out that in ra’anan and sha’anan the final root letter is doubled. See Radak, Sefer Ha-sharoshim.
5 Full of sap, as in a leafy tree.
6 The land containing the tabernacle, where God’s glory dwells.
7 For Scripture goes on to speak of food that may not be eaten by Israelites. See I.E. on verse 17.
8 On their way to the Land of Israel.
9 After Aaron’s death the bringing of sacrifices was optional. Hence some brought sacrifices; others did not.
10 To offer sacrifices. After Aaron’s death the bringing of sacrifices was optional. Hence some brought sacrifices others did not. Thus every man did whatsoever was right in his eyes.
11 Hence Scripture tells the Israelites that once they enter the Land of Israel, they must offer the sacrifices that Scripture commands.
12 The meaning of, Ye shall not do after all that we do here this day. Every man whatsoever is right in his own eyes.

13 Even though Moses was not included among those who did not fear the Lord. The first part of the verse, where the term “we” is found, applies to the laws which Israel did not observe in the wilderness.
14 The burnt offering is representative of all laws in force only in the Land of Israel.
15 From place to place. In other words, the reference is to when Israel settled in the Land of Israel.
16 The word inheritance (nachalah) explains rest (menuchah). Nachalah refers to a place of final settlement. So does menuchah.
17 After Israel has conquered the entire Land of Israel.
18 After conquering the land. According to the first interpretation rest refers to being in the land. According to the second interpretation it refers to living securely in the land.
19 Of the animals. The point is that our verse does not repeat, for it adds that vows be brought from among the choicest of the animals.
20 In addition to telling us that vows are to be offered from the choicest animals, it also commands the laws of rejoicing.
21 After having stated this already in verse 5.
22 Meat which is not sacred.
23 That is, the law of clean and unclean does not apply to the eating of nonsacred meat (v. 15).
24 I.E. believes that, according to the plain meaning of the text, only the fat of an animal that has actually been offered on the altar is forbidden. See I.E. on Lev. 7:20.
25 According to the rabbis of the Talmud the fat of an animal that may be offered on the altar is forbidden.
26 For our verse speaks of the first tithe.
27 According to this interpretation the tithe spoken of in our verse refers to the first and the second tithe.
28 Only they may eat of the first-born.
29 Hence Scripture does not specify that it is speaking to the Levites or the kohanim.
30 The import of the verse is, those among you who are obligated to redeem, shall redeem. Similarly, the previous verse speaks only to those Israelites to whom it applies.
31 In our verse.
32 Not to all Israelites.
33 The Karaites.
34 Which any Israelite may eat.
35 Elsewhere Scripture states that an Israelite may not eat the first tithe or the first -born of the flock and sheep.
36 In other words, the term ki (because) has the meaning of if here.
37 In verse 15.
38 This verse teaches that they may eat non-sacred meat outside the sanctuary only if they are far from it.

39 Verse 15 speaks of the Land of Israel. However, our verse speaks of the land beyond the borders of Israel. Thus our verse teaches that it is permitted to slaughter cattle for meat beyond the borders of the Holy Land.

40 That is, the law regarding the eating of non-sacred meat outside the land of Canaan is the same as the law dealing with the eating of non-sacred meat within the gates of the cities in the land of Canaan. See verse 15.
41 See I.E. on Gen. 9:4 (Vol. 1, p. 122).
42 According to Ibn Ezra the eating of anything which the Torah proscribes has a deleterious effect on the soul.
43 A person’s soul and form are in the image of his father.
44 If you eat blood it will have a bad effect on your children. However, if you abstain from eating blood, it will be well with your children who follow you.
45 Literally, thou shalt carry (tissa).
46 In other words, thou shalt carry should not be taken literally. It is to be understood as, you shall bring.
47 The meat of.
48 From any cattle slaughtered for meat.
49 The kohen’s share of the peace offering consists of the shoulder, the cheeks, and the maw. See Deut. 18:3.
50 In addition to the one dealing with non-sacred slaughter, (verses 20-28).
51 I.E. reads our clause as follows: And lest thou follow their practices and inquire after their gods, etc.
52 Do not add additional pagan practices to My worship. Worship Me in the manner that I commanded you. I.E. is paraphrasing Deut. 13:1, which, in the Hebrew Bible, closes our chapter.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 13
chapter.p: 2. IF THERE ARISE IN THE MIDST OF THEE. Scripture reads in the midst of thee because there is no prophet except from among Israel.1 This section is connected to the previous one2 because they both deal with idol worship, for the burning of the children (Deut. 12:31) was an act of idol worship.

Our verse deals with a prophet who claims that God, or God’s messenger, spoke to him while he was awake or in a dream. Some say that it is possible that the prophet3 was one of those who steal God’s word (Jer. 26:30). They explain that a true prophet said that a certain sign would appear to verify his word.4 Someone heard this and related the sign so that it should bear witness for him.5 Others say that even if the sign or a wonder came to pass6 we do not believe him,7 for what he says8 contradicts reason.9

I believe that the terms wonder10 and sign11 apply also12 to symbolic acts.13 Compare, the words of the prophet Isaiah: Behold, I and the children whom the Lord hath given me shall be for signs and for wonders (Is. 8:18); the sign of the prophet14 in Like as My servant Isaiah hath walked naked and barefoot (Is. 20:3);15 the names of his children, which served as signs regarding things that would occur in their lifetime, namely, Emanuel (Is. 7:14); Maher-shalal-hash-baz (Is. 8:3); Shearjashub (Is. 7:3). Also Scripture’s statement with regard to the plagues,16 And they shall be upon thee for a sign and for a wonder (Deut. 28:46). There are many such instances.17

4. [PUTTETH YOU TO PROOF.] Scripture says, for the Lord…putteth you to proof, because God left the prophet18 alone and did not kill him. The purpose of God’s test is to show the righteousness of the one who is being tried.19
5. AFTER THE LORD YOUR GOD SHALL YE WALK. You shall do your utmost to imitate God’s deeds and pursue His paths.
AND HIM SHALL YE FEAR. You shall refrain from asking why this is so.20
AND HIS COMMANDMENTS SHALL YE KEEP. The commandments which are most important.21
AND UNTO HIS VOICE SHALL YE HEARKEN. This refers to precepts which recall that which is most important.22
AND HIM SHALL YE SERVE. In deed.
AND UNTO HIM SHALL YE CLEAVE. With your heart. In the beginning and at the end.23

6. BECAUSE HE HATH SPOKEN PERVERSION. The word davar (thing) has been omitted from our clause.24 But in the multitude of counselors established25 (Prov. 15:22) is similar.26 Scripture reads sarah (perversion) because God commanded Israel to turn away (la-sur) from idolatry.27 On the other hand, the word sarah might be related to the word soreh28 (defiant) in defiant29 and rebellious (Deut. 21:20). The latter interpretation is correct. The resh should have received a dagesh.30
WHO BROUGHT YOU OUT OF THE LAND OF EGYPT, AND REDEEMED THEE OUT OF THE HOUSE OF BONDAGE. Scripture repeats itself for the sake of emphasis.
SO SHALT THOU PUT AWAY. I have previously explained the meaning of u-vi’arta (so thou put away).31

7. IF THY BROTHER…ENTICE THEE. This means even thy brother.32 The import of thy mother is, you33 were in one womb. The mother is like matter and the father is like form.34 Very few people understand the nature of form.
9. THOU SHALT NOT CONSENT UNTO HIM. By believing in your heart.
NOR HEARKEN UNTO HIM. In deed.
NEITHER SHALL THINE EYE PITY HIM. You shall not refrain from killing him.
NEITHER SHALT THOU CONCEAL HIM. You shall not leave him alone but you shall reveal the matter until witnesses hear it35 from his mouth, as is stated in Scripture.36 You shall then kill him.
10. THY HAND SHALL BE FIRST UPON HIM. Were it not for tradition,37 it would appear that the reference38 is to the two witnesses.
11. AND THOU SHALT STONE HIM. Scripture explains the manner of his death.
15. THEN SHALT THOU INQUIRE, AND MAKE SEARCH, AND ASK DILIGENTLY. These words are well explained in the writings of our rabbis of blessed memory.39
17. EVERY WHIT. Completely to the Lord your God.40 You shall bum it in fire because of God’s honor.41
A HEAP. The word tel (heap) is related to talul (heaped) in upon a high mountain and heaped (Ezek. 17:22).42
18. THAT THE LORD MAY TURN FROM THE FIERCENESS OF HIS ANGER. And He will not destroy you because of the sins of that city.
[19. WHEN THOU SHALT HEARKEN.] The meaning of When43 thou shalt hearken is, thus shall you do if you desire to do what is right in the eyes of God.

The section which opens with Ye are children of the Lord (Deut. 14:1) is connected to this section because of the enticers,44 namely, a brother, a sister, and a son or daughter (v. 7), or the inhabitants of the idol-worshipping city (v. 14). It is prohibited to mourn for them,45 and it is certainly prohibited to cut oneself,46 for behold, that is prohibited over any deceased.47
chapter.ftnote: 1 Prophesy is found only among Israelites. I.E. considered Balaam an astrologer who claimed to be a prophet. See I.E. on Num. 22:28 (Vol. 4, p. 186). This is also the opinion of Rabbi Yehudah Ha-Levi. See Book I of the Kuzari.
3 Spoken of in our verse.
4 The true prophet gave a sign to show that what he said was true.
5 The false prophet used the sign given by the true prophet for his own purposes.
6 By the prophet.
7 The prophet.
8 His call to serve other gods.
9 See Rabbi Saadiah Gaon, Sefer Ha-Emunot Ve-Ha-De’ot, Treatise III.
10 Hebrew, mofet.
11 Hebrew, ot.
12 In addition to referring to supernatural events, as in Or hath God assayed to go and take Him a nation from the midst of another nation, by trials, by signs, and by wonders (Deut. 4:34).

13 The terms mofet (wonder) and ot (sign) usually refer to a miraculous act such as changing a rod into a serpent or water into blood. However, it may also refer to an act which illustrates what the prophet predicts will happen. According to I.E. the sign spoken of in our verse refers to the latter. Hence Scripture speaks of the sign coming to pass; i.e., the act played out by the prophet came to be.

14 Isaiah gave his sons names which alluded to that which would occur in the future. Thus he named one son Immanuel (God is with us) to indicate that Judah would survive. He named another son Shear-jashub (a remnant shall return) to indicate that the remnant of Judah will repent and return to God.
15 Isaiah walked naked and barefoot in Jerusalem to indicate that the people of Judah will be led into exile barefoot and naked.
16 Which would befall Israel.
17 Where signs and wonders are used in the sense of omens.
18 Who tried to lead the Jews into idolatry.
19 So too Maimonides, Guide for the Perplexed, 111:24. Also see I.E. on Gen. 22:1 (Vol. 1, p. 223).
20 A person must observe the commandments even if he does not understand the reasons for them.

21 Such as belief in God. See chapter 5 of Yesod Mora. The most important “commandments are those precepts that are implanted in the heart, They are not contingent on place, time or anything else…[they] were known by reason before the Torah was given through the agency of Moses…The decalogue, with the exclusion of the Sabbath, is an example” (Strickman translation, pp. 75,76).

22 Some commandments serve as reminders of the most important precepts. For example, the Sabbath commemorates creation. Likewise, not permitting one’s slaves to work on the Sabbath recalls the exodus from Egypt. Similarly…the matzot…the tefillin…the tzitzit [all serve as reminders] (Ibid, p. 78). The tzitzit (the fringes), for example, remind us of God’s commandments.
23 In the beginning of life and at the end of life, namely, in youth and in old age (Weiser).

24 Our verse reads, ki dibber sarah (for he hath spoken perversion). Sarah is an adjective. Hence I.E. notes that the word which sarah is describing has been omitted. Our text is to be interpreted as if written, ki dibber davar sarah. I.E. interprets the latter as, for he has spoken words commanding us to turn away from the Lord.
25 Translated according to I.E.
26 Our text should be read as if written: But in the multitude of counselors, counsel is established.
27 I.E. interprets ki dibber sarah as meaning for He has spoken words urging us to turn away from the Lord.
28 From the root samekh, resh, resh.
29 Translated according to I.E.
30 To compensate for the missing resh. However, it doesn’t, for resh does not receive a dagesh.
31 See I.E. on Num. 24:22 (Vol. 4, p. 210).
32 If thy…brother entice thee is to be understood as even if your brother entices you, for the law applies to anyone who entices you.

33 And your brother were in one womb. Thus the meaning of our verse is, even if your brother who was in one womb with you entices you. Our verse speaks of thy brother, the son of thy mother. This is an appellation rarely used in Scripture. The question thus arises, “Why did Scripture add the son of thy mother?” Furthermore, why did the Torah not describe the brother as the son of thy father? Hence I.E. comments that the matter from which a person is made comes from the mother; the father’s sperm (so I.E. believed) shapes the matter. Thus a person, biologically speaking, is closer to a brother from a mother than to a brother from a father, and probably has closer emotional ties to him. Hence Scripture states, even if your brother who is made of the same matter as you entices you, do not listen to him.

34 Form gives shape to matter. Form is intangible. Different men will give different form to the matter produced by the same woman. However, all of the children will share the same matter. Hence Scripture speaks of thy mother not thy father.
35 His incitement to worship idols.
36 Scripture requires two witnesses in capital cases. See Deut. 17:6.
37 That teaches that thy hand refers to the hand of the people whom he tried to entice. See Sifre.
38 Thy hand.
39 See Sanhedrin 40.
40 In other words, the term kalil (every whit) is connected to la-Adonai. Our clause is to be read, every whit unto the Lord thy God.

41 To the Lord thy God means for the honor of the Lord thy God. By burning the contents of the city, the Israelites demonstrated that they destroyed the city because its inhabitants worshipped idols, and not for the purpose of looting.
42 Translated according to I.E.
43 Hebrew, ki. I.E. renders ki if. Thus our clause reads, if thou shalt hearken. Hence his interpretation.
44 Our chapter tells us that the enticers are to be put to death.
45 After they are put to death.
46 To lacerate one’s flesh as a sign of mourning over their deaths.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 14
chapter.p: 1. YE SHALL NOT CUT YOURSELVES. Titgodedu (ye shall not cut yourselves) means the same as ve-seret (cuttings) in cuttings…for the dead (Lev. 19:28).1 Titgodedu is related to the word gedudot2 (cuttings) in Upon all the hands are cuttings (Jer. 48:37).
NOR MAKE ANY BALDNESS. As the nations do unto this very day.

[CHILDREN.] The meaning of children is, now that you know that you are children of God and that the Lord loves you more than a father loves his son, do not cut yourselves over anything that God does, for whatever the Lord does is for the good. If you do not understand God,3 then act like small children who do not understand what their father does but nevertheless rely upon him. For thou art a holy people (v. 2) and you are not like all the Canaanites. You shall therefore not imitate their practices.

The section opening with the words Thou shalt not eat any abominable thing (v. 3) follows because Scripture says, as it were, you are holy in your heart and in your mouth. You shall be separated from the nations. All who see you shall recognize you, for you will not make yourself bald for the dead and you do not eat all living creatures. If you are a holy people, then it is unfitting for you to eat that which is unclean and defiles one’s soul.
3. ANY ABOMINABLE THING. Anything which is abominable to a pure soul such as anything that crawls on the ground.
4. THE OX, THE SHEEP. A vav should have been placed before the word seh (sheep).4 The term seh applies to both sheep and goats.5
5. THE HART, AND THE GAZELLE. We know the meaning [of ayyal (the hart) and tzevi (the gazelle)]. We need tradition6 for the other five.7
8. BUT CHEWETH NOT THE CUD. The word yiggar (will chew) is missing.8 Our text employs abbreviated terminology.9 On the other hand, the word lo (to it) might be missing.10
9. FINS AND SCALES. This has been explained previously.11

11. OF ALL CLEAN BIRDS YOU MAY EAT. Tzippor (birds) is a general term.12 The dove and turtledove are subcategories of the general term “birds.”13 The dayyah (the kite)14 and the ayyah15 (the falcon)16 are subcategories of the da’ah (falcon) (Lev. 11:14),17 as Scripture now elaborates.18
20. OF ALL CLEAN WINGED THINGS. Such as the lo-cust.19
21. YE SHALL NOT EAT OF ANY THING THAT DIETH OF ITSELF. Of fowl or beast.20
THOU MAYEST GIVE IT UNTO THE STRANGER. Who, as I have explained, did not convert to the Jewish faith.21
OR THOU MAYEST SELL IT UNTO A FOREIGNER. Who does not live in your country. The law stating Thou shalt not seethe a kid22 follows, for it23 refers to meat.24 I have already explained the latter.

22. THOU SHALT SURELY TITHE. This section25 follows26 because it is prohibited to eat any unclean winged creature and any unclean animal, nor any animal which died of natural causes.27 Now it is similarly forbidden to eat sacred grain28 or sacred meat in any but the chosen place.

WHICH IS BROUGHT FORTH IN THE FIELD YEAR BY YEAR. Rabbi Yehudah Ha-Levi the Spaniard, who rests in Eden, said that which is brought forth in the field is connected to the word seed, and our verse is to be understood as, you shall tithe the seed which is brought into the field for planting.29 However, I believe that we are to interpret the verse according to its plain meaning. Our clause refers to the produce which the field brings forth.30 Should some dispute this and argue that Scripture reads ha-yotze (which is brought forth), and yotze (brought forth) is an intransitive verb, then we will show him ha-ir ha-yotzet31 elef (the city that sent forth a thousand) (Amos 5:3). Shall have a hundred left (Ibid.)32 proves this.33
The rabbis said that the reference is to the second tithe.34
Note.35 If you start from the top,36 then one is the first number. If you start from below,37 then, behold, ten is the first number.38 This is the secret of the first-born and the tithe.39

Observe. The number one does not depend on a sum.40 The number ten is similar. It is the counterpart of one because it is the beginning of the second series of numbers.41 It is also the end of the first series.42 All parts of sums are connected to ten in front and in back.43

The numbers one and ten are the main numbers; the middle numbers, five and six, are called the round numbers.44 These four numbers45 therefore46 form the silent letters.47 They are also the letters that form the glorious and awe-inspiring name.48
23. AND THE FIRSTLINGS OF THY HERD. The one who is fit49 to eat them shall eat them, as I have previously explained.

THAT THOU MAYEST LEARN.50 This means that when you go to the revered place,51 there they [kohanim] will teach you. There is a second meaning to le-ma’an tilmad (that thou mayest learn). Tilmad is similar in meaning to melummadah (well broken), as in And Ephraim is a heifer well broken (Hos. 10:11). Its meaning is habituated.52 This interpretation appears correct to me.
25. THEN SHALT THOU TURN IT INTO MONEY. The reference is to the tithe.53
IN THY HAND. It is placed in your hands.54
26. OR FOR STRONG DRINK. Made from honey, dates, wheat, or barley.
OR FOR WHATEVER THY SOUL ASKETH OF THEE. Fruits.55

THOU AND THY HOUSEHOLD. You and your sons are obligated.56 It is optional for your household, for the commandment mandating the three pilgrimages falls on males.57 The woman who goes to the chosen place, as Elkanah’s wives did,58 is rewarded.

27. AND THE LEVITE THAT IS WITHIN THY GATES. The reference is to the house of Levi.59 You will be rewarded if you do not forsake him. You shall give the Levite what you can afford.60 The verse probably speaks of the first tithe.61 Since Scripture mentioned the second tithe,62 it now goes on to say, do not think that you have fulfilled your obligation63 with the second tithe alone.64

[THAT IS WITHIN THY GATES.] The meaning of that is within thy gates is that one should give it to the Levite that is within his gates. Her should not say,65 I will keep it with me and give it to another Levite, or66 that I have given it.67

28. AT THE END OF EVERY THREE YEARS. The reference is to the third tithe.68 The Israelites do not have to give the second tithe this year. Some say that the Israelites had to give all thee tithes.69 Those who deny the Rabbinic tradition70 say that the first tithe71 is the commandment referred to in the verse that begins, Thou shalt surely tithe (v. 1). They say that thou shalt turn it into money (v. 25) is directed to the Levite72 and that similarly the firstlings… of thy flock (v. 23) is directed to the kohen.73 They say there is no such thing as the second tithe except for tithe given in the third year.74
AT THE END.75 At the beginning.76 The tithe given in the third year is called the “poor tithe.” We will rely on the tradition of our fathers.77
chapter.ftnote: 1 In other words, lo titgodedu means you shall not cut yourselves.
2 Both words come from the root gimel, dalet, dalet.
3 If you do not understand God’s actions.
4 Our verse reads, shor seh kevasim (the ox the sheep). Hence I.E. comments that our verse is to be read as if written, shor ve-seh kevasim (the ox and the sheep).
5 Our verse reads, seh kevasim ve-seh izzim. Hence I.E.’s comment.
6 For the meaning.
7 Mentioned in our verse.
8 Our text reads, ve-lo gerah. Gerah is a noun. Thus our text reads, and no cud. Hence I.E.’s comments.
9 Ve-lo gerah is short for ve-gerah and lo yiggar. See Lev. 11:7.
10 Ve-lo gerah is short for ve-lo gerah lo, meaning, and it has no cud; that is, it does not bring up a cud. In other words, it does not chew the cud.
11 See I.E. on Lev. 11:9.
12 It does not refer to a specific species of birds.

13 Gen. 15:10 reads, “but the birds (tzippor) divided he not.” The reference there is to the dove and the turtledove mentioned in Gen. 15:10. Scripture can refer to the dove and turtledove by the term tzippor because they are subcategories of tzippor.
14 Mentioned in our verse but not in Leviticus’ enumeration of the prohibited birds. See Lev. 11:13-20.
15 Some suggest reading ra’ah, for ayyah is mentioned both here and in Lev. 11:14.
16 Mentioned in our verse.

17 Mentioned only in Leviticus. Thus there is no contradiction between the lists of the 20 prohibited birds in our chapter and the 21 of Leviticus. See The Secret of the Torah, pp. 36,37: “We find that the number of prohibited fowl listed in the Torah portion Shemini is 20. However, in the Torah portion Re’eh Anokhi, the number is 21. The answer is found in the science of logic, for da’ah (Lev. 11:14) is a supreme kind that includes both the dayyah and the ra’ah (Deut. 14:13).”
18 That is, it lists some of the particulars, viz., the dayyah (the kite), the ayyah (the falcon), and the ra’ah (the glede), which are included in the category da’ah (falcon) in Leviticus.
19 In other words, this verse does not apply to birds.
20 Fish are excluded.
22 In its mother’s milk.
23 Like the law which precedes it.
24 And not to fruit. See I.E. on Ex 23:19 (Vol. 2, p. 503): “The fools say that the word gedi (kid) comes from the same root as meged (precious fruit).”
25 Verses 22-27.
26 The chapters dealing with forbidden animals, etc. (verses 3-21).
27 Either of old age or of any wounds it might have received.
28 The tithe.
29 That is, the produce from the seed. Rabbi Yehuudah believes that yotze (is brought forth) is intransitive. Hence his interpretation.
30 In other words, that yotze (is brought forth) is transitive. Our verse is to be understood as follows: You shall tithe the seed which the field produces.
31 Ha-yotzet is the feminine form of ha-yotze. It is transitive. We thus see that ha-yotze can also be transitive.
32 This clause follows in the same verse.
33 That ha-yotzet is transitive, for it speaks about what is left in the city.
34 A tithe which is set apart after the Levite has received die first tithe. The second tithe must be eaten in Jerusalem or be redeemed and the money spent in Jerusalem.
35 Ibn Ezra believed that the numbers one, five, six, and ten have special significance. See I.E. on Ex. 3:15 (Vol. 2, pp. 69-86).
36 At the beginning of the numbers.
37 At the bottom of the first ten numbers.
38 That is, the first of the tens.
39 This is the reason the first-born and the tithe are holy. The first-born corresponds to the number one, while the tithe corresponds to the number ten.
40 Every number is made up of sums. However, the number one stands by itself. It does not consist of any sum.
41 It is the first of the tens. Hence it is similar to one.
42 One through nine.

43 “Front” means before ten. “Back” means after ten. I.E.’s point is that the main numbers, that is numbers 1-9 end in 10. Thus 1-9 are connected to ten in front. All numbers after 10 are either 10 plus one of the main numbers or multiples of ten plus one of the main numbers.

44 If 5 and 6 are squared, cubed or raised to the nth power, their root is always visible. For example, 5 squared is 25, 5 cubed is 125; 6 squared is 36, 6 cubed is 216, and so on (Meijler). Thus 5 and 6 are called round numbers because in effect, they orbit their root or make a circle and ultimately return to their root.
45 One, five, six, and ten.
46 Because of their importance.

47 The letters alef (1); heh (5); vav (6), and yod (10). These letters are not always sounded. They are vowel letters. One of them is present whenever a word is enunciated. Without these letters, language would be impossible.
48 The Tetragramatton. The latter is spelled with an alef in Ex. 3:14.
49 The kohen.
50 Hebrew, le-ma’an tilmad.
51 The place where God’s glory dwells.
52 According to this interpretation our verse reads: that you will be habituated to fear the Lord.
53 That is, the second tithe.
54 You are to take care of it so that it is not lost.
55 Wine and meat are mentioned earlier in the verse. Hence I.E.’s interpretation.
56 To make the pilgrimage.
57 Scripture explicitly states this in Ex. 23:17.
58 See the first chapter of I Samuel.
59 Any descendant of the house of Levi.
60 According to this interpretation our verse does not speak of the tithe to be given to the Levite; it speaks of the obligation to support the Levite above and beyond the tithe.
61 This is a new interpretation.
62 In verses 22-26.
63 To God.
64 For you must also give the first tithe to the Levite.
65 To the Levite who lives in your city.
66 Tell the Levite in your city that you have given the tithe to a Levite in a different city.
67 To another Levite. I.E. offers two excuses that one might use to put off the local Levite. His point is, do not make up any excuse not to support the local Levite.
68 The tithe given to the poor.
69 At the end of the third year.
70 The Karaites.
71 The tithe given to the Levite.
72 Not the Israelite.
73 In other words, the entire chapter deals with food prohibited to Israelites.
74 That is, the only tithe in addition to the first tithe is the one given in the third year, i.e., the poor tithe.
75 Hebrew, miktzeh.
76 I.E. renders miktzeh at the beginning. See I.E. on Num. 13:25 (Vol. 4, p. 104), “The word mi-ketz (at the end) sometimes means at the beginning and sometimes at the end.”
77 That there are three tithes, and that the poor tithe comes in the third year in place of the second tithe.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 15
chapter.p: [1. AT THE END OF1 EVERY SEVEN YEARS.] Its meaning, as I have explained, is, at the beginning of the year.2 Assemble the people (Deut. 31:12) is proof of this.3 This section follows4 because Scripture states that the poor tithe5 belongs to the Levite, the stranger, the orphan, and the widow.6 Scripture now says that the same applies to the remission of debts (shemittah).7 The word shemittah is similar to shimtuha (throw her down) (II Kings 98:33), the meaning of which is, release her and she will fall.8

2. CREDITOR. The word masheh (loan) follows the paradigm of matteh (rod) (Ex. 4:4).9 I believe that masheh is a noun.10 However, many believe that masheh is a verb.11 The word ba’al (creditor) is similar to be’aleha (him that hath it) in wisdom preserveth the life of him that hath it (Eccles. 7:12) and be’alav (the owners thereof) in It taketh away the life of the owners thereof (Prov. 1:19). It means the one who has the matter12 in his power.
THAT WHICH HE HATH LENT. Yasheh (that which he hath lent) is a transitive verb. The one who borrows is called a nosheh bo (a borrower) (Is. 24:2).13

HE SHALL NOT EXACT IT. The word yiggos (exact) means to press. Compare, tingosu (exact) in and exact all your labors (Is. 58:3). Look, the nun is visible in the imperfect in a word whose stem begins with a nun.14

THE LORD’S RELEASE.15 In honor of God,16 who has bestowed wealth upon him. The name of God is connected to the word release because the year of release is called a Sabbath unto the Lord (Lev. 25:2,4).17
3. OF A FOREIGNER THOU MAYEST EXACT IT. It is optional.

4. HOWBEIT. This means that you shall take note that that which I commanded you, not to exact interest from your brother, will be unnecessary if all of Israel or most of them will listen to God’s voice. In this case, there will be no poor among you who need you to lend to them. On the contrary, all of you shall lend to many nations (v. 6). The meaning of ve-ha’avateta (and thou shalt lend) (v. 6) is, you shall take his pledge (avot), that is, his pawn, for the money that you shall give him, which he needs to do business.

6. AND THOU SHALT RULE. Furthermore, being upright you will rule over nations. However, there is a commandment stating If there be among you a needy man (v. 7).18 Moses knew that a generation will arise that will not be mostly meritorious. He therefore said, For the poor shall never cease out of the land (v. 11).
7. THOU SHALT NOT HARDEN THY HEART. By refraining from addressing comforting words to him.

SHUT. Tikpotz19 means you shall shut. Compare, kafetzah20 (stoppeth) in kafetzah21 piha (stoppeth her mouth) (Ps. 107:42; Job 5:16); kafatz22 be-af (shut up His compassion) (Ps. 77:10); and yikpetzu23 (shall shut) in Kings shall shut their mouths (Is. 52:15). Tikpotz is a verb in the kal.

NEEDY. Some say that the word evyon (needy) is related to the word avah24 (would) in and he would not (Ex. 10:27), for evyon follows the paradigm elyon, chevy on, and hegyon, the roots of which are ayin, lamed, heh; chet, bet, heh; heh, gimel, heh. An evyon is so called because he desires everything because of his need.

8. BUT THOU SHALT SURELY OPEN THY HAND. Pato’ach (open) is an infinitive. Whenever Scripture omits the infinitive,25 it is employing an abridged style. The midrashic interpretation is also beautiful.26
OPEN THY HAND TO HIM. To the one who has nothing.
AND SHALT SURELY LEND HIM. The meaning of veha’avet tavitennu (and shalt surely lend him) is, give him from yours by taking his pledge.27 Tavitennu means take his pledge.
9. BASE. The word beliya’al (base) is a noun. Some say that beliya’al is a compound. It refers to a prayer that the vile person should not ascend, should not grow, and should not live.28

AND THINE EYE BE EVIL. Ve-ra’ah (and thine eye be evil) is similar to ve-shavah (and is returned) in and is returned unto her father’s house (Lev. 22:13). The word comes from a root two of whose letters are pronounced.29

10. THAT. Bi-gelal (that) means the same as sibbah (because of). Compare, sabbev (cause) in cause to change (II Sam. 14:20).30 For the All31 is in the parts,32 that is, in the parts of the All, that is, the body.33
THOU SHALT SURELY GIVE HIM. It means that if you give him, then God will add to your wealth.
11. FOR THE POOR SHALL NEVER CEASE OUT OF THE LAND. As I have explained.34
UNTO THY…BROTHER. First, the one who is close to you.35
UNTO THY POOR. The poor of your family. The needy of your land come before the needy of another place.
If thy brother, a Hebrew man (v. 12) follows36 because of thou shalt furnish him liberally (v. 14).37
12. THY BROTHER A HEBREW. I have explained this.38
OR A HEBREW WOMAN. The reference is to And if a man sell his daughter to be a maid-servant (Ex. 21:7).39
13. EMPTY. I have explained this.40

14. THOU SHALT FURNISH HIM LIBERALLY. Ha’anek ta’anik (thou shalt furnish him liberally) means treat him gloriously. Ta’anik (thou shalt furnish him) is related to the word anakim (chains)41 in And chains about thy neck (Prov. 1:9).42 On the other hand, the meaning of ta’anik is to be derived from its context.43 In this case, the word has no brother.44

17. THROUGH HIS EAR AND INTO THE DOOR. I have explained this.45 Scripture mentions this46 because it states47 that you are obligated to furnish him liberally when he goes free. However, if the slave does not want to go free, then you shall pierce his ear through with an awl.

AND ALSO UNTO THY BONDWOMAN THOU SHALT DO LIKEWISE. This is connected to48 thou shalt furnish him liberally (v. 14), even though it is some distance from it, for a woman does not have her ear pierced. Compare, He shall make restitution; if he have nothing49 (Ex. 22:2);50 And if he do not these three unto her (Ex. 21:11),51 and many other instances.

18. IT SHALL NOT SEEM HARD UNTO THEE. We find it written in Scripture, three years, as the years of a hireling (Is. 16:14). The latter proves that a person has no right to hire himself out for more than three years. The law similarly applies to the one who hires him and pays his. wages.52

[DOUBLE.]53 The following is the definition of mishneh. It means double. Similarly mishneh (twice) in ve-hayah mishneh (and it shall be twice as much) (Ex. 16:5). The word mishneh in the latter is a noun. However, mishneh (next) in mishneh la-melekh (next unto king) (Esth. 10:3) is an adjective.54 It55 is also related, as I have explained,56 to the word shenayin (two).57

Note, our verse explains that and in the seventh he shall go out free for nothing (Ex. 21:2) refers to the beginning of the year.58 There is also proof of this from the year of release (shemitttah)59 as well as from the Sabbath day.60
AND…WILL BLESS THEE. U-verakhekha (and will bless you) is an imperfect, not a perfect.61 There is no difference between the perfect and imperfect.62 The tense can only be determined by the context.
19. ALL THE FIRSTLINGS. This is mentioned63 because of thou shalt do no work with the firstling of thine ox.64
20. THOU SHALT EAT IT. The one who is fit to eat it, as I have previously explained.65 Scripture mentions this a second time66 in order to explain the law regarding a blemished firstling.
THOU AND THY HOUSEHOLD. The household of the kohen.
21. ANY ILL BLEMISH. That are mentioned.67

22. WITHIN THY GATES. Some say that this means that the kohen shall eat it outside of the sanctuary.68 Others say, since the animal has a blemish it belongs to the Israelite. However, this appears far-fetched to me.

THE UNCLEAN AND THE CLEAN. The reference is to may eat it.69 Our verse is to be understood as a call: you, the clean and the unclean. Its meaning is, one is permitted to eat it whether one is clean or unclean. Scripture states this because one who is unclean and eats holy meat is punished with karet (excision).

Scripture reads three times in a year (Deut. 16:16) because it here (v. 20) states year by year.70 Additionally,71 because the firstling is to be eaten in the sanctuary.72 The paschal offering73 is similarly to be eaten in the sanctuary, not outside it.
chapter.ftnote: 1 Hebrew, mikketz.

2 According to I.E. the word mikketz means either at the end of or at the beginning of. Here it means at the beginning. Thus our clause reads, At the beginning of the seventh year. See I.E. on Deut. 9:11.

3 To hear the Torah read. This took place At the end of (mikketz) every seven years (Deut. 31:10). According to I.E. the latter should be rendered: At the beginning of the seventh year. We thus see that mikketz can be rendered, at the beginning of.
4 The laws of the poor tithe (Deut. 14:28,29).
5 A tithe set apart for the poor.
7 The remission of debts in the seventh year is primarily for the benefit of the Levite, the stranger, the orphan, and the widow, i.e., the poor.
8 In other words, the meaning of shemittah is, a release.
9 Masheh can be taken as a verb. Hence I.E.’s comment that it is a noun and follows the vocalization of nouns like matteh.
10 Meaning a loan.
11 Meaning lending.
12 Under discussion.
13 See I.E. on Is. 24:2.
14 In other words, the nun is present in tingosu (exact), which is an imperfect whose stem begins with a nun. The nun is usually dropped in such instances. Hence I.E.’s comment.
15 Hebrew, shemittah la-Adonai. Literally, a remission to the Lord.
16 A release unto the Lord means a release in honor of the Lord.
17 A release unto the Lord is a variant of a release unto the Lord.
18 Which appears to contradict there shall be no needy among you (v. 4).
19 From the root kof, peh, tzadi.
20 From the root kof, peh, tzadi.
21 From the root kof, peh, tzadi.
22 From the root kof, peh, tzadi.
23 From the root kof, peh, tzadi.
24 From the root alef, bet, heh.
25 Which should accompany a verb. It does so here, for our text correctly reads, pato’ach tiftach.

26 According to the midrash the repetition of the verb in pato’ach tiftach (thou shalt surely open) indicates that one should open his hand to the poor even one hundred times. However, I.E. believes that the form pato’ach tiftach is the correct way to say you shall open.
27 See I.E. on verse 4.

28 Beliya’al is short for beli ya’aleh (without ascending). When one sees the wicked, one utters a curse to the effect that the wicked not ascend. The meaning of our verse is, may the wicked neither grow nor live.
29 An ayin vav. Its root is resh, vav, ayin.
30 I.E. is explaining the origin of the word sibbah.
31 God.
32 In human beings, who are part of the whole.

33 Thus by being kind to his fellow human being, a person is being kind to God (Weiser). Other commentaries explain that the All refers to the community of Israel and the parts to each individual Jew. Now, since all of Israel forms one body, by helping another Jew one is helping oneself (Motot and Rabbi Yosef ben Eliezer tov Elem, followed by Krinsky, Netter, and others). See Book III of the Kuzari: “Plato calls…that which is expended on behalf of the law the portion of the whole. If, however, an individual neglects ‘the portion of the whole’…of which he forms a part, he sins against the commonwealth and more against himself; for the relation of the individual to the commonwealth is as the relation of the single limb to the body…” (Isaak Heinemann translation in Three Jewish Philosophers, N.Y., 1969, p. 99). In other words, the All is the nation, and the individual is a part of the nation. However, it should be noted that I.E. refers to God as the All. See I.E. on Gen. 1:26 (Vol. 1, p. 46), “God is one…He is all.” Also see I.E. on Gen. 18:21 (Vol. 1, p. 196) and Ex. 33:21 (Vol. 2, p. 695). The above-noted commentaries may have shied away from interpreting God as All here because of its pantheistic implications. It should be noted that when I.E. says that God is All, he does not intend to identify God with the world as the pantheists do. He means that God’s power and supervision hold the world together and give it continuous existence. Indeed, I.E. compares God’s relation to the world to that of speech to the speaker. As long as the speaker speaks, sounds are uttered. However, the speaker is not identified with the speech which he utters. On the other hand, I.E. was a contemporary of Rabbi Yehudah Ha-Levi and may be employing terminology similar to the one quoted above.
34 See I.E. on verse 6.
35 Your bother has priority.
36 The laws of charity.
37 You have to give your servant from your property. Thus both sections deal with the concept of giving.
39 The Hebrew bondwoman spoken of in our verse refers to a girl sold into slavery by her father.
40 See I.E. on Gen. 31:42 (Vol. 1, p. 306) and Ex. 3:21 (Vol. 2, p. 93).
41 Ornamental chains.
42 According to this interpretation, ha’anek ta’anik (thou shalt furnish him liberally) literally means thou shalt put ornament on him. Hence I.E.’s interpretation.
43 In other words, ta’anik (thou shalt furnish him) is not related to the word anakim (chains) in And chains about thy neck (Prov. 1:9).
44 It is not found again in Scripture. Its meaning is to be derived from its context.
45 See I.E. on Ex. 21:6 (Vol. 2, p. 457).
46 The piercing of the slave’s ear.
47 In verses 14 and 15.
48 This is related to.
49 Then he shall be sold for his theft.
50 This clause (Ex. 22:2) relates to Ex. 21:37, not that which immediately precedes it. See I.E. on Ex. 22:2 (Vol. 2, p. 482).
51 This clause (Ex. 21:11) relates to Ex. 21:8,9 not to verse 10, which immediately precedes it. See I.E. on Ex. 21:11 (Vol. 2, p. 464).
52 One cannot hire a person for more than three years.
53 Hebrew, mishneh.

54 For it describes an office. We have followed the reading of Vat. Ebr. 38. The Mikra’ot Gedolot reads: “The following is the definition of mishneh. It means double. Similarly mishneh (twice) in ve-hayah mishneh (and it shall be twice as much) (Ex. 16:5), the meaning of which is mishneh lamelekh (double unto the king). The word mishneh in the latter is a noun. However, mishneh (next) in mishneh la-melekh (next unto king) (Esth. 10:3) is an adjective.” The words “the meaning of which mishneh lamelekh (double unto the king)” appear to be a gloss. See Weiser and Krinsky.
55 Mishneh (next) in mishneh la-melekh.
56 See I.E. on Gen. 41:43 (Vol. 1, p. 382).
57 “The king is like the number one; next comes the mishneh, which means second to him” (Vol. 1, p. 382).
58 For the clause that precedes it states, he shall serve thee six years. If the slave did not go out at the start of the seventh year he would be serving seven not six years.
59 The year of release begins at the start of the seventh year. See I.E. on Ex. 23:10,11 (Vol. 2, pp. 498,499).
60 Which begins at the start of the seventh day.
61 Meaning, and he blessed you.
62 In the form of this word.
63 Here. I.E. explains why the law of the firstling follows the law of the Hebrew slave.
64 The previous section deals with the work done by a Hebrew slave. This section prohibits working with an ox that is a firstling. Thus both chapters deal with work.
65 See I.E. on Deut. 12:17.
66 After having mentioned it in Deut. 12:17.
67 In the first part of this verse.
68 This is the opinion of the rabbis of the Talmud. See Rashi on verse 20.

69 Our verse literally reads, you shall eat it, the unclean and the clean. According to I.E. this is to be read as, the unclean and the clean you shall eat it. He interprets the heh prefaced to the Hebrew words for clean and unclean as a vocative heh. Thus ha-tame (the unclean) means you who are unclean, and ha-tahor (the clean) means you who are clean. The meaning of our clause thus is, you who are unclean and you who are clean shall eat of it.
70 In other words, the laws of the pilgrimage festivals follow our chapter because it ends with a law to be observed year by year, and so are the pilgrimage festivals to be observed.
71 Another reason the laws of the pilgrimage festivals follow the laws of the first-born.
72 The place where the Israelite makes his pilgrimage three times a year. See Ex. 23:17.
73 I.E.’s interpretation contradicts Zevachim 5:8.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 16
chapter.p: 1. THE MONTH OF ABIV. It is called the month of Aviv because when the Israelites went out of the land of Egypt, the first of the barley crop (aviv)1 appeared in the fields in that month. Those who deny the Rabbinic tradition say that Passover2 is not to be observed if the first of the barley crop has not appeared.3 I have previously responded to their nonsense.4 We will also admit that the Beth Din5 took the appearance of the first barley crop into consideration.6

Note that in Hebrew the months have no names.7 Nisan (Esth. 3:7; Neh. 2:1), Sivan (Esth. 8:9), and also Kislev (Neh. 1:1), Tevet (Esth. 2:16), and Adar (Esth. 3:7), which are mentioned in Scripture, are Chaldean terms. Hence Scripture states, which is the month of Nisan (Ibid.).8 However, we find Ziv (I Kings 6:37),9 Etanim (I Kings 8:2),10 and Bul (I Kings 6:38).11

The meaning of first12 is that when you find the first barley ripe, then the first month has arrived, for one starts counting the months from it We do not care about this,13 whether the year that passed consisted of twelve months or thirteen months.14 This is the meaning of first.15 However, the ancients of blessed memory transmitted traditions regarding many other things along with the ripe barley grain.16 All of their words are true.
BY NIGHT.17 He took you from the authority of Pharaoh. They left Egypt close to night.18 I will explain it later.19
2. OF THE FLOCK. To fulfill the obligation of the paschal sacrifice.

AND THE HERD. For peace offerings.20 The fact that Scripture says, and three thousand bullocks (II Chron. 35:7), after it says, all of them for the passover-offerings, with regard to the lambs and kids (Ibid.), is proof.21 It similarly tells us that they gave (unto the Levite) for the passover-offerings five thousand small cattle, and five hundred oxen (Ibid., v. 9). Scripture thus mentions the Passover offerings before it mentions the cattle.22 It similarly states, thou and thy household (Deut. 14:26).23 Some say that Scripture commanded that a lamb or a he-goat were to be offered in Egypt.24 However, Scripture now tells us if one is able to, he may offer cattle. However, the first interpretation is correct.25
3. THOU SHALT EAT NO LEAVENED BREAD. No leaven shall be present when the paschal offering is slaughtered.
BREAD OF AFFLICTION. For a memorial.
ALL THE DAYS OF THY LIFE. Every year.
4. WHICH THOU SACRIFICEST…AT EVEN. The reference is to the flesh of the Passover offering.
6. AT EVEN, AT THE GOING DOWN OF THE SUN. I have explained this previously.26

AT THE SEASON THAT THOU CAMEST FORTH OUT OF EGYPT. The reference is to the Passover offering, as the Israelites left Egypt in the month of Aviv. It27 is not connected to at the going down of the sun.28

7. AND THOU SHALT ROAST.29 I have previously explained that u-vishalta means you shall roast in fire.30 Compare, And they roasted (va-yevashelu)31 the passover with fire (II Chron. 35:13). Scripture reads u-vishalta to indicate that the Passover offering is not to be eaten raw.32

AND THOU SHALT TURN IN THE MORNING. Those who deny the Rabbinic tradition33 say that the verse tells the Israelite to go to his house and land on the holy day.34 We will not rely on our own minds when it comes to the commandments. We will rely only on those who transmitted the Torah.35 Look, we find Scripture stating, On the eighth day36 he37 sent the people38 away (I Kings 8:66). The latter was a holy day.39 Another verse says, And on the three and twentieth day of the seventh month40 he41 sent the people42 away unto their tents (II Chron. 7:1). Some say that the meaning of unto their tents is, to their tents, which were close by.43 They went to their lands44 on the weekday.
AND GO UNTO THY TENTS. Around Jerusalem. The Israelite would then go to his land on the weekday.

8. SIX DAYS. The ancients said six days from the lifting of the sickle.45 It is possible that and on the seventh day is connected to six days.46 And on the seventh day was separated from the first half of the verse and placed in the second half of the verse because Scripture wanted to warn against doing work.47 Scripture does not say all manner of work.48 The reason for the latter is that only servile work49 is prohibited. Where Scripture does state all manner of work,50 it reads, “Save” [that which every man must eat].51

When Scripture mentions that one is obligated to offer the Passover sacrifice in the glorious place, it also mentions the second festival (v. 9)52 and the third festival (v. 13).53 It does not mention the day of shofar sounding54 and the tenth day,55 because the congregation does not gather then in the sanctuary.56
10. AFTER THE MEASURE. The samekh of missat (after the measure) receives a dagesh to compensate for the missing nun.57 Missat is related to the word nes (banner). It means the lifting of the hand.58
THE FREEWILL-OFFERING OF THY HAND. For burnt offerings and peace offerings.
12. AND THOU SHALT REMEMBER THAT THOU WAST A BONDMAN. This is connected to thy man-servant and thy maid-servant (v. 11).59
13. AFTER THAT THOU HAST GATHERED IN FROM THY THRESHING-FLOOR AND FROM THY WINEPRESS. Hence this festival is called the feast of ingathering (Ex. 34:22).60

15. SHALT THOU KEEP A FEAST. Tachog (shalt thou keep a feast) means you shall sacrifice the offering.61 The reference is to the congregation.62 On the other hand, it might refer to the individual. The Israelite is told to make burnt and peace offerings. Shall bless thee is proof of this. It means do this63 because God blessed you. Scripture adds all thine increase to explain that the object of bless thee is the produce which the earth will bring forth.
THE WORK OF THY HANDS. Trade and goods produced by craftsmen.
AND THOU SHALT BE ALTOGETHER JOYFUL. There is a commandment to be joyful on the festival of Sukkot.64 Others say that it means that God will bless you in the future and you will always be happy.65
[ALTOGETHER.] The meaning of altogether is, you shall always be happy.
16. AND THEY SHALL NOT APPEAR…EMPTY. This is what Scripture means by after the measure of the freewill-offering of thy hand (v. 10).
BEFORE THE LORD. I have already explained this.66
18. [JUDGES.] Even though each and every commandment stands by itself there is, as it were, a midrashic reason for the connection of the sections.67

The meaning of Judges…is, even though you are obligated to go three times a year to the place of the kohanim who serve in the sanctuary and there inquire regarding the statues and laws, it will not suffice. You must have judges in all of your cities.68

OFFICERS. Shoterim (officers) means rulers. It is related to shoter (ruler) in Overseer, or ruler (Prov. 6:6) and similarly mishtaro (dominion thereof) in the dominion thereof in the earth (Job 38:33).
The shofetim (judges) judge and the shoterim (officers) force the crooked [to obey the law].
IN ALL THY GATES. We find that Jehoshaphat69 acted in this manner.70
TRIBE BY TRIBE. In all the gates of each and every tribe.
AND THEY SHALL JUDGE. The reference is to the judges.
19. THOU SHALT NOT WREST JUDGMENT. Scripture speaks to each one of the judges.
THOU SHALT NOT RESPECT PERSONS. I have explained the word takkir (thou shalt respect) in my comments on Ye shall not respect (takkiru) persons in judgment (Deut. 1:17).

20. JUSTICE, JUSTICE. Moses speaks to the disputants. Moses repeats the word justice to indicate that one should pursue justice whether one gains or loses. Or the word is repeated to indicate that one should pursue justice as long as one exists;71 or the word is repeated for emphasis.
THAT THOU MAYEST LIVE. Moses speaks to those who are entering the land.
AND INHERIT THE LAND. Moses speaks to their children. It means, you72 will keep this inheritance.73

The first thing that the judge has to be concerned with is widespread pagan practices such as the one referred to in Thou shalt not plant thee an Asherah (v. 21).74 The Torah states the latter, for such is the practice of pagan worship, as Behind one in the midst (Is. 66:17)75 shows.

22. NEITHER SHALT THOU SET THEE UP A PILLAR. For an idol, as which the Lord thy God hateth proves.76 However, a pillar which is not set up for idol worship is permitted. The most convincing proof of this is found in the portion which opens with the words And Jacob sent (Gen. 32:4).77
chapter.ftnote: 1 See I.E. on Ex. 13:4 (Vol. 2, p. 259). I.E. there renders aviv as the first of the barley crop. Thus according to I.E. the month of Abiv means the month when the first of the barley crop appears in the field.
2 The offering of the paschal lamb (Meijler).
3 If the aviv did not appear, then the paschal lamb was not offered that year. They do not believe that an additional month was added to the year if the aviv had not yet arrived. (See Meijler).
4 See I.E. on Ex. 12:2 (Vol. 2, p. 203).
5 The law court which determined the onset of the new month.
6 When deciding whether to add an additional month to the year. However, they also took other things into consideration. See Talmud San. 11a,b.
7 Hence adding a thirteenth month presented no problems.
8 Esth. 3:7 reads, In the first month, which is the month of Nisan. Scripture identifies the first month by its Chaldean name because the Jews did not call the month by that name in earlier times.
9 For the second month.
10 For the seventh month.
11 For the eighth month. In other words, only the second, seventh, and eighth months had appellations. The other months were known only by number.
12 Why Scripture calls Nisan the first month. See Ex: 12:2, It shall be the first month of the year to you.
13 The declaration of the first month.

14 The arrival of Aviv determines the arrival of the first month. The number of months of the previous year is irrelevant. If the year had a set number of months their exhaustion would determine the year.
15 The point is, we start to count the months when the aviv arrives.

16 According to the Talmud the year may also be intercalated and the coming month not declared the first month because the fruit has not yet ripened and because the season of spring has not yet arrived. See San. 11:a,b.
17 The night of the fifteenth. I.E. comments thus because according to Ex. 13:4, Israel left Egypt by day.
18 They actually left in the early morning, when it was still dark. Hence Scripture refers to it as night (Weiser). See I.E. on Ex. 12:31 (Vol. 2, p. 245).
19 He didn’t in this commentary. However, he did in the Long Commentary. See Vol. 2, p. 245.
20 The paschal sacrifice could only be brought from the flock. See Ex. 12:5.

21 That And the herd refers to peace offerings, for Scripture implies that only the lambs and kids were offered as paschal sacrifices. II Chron. 35:7 states: And Josiah gave to the children of the people, of the flock, lambs and kids, all of them for the passover-offerings, unto all that were present, to the number of thirty thousand.
22 Which shows that the oxen were not for the Passover offerings, for if they were they would have been so mentioned.

23 The meaning of which is, you are obligated to eat the tithe in the place of the sanctuary. Your household may do so if they want to. However, they are not obligated to do so. We thus see that Scripture juxtaposes two things that are similar but not identical in one verse. The same is true of the flock and the herd. The former applies to the paschal offering and the latter to peace offerings.
24 In Ex. 12:5, I.E. quotes this in the name of Rabbi Moses ben Amram Ha-Parsi. The later was a Karaite Bible commentator. See Vol. 2, p. 220.
25 The first interpretation is that of the rabbis.
27 At the season that thou camest forth out of Egypt.

28 At the season that thou camest forth out of Egypt refers to thou shalt sacrifice the passover-offering, not to at the going down of the sun, which precedes At the season, etc., for the Israelites did not leave Egypt at the going down of the sun.
29 Hebrew, u-vishalta [literally, and you shall cook].
30 See I.E. on Ex. 12:9 (Vol. 2, pp. 228-231). Ex. 12:9 states, Eat not of it…sodden at all with water, but roast with fire. Hence I.E.’s comment.
31 Here too the word means roasted, not cooked.
32 The word bashel (cooked) comes from the same root as the word ripe. Thus u-vishalta can be taken to mean prepare (cook or roast) it to the point where it is fit to be eaten.
33 The Karaites.
34 On the first day of Passover, for that is the day following the night that the Passover offering is eaten.
35 According to the rabbis, and thou shalt turn in the morning refers to the morning of the sixteenth of Nissan. See Hagigah 17a,b.
36 Of Sukkot, i.e., Shemini Atzeret.
37 King Solomon.
38 Who came to celebrate the dedication of the Holy Temple.
39 For it was Shemini Atzeret.
40 That is, on Shemini Atzeret.
41 King Solomon.
42 Who came to celebrate the dedication of the Holy Temple.
43 Around Jerusalem. Thus going to their tents did not entail a violation of the festival. The same is true in our verse.
44 To their place of residence.

45 On the new crop. The reference is to the cutting of the “omer.” This took place on the second day of Passover. See Lev. 23:9-12. Scripture prohibits eating of the new crop of grain before a measure (an omer) of new grain is cut and offered on the altar. Now, the Torah commands that matzot be eaten for seven days (v. 3). This contradicts our verse which states that matzot be eaten for six days. The Talmud (Menachot 66a) explains that our verse refers to matzot baked from the new crop, which could not be eaten before the second day of Passover, while the verse that tells the Israelites to eat matzot for seven days speaks of matzot made from grain from the previous year. See Rashi.
46 In other words, our text should read, Six days thou shalt eat unleavened bread and [so too] on the seventh day. In other words, you shall eat unleavened bread for seven days.

47 On the seventh day. The point is and on the seventh day refers to both the first part of the verse and to the second. Our verse is to be understood as follows: Six days thou shalt eat unleavened bread; and [so too] on the seventh day; and on the seventh day shall be a solemn assembly …thou shalt do no work therein.
48 All manner of work is prohibited on the Sabbath and Yom Kippur. However, work necessary for the preparation of food is permitted on festivals.
49 All work except that which is necessary for the preparation of food. See Ex. 12:16.
50 With regard to a festival.
52 The second pilgrimage festival, i.e., Shavu’ot.
53 The third pilgrimage festival, i.e., Sukkot.
54 Rosh Ha-Shanah.
55 The tenth day of Tishri, i.e., Yom Kippur.
56 On these days. There is no commandment to make a pilgrimage to the sanctuary on Rosh Ha-Shanah and Yom Kippur.
57 Missat comes from the root nun, samekh, samekh.

58 Thus missat nidvat yadekha (after the measure of the freewill-offering of thy hand) means the lifting of the freewill-offering of thy hand. Scripture uses the term lifting when it deals with an offering to the sanctuary. Compare the word trumah (offering), which literally means a lifting.
59 You shall be kind to your servants, for you were a slave in the land of Egypt.
60 The festival of Sukkot is also referred to as the festival of ingathering.
61 According to I.E. the word chag not only means a holiday, it also refers to the sacrifice that is offered on the festival. See I.E. on Ex. 5:1 (Vol. 2, p. 115).
62 The injunction, you shall sacrifice the offering, is directed to the congregation, for the congregation is obligated to bring the special offerings on the festivals (the musaf offerings).
63 Sacrifice burnt and peace offerings
64 In other words, and thou shalt be…joyful refers to the festival of Sukkot
65 In other words, and thou shalt be…joyful refers not only to the festival of Sukkot, it refers to the whole year.
66 See I.E. on Ex. 23:15 (Vol. 2, p. 501). I.E. there explains that et pene Adonai means before the Lord. Et pene Adonai literally means the face of God. Hence I.E.’s comment.
67 The commandments.
68 Literally, your gates. Hence the law of judges follows the law of the three pilgrimage festivals.
69 A king of Judah.
70 See II Chron. 19:5.
71 The repetition of the word connotes continuity.
72 The children of those who inherit the land.
73 The Land of Israel.
74 Hence this law follows the one of appointing judges.
75 I.E. in Isaiah renders this as, Behind one asherah in the midst of the garden. See I.E. on Is. 66:17.
76 God hates a pillar set up to an idol.
77 There, Scripture (Gen. 35:14) relates that Jacob set up a pillar to God. Also see I.E. on Gen. 28:17, (Vol. 1, p. 279), where he writes that Scripture does not prohibit a pillar to honor God.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 17
chapter.p: 1. THOU SHALT NOT SACRIFICE UNTO THE LORD THY GOD. Look, when Moses mentions the asherah and the pillar he also mentions that it is prohibited to slaughter any blemished animal to God.1
EVEN ANY EVIL THING. Any evil thing explains any blemish.

FOR THAT IS AN ABOMINATION. Its meaning is similar to Present it2 now unto thy governor3 (Mal. 12:8). The one who offers it is punished. However, no punishment befalls one who does not sacrifice at all, unless he is obligated to bring an offering.4

2. IF THERE BE FOUND IN THE MIDST OF THEE. After Moses mentions that one is prohibited to plant an asherah near an altar which is in public view, he backtracks and warns the individual not to worship idols.5
IN TRANSGRESSING HIS COVENANT. La’avor brito (in transgressing His covenant) is the reverse of keeping His covenant.
I have previously explained grammatically the word vayishtachu (and worshipped), in the Sefer Ha-Yesod.6
3. OTHER GODS. Idols, the work of man.
OR THE SUN, OR THE MOON, OR ANY OF THE HOST OF HEAVEN. Which are the work of God.
WHICH I HAVE COMMANDED NOT. To serve them, even though they are My works.

THEN THOU SHALT INQUIRE DILIGENTLY. Hetev (diligently) means very much. Similarly hetev (greatly) in Art thou greatly angry (Jonah 4:9). It is a bit far-fetched to connect hetev to the word tov (good).7

5. AND THOU SHALT STONE THEM. The man or the woman.8 It is similar to they shall be burnt with fire, both he and they (Lev. 20:14).9 Since Scripture says, and it be told thee (v. 4) in secret,10 and thou hear it (Ibid.) in public,11 it had to explain that even though it was told to you, and you heard, they shall not be put to death except upon the testimony of two witnesses.12

6. OR THREE WITNESSES. Who accept the testimony of two witnesses.13 So says the Gaon.14 Look, the Torah does not state whether we accept the testimony of relatives or of a woman or the testimony of an enemy of the deceased.15 Some say that if two witnesses contradict two witnesses, then a third witnesses determines innocence or guilt.16 Others say two witnesses from among the wise men and three from the others.17 We are thus forced to rely on the words of tradition.18
7. THE HAND19 OF THE WITNESSES.20 The hand of each one of the witnesses.21 Similarly and the heart of the people melted22 (Josh. 7:6).23 There are many other such instances.
SO THOU SHALT PUT AWAY. I have previously explained the meaning of u-vi’arta (so thou shalt put away).

8. IF THERE ARISE A MATTER TOO HARD FOR THEE. Moses speaks to the judges. This follows the previous law because two witnesses are required in order to execute a person. The meaning of between blood and blood is, between innocent blood and guilty blood.24
The word yippale (too hard) is similar to the word hayippale (is anything too hard) (Gen. 18:14). I have explained it there.25
BETWEEN PLEA AND PLEA. With regard to money.
AND BETWEEN STROKE AND STROKE.26 Such as wounds and bruises.27
Even matters of controversy is a general term.
THEN THOU SHALT ARISE, AND GET THEE UP. I have explained this before.28
9. THE PRIESTS THE LEVITES. For, as I have explained,29 there are kohanim who are not descended from Levi.30
AND UNTO THE JUDGE. The reference is to the king who writes a copy of the Torah from the one which is in the hands of the kohanim.31
AND UNTO THE JUDGE. In the place where he is.32
11. ACCORDING TO THE LAW WHICH THEY SHALL TEACH THEE. With regard to the matter that is too hard for you.

12. EVEN THAT MAN SHALL DIE. The court shall put him to death. The reason for the latter is so that the people shall hear, and fear (v. 13). When Moses mentions the judge, he explains the laws that the judge must keep.
15. THOU SHALT IN ANY WISE SET HIM KING OVER THEE. This is optional.
WHOM THE LORD THY GOD SHALL CHOOSE. Via a prophet or via the urim (Ex. 28:30). The point of the clause is you shall not choose him.33
THOU MAYEST NOT.34 From a rational point of view.35
WHO IS NOT THY BROTHER. Who is not of the family of Israel, and also one who is an Edomite even though Scripture refers to Edomites as “your brother.”36

Now in those days horses were brought from Egypt. Scripture’s words concerning Solomon, And a chariot came up and went out of Egypt (I Kings 10:29), is proof of this. The king would thus cause Israel to sin if he wanted to multiply his horses, for he would cause the people to return to Egypt. This is clearly so:37 God took Israel out of Egypt, and by going back they would desecrate God’s name. Uriah the prophet fled to Egypt because his life was in danger.38 Also Jeremiah went to Egypt against his will.39

16. YE SHALL HENCEFORTH RETURN NO MORE. This was a commandment that was not written down.40 Some say that this law is derived from ye shall see them again no more for ever (Ex. 14:13). However, the latter has a different meaning.41
17. THAT HIS HEART TURN NOT AWAY. For he will go after his lusts.

NEITHER SHALL HE GREATLY MULTIPLY TO HIMSELF SILVER AND GOLD. So that he does not punish42 Israel. Now Israel complained about Solomon who, because of his great love of money, made silver to be in Jerusalem as stones (I Kings 10:27). They said [to his son], Thy father made our yoke grievous (I Kings 12:10). Some say that they complained because of the buildings.43 However, this is not so, for strangers built the house.44 The latter is clearly stated in Scripture.45 Look, following Solomon’s death Adinoram, who was over the levy,46 was stoned to death by the Israelites (I Kings 10:18).47
18. AND IT SHALL BE, WHEN HE SITTETH UPON THE THRONE. At the beginning of his kingship.
A COPY. The meaning of mishneh is a second rendition.48
chapter.ftnote: 1 That is, since Moses mentions that the asherah and the pillar are prohibited, he also mentions that it is prohibited to sacrifice any blemished animal to God, for these acts are an abomination to God.
2 A blemished animal.
3 As a gift. Will he accept it? No, he will reject it and despise you for insulting him.
4 Such as the Passover or sin offering.
5 In private.
6 See I.E. on Gen. 23:7 (Vol. 1, p. 230) and Ex. 18:7 (Vol. 2, p. 351).
7 If we connect hetev to the word tov (good), the meaning of our clause is, then thou shalt inquire well.
8 Who worshipped idols. And thou shalt stone them cannot refer to both of them, for Scripture speaks of a man or a woman.

9 The verse speaks of a man who takes a mother and daughter, or a daughter and mother. They shall be burnt with fire, both he and they (ethen) can’t refer to both women, for what sin did the first woman commit? It is only the second woman taken who is put to death. If he first takes the mother, then it is the daughter who is put to death. If he first takes the daughter, then it is the mother who is put to death. The meaning of ethen (they) thus is, one of them.
10 I.E.’s elaboration of the verse.
11 I.E.’s elaboration of the verse.
12 The law of witnesses follows the law of idolatry because the punishment of idolaters requires two witnesses to the act of idol worship.

13 According to the Gaon two witnesses may testify before three witnesses. The latter may then testify as to what they heard. However, two witnesses cannot testify before two other witnesses. Thus according to the Gaon our verse should be read as follows: at the mouth of two witnesses who saw the event that they are testifying to, or at the mouth of three witnesses who heard it from two witnesses, shall he that is to die be put to death. The Gaon so interpreted our verse because he wanted to avoid the question, “If two witnesses are enough to convict a person, why does Scripture go on to say or three witnesses?”
14 Rabbi Saadiah Gaon.
15 We must rely on tradition in these instances. I.E. comments thus because he will soon say that we must rely on tradition regarding the understanding of our verse.
16 Hence Scripture reads, At the mouth of two…or three witnesses shall he…be put to death.
17 Non-scholars.

18 In understanding our verse, as we must with regard to the testimony of relatives, or of a woman, or the testimony of an enemy of the deceased. According to the rabbis the meaning of At the mouth of two…or three witnesses is, just as two witnesses form one unit, so do three witnesses form one unit, and if one of the three is disqualified the entire unit is disqualified.
19 Hebrew, yad.
20 Hebrew, edim.
21 Yad is the singular. Edim is in the plural. We would thus expect yede haedim. Hence I.E.’s explanation.
22 Heart is in the singular, people is in the plural. Thus our text should have read, the hearts of the people.
23 Translated according to I.E.
24 In other words, the previous verse deals with executing a culprit. Our verse tells us what the judge is to do if he cannot determine whether the accused is guilty or not.
25 See I.E. on Gen. 18:14 (Vol. 1, p. 195).
26 Hebrew, ben nega la-nega. Literally, between plague and plague. See Rashi.
27 In other words, nega here does not have its usual meaning of plague, but rather means a wound.
28 See I.E. on Num. 16:12 (Vol. 4, p. 130).
29 See I.E.’s commentary on Gen. 14:18 (Vol. 1, p. 167) and his Short Commentary on Ex. 19:6. I.E. there notes that anyone who serves God is called a kohen.
30 The term kohen at times connotes a prince (Rashbam on Ex. 19:6). Cf. And ye shall be unto Me a kingdom of priests (Ex. 19:6).
31 See verse 18.
32 The judge is not necessarily near the sanctuary.
33 The Lord, not you, shall choose the king.
34 Hebrew, tukhal. Literally, you cannot.

35 Literally, from the true way. In other words, You cannot does not mean you are physically restrained. It means you are rationally restrained. It is irrational for you to place a non-Jew on the throne of Israel.
36 See Deut. 23:8.
37 That is, that multiplying horses would entail going down to Egypt.
38 Otherwise he would not have gone down to Egypt. See Jer. 26:21.
40 Our verse reads, As the Lord hath said unto you, Ye shall henceforth return no more [to Egypt]. The problem is that Scripture does not record such a command earlier. Hence I.E.’s comment.
41 It is a prophecy, not a command.
42 That is, oppress.
43 That is, they complained because Solomon forced them to build his buildings.
44 The temple and, by extension, all the other royal buildings.
45 See I Kings 9:20-22; II Chron. 2:16,17.
46 I.E. takes this to mean in charge of the taxes.
47 For taxing them.
48 That is, a copy.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 18
chapter.p: 1. THE PRIESTS THE LEVITES, EVEN ALL THE TRIBE OF LEVI, SHALL HAVE NO PORTION. When Scripture mentions the laws of the king,1 who is the judge,2 it makes mention of the laws of the kohanim, who are the teachers of the Torah. After Scripture states that they have no inheritance,3 it states that they will take from the sacrificer4 the shoulder, the cheeks, and the maw:5 the shoulder from the body; the cheeks, which have the tongue between them, from the head; and the maw from the insides. There is a midrashic interpretation that since the kohen slaughters the peace offerings, he receives the shoulder as payment for the use of his shoulder in the slaughtering, the cheeks as payment for reciting the blessing,6 and the maw as payment for the investigation.7 However, according to the plain meaning of the text, these8 are better than the rest of the meat.9
Scripture also mentions the laws regarding the Levites,10 for they too11 will teach the Torah in the gates. The Book of Chronicles shows this to be the case.12

8. BESIDE THAT WHICH IS HIS DUE. Some say that mimkarav (which is his due) is similar to makkarekhem13 (them that bestow it upon you)14 in from them that bestow it upon you (II Kings 12:8).15 However, they are a bit off the mark. The rules of grammar will not accede to it.16 On the contrary, mimkarav is related to timkeru mimkar (sell aught) in and if thou sell aught (Lev. 25:14).17 The meaning of le-vad mimkarav al ha-avot (beside that which is due according to the father’s house)18 is, if the kohen sold his house, which he inherited from his father as Scripture states, then the house that was sold in the city of his19 possession, shall go out20 (Lev. 25:33). The latter explains according to the fathers.21 The local kohanim shall not say to him, Look, you have money, you shall not in addition eat the sacred food with us. On the contrary, they shall eat like portions.22
After Moses concludes the laws pertaining to the judge23 and the kohen,24 he mentions the laws regarding the prophet.25
10. ONE THAT MAKETH HIS SON OR HIS DAUGHTER TO PASS THROUGH THE FIRE. This was a form of idol worship, for we have among us today many gentiles who worship the fire.26

ANYONE THAT USETH DIVINATION.27 Kosem (one that useth divination) is most probably a general term. It refers to those who issue decrees and declare things will undoubtedly be so.28 The term gazerin (magicians) is similar.29 The word kesem (divine sentence) in A divine sentence is in the lips of the king (Prov. 16:10) is close in meaning to it. The particulars30 are a soothsayer (me’onen), or an enchanter (menachesh), or a sorcerer (mechashef). It is also possible that kosem is a specific term for astrologers31 and that kesamim (divinations) refers to divination that astrologers make based on the primary and secondary stars.32
A SOOTHSAYER,33 OR AN ENCHANTER.34 I have explained these terms previously.35
OR A SORCERER.36 I have also explained this term.37
11. OR A CHARMER.38 One who calls the demons together.
OR ONE THAT CONSULTETH A GHOST OR A FAMILIAR SPIRIT. I have explained these terms before.39

OR A NECROMANCER. Such as those who go to cemeteries and take the bone of a dead person and, because of their imagination and madness, see shapes40 while they are awake41 or in a dream. All of these things42 are abominations to God. The truth is that a person must fully believe in his creator in his heart. When a person relies on his wisdom, and not on God, in seeking the truth and what will be in the future, his mind is deficient, for it is perverted. The person who wants to inquire,43 let him inquire from God via a prophet. Scripture therefore afterward reads, A prophet will the Lord…raise up…from the midst of thee (v. 15). The latter refers to Joshua. Unto him ye shall hearken (Ibid.), which is later followed by and the children of Israel hearkened unto him (Deut. 34:9), is proof of this. The fact that we do not find any other prophet but Joshua entering Canaan44 is additional proof of this.45 It is also possible that our verse lays down a general rule for each and every prophet who will arise after Moses.46
15. LIKE UNTO ME. Who is a prophet of God and not an enchanter.

19. I WILL REQUIRE IT OF HIM. His death is thus caused by God.47 What happened to the man who did not listen to the words of the prophet who said, Smite me, I pray thee (I Kings 20:35) is proof of this.48 Scripture states there that the prophet49 spoke by the word of the Lord50 (I Kings 21:35), The prophet was previously known as a prophet of God.
22. WHEN A PROPHET SPEAKETH. The prophet Jeremiah similarly says, when the word of the prophet shall come to pass (Jer. 28:9) in the time predicted by the prophet.51

After Moses finished explaining the law relating to the soothsayers and their practices, which were practiced by the idolaters of the land, he warned52 that no innocent blood be shed in the land. The reason for this is that the land shall be pure from the abomination of the soothsayers, and it should also not be defiled by the shedding of innocent blood.
chapter.ftnote: 2 Spoken of in Deut. 17:1.
3 They will not receive a portion in the land of Canaan when it is divided among the tribes.
4 Of a sacrifice. See verse 3.
5 Verse 3.
6 Before slaughtering the offering.
7 The kohen checks the innards to see if they are healthy. If they are not, the animal is declared unfit and cannot be eaten.
8 The maw, the shoulder and the cheeks.
9 In other words, the maw, the shoulder and rhe cheeks are the choicest parts of the animal.
10 Verses 6-8.
11 Like the kohanim.

12 Cf. II Chronicles 17:9: And they (the Levites) taught in Judah, having the hook of the Law of the Lord with them; and they went about throughout all the cities of Judah, and taught among the people.
13 This is the reading in II Kings 12:8 and in the Vat. Ebr. 38. The printed texts have makkarehem.
