14 Your friends or relatives. This opinion renders mimkarav (which is his due) his relatives. They read our verse as, beside that which his relatives from his fathers’ houses bestow upon him. They interpret the latter as follows: if a member of a kohen family allows another kohen to sacrifice in his place, then his colleagues cannot say to him, “Since you are offering the sacrifice in place of your relative, you shall not in addition eat the sacred food with us.” See Rashbam. It should be noted that according to the commentaries, Levite in our verse refers to a kohen from the house of Levi.
15 This is the opinion of Rashbam.
16 For makkarav comes from the root nun, kaf, resh, while mimkarav comes from the root mem, kaf, resh.
17 From the root mem, kaf, resh.
18 According to I.E., literally, beside that which he has sold according to the fathers.
19 The Levite’s. The same law applies to a kohen.
20 In the year of the jubilee. The point is that Lev. 25:33 indicates that a Levite (or kohen) may sell, in a Levitical city, the house which he received as an inheritance.
21 In other words, it means that which he (the Levite, or kohen) has inherited from his fathers.
22 Of the sacrificial meat. In other words, the kohen shall receive an equal share in the sacrificial meat.
23 In chapters 16-18.
24 In chapter 18.
25 Verses 18-22.
26 I.E. was probably alluding to the Zoroastrians.
27 Hebrew, kosem kesamim.
28 They predict the future in no uncertain terms.
29 Gazerin (Dan. 2:27) comes from gazar (to decree). Thus gazerin means those who decree.
30 Following the general term kesamim.

31 The term used by I.E. is hovere shamayim. This is a phrase found in Is. 47:13. I.E. there defines it as astrologers. I.E. believed that the study of astrology was permitted. What was prohibited was making absolute predictions using astrology. It should be noted that I.E. believed that the urim and tummim entailed the use of astrology. Therefore I.E. probably believed that certain types of astrological predictions were prohibited, while others, i.e., those sanctioned by the Torah, were permitted. See I.E. on Ex. 28:5 (Vol. 2, pp. 595-598? and the notes thereto). See also Dov. Schwartz, Astral Magic in Medieval Jewish Thought (Heb.), Bar-Ilan University, Israel, 1999, pp. 62-91.

32 The primary stars are the true stars. The secondary stars are shooting stars and the like. The latter were thought to be produced by the stars themselves. Hence they are called secondary stars. See I.E. on Gen. 1:14 (Vol. 1, p. 38). See also Motot.
33 Hebrew, me’onen.
34 Hebrew, menachesh.
35 See I.E. on Lev. 19:26.
36 Hebrew, mechashef.
37 See I.E. on Ex. 7:11 (Vol. 2, p. 148).
38 Hebrew, chover chaver.
39 See I.E. on Lev. 19:31.
40 See things.
41 Hallucinate.
42 Mentioned in verses 10,11.
43 As to what the future holds.
44 That is, leading Israel.
45 Verse 15 speaks of A prophet…like unto me. The only one who fits that description is Joshua, for we do not find any other prophet but Joshua immediately following Moses.
46 In other words, A prophet…like unto me applies not only to Moses’ successor, but to all prophets following Moses.
47 He is not executed by a human court.
48 The man who did not listen to the prophet was killed by a lion.
49 Who said, Smite me, I pray thee.
50 What he said came from God, not from the prophet’s mind. Hence the addressee was obligated to follow what he said.
51 Then shall the prophet he known (Jer. 28:9).
52 In the following chapter.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 19
chapter.p: 3. THOU SHALT PREPARE THEE THE WAY. The cities should be in a place where the way1 is prepared2 and settled.3
AND DIVIDE. Ve-shillashta (and divide) means divide the land into three, or place a city of refuge in each third of the land.
5. HIS NEIGHBOR. Et re’ehu means with his neighbor. There are many such cases.4
FETCHETH A STROKE. Ve-niddechah (fetcheth a stroke) is a nifal. Nidche (the dispersed of) in He gathereth together the dispersed of Israel (Ps. 147:2) is the kal form.
WITH THE AXE. Garzen (axe) refers to a metal instrument used to cut a tree down. It is related to the word nigzarti (I was cut off).5

AND THE HEAD SLIPPETH FROM THE HELVE. Venashal (slippeth) is similar to ve-nasa (shall set forward) (Num. 2:17).6 It is related to the word yishal (shall drop off) in for thine olives shall drop off (Deut. 28:40). The word ve-nashal (and shall cast) in and shall cast out many nations (Deut. 7:1) is transitive. However, ve-nashal (slippeth) in our verse is intransitive. According to a great grammarian the same is true of the word yasaf (more) in with a great voice, and it went on no more (Deut. 5:19) and yasaf (added) in For the Lord hath added sorrow (Jer. 45:3).7 However, I believe that they are both transitive.

6. AND SMITE HIM MORTALLY. Ve-hikkahu nefesh8 (and smite him mortally) is short for ve-hikkahu makkat nefesh (and smite him with a mortal blow). He will strike him in a place where his soul will depart.

8. AND IF THE LORD THY GOD ENLARGE THY BORDER. If Israel observes the entire Torah.9 Scripture therefore reads,10 if thou shalt keep all this commandment (v. 9), the reference being to the commandment dealing with the three cities of refuge.11
9. AND TO WALK EVER IN HIS WAYS.12 Without any break in them.13

14. THOU SHALT NOT REMOVE THY NEIGHBOUR’S LANDMARKS. The meaning of tassig (thou shalt…remove) is known.14 Its meaning is similar to the word tasseg (remove) in Remove not the ancient landmark (Prov. 22:28). It is close in meaning to destroyed.15
WHICH THEY OF OLD TIME HAVE SET. The ones who divided up the land.16

[15. ONE WITNESS SHALL NOT RISE UP.] This section17 follows,18 because destroying the boundary markers19 leads to quarrels, blows, and murder. Scripture therefore goes on to state, following this, Life for life, eye for eye, tooth for tooth (v. 21). The one who claims that his neighbor removed his landmark must bring witnesses. Hence, Scripture reads, one witness shall not rise up, which means that two witnesses are required in cases involving murder, assault, landmark removal, or any matter.20 Shene edim (two witnesses) is an abridged phrase,21 for Scripture elsewhere reads, shenayim edim (two witnesses) (Deut. 17:6).
16. TO BEAR PERVERTED WITNESS AGAINST HIM. Such as accusing him of idol worship.
18. TESTIFIED. Anah means testified. The same law applies to flogging22 and fines.23
[21. AND THINE EYE SHALL NOT PITY.] This means thine eye shall not pity the false witness.24
chapter.ftnote: 1 The way of the person fleeing to the city of refuge.
2 The city of refuge shall have prepared roads leading to it.
3 The road should run through settled areas so that it is a safe road and provisions are available for the person on the way to the city of refuge.
4 Where et has the meaning of im. See Ex. 1:1.
5 See Ps. 31:23. The reading there is nigrazti. However, I.E. believes that nigrazti and nigzarti are one and the same word, with the letters inverted. See I.E. on Ps. 31:23.
6 Both words are intransitive and are similarly vocalized.
7 Yasaf is intransitive in Deut. 5:19 and intransitive in Jer. 45:3.
8 Literally, and smite him life. Hence I.E.’s comments.
9 If Israel observes the entire Torah, God will enlarge Israel’s borders.
10 In the next verse.

11 As this is the law which this section deals with. This appears to contradict I.E.’s first statement that the reference is to all the laws of the Torah. Filwarg suggests reading “or the reference is (or, some say the reference is) to the commandment dealing with the three cities of refuge. See Nachmanides on this verse.
12 Literally, and to walk in His ways all the days.
13 With out any break in the days that you walk before the Lord.
14 From its context (Weiser).
15 I.E. renders our clause, thou shalt not destroy thy neighbor’s landmark. He renders Prov. 22:28, destroy not the ancient landmark.
16 When Israel first entered the Land of Israel. See Josh. 19:51.
17 The section dealing with witnesses (verses 15-21).
18 It follows the section dealing with the removal of boundaries.
19 Translated according to I.E.
20 It does not apply only to boundary disputes which precede it.
21 In other words, sheni is short for shenaim.
22 Where a false witness accused an innocent person of a crime for which the punishment is a flogging.
23 Where a false witness accused an innocent person of a crime for which one is punished with a fine (Weiser).

24 This is the reading in most mikra’ot gedolot editions. Vat. Ebr. 38 reads, “upon one who deserves punishment.” The Pardes edition of Scriptures reads, al sheker (for lying). However, this appears to be an error for al ed sheker (upon a false witness).

chapter.title: CHAPTER 20
chapter.p: 1. WHEN THOU GOEST FORTH TO BATTLE. This is connected to And thine eye shall not pity (Deut. 19:21), for one is not to have pity.1 However, when going forth to war you should pity2 the man who has betrothed a woman, or built a house, or planted a vineyard, or one whose heart is faint.3
2. THAT THE PRIEST SHALL APPROACH. The kohen who has been anointed for war.4
3. FEAR NOT. In your heart.
NOR BE ALARMED. And flee.
NEITHER BE YE AFFRIGHTED. In deed.5

5. DEDICATED IT. Chanakho (dedicated it) is similar to the word chanukkat (dedication of) in the dedication offer of the altar (Num. 7:10). The word chanokh (train) in Train up a child (Prov. 22:6) is similar. Our rabbis, of blessed memory, learned from the latter that we train (mekhannechin) children.

The reason that [one who has not dedicated his house is released from service] is that such a man’s heart and desire is to dedicate his house. Look, his mind will be upon his house, not on the battle. He will therefore flee and cause others to flee.
6. USED THE FRUIT THEREOF. The word chillelo (used the fruit thereof) is connected to the word challilim (flutes), for they were in the habit of dancing6 in the vineyards7 (Jud. 21:21).8

7. AND WHAT MAN IS THERE THAT HATH BETROTHED A WIFE, AND HATH NOT TAKEN HER? In marriage.9 Look, this verse is a sign that there are people who die when their time comes.10 However, the one who dies in battle dies before his time. Hence David said, or he shall go down into battle, and be swept away (I Sam. 26:10).11
8. THAT IS FEARFUL. To strike another person.
AND FAINT-HEARTED. To suffer someone’s blow.
HIS BRETHREN’S HEART. Look, the word et appears superfluous.12 However, its meaning is as I have previously explained.13 It indicates the thing itself.14
9. SHALL BE APPOINTED. U-fakedu (shall be appointed) is related to the word pekod (appoint).
10. THEN PROCLAIM PEACE UNTO IT. The meaning of ve-karata is proclaim unto it.15 This is a commandment, or it is most likely an option.16
12. AND IF IT WILL MAKE NO PEACE. The meaning of tashlim is, it will make peace.
15. WHICH ARE VERY FAR OFF FROM THEE. Who are not of the seven nations.

16. THOU SHALT SAVE ALIVE NOTHING. It is forbidden to give them food or drink. The general rule is that they were to kill them if possible. The latter applied to their days. Moses does not mention the Girgashites,17 for they were the least and the smallest among them.

19. FOR IS THE TREE OF THE FIELD MAN.18 I have previously explained in the Sefer Ha-Yesod19 that it is possible in all languages to be brief and to apply an abbreviated style, as in “an ass bread”20 (I Sam. 16:20).21 However, it is impossible to leave out the word lo (no, not),22 for in this case the meaning would be reversed.23

A great Spanish grammarian24 said that a heh25 has been omitted.26 Our clause should be interpreted as if written, hakhi adam etz ha-sadeh (for is the tree of the field man).27 Now this interpretation does not appear correct to me. Why would Scripture say that you shall not destroy fruit trees, because, unlike a human being, they cannot run away from you?28 I believe there is no need for all this.29 The following is the meaning of our clause. For thou mayest eat of them, but thou shalt not cut them down, for the tree of the field is man; that is, the life of man is supported by trees.30 Compare, For he taketh a life to pledge (Deut. 24:6), which is short for, for he taketh that which sustains man’s life to pledge.

BUT THOU SHALT NOT CUT THEM DOWN. This is connected to that it should he besieged of thee.31 Look, do not destroy a fruit tree, which is a source of sustenance for human life. Be that as it may, you are permitted to eat of it but you are prohibited from destroying it so that the city will be besieged because of you. The fact that Scripture then states thou mayest destroy and cut down,32 that thou mayest build bulwarks (v. 20), is proof of this.
20. UNTIL IT FALL. Scripture would not have said a long time (v. 19) if the city were not mighty.33
chapter.ftnote: 1 On the guilty or on the one who is obligated to go into battle.
2 And exempt from battle.
3 See verse 5.
4 The kohen appointed for this very purpose.
5 When engaged in combat.
6 When the harvest was concluded.
7 To the accompaniment of flutes.
8 According to I.E. we should render our clause, and did not play music over it; i.e., he did not harvest his vineyard.

9 Brought her into his house. There were two stages to marriage in ancient Israel, erusin (betrothal) and nesu’in (marriage). In the first stage the woman, though married, still lived in her father’s house. In the second stage she went to live with her husband. The marriage was not consummated till the second stage.

10 Thus the man who has married a woman but has not consummated the marriage is exempt from the army because his time to die has probably not yet come. He will therefore be able to consummate his marriage if he does not go forth to war.
11 The entire clause reads: or his day shall come to die; or he shall go down into battle, and be swept away.

12 The Hebrew reads, ve-lo yimmas et levav echav (lest brethren’s heart melt). The particle et usually connects an active verb with the object. However, yimmas is in the nifal; it is passive. Hence the particle et appears to be superfluous.
13 That et does not always connect an active verb with the direct object. See I.E. on Ex. 10:8 (Vol. 2, pp. 187,188).
14 It is used to emphasize the word which follows in this case lev (heart).
15 In other words, ve-karata is an imperative.
16 In this case, ve-karata is to be rendered, you may call unto her.
17 Canaanite nation. See Gen. 15:21.
18 Hebrew, ki ha-adam etz ha-sadeh. The latter literally means for man is a tree of the field. This, as I.E. goes on to say, does not make sense. Hence the interpretations which follow.
19 A Hebrew grammar composed by I.E. The book survives only in fragments.
20 Translated literally.
21 An ass bread is short for an ass laden with bread.
22 If one wants to employ an abbreviated style.

23 Onkelos renders ki ha-adam etz ha-sadeh as if written ki ha-adam lo etz ha-sadeh (for the tree of the field is not a man). In other words, Onkelos claims that the word lo has been left out of the verse. I.E. disagrees. Hence his comment.
24 I.E. does not identify the grammarian.
25 An interrogative heh.
26 From the word ki in ki ha-adam etz ha-sadeh.
27 Our verse reads, ki ha-adam etz ha-sadeh. The latter literally means for man is a tree of the field. Hence the unnamed grammarian’s interpretation.
28 This is the meaning of our verse if we render ha-khi adam etz ha-sadeh as, for is the tree of the field man.
29 To interpret ki ha-adam etz ha-sadeh as if written ha-khi adam etz ha-sadeh.
30 In other words, ki ha-adam (for man) is short for ki chayye ha-adam (for the life of man).
31 In other words, you shall not cut down the fruit trees to use their wood to build siege works.
32 The trees that do not produce fruit.
33 And required siege works to take it.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 21
chapter.p: 1. IF ONE BE FOUND SLAIN. As Scripture mentions the war against enemies,1 it goes on to say what the law is if one fights against his fellow2 and a corpse is found in the land of Israel, and the one who slew him is unknown.3
2. THY ELDERS. The elders and judges of the cities that are close to the body.
3. A HEIFER OF THE HERD, WHICH HATH NOT BEEN WROUGHT WITH. Never used for plowing.4
AND WHICH HATH NOT DRAWN IN THE YOKE. To bring stones, as is the practice with heifers.5
4. ROUGH. The word etan (rough) means mighty.
AND SHALL BREAK…THE NECK. Ve-arefu (and they shall break) means they shall remove the back of the neck of the heifer.6
5. AND THE PRIESTS THE SONS OF LEVI SHALL COME NEAR. The priests (kohanim) who are clearly of the sons of Levi.7
AND ACCORDING TO THEIR WORD SHALL…BE. The punishment for every controversy and every stroke.8
6. AND ALL THE ELDERS OF THAT CITY. The elders referred to in then thy elders…shall come forth (v. 2).

7. [SHED.] The heh in shafekhu (shed) indicates the plural.9 It is like the heh in shafekhu ashurai (my steps slipped) (Ps. 73:2).10 However, interpreting it midrashically, the heh refers to each one of the hands, for the word yad (hand) is in most cases feminine.11

NEITHER HAVE OUR EYES SEEN IT. It is possible that God commanded the city closest to the slain to perform this12 because if the city had not committed a similar deed, then the murder of a person near their city would not have occurred. God’s thoughts are deep and infinitely beyond our comprehension.13
AND THEY SHALL SPEAK AND SAY. Ve-anu ve-ameru (and they shall speak and say) is similar to ve-anita ve-amarta (and thou shalt speak and say) (Deut. 26:5). I will explain it there.14
8. FORGIVE, O LORD, THY PEOPLE. Who erred and did not guard the dangerous roads.15

SHALL BE FORGIVEN. A tav has been omitted in the word ve-nikapper16 (shall be forgiven). It is similar to the word venivasseru17 (may be taught) in that all women may be taught (Ezek. 23:48). They18 are a combination of two forms, the nifal and the hitpa’el.

Scripture mentions whom thou hast redeemed19 to indicate that as You redeemed Israel from Egypt as a manifestation of Your great mercies, similarly redeem them from this blood and the punishment for its shedding.

9. SO SHALT THOU PUT AWAY THE INNOCENT BLOOD. The meaning of the innocent blood is, the punishment for the shedding of the innocent blood.20 On the other hand, the word ha-dam ha-naki (the innocent blood) is short for ha-dam, dam ha-naki (the blood, the innocent blood).21

Some say that the meaning of so shalt thou put away the innocent blood is, you must eradicate the shedding of blood. However, in my opinion, and I have mentioned this before, it means no innocent blood will be shed in your land if you do what is right in the eyes of God. The latter is in keeping with the secret that the reward of sin is sin, and the reward of a commandment is the commandment.22

10. WHEN THOU GOEST FORTH TO BATTLE. This section is connected with When thou shalt besiege a city (Deut. 20:19).23 The section dealing with the decapitated heifer24 was inserted between them because it deals with a slain person found in the Land of Israel.25 This law does not apply outside of the Land of Israel26 and certainly not in time of war.27
11. A WOMAN. The rabbis have already explained this.28
OF GOODLY FORM. In his own eyes.29
AND THOU HAST A DESIRE UNTO HER. You will desire to take her for a wife,30 for after this Scripture states, and be her husband. So I took her to be my wife (le-ishah) (Gen. 12:19) is similar.31
12. THEN THOU SHALT BRING HER HOME TO THY HOUSE; AND SHE SHALL SHAVE HER HEAD. Some say that she shaves her head as he may have desired her because of her hair.
PARE. Ve-asetah et tzipparneha (and pare her nails) means she shall let her nails grow long so that she will appear disgusting in his eyes.
13. AND SHE SHALL PUT THE RAIMENT OF HER CAPTIVITY FROM OFF HER. For he may have desired her because of her beautiful garments.
AND BEWAIL. So that he is no longer happy with her.32
A FULL MONTH. Perhaps his desire will cool.
Others say:33
[12. SHE SHALL SHAVE HER HEAD.] Because she is unclean.34 The law regarding the leper is similar.35

AND PARE. Ve-asetah (and pare)36 means and fix. Its fixing consists in cutting off the excess.37 Compare, asah (trimmed)38 in nor trimmed his heard (II Sam. 19:25) and in And instead of curled hair (ma’aseh39 miksheh) baldness (Is. 3:24). The main meaning of the word ma’aseh (work) in Scripture is fixing,40 except for instances when something unseemly follows.41 However, even in the latter instance the reference might be to complete an evil deed.
AND SHE SHALL PUT THE RAIMENT OF HER CAPTIVITY FROM OFF HER. For it is filthy.42
AND SHALL REMAIN IN THY HOUSE, AND BE WAIL…A FULL MONTH. This means she shall remain in your house a month to cry.43

HER FATHER AND HER MOTHER. If close by.44 Some say that she bewails her father and mother because they did not convert to Judaism.45 However, I believe that reason teaches us that every person is obligated to honor his father and his mother while they live and also after their deaths. The meaning of and bewail… is, she shall mourn her parents if they were killed while she was taken captive in the same manner that an Israelite women mourns, for she is converting to Judaism.
Scripture had no need to mention that she shall bathe,46 for it is necessary for her to be purified by the waters of sprinkling,47 as Scripture earlier states, ye and your captives (Num. 31:19).48

[AND AFTER THAT THOU MAYEST GO INTO HER, AND BE HER HUSBAND.] Our rabbis, of blessed memory, said that he has to wait three months.49 Even though the words of our sages need no support50 I offer the following as proof, And it came to pass about three months after (Gen. 38:24).51 The latter is the time when the fetus begins to move. It is prohibited to have sexual relations with a women when one is in doubt as to whether she is pregnant or not, because of the uncertain paternity of the fetus; for some women give birth two months short of the normal term.52 Others give birth later than the normal term.53 However, the latter rarely occurs.54
A FULL MONTH. Yerach yamim (a full month) is similar to chodesh yamim (a whole month) (Num. 11:21).55 I have explained this previously.56 A month is called a yerach57 because the moon is its basis.
14. THEN THOU SHALT LET HER GO.58 You shall do to her as she desires.59
BUT THOU SHALT NOT SELL HER AT ALL FOR MONEY. Scripture speaks of what is widely practiced.60 Its true meaning is, do not sell her.

THOU SHALT NOT DEAL WITH HER AS WITH A SLAVE. The word titammer (deal as with a slave) is similar to the word ve-hitammer (and he deal as with a slave) in and he deal with him as a slave (Deut. 24:7). The word is not found a third time.61 The meaning of the word has to be ascertained from its context. It means deceitfully.62
15. BELOVED. In his eyes, not in the eyes of God.63
THAT WAS HATED. Seni’ah (hated) is an adjective. This section follows64 because the preceding section65 reads, and thou hast a desire unto her (v. 11)66 and…if thou have no delight in her (v. 14).67
16. IN THE DAY THAT HE CAUSETH HIS SONS TO INHERIT. When he is in good health; or on the day of his demise when he is deathly ill;68 or the law courts cause his sons to inherit.69
MAKE…FIRST-BORN. In word70 and in status.
[THAT HE MAY NOT.] Lo yukhal (that he may not) is to be understood like its counterparts.71

17. HE SHALL ACKNOWLEDGE. He shall acknowledge him by an act,72 or he shall admit before others who the firstborn is, if the first-born is in a place where he is unknown, or he is obligated right at the beginning to acknowledge which one of his sons is the first-born should they be twins.

BY GIVING HIM A DOUBLE PORTION. The first-born shall take two parts. If there are three sons let them imagine that there are four and the first-born shall take two parts. If there are two sons let them imagine that there are three, and so in all cases. In my opinion this too is the meaning of I pray thee, let a double portion of thy spirit be upon me (II Kings 2:9), as I explained in its place.73
FOR HE IS THE FIRST-FRUITS OF HIS STRENGTH. The one known as first-born. Scripture speaks of the upright.74 All of Israel are presumed to be upright.75
18. STUBBORN AND REBELLIOUS. Towards God and towards the parents if they be God-fearing.76
STUBBORN. The word soreh (stubborn) is similar to the word sorre’ah (stubborn) in like a stubborn heifer (Hos. 4:16). He does not keep the positive commandments.
AND REBELLIOUS. With regard to the negative commandments.
AND THOUGH THEY CHASTEN HIM. In the presence of witnesses. The parents are commanded to take hold of him and bring him [to the elders]. The words of tradition are true.77

[20.] HE IS A GLUTTON. The meaning of zolel (glutton) is explained.78 It refers to one who gluttonously devours meat. However, the term refers to anyone who commits himself to all that he lusts for, to all that his desires ask of him.79
AND A DRUNKARD. Sove refers to one who drinks a lot. It refers to a drunkard. This individual is essentially a heretic.80 He desires life in this world only for eating and drinking.

This portion81 was placed here because of the woman of goodly form.82 And his83 mother’s name was Shelomith84 (Lev. 24:11) and the hint which I gave with reference to the sons of Aaron85 are proof of this.
22. AND THOU HANG HIM. We have received from the rabbis, of blessed memory, traditions regarding those who are hanged.86

23. FOR HE THAT IS HANGED IS A REPROACH UNTO GOD.87 For he cursed God.88 However, according to the plain meaning of the text, God is the subject.89 The curse comes to all places close to the hanged.90 It91 has a secret connected to the soul.92 Scripture therefore goes on to say, that thou defile not thy land.93

This section follows because of the war,94 for Scripture first states, When thou goest forth to battle (Deut. 20:1). Now the incident at Gibeon95 shows that the purpose of the law which says that his body shall not remain upon the tree all night is not out of respect for the deceased but rather out of respect for the land,96 for the law of the Canaanites and the law of the Israelites differ.97
chapter.ftnote: 1 In the previous chapter.
2 And kills him.
3 In other words, the previous chapter deals with war against enemies. Our chapter deals with conflict between Israelites.

4 The heifer was not tied to a plow. The Hebrew reads lo ubbad bah (which hath not been wrought with). I.E. interprets ubbad as referring to plowing, for Scripture later uses a word from this root in the sense of ploughed. Compare, lo ye’aved bo (which may neither be plowed) (v. 4).
5 They are used for pulling wagons.
6 That is, they shall decapitate it. Oref means back of the neck. Ve-arefu literally means they shall neck it. Hence I.E.’s interpretation.
7 There are some who are called kohanim who are not descended from the tribe of Levi. See I.E. on Deut. 17:9.
8 Wound. See I.E. on Deut. 17:8.
9 A vav is usually used to indicate the third person plural perfect. In our verse a heh is used in place of the vav.
10 Here too the word shafekhu is spelled with a heh in place of a vav.

11 If we ignore the vowels, then our word reads shafekhah. Shafekhah is the third person perfect feminine. In this case our verse reads: yadenu shafekhah (our hands it has spilled). According to I.E. a combination of the plural with the singular refers to each one of the plural. See I.E. on Gen. 49:22 (Vol. 1, p. 441).
12 Ritual.
13 Hence it is very difficult to understand the details of the ritual which they must perform.
14 See I.E. on Deut. 26:5.
15 And are thus indirectly responsible for the death.
16 The word should have read ve-nitkapper.
17 The word should have read ue-nitvassseru.
18 Ve-nikapper and ve-nivasseru.
19 The question is, why add this appellation to Israel? The Bible does not usually describe Israel in this manner.

20 Our verse reads, So shalt thou put away the innocent blood (ha-dam hanaki) from the midst of thee. The question arises, “What does this clause mean?” The innocent blood has already been shed, i.e., put away. Hence I.E. points out that ha-dam ha-naki is short for onesh ha-dam ha-naki (the punishment for the innocent blood), and our verse teaches that by performing this ritual you remove from your midst the punishment for the shedding of innocent blood. See Meijler.

21 According to Meijler our verse is interpreted as if written shofekh hadam, dam ha-naki, the spiller of innocent blood. That is, if after the ritual is performed the murderer is discovered, you shall put away the shedder of blood, of innocent blood.
22 Avot 2:1. If innocent blood was shed near the city it was because the people of the city committed a similar crime. Thus the wages of sin is more sin.
23 Both deal with war.
24 Verses 1-9.
25 When one goes to war he encounters slain people. There is thus a thematic connection between the sections.
26 For verse 1 explicitly states, in the land which the Lord thy God giveth thee.
27 In the Land of Israel. Thus Scripture contrasts the law regarding finding a slain person in time of peace and finding one in time of war.
28 The rabbis tell us that the law also applies to married women. See Sifre on this verse.
29 In other words, the law applies even in cases where most people would consider the captive woman unattractive. See Sifre on this verse.

30 Our verse literally reads: and thou hast a desire unto her, and wouldest take her to thee for a woman (le-ishah). “Wouldest take her to thee for a woman” might mean that the Israelite merely wants to have sex with her. Hence I.E.’s comment that the intention is to marry her.
31 That I took her to be my woman means I took her to be my wife.
32 So that he no longer enjoys her company, for she is morose.

33 What follows is an alternate interpretation of verses 12 and 13. It may be a later insertion into the commentary by I.E., for he repeats the verse. It should be noted that a similar phenomenon appears at the end of his comments on Ex. 20:14 and in his comments on Ex. 34:6.
34 Ritually unclean.
35 The leper shaves his head when undergoing purification. See Lev. 14:8,9.
36 Literally, and do.
37 The part of the nail that is longer than usual.
38 Literally, did.
39 Literally, the work of.
40 See I.E. on Gen. 2:4 and the notes thereto (Vol. 1, p. 51).
41 Compare, la’asot ha-ra (in doing that which was evil) (Deut. 9:18).

42 Her garments are most probably soiled. This interpretation, unlike the previous one, does not believe that he removes her garments of captivity because they were the cause of her captor’s desire for her.
43 For her father and her mother.

44 If her parents were recently killed, that is, if they were killed in the war. Weiser believes that the reference is to her parents’ residence. If the place of their residence is close by, then the captive woman can ascertain the fate of her parents. Vat. Ebr. 38 reads, if he (her captor) killed them.
45 In this case she bewails her parents even they are still alive.
46 In a mikveh, a pool of water which purifies the impure. All converts have to immerse themselves in a mikveh.
47 Hebrew, me niddah. According to Rabbinic interpretation the reference is to a mikveh.
48 Shall purify yourselves in the “waters of sprinkling.”
49 Before marrying the captive woman, in order to ascertain the paternity of the child that she might be carrying. See Sifre on this verse.
50 That it takes three months before one is certain as to whether or not a woman is pregnant.
51 Three months after Tamar had intercourse with Judah her pregnancy first became evident.

52 Thus if a woman gives birth after nine months and had intercourse with one man nine months ago, and intercourse with another man seven months ago, we do not know whether she carried for nine months and the first man is the father, or she had the child prematurely and the second man is the father.

53 At 11 months it is thus possible for the captor to wait three months before taking the captive woman and for the latter to have a child 8 months later without the captor being the husband. This being the case, why did the rabbis say that the captor has to wait three months? They should have said that he should wait four months.
54 The rabbis were not concerned with what occurs rarely.
55 Both terms mean a full month.
56 The term chodesh yamim. See I.E. on Gen. 4:4 (Vol. 1, p. 81). According to I.E., chodesh yamim refers to a complete cycle of the month.
57 Yerach means a moon.
58 Hebrew, ve-shilachta le-nafshah.
59 I.E. takes the word nafshah to mean her desire. He interprets veshilachta le-nafshah as you shall allow her to do whatever she wants.
60 Most take money when they transact a sale.
61 It is found only twice in Scripture.
62 According to I.E. our clause reads, thou shalt not deal with her deceitfully, and Deut. 24:7 as, and he deal with him deceitfully.

63 Contra the Rabbinic interpretation. According to the Talmud, “hated” means hated by God, i.e., taken in a marriage which God hates, that is, in a prohibited marriage (such as a kohen marrying a divorced woman). See Yevamot 23a.
64 The section dealing with a captive woman.
65 Verses 1-14.
66 This section speaks of a woman who is beloved.
67 Our chapter speaks of a woman who is not beloved.
68 And, realizing that he is about to die, makes a will.
69 If he instructs the law court to carry out his wishes, he may not tell them to treat his younger son as a first-born.
70 To address him as his first-born or declare him to be his first-born.
71 He is prohibited from acting in this manner. See I.E. on Deut. 17:15.
72 He shall treat him as a first-born.
73 We no longer have I.E.’s commentary on Kings.
74 We can trust the father to testify honestly as to who is his first-born.
75 Hence we believe the father.
76 One does not have to follow the dictates of ungodly parents.
77 According to the Talmud the law of the rebellious son applies only to one who has parents.
78 Prov. 23:20 speaks of zolele basar.
79 Even though Prov. 23:20 speaks of being gluttonous in regard to meat.
80 The term used by I.E. is apikores.
81 The portion dealing with the rebellious son.
82 The captive woman.
83 The man who cursed God.
84 Shelomith fornicated with an Egyptian. A woman of such questionable morals gave birth to a son who cursed God.
85 Aaron married Elishva, who was a righteous woman. He therefore had righteous children.

86 Which culprits are to be hanged. Rabbi Eliezer believes that all those who are executed by stoning are then hanged for display. The sages limit this punishment only to those who are hanged for cursing God.
87 Hebrew, ki killelat Elohim taluy.

88 This intrerpretation renders ki killelat Elohim taluy as, he is hanged (taluy) for cursing God (ki killelat Elohim). When people see his body they are reminded that God was cursed. The latter is a reproach to God.
89 And he that is hanged the object.
90 I.E. renders ki killelat taluy as for God curses the hanged. He interprets this as meaning God curses those who are near a hanged person.
91 This law.

92 The area infects the soul. I.E. probably meant that the sight of a hanged person and its putrefying smell affect a person’s psyche and prevent him from concentrating on philosophical and religious studies.
93 By leaving a putrefying body exposed.
94 Dealt with in verses 10-15.

95 In the war at Gibeon Joshua captured five Canaanite kings and hanged them. He removed their bodies before nightfall. He did not do this out of respect for the deceased, for according to Canaanite practice there was nothing wrong in allowing the bodies to rot in public. Hence he did this out of respect for the land. See Josh. 10:26,27.
96 That it not be defiled.

97 The Gibeonites did not allow burial of the sons of Saul whom they hanged. Their bodies remained on the tree for months. See II Sam. 21:1-14. So Vat. Ebr. 38 and other manuscripts. Some printed editions read: for the law of the uncircumcised and the law of the Israelites are the same. According to this reading Israel did not allow non-Jews to remain hanging on the tree because the Israelites respected Canaanite practice. The Vat. Ebr. 38 version is to be preferred for many reasons.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 22
chapter.p: 1. THOU SHALT NOT SEE THY BROTHER’S OX. Even when you go out to war.1 This is midrashic.
[2.] THEN THOU SHALT BRING IT HOME.2 If you are coming back3 or you command someone; that is, you give it to an honest person for safekeeping. 4
AND HIDE THYSELF. This is connected to Thou shalt not see.5 Scripture mentions the ox and the sheep (v. 1). The ass was previously mentioned (Ex. 23:4).6 The same law applies to all beasts.
3. THOU MAYEST NOT. Lo tukhal (thou mayest not)7 is to be understood like its counterparts.8
4. FALLEN DOWN. Nofelim (fallen down) means crouching. The word nofelim is a general term.9
THOU SHALT SURELY HELP HIM TO LIFT THEM UP AGAIN. Not by yourself.10 Compare, thou shalt surely release it with him (Ex. 23:5).

5. A WOMAN SHALL NOT WEAR THAT WHICH PERTAINETH UNTO A MAN. This law was stated here because Scripture deals with going out to war. Women were created only to have children.11 If a woman joins men in going to war she will come to engage in illicit sexual relations on the way.12 The law that states neither shall a man put on a woman’s garment is similar.13 The reason for this law is as follows. If a male who does not have a full beard14 mixes with women, then he and they will have sexual relations without anyone knowing.15 This law indicates that the custom of Israel was for the garments of men to be unlike the garments of women. There was a definite difference between the garments.16 This is also the practice in most countries.
Some say that our verse speaks of unnatural intercourse.17 However, there is no need for this interpretation.18 The fact is that God abominates the one who changes the works of the Lord.19
6. IF A BIRD’S NEST CHANCE TO BE BEFORE THEE IN THE WAY. This section20 follows because Scripture earlier mentioned by the way (v. 4).21
CHANCE. The word yikkare (chance) is similar to nikro nikreti (As I happened by chance) (II Sam. 1:6). These words have the meaning of chance.22 It is close in meaning to “meet.”

[YOUNG ONES.] The alef in efrochim (young ones) is superfluous. It is like the alef of u-ve-ezro’akha (and with your arm) (Jer. 32:21).23 It is very cruel to crush a mother with her children. Hence the reason for this law. The same applies to an ox 24 or a sheep.25
7. THAT IT MAY BE WELL WITH THEE. For God will pity you and do good things for you.
AND THAT THOU MAYEST PROLONG THY DAYS. As you did not exterminate all of the nest but left its root.26
8. WHEN THOU BUILDEST A NEW HOUSE. This section27 is placed here because it deals with Israel in its land after they wage war. Scripture opens with the law dealing with a house.

A PARAPET. The meaning of ma’akeh (parapet) is known from its context. It has no neighbor.28 A grammarian connected it to the word akat (oppression of) in the oppression of the wicked29 (Ps. 55:4).30 However, he oppressed himself.31

IF ANY MAN FALL.32 Scripture speaks of the end result.33 The following are similar: The dead shall be put to death (Deut. 17:6);34 And stripped the naked of their garments (Job 22:6);35 And the children36 struggled together (Gen. 25:22). There are an innumerable number of words that are named because of the end result. We do not know if this is linguistic style or prophetic statements, as in and pursued as far as Dan37 (Gen. 14:14); unto the valley of Eshcol38 (Num. 13:23); and Therefore shall a man leave his father and his mother39 (Gen. 2:24).
After laying down the law dealing with the house, Scripture goes on to deal with the laws of seeds and plants, for after entering the land the Israelite would build a house and then plant.

9. THOU SHALT NOT SOW THY VINEYARD. The following is the meaning of pen tikdash (lest the fullness): Rabbi Menachem ben Saruk the Sephardi has already explained in his notebook that the word tikdash (fullness) is related to the word kodesh (holy).40 [The product of two seeds sown together becomes holy] because one mixes with the other.41

10. THOU SHALT NOT PLOW WITH AN OX AND AN ASS. This law is connected to the one dealing with sowing two kinds of seed. God had mercy on his creatures. An ass is not as strong as an ox. The law prohibiting the mixture of linen and wool42 follows43 because Scripture earlier mentioned the prohibition of mixing seeds. This law was previously mentioned in general terms.44 However, Scripture is specific here. It limits the prohibition to wool and linen, and not to any other kinds of material.

12. THOU SHALT MAKE TWISTED CORDS. The deniers45 say that this is a separate commandment46 pertaining to nighttime. It is similar to the fringes that are to be worn during the day. Scripture therefore reads, wherewith thou coverest thyself.47 However, the transmitters of tradition say that our verse speaks of the fringes that are to be worn during the day.48 The meaning of gedilim (twisted cords) is similar to the word gedilim (wreaths) which is employed with regard to the building of the temple. Compare, wreaths (gedilim) of chainwork (I Kings 7:17).49 The deniers connect the word gedilim to the word gedolah (large).50 We believe only in the words of our ancestors.

Scripture mentions this law a second time51 in order to add upon the four corners.52 The law mandating fringes is connected to the law prohibiting a mixture of linen and wool because the latter does not apply to fringes.

13. IF ANY MAN TAKE A WIFE. According to the deniers53 this section was connected to the law of fringes because the latter contain the phrase wherewith thou coverest thyself.54 Its true reason can be explained midrashically. The laws are placed one next to the other because first comes the house, next a garment,55 and then the mistress of the house.56
14. WANTON. The word alilot (wanton) means a cause.57
CHARGES. Whether true or false.58
VIRGINITY. The word betulim (virginity) is a plural. It never comes in the singular. The same applies to bacharut (youth), zekunim (old age), alumim (youth).
15. THE FATHER OF THE DAMSEL, AND HER MOTHER. If they are alive. Otherwise, someone appointed by the court.
19. [HE MAY NOT PUT HER AWAY ALL HIS DAYS.] The meaning of all his days is that she shall always be under his care. She shall be so until the day of his death.

21. SHALL STONE HER. Someone most likely slept with her after he betrothed her, for the one who betrothed her would not have done so unless she told him that she was a virgin. The transmitters of the law explained the matter very clearly.59

The signs of virginity are found until a fixed time, according to the nature of young ladies.60 The law dealing with a married women was connected to the law of the betrothed damsel because Scripture states, and the men of the city shall stone her.61
[22. BOTH OF THEM.] The meaning of gam62 is this one like the other one. Now Scripture goes on to further elucidate this topic.
23. IF THERE BE. When this thing shall happen.

24. THE GATE. The place where the elders of the city sit. Look, Scripture refers to the betrothed woman as his neighbor’s wife. We cannot ascertain the meaning of betrothal except through tradition.63
[26. UNTO THE DAMSEL…DO NOTHING.] She most probably did not agree64 and was unaware until he came and raped her. Hence the rapist is compared to a murderer.65
27. CRIED. She most likely cried.
28. THAT IS NOT BETROTHED. Our verse deals with rape, not with seduction.66
chapter.ftnote: 1 The law concerning a lost object was placed in the Torah portion When Thou Goest Forth to Battle to teach us that this law applies even in time of war.
2 This superscription from verse 2 was probably inadvertently misplaced by a copyist because it seems to belong after I.E.’s comment’s on verse 1.
3 If you find the lost animal on your way back from the war.
4 When you go off to war you ask someone else to bring the animal home.
5 The meaning of our verse is, thou shalt not see and hide thyself.
6 Where Scripture first mentions the law dealing with a lost animal. I.E. was disturbed by the omission of ass in verse 1. Hence his Exodus citation.
7 Literally, you will not be able.
8 It (lo tukhal), like its counterparts, is to be rendered, you are not permitted (thou mayest not). See I.E. on Deut. 17:15; 21:16.
9 It applies to all sorts of non-standing positions.

10 You do not have to do the lifting by yourself. You are obligated to help the owner lift the animal. However, this obligation does not apply in instances where the owner stands by and does not assist you.
11 Legitimate children.

12 Women who march off to war with men will have relations with them and produce illegitimate children. I.E. most probably inserted “on the way” because he wanted to explain why this law follows the previous one. It does so because both deal with something happening on the way. See I.E.’s comments on verse 6 and the notes thereto.
13 The purpose of the law is to prevent illicit sexual intercourse.
14 A full beard is not to be taken literally. It means enough facial hair to indicate that the person is a male.
15 Reading ve-en yode’a, as in Vat. Ebr. 38. A male dressing as a female has access to women. Rashi has a similar explanation.
16 Of males and females.
17 The reference is to homosexuality.
18 Our verse should be taken in accordance with its plain meaning.
19 Which cross dressing does, for one is then unable to distinguish between male and female.
20 Verses 6 and 7.
21 Both sections thus have a common theme.

22 The root of yikkare and of nikro nikreti is kof, resh, alef. This root means to call. However, this meaning would be out of place here and in II Sam. 1:6. Hence I.E. points out that our root is a variant of kof, resh, heh, which means to meet or to chance upon.
23 There is no such word in Scripture. I.E. probably has Jer. 32:21 in mind. However, the reading there is u-ve-ezro’a. I.E. probably quoted from memory.
25 Ibid. Lev. 22:28 prohibits the killing of a lamb or an ox and its mother in the same day.
26 The mother bird. God will repay you measure for measure.
27 Verses 8 and 9.
28 That is, it is not found again in Scripture.
29 The grammarian reads this as the enclosure of the wicked; i.e., the wicked surround him with trouble.
30 The roof is enclosed by the fence.
31 By offering an unacceptable interpretation. For ma’akeh comes from the root ayin, kof, heh, and akat from ayin, vav, kof.
32 Literally, for the one who falls will fall.
33 Hence Scripture refers to the person who will fall as the one who falls, even though he had not yet fallen.
34 Translated literally.
35 The naked cannot be stripped. Thus Scripture refers to those who are about to be stripped as stripped.
36 The reference is to the fetuses that Rebekah was carrying. Scripture refers to them as children because they soon would be so.

37 Scripture speaks of Abraham’s pursuit of the Mesopotamian kings who invaded Canaan. Dan, the person after whom the city of Dan was named, was not yet born. Hence the name is used prophetically. See I.E. on Gen. 14:14.
38 The Torah relates that the spies sent out by Moses came to a place called the valley of Eshcol. However, it was so named after the spies came there.
39 This was said prophetically by Adam. When Adam made the statement, there were as yet no children or fathers and mothers.
40 The word kodesh can also be taken to mean profaned. See Rashi.
41 I.E. does not explain why. He most likely believed that producing a species which God did not create was emulating God’s work. The product was thus a godlike creation and holy.
42 Shatnez.
43 In verse 10.
44 In Lev. 19:19. There, Scripture forbids the wearing of a garment from of a mixture. However, it does not say what sort of mixture is prohibited. It does so here.
45 Those who deny the Rabbinic tradition. The reference is to the Karaites.
46 It is not to be identified with a similar commandment in Num. 15:37-41 requiring the wearing of fringes, for the latter pertains to the day, whereas our verse deals with the night.
47 To indicate that it deals with fringes that are to be worn at night.
48 See Menachot 43a.
49 In other words, gedilim means twisted threads, for chain-work means twisted.
50 They saw that gedilim means large threads.
51 That is, in addition to mentioning it in Num. 15:37-41, it also mentions it here.
52 Numbers mentions corners, it does not mention four corners.
53 The Karaites.
54 They take coverest thyself (v. 12) to refer to a blanket. Scripture alludes to marriage as placing a covering over a woman. Cf. Ruth 3:9. The allusion is to sharing one blanket.
55 The reference must be to new garments, for one does not build a house if he does not have a garment to wear.
56 A wife. A person first builds a house, then buys new garments, and then marries.
57 I.E. connects alilot to the word illah (cause). He renders alilot devarim as “a cause of words.” In other words, he states the reason he wants to divorce her.
58 Some commentators interpret alilot devarim as false charges. Hence I.E.’s comment.
59 Witnesses are required to the act of adultery if the damsel is to be executed. She is not executed if she is merely found not to be a virgin.

60 Thus past a certain age the husband cannot claim that his wife was not a virgin. According to the Talmud, the virginity of a girl above the age of 12 1/2 dissipates. See Yevamot 59a, “And he (the High Priest) shall take a wife in her virginity (Lev. 21:13) excludes one who is a bogeret (a female above the age of 12 1/2) for her virginity has ended.” I.E. took this statement literally. However, other rabbis interpret this to mean that older women bleed less than those younger than 12 1/2. See Tosafot, Yevamot 59a. Also see Ketuvot 9a,b and Rashi and Tosafot comments there. Also see Maimonides, Mishneh Torah, Hilkhot Ishut 11:12,13.
61 The same penalty is exacted from a woman living in the house of her husband (v. 24).

62 The literal meaning of gam is also. The literal meaning of u-metu gam shenehem (then they shall both of them die) thus is, they shall also die both of them. The word gam seems out of place. Hence I.E. renders gam as this one like that one. The meaning of u-metu gam shenehem thus is, the two of them shall die, this one like that one.
63 According to the rabbis, betrothal is the first step in marriage. Thus a betrothed damsel is in reality a married woman although she lives in the home of her father.
64 To the sex act.
65 The rapist, like a murderer, stalks and commits an act of violence upon an unwilling victim.
66 The parallel law in Ex. 22:15,16 deals with seduction.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 23
chapter.p: 1. A MAN SHALL NOT TAKE HIS FATHER’S WIFE. The woman whom his father raped.1 This section therefore follows.2

2. HE THAT IS CRUSHED.3 Dakkah (crushed) refers to the testicles.4 The word5 does not appear again in Scripture.6 The grammarians say that it refers to the flesh,7 which is soft.8 However, this is far-fetched.
PRIVY PARTS. Shofkhah (privy parts) refers to the organ from which urine and semen pour.

INTO THE ASSEMBLY OF THE LORD. It means that they shall not be considered as part of God’s assembly with regard to taking a daughter of Israel. Similarly, an Ammonite male to the exclusion of an Ammonite female, and a Moabite male to the exclusion of a Moabite female.9 Ruth is the true witness to the latter.10 The verse that says neither shall they come among you (I Kings 11:2)11 speaks of the women of the seven nations.12 Furthermore, the verse in the Book of Ezra13 which states, that they separated from Israel all the alien mixture (Neh. 13:3),14 refers to the males. I have explained it there.15

Our rabbis, of blessed memory, said that a mamzer (bastard) is a child that results from a sexual act which is deemed an uncovering of the nakedness.16 The two mems of mamzer are superfluous.17 They are like the mems in mamgurot (barns) in the barns are broken down (Joel 1:17). Others say that mamzer is the name of a people. Compare, And a mamzer shall dwell in Ashdod (Zech. 9:6), for it is far-fetched for Israel to be given a shameful name.18 It is even more unlikely for this to happen in the time of the salvation.19 The Aramaic translator of the Bible was brief and midrashic.20
6. BUT THE LORD THY GOD TURNED. For Balaam intended to curse. However, God did not permit him to do so.

10. WHEN THOU GOEST FORTH IN CAMP. The reference is to a camp which goes out to fight the enemy accompanied by the ark. Scripture speaks of a small camp. The Torah does not speak of the great camp,21 for this camp had built partitions.22 When Israel went to war they were close to and around the ark. It is clear that a person who is unclean because of a nocturnal event23 destroys his seed.24

This section follows because of the Midianite war, for Scripture mentioned the topic of Balaam.25 The Midianites assailed Israel because of the affair of their sister.26 The ark was with the camp that went out to fight the Midianites.27
FROM EVERY EVIL THING. Spiritually28 or physically, such as ejaculations.29
11. CHANCETH. The mem of mi-kereh (chanceth) is a preposition.30 Mi-kereh follows the paradigm of mi-sedeh (part of the field) in part of the field of his possession (Lev. 27:16).

12. WHEN EVENING COMETH ON. Li-fenot erev (when evening cometh) is similar in meaning to ki fanah ha-yom (for the day declineth) (Jer. 6:4).31 This also strengthens the opinion of the rabbis of blessed memory.32 The deniers33 say that li-fenot (cometh on) means before.34 They say nothing of value. Some say35 that the meaning of li-fenot erev (when evening cometh) is, when the evening begins to come.36 Now, after Scripture employs the phrase li-fenot erev, it says, and when the sun is down. Li-fenot erev thus means before the evening.37 Li-fenot boker (when the morning appeared) is similarly before sunrise.38

13. A PLACE. The word yad means a place.39 Compare, yad ha-yarden (by the side of the Jordan) (Num. 13:29). This too is proof [that Scripture speaks of a small camp],40 for none of the following had to leave the camp of Israel:41 one who experienced an ejaculation, one who had to tend to his bodily needs, and certainly no children. Proof of this is the verse which states, that they put out of the camp every leper, and every one that hath an issue, and whosoever is unclean by the dead (Num. 5:2),42 which refers to uncleanliness that is passed on43 and not to one who is unclean for a day.44
14. [THY WEAPONS.] The alef of azenekha (thy weapons) is superfluous.45 Azenekha is related to the word zonot (weapons) in and the weapons washed (I Kings 22:38).46
AND COVER THAT WHICH COMETH FROM THEE. For all disgusting things which are visible to the eye give birth to a defect in the soul.47
15. NO UNSEEMLY THING. In deed or speech.48
AND TURN AWAY FROM THEE. Its meaning is that God will not go before you, for the latter49 is clearly stated.50
16. THOU SHALT NOT DELIVER…A BONDMAN. It is possible that when Israel goes to war, a non-Israelite bondman escapes into their camp.51

FROM HIS MASTER. The master too is not an Israelite. The bondman came for the glory of God, whose name is called over Israel.52 If the Israelite turns the slave over to his master this will entail the desecration of God’s name.53 Scripture therefore reads, thou shalt not wrong him.

18 [THERE SHALL BE NO HARLOT] The law of the kedeshah (harlot) follows because the previous section deals with a bondman.54 The transmitters of tradition say that the term kadesh (sodomite) refers to the one who is slept with.55 The phrase of the sons of Israel is proof of this.56 Elihu said, [Their soul perisheth in youth] And their life as that of the depraved (kedeshim) (Job 36:14); their soul corresponds to their life and kedeshim corresponds to in youth.57 Scripture also states, And there were also sodomites (kadesh) in the land (I Kings 14:24); the house of the sodomites (kedeshim) II Kings 23:7). Scripture there continues, where the women58 wove coverings (Ibid.).

I do not understand the meaning of the word kedeshah. (harlot). When we investigate carefully the meaning of the word we find that it refers to a woman who is known to be prepared to offer herself to all who come and go. Where is the harlot (kedeshah) (Gen. 38:21) is proof of this. If this is so,59 then the term kadesh refers to an Egyptian-like practice.60 The intelligent will understand.61 The law dealing with a harlot’s hire follows because our section deals with a harlot.

19. HIRE. The word etnan (hire) is similar to mattan (gift).62 The alef63 is superfluous and the nun64 is doubled65 like the peh of na’afufehah66 (her adulteries) (Hos. 2:4) and like the resh of the word sagrir (rainy) (Prov. 27:15). Etnan refers to what the harlot took, that which those who turn to her give her. [The hire of a harlot shall not be brought to the house of God] because it was given for a prohibited act.
OR THE PRICE OF A DOG. For it is a disrespectful act.67 Scripture therefore goes on to say, for…these are an abomination.

20. THOU SHALT NOT LEND UPON INTEREST TO THY BROTHER. This law is mentioned here because Scripture earlier mentions the non-Jewish bondman (v. 17). Scripture states that even though it is prohibited to wrong the latter,68 it is permitted to take interest from him.

THOU SHALT NOT LEND UPON INTEREST TO THY BROTHER. There is a difference between tishokh (you shall take interest)69 and tashikh (Thou shalt lend upon interest).70 The meaning of lo tashikh (Thou shalt not lend upon interest) is, you shall not accept interest from your brother when he offers it;71 your brother also violates the law regarding interest.72 Notice, tashikh is a word governing two acts.73 Many say that tashikh is similar to tishokh.74 There is no difference between them. There are many such verbs in Scripture.75
22. WHEN THOU SHALT VOW A VOW. This law follows because Scripture mentioned for any vow when it spoke of the hire of a harlot (v. 19).
FOR THE LORD THY GOD WILL SURELY REQUIRE IT. This is a metaphoric statement. God will act like a person.76 He will demand what you vowed.
AND IT WILL BE SIN IN THEE. Chet (sin) means punishment.77
24. THAT WHICH IS GONE OUT OF THY LIPS. Regarding anything where God’s name is mentioned.78
FREELY.79 For every vow offering80 is a free-will offering.81 However, not every free-will offering is a vow offering.82 The aforementioned is clear.83
WHICH THOU HAST PROMISED WITH THY MOUTH. After the vow has come out of your mouth you cannot take it back.

25. WHEN THOU COMEST INTO THY NEIGHBOR’S VINEYARD. To harvest grapes84 then you are permitted to eat of them. This section follows to indicate that you are obligated to set aside from your own when taking a vow, but you must not take to yourself that which belongs to another.85
IN THY VESSEL. The word kelyekha (thy vessel) is similar to the word edyekha (thy ornaments) (Ex. 33:5).86
26. WHEN THOU COMEST INTO THY NEIGHBOR’S STANDING CORN. To harvest.87
THEN THOU MAYEST PLUCK. The word ve-katafta (then thou mayest pluck) is similar to the word ha-kotefim (they pluck) in They pluck salt-wort (Job 30:4).
EARS. The meaning of melilot (ears) is known from its context.
A SICKLE. Chermesh (sickle) is a quadriliteral.88 The deniers89 say that this law applies to those who pass by the field,90 for Scripture says, thou shalt not move a sickle.91
chapter.ftnote: 1 This is the opinion of Rabbi Judah in the Talmud. However, the halakhah is not in keeping with this ruling. See Yevamot 97a.
2 For the previous section deals with rape.
3 Hebrew, petzu’a dakkah.
4 I.E. renders petzu’a dakkah as one who is wounded (petzu’a) in the testicles (dakkah).
5 Dakkah.

6 With the meaning of testicle. We have followed the reading of Vat. Ebr. 38, which says, betzim belo chaver. The Mikra’ot Gedolot edition of I.E. reads: betzim belo ever (testicles without a penis). This reading appears wrong in view of the fact that Scripture goes on to say that one missing a penis shall not enter the congregation of God.
7 The flesh of the testicles, literally their flesh.
8 The word dakkah (testicles) means soft. The grammarians explain that the testicles are referred to by the term dakkah because the flesh of the testicles is soft.
9 Similarly when Scripture states that an Ammonite and a Moabite may not enter the congregation of the Lord (v. 4), it means that they are not permitted to marry an Israelite woman.

10 That the law prohibiting a Moabite from coming into the congregation of the Lord is limited to males, for Ruth was a Moabitess and she was permitted to marry an Israelite. The same rule would apply to the Ammonites, for the prohibition of marriage between Ammonites or Moabites and Israelites is stated in the verse.

11 The verse speaks of the women whom Solomon took. Scripture mentions Moabites, Ammonites, Zidonians, and the Hittites (I Kings 11:2). Prima facie, Ammonite and Moabite women fall under Scripture’s marriage ban.
12 The seven Canaanite nations. In other words, neither shall they come among you refers to the Zidonians and Hittites, who were Canaanites, and not to the Moabites and the Ammonites.
13 I.E. refers to both Ezra and Nehemiah as the Book of Ezra.
14 The verse speaks of Ammonites and Moabites. See Neh. 13:2.
15 Our editions of I.E.’s comments on Nehemiah do not have this explanation.
16 A sexual act involving people who cannot marry each other, e.g., as in incest or adultery.
17 For mamzer is a variant of zar, (a stranger). A mamzer is a child born to people who must remain strangers to each other with regard to sexual relations.
18 Mamzer.

19 Zechariah speaks of the messianic era. If mamzer refers to Israel then the prophet is saying that the bastards (Israel) shall dwell in Ashdod when the messiah comes. Therefore what the prophet says is that in the messianic era a nation called mamzer will dwell in Ashdod.

20 Targum Jonathan to Zech. 9:6 renders And a mamzer shall dwell in Ashdod, and the children of Israel shall dwell in Ashdod where they were strangers. Thus the Targum renders mamzer in Zechariah as strangers. Vat. Ebr. 38 says, the Aramaic translator of the Bible interpreted it midrashically. The latter reading appears correct, for the Targum elaborates on the text.
21 The camp which comprised the entire Israelite nation.
22 Which separated the ark and the people. The reference is to the tabernacle where the ark was placed.
23 That is, he had a seminal emission. Hence he had to leave the camp.
24 Any emission of seed renders a person unclean. See Lev. 15:16-18.
25 In verses 5 and 6. In other words, this section follows because it is connected to the Midianite war which came about because of Balaam.

26 Their sister Cozbi slept with Zimri, a prince of the tribe of Simeon. I.E. does not refer only to Cozbi. He is referring to all of the Midianite women who enticed Israel to worship idols. See Num. 25:18; 31:15-18.
27 See Num. 31:6.
28 Evil thoughts.
29 Or other acts which defile the body.
30 Placed before the noun kareh (chance). Mi-kereh means from a chance. Mi-kerah laylah (that which chanceth him by night) thus means from a chance of the night

31 The verse continues, For the shadows of the evening are stretched out. In other words, li-fenot erev means when the day declines, when the shadows of evening come. According to Krinsky and others the reference is to the afternoon when the sun begins its decline. Filwarg believes the reference is to about an hour and a third before the onset of night. See I.E. on Gen. 1:18 (Vol. 1, p. 40). “Know that evening begins at sunset and lasts for one and a third hours, during which time a light-like appearance is seen before sunrise.” Also see Rashi: “He should immerse himself close before the setting of the sun” (Rosenbaun and Silberman translation).
32 That a person who experiences a seminal emission immerses himself before sunset.
33 The Karaites.
34 According to the Karaites, erev refers to night. They interpret li-fenot erev as before night comes, i.e., after sunset.
35 This too is a Karaite opinion (Meijler).
36 That is, when night begins, for they believe that evening is identical with night.
37 Before the sun sets, that is, close to sunset.
38 Close to sunrise.
39 Yad literally means a hand. Hence I.E.’s comment.
40 A camp going to war. See I.E. on verse 10.
41 Whereas they would have to leave a small camp.
42 Otherwise Scripture would have mentioned, in Num. 5:2, the one who is unclean by virtue of a seminal emission.
43 To another person by the one who is unclean.
44 Who does not render unclean a person whom he touches.
45 Zayin is a weapon. Azenekha is a variant of zaynekha.
46 Translated according to I.E.
47 Looking upon something that is disgusting has a negative effect on the soul.
48 Lewd talk.
49 That God goes before Israel.
50 See Deut. 31:8: And the Lord, He it is that doth go before thee.
51 Hence the reason for codifying the law of the escaped slave at this point.
52 I.E. believes that the escaped slave took refuge with Jews because he wanted to serve the God of Israel.
53 For the escaped slave wants to serve the God of Israel.
54 Slaves were considered to be promiscuous.
55 The one who takes the passive position in male homosexual intercourse.

56 That the reference is to the passive partner in male homosexuality, for the term “of” implies passivity. Otherwise Scripture would have used the term “among” (Krinsky, Meijler). I.E.’s point is that “of” means belonging to. Hence within the context of our verse it alludes to the docile sex partner.
57 I.E. renders this like youth; that is, their soul perishes like the souls of young men who are sodomites.
58 I.E. takes this reference to be to prostitutes (Krinsky).
59 If the term kedeshah refers to a female engaged in heterosexual intercourse, then so must the term kadesh, for kadesh is the masculine form of the noun.

60 I.E. believed that the ancient Egyptians were weak, and when they reached the age of forty they did not have the strength to deflower a virgin. They therefore had to turn to an individual who had the ability to do so on their behalf. This individual was called a kadesh. See I. E. on Haggai 2:12.
61 What I.E. is alluding to.
62 Both come from the root nun, tav, nun.
63 Of etnan.
64 Of etnan.
65 For there is only one nun in its root.
66 Which comes from the root nun, alef, peh.
67 Dogs were considered lowly creatures. See I Sam. 24:15. To give the money that one acquired by selling a dog to God’s house was thus considered an insult.
68 The foreign bondman who has found refuge in Israel.
69 Which is a kal.
70 Which is a hifil.
71 The meaning of lo tashikh is you shall not cause interest to be given.
72 When he gives it.
73 It is a hifil and refers to both you and your brother. You shall not cause your brother to give you interest, and your brother shall not give you interest.
74 In other words, even though tashikh is a hifil, it has the meaning of a kal. It means you shall not take interest.
75 Verbs in the hifil with the meaning of the kal.
76 Who demands what was promised to him.
77 “In Hebrew…and the harsh punishment which comes as a result of iniquity is occasionally referred to as sin” [I.E. on Gen. 4:11 (Vol. 1, p. 84)].
78 Any sort of oath wherein God’s name is mentioned.
79 Hebrew, nedavah. The reference is to an offering which is freely given.
80 Hebrew, neder.

81 Hence our verse refers to that which is given by vow as a nedavah (freely). According to I.E. comments on Lev. 7:15 a neder refers to a vow made in a time of stress, a nedavah refers to an offering brought whenever the spirit moves a person to do so. For the talmudic point of view see Megillah 1:6.
82 One may set aside an offering without making a vow to do so.
83 See I.E on Lev. 7:16.
84 As a laborer.
85 And then donate it to God (Weiser).
86 It is similarly vocalized.
87 As a laborer.
88 Its root is chet, resh, mem, shin. Most Hebrew words are triliteral. Hence I.E.’s comment.
89 Those who deny the Rabbinic tradition, the Karaites.
90 That one may pluck ears of corn even if he is not employed by the owner of the field.
91 If the individual spoken of in our verse was a laborer, Scripture would not say, thou shalt not lift up a sickle unto thy neighbor’s standing corn, for this is the very task of a farm laborer.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 24
chapter.p: 1. WHEN A MAN TAKETH A WIFE. She is also considered fit.1
FAVOR IN HIS EYES. For her nature is the reverse of his.2
AND HE HATH FOUND.3 And he cannot reveal it,4 for he has no witnesses.5 The meaning of and he hath found is, or he hath found, as in And he that smiteth his father, or his mother (Ex. 21:15).
2. AND SHE DEPARTETH. She will not return there.6 It is public knowledge that she left his house permanently.
AND BECOMETH. She becomes another man’s wife.
[ANOTHER.] The words acher (another) and acharon (latter) (v. 3) are adjectives.
3. OF DIVORCEMENT. A bill of divorce is called a sefer keritut7 because their marriage has been severed forever.

[4.] AFTER THAT SHE IS DEFILED. With regard to the first husband. Its meaning is defiled to him because another man knew her. The tet of huttamma’ah (she is defiled) receives a dagesh to compensate for the missing tav of the hitpa’el.8 Similarly the word hukkabbes (is washed) in after that the plague is washed (Lev. 13:55).9
AND THOU SHALT NOT CAUSE THE LAND TO SIN. This is a command to Israel.

5. A NEW WIFE. Some say a virgin.10 According to many its meaning is new to him,11 for it is possible for a man to remarry the woman whom he has divorced if she has not been defiled. Scripture therefore reads a new wife.
HE SHALL BE FREE FOR HIS HOUSE. The yoke of the king shall not be upon him.12
FREE. Naki (free) is similar to naki (innocent)13 in him that is innocent (Job 22:30).
[WITH ANY BUSINESS.] The lamed placed before le-khol davar (with any business) is superfluous.14 It is like the lamed in le-avshalom (Absalom) in the third, Absalom (I Chron. 3:2).15

6. NO MAN SHALL TAKE THE MILL OR THE UPPER MILLSTONE TO PLEDGE. The deniers16 say that this section is connected to and shall cheer his wife whom he hath taken (v. 5),17 for our verse alludes to coitus, namely, that it is forbidden to abstain from sexual intercourse. However, this is sheer nonsense. They offer as proof, Then let my wife grind unto another (Job 31:10). I have previously explained the latter.18 The truth is that our verse is to be taken at face value,19 that a person is prohibited from taking a mill to pledge. The word chovel (one who takes a pledge) is missing from our verse.20 It is similar to and he said to Joseph (Gen. 48:1) and to whom she bore to Levi (Num. 26:29), for the meaning of the former is, someone said to Joseph, and of the latter, the one who bore, bore to Levi.21 There are many such cases.22
THE MILL. The word rechayim (mill) is in the dual form. It does not come in the singular.

THE UPPER MILLSTONE. Rechev (upper millstone) refers to a water mill. Others say that it refers to the wood which is placed on the mill.23 Still others say that the rechayim (mill) refers to the lower millstone and rechev to the upper millstone.
FOR HE TAKETH A MAN’S LIFE TO PLEDGE. For life is sustained by these instruments.

Those who rely on the juxtaposition of the sections have no argument,24 for each commandment stands by itself.25 The explanation of their juxtapositions is midrashic.26 This section27 is connected to the previous ones in the following way:28 the Torah mentions that one is not to steal grapes by putting them in his pots (Deut. 23:25), or to lift up a sickle upon his neighbor’s grain (Deut. 23:26); or to take a woman after she has been his and then left his house and married another (v. 1). It also states that one has to cheer the woman whom he marries (v. 5); he is not to be oppressed by going into the army (Ibid.). The taking of a millstone in pledge is a form of oppression.29 So too is kidnapping a person. Similarly the plague of leprosy, for if he does not observe its laws then the plague will injure those in proximity to it.30 Scripture similarly states, do not oppress a poor person by taking a pledge from him (v. 10). It similarly states do not oppress a hired person (v. 14) and small children should not be put to death for the sins of the fathers (v. 16). It likewise warns against perverting the justice due a stranger or the fatherless (v. 17). It prohibits the taking of a widow’s garment as a pledge (v. 17). It prohibits one from retrieving a sheaf which was forgotten in the field, for it belongs to the poor (v. 19). Similarly Thou shalt not glean (v. 21). Likewise lest if he should exceed…Then thy brother should be dishonored (Deut. 25:3).31 The muzzling of an ox (v. 4) is an act of oppression, for the animal toils but cannot eat of its toil. Similarly, refusing to perform levirate marriage (Deut. 25:5-10) is a form of oppression. The woman who grabs a man’s testicles (Deut. 25:11) commits an act of oppression. Employing diverse weights and diverse measures (Deut. 25:13,14) is oppression in its purest form. Furthermore, Amalek oppressed Israel (Deut. 25:17-19).32
7. ANY OF HIS BRETHREN. Scripture adds of the children of Israel because the Edomites are called brothers.33
AND HE DEAL WITH HIM AS A SLAVE. The word vehitammer (and he deal with him as a slave) is to be explained as its counterpart.34
8. THE PRIESTS THE LEVITES. The kohanim who are members of the tribe of Levi.35
9. UNTO MIRIAM. Here is proof of the midrashic statement that we should not read the word metzora as metzora (a leper) but as an acronym for motzi shem ra (one who invents libel).36
10. DOST LEND. The word tasheh (thou…dost lend) comes from the root nun, shin, heh.
The heh of the word me’umah (any manner of loan) is superfluous.37 It is like the heh of laylah (night).38
TO FETCH. To take his pledge.39

13. AND IT SHALL BE RIGHTEOUSNESS40 UNTO THEE. You shall weigh your neighbor in the righteous scales41 which you possess42 so that he sleeps with his pledge.43 According to the transmitters of tradition there are places wherein there is a difference between the word tzedek (righteousness) and tzedakah (righteousness).44
[THE PLEDGE.] I have previously explained the meaning of the pledge45 in the Torah portion Now These Are the Ordinances (Ex 21:1) in my comments on “his garment” (Ex. 22:26).46
15. IN THE SAME DAY THOU SHALT GIVE HIM HIS HIRE, NEITHER SHALL THE SUN GO DOWN UPON IT. A negative commandment follows the positive commandment for emphasis.
UPON IT. His wages
SETTETH HIS HEART. To sustain himself from it. He therefore hired himself out.

16. [THE FATHERS SHALL NOT BE PUT TO DEATH.] Those whose spirits wander ask: “How could Scripture say: The fathers shall not he put to death…when it says in another place, visiting the iniquity of the fathers upon the children (Ex. 20:5; Deut. 5:9)?” Their question is nonsense, for the fathers shall not he put to death for the children is a commandment directed to Israel.47 However, God is the one who metes out punishment in visiting the iniquity of the fathers upon the children. I have earlier explained this in its place.48

18. BUT THOU SHALT REMEMBER. Scripture mentioned the stranger49 for this reason,50 namely, that you do not pervert the justice due him. Moses previously mentioned some of the laws to the fathers.51 He also repeated them to the children.52
19. THAT THE LORD…MAY BLESS THEE. For you gave53 what you thought was yours54 but God will give you what is truthfully His.55

20. WHEN THOU BEATEST. Tachbot (thou beatist) is similar to chovet (beating) in beating out wheat (Jud. 6:11). It is in the pa’al.56 The word yechavet (is beaten) in But the black cummin is beaten (Is. 28:27) is a nifal. All letters whose first root letter is an alef, chet, heh, ayin, or resh are vocalized like yechavet when conjugated in the nifal. The following are examples of each one of the aforementioned: ye’atzer57 (treasured) and yechasen58 (laid up) in it shall not be treasured nor laid up (Is. 23:18); yehareg59 (killed) as in ve-lo yehareg (and will not be killed); ye’aved60 (plowed) in neither be plowed (Deut. 21:4); yera’eh61 (appear) in and they shall not appear (Deut,. 16:16), for this is the rule.62

20. THOU SHALT NOT GO OVER THE BOUGHS AGAIN. Lo tefa’er (Thou shalt not go over the boughs) means you shall not seek after its “glory,” that is, after its branches. Compare, pore’ot (sprigs) in And shot forth sprigs (Ezek. 17:6). It too63 is spelled with an alef even though it is read as if written with a vav.64 Compare, nodot65 (wineskins) in and wineskins, worn (Josh. 9:4).
22. AND THOU SHALT REMEMBER. This66 is connected to for the stranger (v. 21).67
chapter.ftnote: 1 Hebrew, kesherah. However, she is disliked by her husband. I.E. takes issue with Beth Shamai, which interprets some unseemly thing as a sexual transgression. See Mishnah, Gitten 9:10. Other editions read, she is also considered as a field (ke-sadeh). A woman, like a field, is acquired by a money transaction. See Kedushin 2a. Hence the law regarding a woman follows that of the field. Filwarg believes that I.E. compares a woman to a field in that both are seeded and produce fruit.
2 The reason that she did not find favor in her husband’s eyes was not due to a moral imperfection.

3 Hebrew, u-matza. I.E.’s reading is And he had found. The problem is that the verse reads ki matza (because he has found). Weiser suggests that u-matza is I.E.’s paraphrase of ki matza. However, I.E. goes on to prove that the vav prefixed to a word sometimes has the meaning of “or.” It is a bit farfetched to say that I.E. intends to say that ki matza should be interpreted as u-matza, and that u-matza should be interpreted as or has found, because a vav sometimes has the meaning of or. It thus appears either that I.E.’s copy of Deuteronomy had u-matza or that I.E. quoted from memory and committed an egregious error.
4 The moral imperfection found in her.
5 To the immoral act that he accuses her of.
6 To his house.
7 Literally, a book of severance.
8 Which should have followed the heh.
9 It too is a hitpa’el with the tav of the form omitted. The latter is compensated by placing a dagesh in the caf.
10 In other words, new means a woman who was never married.
11 Even a widow or divorcee.
12 He shall not be conscripted into doing any of the king’s service.
13 That is, free from guilt.
14 Le-khol davar should be read kol davar. Le-khol davar literally means to any business. Khol davar means any business.

15 Hebrew, ha-shelishi le-avshalom. Literally, the third, to Absalom. However, the context does not permit this interpretation. Hence the lamed of le-avshalom is superfluous, and le-avshalom is to be read as if written avshalom.
16 The Karaites.

17 The reference is to the Karaite Bible commentator Levi ben Yefet. According to Levi ben Yefet the meaning of our clause is that a man (the upper millstone) or a woman (the mill) shall not abstain from sexual relations with each other. The Hebrew word for take to pledge is lo yachavol. This can be rendered, he shall not harm (Krinsky). Thus the meaning of our verse is, one shall not harm his partner by refraining from taking the upper position (the upper millstone) or the lower position (the mill).
18 That intercourse is metaphorically described by the term “grinding.” See I.E. on Job 31:10.
19 Despite the fact that “grind” is used as a metaphor for sexual intercourse in Job.

20 Our verse reads, lo yachavol rechayim va-rechev. This literally means he shall not take the mill or the upper millstone to pledge. The question is: To whom does “he” refer? Hence I.E. points out that the word chovel (anyone that takes a pledge) has been omitted. Our verse should be read as if written, lo yachavol chovel rechayim va-rechev (any one that takes a pledge shall not take the mill or the upper millstone to pledge).
22 Where Scripture omits the subject.
23 The reference is probably to a wooden handle which was used to turn the upper stone.
