24 That our verse speaks metaphorically of sexual intercourse.
25 The commandments are not necessarily tied together. Each commandment is an independent unit.
26 It therefore cannot be used as a reason to interpret a law metaphorically when the plain meaning of the text is acceptable.
27 The law regarding taking a mill to pledge.
28 That is, if we want to connect this section midrashically to what comes before, we can so in the following manner.
29 Hence the positioning of our law.
30 By infecting them.
31 Deut. 25:3 prohibits the infliction of more that 40 stripes to one being punished by lashes. Exceeding this number of stripes is a form of oppression.
32 Thus the laws in Deut. 23:25-25:19 are thematically related. Hence the law prohibiting the taking of a mill was included in this section.
33 In other words, brethren in our verse applies only to an Israelite. Edom is referred to as Israel’s brother in verse 34.
34 Titammer (deal with…as a slave) in Deut. 21:14. I.E. there explains it to mean treacherously.
35 See I.E. on Deut. 10:7,8; 17:9, and the notes thereto.

36 See Tanchumah on the Torah portion Metzora 2. According to the rabbis, leprosy is a punishment for speaking ill of one’s neighbor. Miriam was punished with leprosy for speaking ill of Moses (see Num. 12). According to I.E., Scripture’s telling us that we are to recall Miriam’s punishment is another way of saying, remember the punishment for speaking ill of your neighbor.
37 The basic word is me’um. Compare, Job 31:7; Dan. 1:4.
38 The basic word is layil. Compare, Is. 16:3. See I.E. on Gen. 1:5 (Vol. 1, p. 33).

39 The verse reads, la’avot avoto. I.E. notes that the verb la’avot means to take a pledge. In other words, Scripture uses a verb which is derived from a noun. Compare, tadshe ha-aretz deshe (let the earth put forth grass) (Gen. 1:11).
40 Hebrew, tzedakah.
41 Righteous scales is I.E.’s metaphor for one’s sense of acting righteously and mercifully.
42 In other words, and it shall be righteousness unto thee means and you shall act righteously.
43 That is, you permit him to sleep in his garment.

44 According to the rabbis, tzedek means righteousness and tzedakah charity. In other words, tzedek is a general term, while tzedakah is a particular term, as in “collectors of charity (tzedakah)” (Sabbath 118b) and “deeds of love are worth more than almsgiving” (tzedakah) (Sukkah 49b).
45 The reason for returning the pledge at night.

46 See I.E. on Ex. 22:6 (Vol. 2, p. 490): “Saadiah Gaon asks, what reason is there to take the pledge during the day and to return it at night? He answers, because the lender fears that the borrower might secure an additional loan from someone else and give him the pledge as security for the loan.”
47 A law court is prohibited from punishing children for the sins of their father.
49 In verse 17.
50 Mentioned in our verse, i.e., that you were a slave in Egypt.
51 The fathers of those to whom Moses now spoke, namely, those who left Egypt.
52 See I.E. on Deut. 1:5.
53 To the stranger, the orphan, and the widow.
54 The sheaf forgotten in the field.
55 His blessings.
56 That is, a kal.
57 From the root alef, tzdai, resh.
58 From the root chet, samekh, nun.
59 From the root heh, resh, gimel.
60 From the root ayin, bet, dalet.
61 From the root resh, alef, heh.
62 The letter prefixed to all words whose first root letter is an alef, chet, heh, ayin, or resh is vocalized with a tzere rather than with a chirik, which is the usual vocalization.
63 Like tefa’er.
64 The alef is pronounced like a cholam.
65 The alef in nodot is pronounced like a cholam.
66 Verse.
67 Its theme is pertinent to the law regarding the stranger. It has nothing to do with the widow or orphan.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 25
chapter.p: 1. AND…JUDGE THEM. U-shefatum1 is to be rendered, and the judges judge them. Our verse is similar to No man shall take the mill or the upper millstone to pledge (Deut. 24:6).2

2. DESERVE TO BE BEATEN. The word bin (deserve) is vocalized with a chirik.3 Compare, bin nun (son of Nun) (Josh. 1:1) and bin yakeh (son of Jakeh) (Prov. 30:1). Bin hakkot (deserve to be beaten) is similar to ben bliyya’al (a base fellow) (I Sam. 25:17).4 Bin laylah (in a night) in which came up in a night (Jonah 4:10) is similar. The judge is obligated to beat him.5 I believe that Scripture calls the culprit wicked6 because he struck his neighbor.
THAT THE JUDGE SHALL CAUSE HIM TO LIE DOWN. By command.7 The same applies to and to be beaten, as before his8 face proves.

ACCORDING TO THE MEASURE OF HIS WICKEDNESS, BY NUMBER. Of blows. It would have appeared to us, were it not for the words of tradition,9 that there are some sins that a person is punished for with ten blows. Others are punished with twenty blows. Other sins are punished with a lesser or greater number. The clause according to the measure of his wickedness is proof of this. In any case,10 the blows shall not exceed forty. However, the words of tradition alone are true.11 Others say that his wickedness12 refers to greater or lesser blows,13 all of which number forty.14

[3. THEN THY BROTHER SHOULD BE DISHONORED.] For the thing15 is well known. It is a decree from the Almighty that the sufferer suffer forty blows. This is a decree from heaven so that the number of blows not depend on the will of the judge.
4. [WHEN HE TREADETH.] The deniers16 say that the bet in be-disho (when he treadeth down) indicates prior to treading.17 However, this is unnecessary.18

5. IF BRETHREN19 DWELL TOGETHER. The deniers also say that these brethren20 are not actual brothers,21 but are relatives. They brought proof from Boaz.22 However, they contribute nothing, for there is no mention of levirate marriage,23 only of redemption.24 Why mention the word together?25 Does it matter if they were in one state or in one courtyard, or if they loved each other?26 They say,27 look, the verse says ve-yibbemah (and shall perform the duty of a husband’s brother unto her).28 This shows that he is her brother-in-law in name only.29 It is like thy sister-in-law (yevimtekh)30 is gone back (Ruth 1:15). Now observe that they have become foolish and stupid, for Scripture states, with regard to the sons of Judah, and perform the duty of a husband’s brother (ve-yabbem) unto her31 (Gen. 38:8).32 Now he33 was her34 brother-in-law.35 Also, the term yevimtekh (thy sister-in-law) (Ruth 1:15) was used because they were married to two brothers.36

All intelligent people know that the negative commandments given to Moses37 were not previously prohibited.38 However, it would not have been evil in the eyes of God if someone abstained from them39 before the law was given to Moses.40 The fact that Scripture states, for all these abominations have the men of the land done, that were before you (Lev. 18:27), shows that this is certainly the case. We do not find a prophet who warned them.41 Look, Scripture says of Onan, who did not give seed to his brother, the thing which he did was evil in the sight of God (Gen. 38:10).42 We will therefore rely on the tradition that they are actual brothers.
AND HAVE NO CHILD. For if the deceased has a son, there is no need for him43 to take his brother’s wife, for she is forbidden to him.
The word yachdav (together) is to be understood in accordance with the explanation of the transmitters of tradition.44
ONE NOT OF HIS KIN. This explains the term ha-chutzah (abroad).45 This law applies only if the brother-in-law intends to marry her.46
6. THE FIRST-BORN THAT SHE BEARETH. Will be called by the name of his47 brother.
THAT HIS NAME BE NOT BLOTTED OUT. Scripture speaks of his inheritance.48 I have previously explained the meaning of that she beareth in my comments on unto a foreign people (Ex. 21:8).49
7. MY HUSBAND’S BROTHER. The yod of yevami (my husband’s brother) is in fact the sign of the object.50
8. AND IF HE STAND, AND SAY. Until the elders hear.51
9. AND LOOSE. Ve-chaletzah (and loose) is similar to chaletzu (draw out) in draw out the breast (Lam. 3:4). Its meaning is to remove.

IN HIS FACE. The transmitters of tradition explain that the word be-fanav (in his face) has the meaning of before his face.52 According to its plain meaning, be-fanav means before the shoe, for panav here is similar to panim (in front) in front and on the back53 (Ezek. 2:9).54
11. WHEN MEN STRIVE. The reverse of If brethren dwell together (v. 5).55 The men spoken of are strangers or brothers.

BY THE SECRETS. Mevushav (the secrets) means his testicles. It is related to the word bushah (shame).56 It is an act of audacity to uncover that which is hidden, namely, a person’s nakedness. It is also a vital organ.57
12. THEN THOU SHALT CUT OFF HER HAND. If she does not pay ransom money. Its meaning is similar to eye for eye (Ex. 21:24).58
THINE EYE SHALL HAVE NO PITY. If she be poor.59

13. IN THY BAG.60 Where you place the scales.61 Or, do not deceitfully take the weights from the bag.62 The first interpretation is correct. The proof text is, Let us all have one hag (kis)63 (Prov. 1:14), the meaning of which is, one scale.64 The word kis (bag) is related to the word tachossu (ye shall make your count)65 in ye shall make your count for the lamb (Ex. 12:4) even though tachossu comes from a different root.66 Many explained the word kis to mean a pouch.67 There is no need for this interpretation.
15. PERFECT. No part shall be missing.68
[JUST MEASURE.] A just measure means a measure which conforms to the market measure.69

THAT THY DAYS MAY BE LONG. For it is well known that all righteous kingdoms will endure, for righteousness is like a building. However, unrighteousness70 is like a ruin. Its wall collapses in a moment

16. FOR ALL THAT DO SUCH THINGS. Those who possess diverse measures and diverse weights. This is followed by a general rule, namely, even all that do unrighteously verbally and by deed, secretly or publicly.
18. HOW HE MET THEE. Karekha (met thee) is related to the word korot (befallen) in all that had befallen them (Gen. 42:29).

AND SMOTE THE HINDMOST OF THEE. Va-yezanev bekhah (and smote the hindmost of thee) means,71 and cut off your tail (zanav), namely, all that were enfeebled in thy rear,72 that is, those who did not have the strength to walk. It is possible that the word necheshalim (enfeebled)73 is similar to nechelashim (enfeebled).74 Similarly keves (lamb) and kesev (lamb).75
WHEN THOU WAS FAINT. For Amalek came to Rephidim where the people thirsted for water. The latter is clearly stated.76
AND WEARY. From the way.

AND HE FEARED NOT. This refers to Amalek. Yare (feared) is a verb in the perfect.77 It is like the word kaved (heavy) in for the thing is too heavy for thee (Ex. 18:8); zaken (old) in that when Isaac was old (Gen. 27:1), and ahev (loveth) in such as he loveth (Ibid., 8).78

19. WHEN THE LORD THY GOD HATH GIVEN THEE REST. It means that this commandment takes effect after Israel inherits the land and the land is quiet from all the wars with the surrounding nations, for as long as they are involved in waging war with the nations close to them they are not obligated to fight Amalek.

THAT THOU SHALT BLOT OUT THE REMEMBRANCE. Namely, slay both man and woman, infant and suckling, ox and sheep, camel and ass (I Sam 15:3), so that no one says this ox is from the spoil taken from Amalek. The words of the Torah79 are a general statement. The words of the prophet Samuel80 go into detail.
THOU SHALT NOT FORGET. Scripture says this after having already stated Remember…(v. 17) for emphasis. The same is true with many other commandments in the Torah.81
chapter.ftnote: 1 U-shefatum literally means and they will judge them. The subject is omitted. Our verse literally reads, if there be a controversy between men and they go unto judgment, and they judge them (u-shefatum). Hence I.E. explains that “and they judge them” is short for: and the judges judge them.
2 Here too the subject is omitted, for the verse literally reads, He shall not take the mill to pledge. See I.E. on Deut. 24:6 and the notes thereto.
3 It is usually vocalized with a segol, i.e., ben.
4 The word ben usually means son of. However, in bin hakkot and ben bliyya’al, ben signifies that the subject belongs to a certain group.
5 Bin hakkot means that the wicked falls into the category of those whom the judge is obligated to have beaten.
6 Hebrew, rasha.
7 The judge shall ask officers of the court to place him in a prone position.
8 The judge’s.
9 Which tells us that whenever the punishment of flogging is administered, thirty-nine (39) lashes are inflicted.
10 Regardless of the sin committed.
11 That all those who are punished by flogging receive 39 lashes.
12 That is, according to the measure of his wickedness.
13 It refers to the intensity of the blows.
14 In other words, all those who are punished by flogging receive 40 lashes. However, their intensity varies according to the type of sin committed.
15 That this particular individual is flogged.
16 The Karaites.
17 The deniers render be-disho, before he treads. The muzzle is not put on the animal while he treads. It is put on the animal before the treading begins. Hence their interpretation.
18 For the meaning of Scripture is, do not put a muzzle on the animal so that it is muzzled while it treads the grain.
19 Hebrew, achim (brothers).
20 The brothers spoken of in our verse.
21 For Scripture explicitly prohibits a man from marrying his sister-inlaw. See Lev. 18:6.
22 Boaz married Ruth, who was the wife of his deceased relative, to raise up the name of the dead upon his inheritance (Ruth 4:5).
23 In the Book of Ruth.
24 Boaz married Ruth so that her husband’s field would not pass into the hands of a stranger. He thus “redeemed” the said field. See Ruth 4:1-6.
25 In our verse.

26 According to the Rabbinic tradition the word brethren means brothers and together means alive at the same time. However, if we accept the Karaitic interpretation then we do not know what Scripture means by the word together.
27 So Vat. Ebr. 38. Mikra’ot Gedolot reads: He says.
28 The word yavam means a brother-in-law.

29 The Karaites interpret ve-yibbemah as, and be a brother-in-law to her. Now if the true brother-in-law was being addressed Scripture would not say, and be a brother-in-law to her. Hence we must interpret ve-yibbemah as meaning “act as a brother-in-law to her.” The upshot of all this is that a true brother-in-law is not being addressed.

30 Yevimtekh is the word yevamah (sister-in-law) plus the second person personal pronoun. Orpah was the wife of Ruth’s brother-in-law (yavam). She is referred to as a yevamah because she took her husband’s place. We thus see that the term yavam in its various forms can refer to one who acts like one’s brother-in-law.
31 Tamar, the widow of Er the son of Judah.
32 Judah told his son Onan to go and perform the duty of a husband’s brother unto your sister-in-law Tamar.
33 Onan the brother of Er.
34 Tamar’s.
35 It is thus clear that levirate marriage was performed by the actual brother-in-law.
36 In other words, the term yevamah was not employed figuratively in Ruth.
37 Excluding the Noahide laws, which were given to Adam and Noah (see Meijler).
38 There was thus no prohibition before the revelation at Sinai against a man to marrying his sister-in-law.
39 That is, from those negative commandments from which reason tells us to abstain.

40 In other words, God would have been pleased with a person who abstained from practices which He would later prohibit. If the law prohibiting intercourse with a sister-in-law was based on reason, i.e., it was an abomination, then Scripture would not have condemned Onan for not wanting to impregnate his sister-in-law.

41 From engaging in the practices that Lev. 18:27 refers to, for Scripture believes that one ought to know not to engage in these practices by employing one’s rationality. See Yesod Mora 5: “The fundamental commandments are those precepts that are implanted in the heart. They…were known by reason before the Torah was given through the agency of Moses” (Strickman translation, p. 75).
42 God thus wants a brother to marry the childless widow of his biological brother.
43 The living brother.
44 According to the rabbis, “together” means that they were alive at the same time. See Yevamot 17b.
45 In other words, abroad (ha-chutzah) means to one not of his kin.
46 If her brother-in-law does not want to marry her, she is free to marry anyone else after the ceremony of chalitzah has been performed.
47 Deceased.

48 The property of the dead brother will be given to the first son born of the levirate marriage. The name of the deceased will thus be tied to his property, for people will say, “This is the property of the deceased, which his ‘son’ (actually his nephew) inherited.”

49 According to the rabbis, And it shall be, that the first-born that she beareth…refers to the deceased’s first-born brother (Yevamot 24a). See Rashi on this verse, “It is the eldest brother who is to perform the duty of levirate marriage.” I.E. in his short commentary on Ex. 21:8 states that this interpretation is not in keeping with the plain meaning of the verse.

50 In other words, the word yevami is not the noun yavam (brother-in-law) plus the yod suffix meaning “my” but a combination of the verb yabem plus the yod suffix meaning me. According to this interpretation yevami means to act as a brother-in-law to me.
51 In a voice audible to the elders.
52 Yevamot 106b.
53 Translated according to I.E
54 According to this interpretation befanav means before it, i.e., before the shoe.
55 There is thus a thematic connection between this law and the one that precedes it. Hence its juxtaposition.
56 Its root is bet, vav, shin. The literal meaning of mevushav is, his shameful things. Hence I.E.’s interpretation that mevushav (the secrets) means his testicles.
57 Literally, a dangerous place. Hence the severe punishment.
58 See I.E. on Ex. 21:24 (Vol. 2, p. 477), “It is fitting for the culprit to give his eye in place of the victim’s eye if he does not pay ransom for it.”
59 And cannot afford to ransom her eye.
60 Hebrew, be-khisekha.
61 Kis (bag) is the name of a receptacle where the scales are kept.
62 False weights. In this case the reference is not to the bag where the scales are kept but to a separate bag where the weights are kept.
63 Translated according to I.E.
64 The meaning of Let us all have one bag (Prov. 1:14) is, let us all have one scale, for let us all have one bag makes no sense in this context.
65 According to I.E. tachossu means you shall apportion. A person uses scales to measure the weight of portions. See I.E. on Ex. 12:4 (Vol. 2, p. 219).
66 Than kis. Kis comes from the root caf, vav, samekh. Tachossu comes from the root caf, samekh, samekh.
67 Hebrew, cheret (a cloth into which an object is placed). In this case kis refers not only to a receptacle for scales but to any bag or purse.
68 No part of the weight or measure shall be missing; i.e., the weight or measure will be accurate.
69 In other words, a just measure means a measure which conforms to a commonly accepted standard.
70 The perversion of justice.
71 The word zanav means a tail. Thus va-yezanev means and he tailed you. Hence I.E.’s comments.
72 In other words, va-yezanev means and he cut off all those in your rear.
73 The root of which is chet, shin, lamed.
74 The root of which is chet, lamed, shin.
75 These words come from one basic root. However, the letters of the root are inverted, giving us two different words.
76 See Ex. 17:1, And…the children of Israel…encamped in Rephidim; and there was no water for the people to drink.
77 Words in the third person past are usually vocalized kamatz, pattach in the kal. However, yare is vocalized kamatz, tzere. Hence I.E.’s comment.
78 All of these words are vocalized kamatz, tzere in the third person perfect.
79 The clause, thou shalt blot out the name of Amalek, is a general statement.
80 But slay both man and woman, infant and suckling, ox and sheep, camel and ass.
81 Scripture repeats itself for emphasis.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 26
chapter.p: 1. AND IT SHALL BE, WHEN THOU ART COME. Since Scripture wrote, Therefore it shall be, when the Lord thy God hath given thee rest (Deut. 25:19),1 God now says that there are commandments that must be observed before He gives you rest. In fact, these commandments take effect as soon as you enter the land. They are: the first fruits,2 the tithes,3 writing the Torah on the stones,4 building the altar,5 and the blessing and the curse on the two mountains.6

2. IN A BASKET. Tene (basket) is a basket-like receptacle. The word tanakha (thy basket) (Deut 28:5) is its companion.7 This commandment8 is incumbent upon those who are close to the place of the sanctuary.
3. [THAT SHALL BE IN THOSE DAYS.] In those days means that this law is in force as long as there is a kohen gadol there.9
I PROFESS. The reason for this utterance is so that the children will hear. Or it is, like a statement of thanks to God, for He has fulfilled his oath. The fruit10 is proof of this.11

5. AND THOU SHALT SPEAK. It is possible that the kohanim will ask,12 “What is this that you brought?” Hence Scripture reads ve-anita13 (and thou shalt speak). On the other hand, ve-anita may mean, and you shall begin speaking. Compare, And Job spoke (va-ya’an)14 and said (Job 3:2).15

A WANDERING ARAMEAN. The word oved (wandering) is an intransitive verb. If Aramean referred to Laban16 then Scripture should have read mavid or me’abbed.17 Furthermore, what reason would Scripture have had for stating, Laban sought to destroy my father and he18 went down to Egypt? Laban did not cause Jacob to descend to Egypt. It thus appears to me that the term Aramean refers to Jacob. Scripture, as it were, reads, when my father was in Aram he was “perishing.” That is, he was poor, he had no money. Similarly oved (perish) in Give strong drink unto him that is ready to perish (Prov. 31:6). Let him drink, and forget his poverty (Prov. 31:7) is proof.19 The meaning of our phrase thus is, a perishing Aramean was my father. Its import is, I did not inherit the land from my father, for my father was poor when he came to Aram.20 He was also a stranger in Egypt. He was few in number.21 He then became a large nation.22 You O Lord took us out of slavery and gave us a good land. Let the one who disputes23 not argue, “How could Jacob be called an Aramean?”24 Look, we find the same with Ithra the Ishmaelite25 who, as Scripture clearly states,26 was an Israelite.27

FEW IN NUMBER.28 The word mete (men of) is in the construct,29 for it is not found in the singular.30 The word metim is a plural. Rabbi Jonah the grammarian explained it very well under the entry mem, tav, heh.
7. OUR AFFLICTION. In lacking wealth.
OUR TOIL. In building.31
OUR OPPRESSION.32 As in [And the taskmasters] were urgent, saying: Fulfill your work (Ex. 5:13).
11. [THOU, AND THE LEVITE, AND THE STRANGER.] This means you are obligated to cheer them up with the fruit of your land.
12. OF TITHING. La-ser (of tithing) is a hifil.33 It has no neighbor.34
WHICH IS THE YEAR OF TITHING. The reference is to the poor tithe.35
UNTO THE LEVITE, TO THE STRANGER, TO THE FATHERLESS. To any one of them that you wish.36
13. I HAVE PUT AWAY THE HALLOWED THINGS. The reference is to the tithe. I have also not deposited it.37 On the contrary, I have handed it over to the one I am obligated to give it to.
I HAVE NOT TRANSGRESSED. Deliberately.
NEITHER HAVE I FORGOTTEN THEM.38 I did not forget to take the tithes from my house. Or its meaning is, I did not forget to give the two tithes.39

14. I HAVE NOT EATEN THEREOF IN MY MOURNING. The word oni (my mourning) is similar to the word oni (sorrow) in ben-oni (the son of my sorrow) (Gen. 35:18) and onim (mourners) in bread of mourners (Hosea 9:4). I alluded40 to its meaning41 in Hebrew.42 The meaning of oni is, my mourning. If I was in mourning then I did not eat of it before setting aside the tithe.43
NEITHER HAVE I PUT AWAY THEREOF. This means neither did I destroy any of that which was holy.44
BEING UNCLEAN. Be-tame (being unclean) means for something unclean.45
FOR THE DEAD. For the need of the dead. Others say the reference is to idol worship.46

These things47 are enumerated48 because it is prohibited to use the grain for any purpose before giving of the tithe which is holy.49 If he gives from the remainder he is acting disrespectfully.50 This is certainly so if he exchanges it for something unclean. As I kept myself and I kept the grain, that is, I removed that which is holy from my house, so may our God watch over our country.51 This is the meaning of and the land (v. 15).
15. [A LAND FLOWING WITH MILK AND HONEY.] It means a land that will always flow with milk and honey.52
16. THIS DAY. These are the words of Moses.53
THOU SHALT THEREFORE OBSERVE. In your heart.
AND DO THEM. In the land.

17. THOU HAST AVOUCHED. He’emarta (avouched) means exalted. It is close in meaning to amir (uppermost bough) in In the top of the uppermost bough (Is. 17:6). Rabbi Yehudah Ha-Levi, who rests in Eden, says that the word is related to va-yomer (said). Its meaning is, you were so righteous that the Lord said He is your God. God likewise acted very righteously towards you that you said that you would be His own treasure. He explained well. Now the word he’emarta is a hifil.54
19. AND TO MAKE THEE HIGH. This is the reward for extolling God.
chapter.ftnote: 1 Then you shall go to war against Amalek and destroy him.
2 Verses 2-11.
3 Verses 12-15.
6 Mount Grezim and Mount Ebal (Deut. 27:11-26).
7 The other place the word is found in Scripture.

8 Placing the first fruits in baskets. See Mishnah Bikkurim 3:4, “When they reached the Temple mount even King Agrippa would take his basket on his shoulder” (Krinsky). Or, bringing fresh fruits (Weiser). See Mishnah Bikkurim 3:3, “They that were near to Jerusalem brought fresh figs and grapes, and they that were far off brought dried figs and raisins.”
9 In the sanctuary.
10 Which I bring.
11 That God had fulfilled his oath.
12 The celebrant.
13 Literally, and you shall answer. Hence I.E.’s comment.
14 Va-ya’an and ve-anita come from the same root.
15 In this case we do not have to assume that the kohanim asked the worshipper, “What is this that you brought?”
16 According to the midrash, arami oved avi (a wandering Aramean was my father) is to be rendered an Aramean (Laban) sought to destroy my father (Jacob). See Sifre, the Passover Haggadah, and Rashi.
17 For these are the transitive forms of the verb.
18 My father.
19 That “perish” in the previous verse refers to poverty.
20 When he fled from his brother Esau.
21 When he came down to Egypt.
22 In Egypt.
23 Against I.E.’s interpretation of arami oved avi.
24 Jacob was a Hebrew.
25 See Chron. 2:17.
26 In II Sam. 17:25.
27 Scripture refers to him as an Ishmaelite because he lived in the land of the Ismaelites. So too Jacob, who was called an Aramean because he lived there.
28 Hebrew, mete me’at. Literally, with men of few, i.e., few men.
29 With the word am. However, the word am has been omitted from our text. Our verse should be read as if written, mete am me’at (Krinsky).
30 Hence the form mete cannot be in the construct with me’at, which is a singular. If mete was in the construct with me’at then our text would read, mete me’atim.
31 The Egyptian store cities.
32 Hebrew, lachatzenu. Literally, our pressure, i.e., the pressure placed on us. Hence I.E. ‘s comment.
33 Even though it does not have a heh in it. Its normal spelling would be leha’aser.
34 In the hifil.
35 Given every third year, for Scripture goes on to mention the stranger an d the fatherless.
36 These were usually in need of charity.
37 With another person.
38 The Hebrew reads, neither have I forgotten. Hence I.E.’s interpretation.
39 The tithe given to the Levites (the first tithe) and the tithe given to the poor.
40 It is not clear where.
41 The reference is probably to bread of mourners.
42 This line is not found in Vat. Ebr. 38. Some emend our verse to read, “in my book on the Hebrew language (Moznayim).” See Weiser.

43 Reading lo akhalti kodem ha-ma’aser. Some editions read lo akhalti kodesh ha-ma’aser, I did not eat the holy, the tithe. The latter is forbidden to a mourner in the time between the death and burial of a close relative.
44 I did not destroy any of the tithe.
45 For the bet of be-tame means for (Filwarg).
46 Offerings to idols are called sacrifices to the dead (Ps. 106:28), for idols have no more life than a corpse. See I.E. and Metzudat on Ps. 106:28.
47 Mentioned in our verse, i.e., not eating of the tithe in a state of mourning, bartering it or exchanging it for something that is unclean.
48 By the celebrant.
49 In other words, it is prohibited to use the grain for any purpose before separating the tithe from it and giving it to the one who is to receive it.
50 If he first uses the grain and then gives the tithe from what remains.
51 I.E.’s explanation of verse 15.

52 As Thou didst swear unto our fathers, a land flowing with milk and honey is to be interpreted as Thou didst swear unto our fathers a land always (reading tamid as in Vat. Ebr. 38) flowing with milk and honey.
53 Up to now Scripture reports the declaration of the one who brought the first fruits. What now follows are Moses’ words to the people of Israel.
54 Meaning you caused [Him] to say. According to Rabbi Yehudah Ha-Levi our verse reads: Thou hast caused the Lord to declare this day to be thy God…

chapter.title: CHAPTER 27
chapter.p: 1. AND MOSES…COMMANDED. By the dictate of God.
AND THE ELDERS OF ISRAEL. He1 said this to lighten his load.2 There are many such instances.3 I have previously noted them.4

KEEP ALL THE COMMANDMENTS. Namely, that thou shalt set thee up great stones to contain the entire Torah. The Gaon,5 of blessed memory, said that the commandments6 were listed upon the stones, as in the Halakhot Gedolot.7 They were listed in a manner similar to the azharot.8 He explained well.
2. [WITH PLASTER] Plaster was employed so that it9 would last.10

3. THAT THOU MAYEST. For God will aid you11 if you begin to observe His commandments. This first precept upon entering the Land of Israel, namely, the command to build a new altar, was to give thanks to God for their starting to inherit the land.
8. VERY PLAINLY. The reference is to the writing.
9. AND MOSES AND THE PRIESTS THE LEVITES. This is in keeping with Scripture’s statement, and the elders of Israel (v. 1).12 Moses was the main one.13
KEEP SILENCE. The meaning of the word hasket (keep silence) can only be known from its context, for it has no neighbor.14
THIS DAY THOU ART BECOME A PEOPLE. For God will make a covenant with you.
10. THOU SHALT THEREFORE HEARKEN. Today, to His voice.
AND DO HIS COMMANDMENTS. In the future.

Scripture mentions the priests and the Levites (v. 9), for they are the ones who said, Cursed be the man (v. 15). The children of the main wives15 stood over the blessings,16 while the children of the handmaids17 stood over the curse.18 Now if the latter lacked two,19 the sons of Leah were numerous,20 and her oldest21 and youngest22 were taken.23

14. AND THE LEVITES SHALL SPEAK. Ve-anu (shall speak) is similar to ve-anita (and thou shalt speak) in And thou shalt speak and say (Deut. 26:5).24 Our rabbis, of blessed memory, said that the meaning of to bless25 is to say, blessed is the man who does not make a graven or molten image, and similarly all of them.26 However, according to the plain meaning of the text, the blessing refers to Blessed shalt thou be in the city (Deut. 28:3).27 The curse is the reverse of this.28 Proof of this is found in the Book of Joshua.29

Scripture mentions these eleven sins30 because an individual can commit them in secret. And setteth it up in secret (v. 15) is proof, for if one commits this crime31 in the open he is put to death.32 He that smiteth his neighbor in secret (v. 24) is similar.
Scripture begins with the most important, namely, that which concerns a person and his creator.33 It then speaks of a person and his parents,34 for who knows if he dishonors them.35
16. DISHONORETH. The word makleh (dishonoreth) means to dishonor. It is a transitive verb.
17. CURSED BE HE THAT REMOVETH HIS NEIGHBOR’S LANDMARK. For it is done in secret.
[MAKETH THE BLIND TO GO ASTRAY.] Likewise it is not possible for the blind person to identify the one who led him astray.

19. CURSED BE HE THAT PERVERTETH THE JUSTICE DUE TO THE STRANGER, FATHERLESS. For they have no one to help them. Look, this too is done in secret.36 Scripture mentions the stranger as well as the orphan and the widow because if the judge perverts the justice due others, they will accuse and publicize him. The stranger, the orphan, and the widow are powerless. Sleeping with one’s father’s wife, with a sister, or with a mother-in-law is an act that is committed in secret, for one is not suspected when he is alone with any one of them. It is not so with other sins.37

21. CURSED BE HE THAT LIETH WITH ANY MANNER OF BEAST.38 Male or female, for neither have a mouth with which to cry out and protest. Thus, a female animal is like a male animal;39 therefore Scripture does not mention the male.
25. HE THAT TAKETH A BRIBE. According to many the reference is to the judge. According to my opinion the reference is to a false witness.

26. THAT CONFIRMETH NOT. Some say that the reference is to the entire Torah. Others say that it refers to the specifically mentioned sins.40 However, what they say is meaningless, for Scripture says, to do them.41 However, it appears to me that Scripture cursed the violators of the precepts which are mentioned.42 It also cursed the one who secretly does not observe the positive commandments. Scripture therefore reads, to do them.
chapter.ftnote: 1 Moses.
2 Moses directed the elders to deliver the message to Israel in order to lighten his own load.
3 Where Moses asked the elders in assisting him in delivering his message to Israel.
4 See I.E. on Deut. 12:21.
5 Rabbi Saadiah Gaon.
6 The 613 commandments of the Torah.

7 A Geonic compendium by Rabbi Simon Kayyra (ninth century) of Talmudic law arranged according to the order of the tractates of the Talmud. The Halakhot Gedolot was the first to enumerate the 613 commandments. Rabbi Saadiah Gaon uses the Halakhot Gedolot as an illustration of a list of the 613 commandments, for it was the first work to provide such a list. Rabbi Saadiah Gaon interprets thus because he does not believe that the stones were large enough for the entire five books of the Torah to have been written upon.
8 Liturgical poems devoted to the enumeration of the 613 commandments. The numerical value of the Hebrew letters of azharot (exhortation) is 613.
9 The monument of stones.

10 SeeRabbi Joseph Bekhor Shor on this verse. He explains that the Torah was written on a number of stones held together by plaster. Without the plaster the stones would fall apart. I.E. apparently interpreted similarly.
11 In conquering the land.
12 The kohanim and the Levites assisted Moses.
13 He was the one who received the revelation from God and related it to the kohanim and the Levites.
14 The word is not found again in Scripture.
15 The tribes descended from Rachel and Leah. See verse 12.
16 On Mount Gerizim (v. 12).
17 The tribes descended from Bilhah and Zilpah. See verse 13.
18 On Mount Ebal (v. 13).
19 Tribes. Only four tribes were descended from the handmaids. However, six tribes were commanded to stand over the blessing and six over the curse.
20 Leah had six sons.
21 Reuben.
22 Zebulan.
23 From the tribes that stood on Mount Gerizim and added to the ones on Mount Ebal.
24 See I.E. on Deut. 26:5 and the notes thereto.

25 Scripture lists only curses in verses 16-21 Blessings are not mentioned. However, the rabbis say that each one of the curses had its blessing counterpart. See Sotah 31a: “They turned their faces towards Mount Gerizim and opened with the blessing: blessed is the man who does not make a graven or molten image, and both parties respond amen. They then turned their faces towards Mount Ebal and opened with the curse: Cursed is the man who maketh a graven or molten image, and both parties respond amen.”
26 All of the curses have their blessing counterpart.
27 That is, the blessing beginning with Blessed shalt thou be in the city, that is, Deut. 28:3-13.
28 The curse recorded in Deut. 28:16-68 is the reverse of the blessing recorded in Deut. 28:3-13.

29 See Josh. 3:35. Joshua speaks of the blessings and curses recorded in the Torah. These can only refer to chapter 28, for the blessings spoken of by the rabbis in Sotah are not mentioned in the Torah.
30 Mentioned in verses 15-25.
31 Making a graven or molten image.
32 By a court of law.
33 Making a graven or molten image.
34 Dishonoring one’s parents.
35 In the privacy of their home.
36 No one knows why a judge ruled the way he did.
37 Hence only these eleven sins are specifically mentioned in Scripture.
38 Hebrew, behemah. Behamah is feminine. Our verse could thus conceivably be translated, cursed be he that lieth with any manner of female beast. Hence I.E.’s comments.
39 As neither can cry out and protest verbally.
40 The sins mention in verse 15-25.
41 The verse curses those who fail to observe positive practices, not only those who violate certain laws.
42 In verses 15-25.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 28
chapter.p: 1. ON HIGH ABOVE ALL THE NATIONS OF THE EARTH. This is a general blessing. It states that there will be no nation in the world like you.1
2. [AND…SHALL COME.] The meaning of And…shall come is that they shall come by themselves.2
AND OVERTAKE THEE. Even though you do not pursue them. It means that you will not tire yourself.
3. IN THE CITY. This is a blessing regarding an increase3 in merchandise.4
IN THE FIELD. In seeding and planting.
4. THE FRUIT OF THY BODY. Sons. The word beten5 (body) is a euphemism.6
THE INCREASE OF…AND THE YOUNG. I have previously explained the meaning of these two phrases.7
5. THY BASKET. The place of bread. Thy basket precedes and thy kneading trough but should come after it.8 On the other hand, thy basket may refer to the place where the flour is placed.9

6. WHEN THOU GOEST OUT. To celebrate festivals,10 to engage in business,11 and to take spoil,12 or in all your daily comings and goings.13 Its meaning is, you shall be successful in all that you do. The reverse is written [in the curses].14

7. [THAT RISE UP AGAINST THEE.] Since Scripture earlier stated that God will set Israel on high above the nations (v. 1), it now goes on to say that should the nations revolt against Israel [the Lord will cause thine enemies] that rise up against thee [to be smitten before thee].

AND…SEVEN. This means many.15 The number seven is employed because of the continuous cycle of seven days of the week.16 It17 has a set number of days because is contingent on the bodies which are on high.18
8. IN THY BARNS. Ba-asamekha (in thy bams) is in your storehouses. Its meaning is determined by its context.
9. FOR A HOLY PEOPLE. Holy by observing God’s commandments. The meaning of yekimekha is, will establish thee.
SHALT KEEP. In your heart.
AND WALK. Practice.
11. AND…WILL MAKE THEE OVERABUNDANT. The meaning of and will make thee overabundant19 is, if evil comes to the world, if hunger or blight comes, you will be set aside for good.

12. HIS…TREASURE. Which is potentially ready in heaven to go out.20 Compare, the treasuries of the snow (Job 38:22).21 Scripture speaks of rain after stating will make thee overabundant,22 for the withholding of rain is the cause of famine.
AND THOU SHALT LEND UNTO MANY NATIONS. For they shall suffer famine. However, no time shall come where you shall borrow. The sum of the matter is, you will always be on top.23

13. IF THOU SHALT HEARKEN. In your heart to observe and to do. The sum of the matter is, do not turn aside from God to serve idols, for the root of all sins is to deny God.24 The reverse of the aforementioned is to affirm that the Lord is one and to hearken and to observe, for the most important aspect of hearkening is observing.
20. CURSING. Diminution.25
DISCOMFITURE. A state wherein one can not finish what he has started.
REBUKE. A state in which one cannot enjoy what he has worked for, but is concerned for it26 after he has toiled.
22. CONSUMPTION. Some say that shachefet (consumption) refers to various types of illnesses.
WITH FEVER. Each day. Kaddachat (fever) is related to kadechah (kindled) in For a fire is kindled (Deut. 32:22).

The words mehumah (discomfiture), migeret (rebuke), shachefet (consumption), kaddachat (fever) and dalleket (inflammation) are adjectives. Dalleket refers to a fever which comes every third or fourth day.
AND WITH FIERY HEAT. The word charchur (fiery heat) is related to the word charah (bum) in and the bottom thereof may burn (Ezek. 24:11).
AND WITH DROUGHT. The word cherev (drought) is related to the word chorev (dry).27
AND WITH BLASTING. Shiddafon (blasting) means bloating. Compare, shedufot kadim (blasted with the east wind)28 (Gen. 41:23). Others say the reverse is true. Its meaning is then thin.29

AND WITH MILDEW. Yerakon (mildew) is to be rendered according to its meaning in Arabic.30 Some say that these31 refer to diseases of the seed.32 U-vashiddafon (blasting) is similar to shidufot (blasted) in blasted with the east wind (Gen. 41:23). I have smitten you with blasting (shiddafon)33 and mildew (Amos 4:9) is proof. Therefore Scripture afterwards reads, and thy heaven that is over thy head shall be brass. We find the same in the Torah portion If Ye Walk in My Statutes (Lev. 26:3).34
23. BRASS. Like brass. The same applies to iron.35
24. POWDER AND DUST. Because of the great dryness and the power of the winds.36
UNTIL THOU BE DESTROYED. Hishamedakh (thou be destroyed) is irregular.37 Compare, hibbare’akh38 (in the day that thou wast created) (Ezek. 28:15).39
25. A HORROR. Some of the letters of za’avah (horror) are reversed.40 Compare, keves (lamb) and kesev (lamb).41
26. AND THERE SHALL BE NONE TO FRIGHTEN THEM AWAY. To frighten away the birds and beasts.
27. [THE BOIL OF EGYPT.] Those who remain will be struck with the boil of Egypt.

AND WITH THE EMERODS. They appear in the hidden places.42 Scripture therefore reads u-vafolim43 (and with the emerods). The latter is related to the world ofel (hill) in And when he came to the hill (II Kings 5:24).44
AND WITH THE SCAB.45 The same is true in Arabic.46

AND WITH THE ITCH.47 Some say that he will need a potsherd48 as Job did.49 This is so50 even though the word cheres (itch) is spelled with a samekh.51 Others say u-ve-chares (and with the itch) means: and with a blow from the sun.52 However, the correct interpretation is that cheres (itch) refers to the name of a disease like the ones mentioned previously. The word has no neighbor.53
[28. MADNESS…] Madness, blindness, and astonishment are afflictions of the heart.54
29. AND THOU SHALT GROPE. In blindness.55
PROSPEROUS. Tatzli’ach (prosperous) is a transitive verb.56
OPPRESSED AND ROBBED. By the enemy, and there shall be none to save thee. Scripture commences to explain in what manner Israel shall be oppressed.
30. SHALL LIE WITH HER. Yishgalennah (lie with her) is a euphemism for sexual intercourse. The same applies to the word shegal (the queen) (Ps. 45:10). It refers to a woman prepared for bed.57
USE THE FRUIT THEREFOF. Techallennu (use the fruit thereof) is related to the word chalil (flute).58

32. AND FAIL WITH LONGING. The word kalot (fail with longing) is similar to the word kaletah (pineth) in My soul yearneth, yea, even pineth (Ps. 84:3) and to va-tekhal (failed with longing) in va-tekhal david (and caused David to fail with longing)59 (II Sam. 13:39). The latter is not lacking the word “soul” as the one lacking in knowledge says,60 for the word vatekhal is transitive. The subject61 is omitted,62 as it is in “whom she bore”63 (Num. 26:59).64
33. AND CRUSHED. Powerfully so.
[34. MAD.] This explains with madness (v. 28.). He will see his body covered with boils (v. 35).65
35. IN THE KNEES, AND IN THE LEGS. For when the boils are upon the knees and the legs, [it is hard to remove them].
WHEREOF THOU CANST NOT BE HEALED. Because they are on the surface of the body.66
36. AND THERE SHALT THOU SERVE. And it shall not avail you but you shall become an astonishment. That is, all who see you shall be astonished.67
37. A PROVERB. In the ear.68
AND A BYWORD. In the mouth.69 Sheninah (byword) is related to the word ve-shinnantam (and thou shalt teach them diligently) (Deut. 6:7).
SHALL LEAD THEE. Because of your sins. However, before this, a year of hunger shall come upon you when you are still in your land.70
38. SHALL CONSUME THEM. Yachselennu (shall consume them) means shall destroy them. Yachselennu comes from chasil, which is the name of a type of grasshopper.71
39. PLANT. You shall toil in planting and in the vineyards.
BUT THOU SHALT NEITHER DRINK OF THE WINE. At the time of the harvest.
NOR GATHER THE GRAPES. Te’egor (gather the grapes) means you will gather. It is a verb. Te’egor is similar to agerah (gathereth) in And gathereth her food in the harvest (Prov. 6:8).

40. BUT THOU SHALT NOT ANNOINT THYSELF WITH THE OIL. As is the practice.72 Compare, neither did I anoint myself at all (Dan. 10:3). This is the reverse of And let thy head lack no oil (Eccles. 9:8).73
SHALL DROP OFF. Yishal (drop off) is a nifal.74
42. SHALL…POSSESS. Yeyaresh (shall possess) is a pi’el. Yeyaresh is similar to le-horish (to drive out) in to drive out nations (Num. 4:38).75
THE LOCUST. Tzelatzal (locust) is a quadriliteral. It has no neighbor.76 Its meaning is according to its place.77
43. HIGHER AND HIGHER. The word is repeated to indicate a height over which no one else towers. On the other hand it may indicate permanency.78 Lower and lower is similar. Its meaning is very low.
44. HE SHALL BE THE HEAD. As in And the borrower is servant to the lender (Prov. 22:7).

46. FOR A SIGN. From God, so that you remember that you rebelled against Him. It will not only be a sign in you but also in your offspring, as in Our fathers have sinned, and are not (Lam. 5:7).79 I have previously explained this.80
47. BY REASON OF THE ABUNDANCE OF ALL THINGS. Which you desired,81 or all your needs.82
49. SWOOPETH DOWN. Yideh (swoopeth down) means flies. Compare, va-yede (he did swoop down) in Yea, He did swoop down upon the wings of the wind (Ps. 18:11).
53. AND THOU SHALT EAT THE FRUIT OF THINE OWN BODY. During the siege.
SHALL STRAITEN THEE. Each one of your enemies.83 Or the word oyevekha is so vocalized84 because it comes at the end of a verse.85
54. WHOM HE HATH REMAINING. This refers to the enemy.86 Or it means which he will leave over by hiding them.87 All of this will he due to the siege.
55. IN ALL THY GATES. In any place.88
57. AND AGAINST HER AFTERBIRTH. Shilyah (afterbirth) refers to the place where the child dwells while in the mother’s belly.89
FROM BETWEEN HER FEET. This is a euphemism.90 Compare, and he had neither dressed his feet (II Sam. 19:25).91
59. THY PLAGUES. Makkotekha (thy plagues) is a compound of a singular92 and the plural.93 Compare, the word edoti (my testimony)94 in And My testimony that I shall teach them (Ps. 132:12).
The meaning of ve-hifla (will make wonderful) is, it will be an extraordinary thing, for nothing like it was ever seen or heard of.
OF LONG CONTINUANCE.95 They will not be removed.96

61. WILL THE LORD BRING UPON. Yalem (will bring) is related to the word he’elah (brought up)97 (Jer. 16:15) even though it98 is vocalized with a sheva. Others say that yalem means will bring.99 It is an Aramaic word.100
63. AS THE LORD REJOICED. You should not think that this will harm God or that God will mourn.101 Its meaning is similar to102 If thou he righteous, what givest thou to him (Job 35:7).
AND YE SHALL BE PLUCKED. Ve-nissachtem (and ye shall be plucked) is a nifal. It is lacking a nun.103 It is related to the word yissach (will pluck) in The Lord will pluck up (Prov. 15:25).
66. SHALL HANG. The word telu’im (shall hang) has an alef in place of the stem heh.104

68. AND…YE SHALL SELL YOURSELVES. Ve-hitmakkartem (and ye shall sell yourselves) does not mean and you will be sold.105 It means you, both men and women, will seek to sell yourselves and no man shall buy you.
Observe, this covenant was made by the command of God in the plains of Moab.106
chapter.ftnote: 1 Vat. Ebr. 38 reads, there will be no human being in the world like you.
2 In pursuit of the blessings. That is, you will not tire yourself in pursuit of what the blessings have to offer.
3 According to I.E. the term blessing mean an increase of good things. See I.E. on Gen. 2:3 (Vol. 1, p. 50).
4 All sort of goods are produced and are found in the city.
5 Literally, belly.
6 For the sexual organ, which is found near the belly. See I.E. on Gen. 15:4 (Vol. 1, p. 170) and Ex. 1:5 (Vol. 2, p. 7).
7 Shegar alafekha and ashterot tzonekha. See I.E. on Deut. 7:13.
8 For the dough has to be kneaded before it is made into bread.
9 Hence Thy basket precedes and thy kneading trough.
10 The three pilgrimage festivals.
11 When you travel a great distance on business.
12 When you go out to war.
13 In your mundane affairs.
14 Verse 19, which states, Cursed shalt thou be when thou comest in, etc., is the reverse of our verse.
15 Seven is not to be taken literally.
16 It is the maximum number of days in the week. Scripture did not use a month because there are not the same number of days in each month.
17 The week.
18 Each day of the week is connected to one of the seven moving heavenly bodies, namely, the sun, the moon, and the five visible planets.
19 Hebrew, ve-hotirekha. I.E. takes this to mean will cause you to be left over.
20 Hence rain is referred to as a treasure.
21 The reference is to heaven.
22 The meaning of which, according to I.E., is, will allow to survive.
23 Literally, the head.
24 Literally, the root. If you worship another god you are in effect denying the Lord.

25 Of that which you require and that which is good. According to I.E. a blessing refers to an increase and a curse to a diminution. See I.E. on Gen. 2:3 (Vol. 1, p. 50) and Gen. 3:14 (Vol. 1, p. 71) and the notes thereto.
26 Lest it be stolen or the like.
27 The usual meaning of cherev is a sword.
28 This interpretation renders shedufot kadim as bloated by the east wind.
29 Withered, shriveled.
30 It is a disease in which the skin develops a greenish color.
31 Shiddafon (blasting) and yerakon (mildew).
32 Unlike the illnesses mentioned up to this point which attack people, these attack plants.
33 Shiddafon here refers to a disease of the seed, for Amos goes on to speak of gardens, vineyards, and olive trees. See Amos 4:9.
34 Scripture first speaks of illnesses that strike people and then of plagues that fall upon the plants.
35 It is to be interpreted, like iron.
36 The drought and the winds will turn the soil to dust and powder.
37 It should have been vocalized with a segol rather than with a sheva beneath the mem and a kamatz beneath the kaf; i.e., compare the word hishamedkha in verse 20.
38 Its vocalization is also irregular.
39 Hishamedakh (thou be destroyed) and hibbare’akh are similarly vocalized. Some editions read, be-yom hibbare’akh (from the day that thou wast created) (Ezek. 28:15).
40 Za’avah is a variant of zeva’ah.
41 There too some of the letters reverse their positions.
42 They are swellings that appear in hidden places.
43 This is the ketib. The keri reads u-vatchorim.

44 Hemorrhoids are called ofalim because they are hill-like; i.e., they consist of swellings. According to Weiser its meaning is, hemorrhoids are called ofalim because hills are used for hiding and hemorrhoids appear in hidden places.
45 Hebrew, garav.
46 The Arabic word for scab is jarabu.
47 Hebrew, cheres.
48 Hebrew, cheres. He will need a potsherd (cheres) to scratch himself to relieve his itching.
49 Job used a potsherd to relief his itching. See Job 2:8.
50 The disease is called cheres because one employs a potsherd for relief if struck by this illness.
51 While the word for potsherd is spelled with a sin.
52 One of the meanings of the word cheres is the sun. See Jud. 14:18. Hence this interpretation renders u-ver-chares, and with sunstroke.
53 It is not found elsewhere in Scripture. Hence we do not know what sort of disease it refers to.
54 They afflict the mind.
55 Its meaning is, and thou shalt grope in blindness.
56 The verb can also be intransitive. Hence I.E.’s comment.
57 For sexual intercourse. See I.E. on Ps. 45:10.
58 So Vat. Ebr. 38. The printed editions read chalilah. See I.E. on Deut. 28:6: “They were in the habit of dancing [to the tune of flutes] in the vineyards.” Hence the term techallennu.
59 Translated according to I.E.

60 The “one lacking in knowledge” says, va-tekhal david is to be rendered, And David’s soul failed with longing. It should be noted that this interpretation was offered by Rashi, Radak, and the Targum.
61 Of va-tekhal, i.e., the one who caused David to fail in longing.

62 According to I.E our text is to be interpreted, and caused David to fail in longing. See Radak on II Sam. 13:29. Radak quotes an interpretation which renders the verse, And the wife of David caused him to fail in longing. This apparently is the way I.E. interprets our verse (Krinsky).
63 Translated according to I.E.
64 Scripture omits the person who did the bearing.
65 And this will drive him mad.

66 According to I.E. a physician is permitted to heal only external wounds and not internal ones. Hence I.E. explains that Scripture here states that Israel will be struck by wounds that a physician will not be able to heal even though they are on the surface and may be dealt with by a physician (Krinsky).
67 All who see Israel will be shocked at what happened to them. Rashi interprets similarly.
68 You will serve as an example illustrating a point.
69 People will speak about you.
70 In other words, verse 38 which follows does not speak of the exile but rather of what will precede the exile.
71 Thus yachselennu means shall be “grasshoppered.”
72 It was the practice of people to anoint themselves.
73 Eccles. 9:8 records the normal practice. Dan. 10:3 records the abnormal practice.
74 From the root nun, shin, lamed.
75 In other words, it means to drive out or to destroy. The word might be confused with a similar word meaning to inherit. Hence I.E.’s comment.
76 The word does not appear again in Scripture.
77 Its meaning can be ascertained from its context.
78 The stranger shall be permanently over you.
79 The verse concludes, And we have borne their iniquities.
80 See I.E. on Lev. 26:39.
81 You had everything that you desired.
82 You had everything that you needed.

83 Yatzik (shall straiten) is in the singular. Oyevekha (thine enemies) is in the plural. According to I.E. when a verb in the singular governs a noun in the plural, the verb refers to each one within the plural.
84 The word reads oyevekha rather than oyivkha.
85 In other words, oyevekha is really a singular. Our text should thus be rendered, wherewith thine enemy shall straiten thee.
86 Yotir literally means he will leave over. According to this interpretation the verse reads, which the enemy will leave alive.
87 According to this interpretation yotir refers to the man mentioned in the opening of the verse. Our verse should be interpreted, which he will save by hiding them.
88 In all thy gates means in any place in your country.
89 It refers to the placenta.
90 For the vagina.
91 Feet refers to the genital area. According to Rashi on II Sam. 19:25, the meaning of and he had neither dressed his feet is, he did not shave his pubic hair. Also see Talmud, Yevamot 103a.
92 Suffix.

93 A noun in the plural. Makkot is a plural. We would thus expect a yod to follow the tav and the tav to be vocalized with a segol in makkotekha. However, the tav in makkotekha is vocalized with a sheva, and makkotekha has no yod in it. The latter is the spelling and vocalization of the singular.
94 Edot is a plural. Thus the word should read edotai, for “i” is a singular suffix. Thus edoti is a compound of a plural with a singular pronominal suffix.
95 Hebrew, ve-ne’emanim. Literally, and faithful.
96 In other words, “faithful” means they will do what they are supposed to do.
97 It comes from the root ayin, lamed, heh, and means bring up.
98 Yalem is vocalized with a sheva. He’elah is vocalized with a chataf segol. Since both words are in the hifil we would expect them to be vocalized similarly. Hence I.E.’s comment.
99 Rather than bring up. There is not much difference in practical meaning between the two interpretations. They only differ as to the etymology of the word.
100 The word al in Aramaic means to enter. See Dan. 2:16.
101 For what happened to you.
102 The import of our verse is similar to Job 35:7.
103 The root nun is dropped. Thus the word reads nissachtem rather than ninsachtem.
104 Telu’im comes from the root tav, lamed, heh. However, telu’im is spelled with an alef. Hence I.E.’s comment.
105 By others, for the word is in the hitpa’el, not in the nifal. (Cf. nimkartem in Is. 50:1.) Furthermore, Scripture goes on to say, and no man shall buy you.
106 I.E.’s paraphrase of verse 69.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 29
chapter.p: 1. AND MOSES CALLED UNTO ALL ISRAEL. To establish a covenant. Scripture therefore reads afterwards, Ye are standing this day (v. 9).1

The reason Scripture reads Ye have seen and then And I have led (v. 4) and then And Og…came out (v. 6) is that some of the Israelites saw the signs that God showed in Egypt,2 and they and those who came after them3 saw the miracle of the manna,4 for they ate no food aside from the manna. And these sons5 saw that God helped them and they smote two kings (v. 6).

3. [BUT THE LORD HATH NOT GIVEN YOU A HEART TO KNOW.] Scripture reads a heart to know because they tested God ten times6 and did not make mention of the signs which they witnessed. Scripture reads given because God is the first cause.7 Furthermore,8 they saw that they had no need for bread or wine.9
4. [ARE NOT WAXEN OLD.] I have previously explained this.10 Sihon and Og were recently11 defeated.12 You are therefore13 obligated to keep the covenant.

8. THAT YE MAY…PROSPER. Taskilu means prosper. It is a hifil14 as the word ta’asun15 (all that ye do) proves. Compare, maskil (great success) in And David had great success in all his ways (I Sam. 18:14).16
9. YE ARE STANDING THIS DAY. Around the ark.

YOUR HEADS. Roshekhem (your heads) is similar to haohelah (the tent) in into the tent Sarah his mother (Gen. 24:67)17 and even the prophecy, Odad the prophet18 (II Chron. 15:8).19 Roshekhem shivtekhem (your heads, your tribes) is to be interpreted as your heads, who are the heads of your tribes.20 Roshekhem (your heads) is like the word va-niram (we have shot at them) (Num. 21:30).21 The word is to be so interpreted for the princes22 were closest to the ark.23 After them came the elders, followed by the officers, after whom came all the men of Israel, that is, the males, followed by the male little ones, after whom came the women, followed by the strangers.

11. THAT THOU SHOULDEST ENTER INTO THE COVENANT. Le-ovrekha (that thou shouldest enter) is an infinitive.24 It is like va-ya’avru (and passed) in and passed between the parts thereof (Jer. 34:18).25 Observe, the word avar (passed) minus the bet26 has the opposite meaning.27
13. NEITHER WITH YOU ONLY. But with you and with those who come after you, namely, your sons and your sons’ sons.
14. [BUT WITH HIM THAT STANDETH HERE WITH US THIS DAY.] The nun of yeshno (that standth here) is superfluous.28

AND ALSO WITH HIM THAT IS NOT HERE WITH US. Ve’et asher ennnu (and also with him that is not) means with him that is not here with us29 but will come after us. It is not to be interpreted as those who say that the spirits of the coming generations were there.30
15. FOR YE KNOW. There are among you some who witnessed the abominations of Egypt, namely, their gods. Additionally, all of you have seen the abominations of the nations.
WHICH YE PASSED. Among them, namely, the Edomites, the Ammonites, the Moabites, and the Midianites.
17. [A ROOT THAT BEARETH GALL AND WORMWOOD.] For gall injures the healthy.31 It is a disease that is infectious.32
[18. THIS CURSE.] This curse refers to Cursed be the man that maketh a graven or molten image (Deut. 27:15).

THAT HE BLESS HIMSELF IN HIS HEART. Rabbi Judah Ha-Levi, of blessed memory, says that he bless himself is to be taken according to its plain meaning. When he hears the curse he will bless himself in his heart and say I shall have peace. In other words, when he hears the ban33 he will say it will not fall on me but upon someone else.

THAT…BE SWEPT AWAY. Rabbi Judah Ha-Levi, who rests in paradise, says that the word sefot (swept away) means to extirpate. Compare, tispeh34 [thou (wilt) sweep away] in Wilt Thou indeed sweep away (Gen. 18:23). In other words, the one who blesses himself35 wants to nullify the words of the righteous,36 who are metaphorically called “the watered,” with the words of “the dry.” Look, the righteous are called watered. Compare, For he shall be like a tree planted by the streams of water (Jer. 17:8). The wicked are called dry. Compare, For he shall be like a tamarisk in the desert (Ibid., v. 6). The wicked person thinks that the blessing which he utters in his heart will also stop the curse. He explained well were it not that the word ravah (well watered) is an adjective.37 Our text should have read, ravi38 et ha-tzama39 (the well watered…with the dry).

Rabbi Jonah the grammarian40 says that it means41 because the corrupt sees the righteous42 destroyed along with the wicked43 he therefore thinks evil in his heart.44 However, this is incorrect because Scripture reads, I shall have peace.45

In my opinion the word sefot (swept) means to add. Compare, sefot chattat (add sin) (Is. 30:1). The added sin is the wicked person’s statement, I shall have peace even though I walk in the stubbornness of my heart. I will live because of the righteousness of the righteous, for the pious are many and I am an individual sinner.46 Scripture therefore afterwards reads, The Lord will not be willing to pardon him47 but then… (v. 19). The meaning of the latter is he shall immediately be destroyed. This verse is also proof of my interpretation of and he shall be forgiven48 (Num. 15:28). The meaning of sefot is that the well watered will add to the dry. Scripture compares the righteous to the well watered, as in And he shall be like a tree planted by streams of water (Ps. 1:3). It compares the wicked to the dry. Compare, For he shall be like a tamarisk in the desert (Jer. 17: 6). The fact that Scripture at first reads, a root that beareth gall and wormwood (v. 17), is proof of this.49 It is in a dry place.50

19. THE ANGER OF THE LORD…SHALL BE KINDLED.51 The fire of God’s anger shall bum him to the point where the smoke will be visible. Observe, if the sinner be an individual he will die immediately, and if it is a family all the curse…shall lie upon him. This means that the curse shall lie upon the family until its name is eradicated. If the sinner be a tribe, the Lord shall separate him unto evil (v. 20).52 Similarly And I will offer it up for a burnt-offering (Jud. 11:31), as I have explained.53
21. AND THE GENERATION TO COME. Your children. Also the foreigners who see the plagues of the land.

22. BRIMSTONE. A prayer to God that all the land should be burnt in brimstone and salt like the overthrow of the places that are mentioned.54 Some explain that even all the nations shall say (v. 23) repeats what was stated earlier55 because Scripture went off on a tangent,56 as is the style of the language.57
[24.] THEN MEN SHALL SAY. The earlier inhabitants.58
[THE GOD OF THEIR FATHERS.] They forsook the God that they and their fathers knew and they served gods whom they did not know.
25. AND THAT HE HAD NOT ALLOTTED UNTO THEM. I have previously explained this.59
27. AND THE LORD ROOTED THEM OUT. Va-yitteshem (and rooted them out) is missing a nun.60 Compare li-netosh (to root out) (Jer. 1:10). The nun is swallowed by the dagesh, as is the rule.61
[AS IS THIS DAY.] These are the words of the respondents.62
28. THE SECRET THINGS. The reference is to one who serves idols in secret.

BELONG UNTO THE LORD OUR GOD. Its meaning is that his punishment is in the hands of God, and the Lord will exact punishment from him. However, if the sin was committed in public there is an obligation on us and our children to do in accordance with that which is written in the Torah.

Others say63 that the secret and the revealed things belong to God. It is incumbent upon us only to observe the words of the Torah. Now this interpretation has no head or foot.64 What reason is there to mention this here?65

Scripture states that if you return unto the Lord (Deut. 30:2), God will turn thy captivity (Ibid., v. 3) even though you are outside of the land because it stated earlier, and cast them into another land (v. 27). According to Rabbi Judah66 the first grammarian, the meaning of ve-shav (then shall turn) (Deut. 30:3) means God will give rest;67 that is, he will give rest to the captives and be merciful to them, and after this He will return and gather.68
chapter.ftnote: 1 And goes on to say, that thou shouldest enter into the covenant of the Lord (v. 11).
2 You have seen…was directed to this group.
3 The first generation born in the wilderness.
4 And I have led…was directed to this group.
5 The second generation born in the wilderness.
6 See Num. 14:22.

7 Man has free will and thus must develop a “knowing heart” on his own. However, our verse implies that it is God who gives man a heart to know. Hence I.E. points out that Scripture ascribes man’s achievements to God because God is the first cause and in that sense can be said to give man a heart to know.
8 Israel is obligated to observe the commandments.

9 In addition to the miracles which Israel witnessed in Egypt, they experienced the miracle of living in the wilderness for forty years without bread or wine (Meijler). In other words, our verse (and the one before it) continues the theme of verse 1.
10 See I.E. on Deut. 8:4.
11 Shortly before Moses gave this address.
12 Thus even the youngest among them witnessed the defeat of these kings. Furthermore, the event was fresh in their minds.
13 Because of what precedes it in verses 1-7.
14 A causative.
15 Ta’asun is the object of taskilu. Hence the meaning of le-ma’an taskilu et kol asher ta’asun is that ye may make to prosper all that ye do.
16 We thus see that the word maskil means to prosper. The root of maskil (sin, kaf, lamed) means intelligence. Hence I.E.’s comments.

17 Translated literally. According to I. E. into the tent Sarah his mother is short for into the tent, the tent of Sarah his mother. Similarly, your heads is short for your heads the heads of. See I.E. on Gen. 24:67 (Vol. 1, p. 243).
18 Translated literally.
19 According to I.E. even the prophecy, Odad the prophet is short for even the prophecy, the prophecy of Odad the prophet. See I.E. on Gen. 24:67 (Vol. 1, p. 243).
20 Roshekhem shivtekhem is short for roshekhem roshe shivtekhem.

21 Num. 21:30 reads, va-niram avad cheshbon (we have shot at them, Heshbon is destroyed). According to I.E. this is to be interpreted as And their king, the king of Heshbon was destroyed. See I.E. on Num. 21:30 (Vol. 4, p. 175).
22 The heads of the tribes.

23 According to I.E. our verse records the hierarchical arrangement of the Israelites before the ark, when the covenant was made. If we take our verse literally the word “tribes” breaks up the arrangement. Hence I.E. insists that our verse reads, your heads, the heads of your tribes.
24 With the pronominal suffix.

25 In other words, le-ovrekha (that thou shouldest enter) means that you should pass, i.e., that you should enter the covenant, for they used to cut an animal in half when making a covenant and walk between the halves.
26 Following it.

27 The word avar preceding brit means to violate the covenant. Hence our verse reads, le-ovrekha bi-verit. Had our verse read, le-ovrekha berit, it would have meant that you should violate the covenant.
28 Yeshno is the word yesh plus the third person pronominal suffix. That suffix is a vav. Thus we would expect yesho rather than yeshno. Hence I.E.’s comment (Krinsky).

29 Here with us today. In other words, ve’et means and with. This is not the usual meaning of et. Hence I.E.’s comment. See I.E. on Gen. 1:1 (Vol. 1, p. 27): “Et means the very thing…However, sometimes…et is used in place of with.”
30 This is the opinion of some midrashim. See Tanchuma, Nitzavim: The souls were there, but the bodies [these souls were to enter] had not yet been created.
31 Hence it symbolizes idolatry. Even a spiritually healthy person is injured by idolatry.
32 The person afflicted by idolatry will infect others.
33 The curse.
34 Both words come from the root samekh, peh, heh.
35 The wicked.
36 Moses.

37 As is tzeme’ah (dry). The point is that Rabbi Judah’s interpretation requires that nouns, not adjectives, be employed in our verse, for according to his interpretation the verse speaks of people. Filwarg argues that Rabbi Judah’s interpretation requires a noun because the dry and the watered are metaphors for curses and blessing, which are nouns. He interprets in this manner because later on I.E. himself interprets the dry and the watered as referring to people. The problem with Filwarg’s interpretation is that I.E. quotes Rabbi Judah as saying, “The righteous are called watered…The wicked are called dry.”
38 A noun.
39 A noun.
40 Rabbi Jonah ibn Janach.
41 The meaning of that he blesses himself in his heart…that the watered are swept away with the dry.
42 The watered.
43 The dry.

44 Rabbi Jonah’s interpretation of that he bless himself in his heart. The wicked person says I might as well be wicked, for both the righteous and the wicked suffer one fate. They are both swept away.
45 That he blesses himself in his heart implies that he says something positive to himself. However, there is nothing positive in saying the righteous and I will be swept away.

46 I.E.’s interpretation of the watered be swept away with the dry. A nation is judged by the majority of its people. The wicked believe that the merit of the majority, who are righteous, will protect the sinners, who are a minority.
47 Hebrew, selo’ach lo.
48 Hebrew, ve-nislach lo. According to I.E. the word salach means to delay punishment. See I.E. on Num. 14:19, “Selach refers to being slow to anger.”
49 That dry refers to the wicked.

50 The root that beareth gall and wormwood grows in parched land. Hence the wicked person is called the dry (Meijler, Krinsky). I.E.’s interpretation presents a problem. He interprets “the watered and the dry” as referring to people. However, earlier I.E. rejects Rabbi Judah Ha-Levi’s interpretation for this very reason. As noted above, Filwarg attempts to justify I.E.’s position. However, his interpretation is forced.
51 Hebrew, yeshan (literally, shall smoke). Our clause literally reads, the anger of the Lord…shall smoke. Hence I.E.’s interpretation.

52 Thus The anger of the Lord…shall be kindled against that man refers to an individual; and all the curse…shall lie upon him refers to a family; and the Lord shall separate him unto evil refers to a tribe.
53 We no longer have I.E.’s commentary on Judges. However, Radak in his comments on Judges notes that the vav there has the meaning of or. It appears that I.E. interpreted similarly.
54 Our verse records the prayer that will be offered by coming generations and by the foreigner. When they see what God did to the land, they too will curse it.
55 In verse 21. Our verse repeats parts of verse 21 because it picks up its trend of thought.
56 In verse 22. In other words, verse 23 is a continuation of verse 21.
57 To go off on a tangent and then return to the original point.
58 The earlier inhabitants shall respond to their children and to the foreigner.
59 See I.E.’s comment on which the Lord thy God hath allotted (Deut. 4:19).
60 Its root is nun, tet, shin.
61 For words whose first root letter is a nun.
62 It is part of the answer given by earlier inhabitants of the land.
63 That the meaning of our verse is.
64 It makes no sense and has no legs to stand on.
65 It does not continue the thought of the previous verse.
66 Rabbi Judah Chayuj.
67 See I.E. on Num. 10:36 (Vol. 4, p. 75). Rabbi Judah renders God will turn thy captivity (Ibid., v. 3) as God will give rest to your captivity.
68 Your captivity. It should be noted that Rabbi Judah renders the first ve-shav in 30:3 as will He give rest, and the second ve-shav as and will He return.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 30
chapter.p: 4. IN THE UTTERMOST PARTS OF HEAVEN. With regard to the Land of Israel.1

6. AND THE LORD THY GOD WILL CIRCUMCISE. For He is the first cause of all actions.2 After saying, you shall return unto the Lord and listen to His voice,3 Moses says that unlike the circumcision of the flesh, which you are obligated to execute, God will help you and will circumcise your heart and the heart of your seed.
9. [AND THE LORD THY GOD WILL MAKE THEE OVERABUNDANT.] Scripture states ve-hotirekha4 (make thee overabundant) because God will place curses upon the enemies [of Israel]5
AS HE REJOICED OVER THY FATHERS. Who inherited the land, for Scripture addresses those who were exiled from it.

10. WHICH ARE WRITTEN IN THIS BOOK OF THE LAW. For the main part of all the commandments is there,6 although they need the explanation provided by tradition.7 They8 cannot be kept unless the heart is complete.9 Scripture therefore states, with all thy heart, for the commandment to keep means to keep with one’s heart.10
11. TOO HARD. The word niflet (too hard) means concealed.11 Or its meaning is, wondrous, that is, something that will cause you to grow weary while trying to accomplish it.12
12. IT IS NOT IN HEAVEN. This explains niflet (too hard) (v. 11).
13. BEYOND THE SEA. This explains neither is it far off (v. 11). It is possible that the reference is to the great sea13 whose width a person cannot enter14 because of the darkness of the water.15

14. IN THY MOUTH, AND IN THY HEART. For the heart is the core of the commandments.16 Some commandments require the uttering of statements which serve to reinforce the heart.17 Others consist of deeds18 so that a person will utter the required statements.19
15. LIFE. Long life.20
AND GOOD. Wealth, bodily health and honor. Death and evil are the reverse of the above.
16. TO LOVE. This is most important.

TO WALK IN HIS WAYS. You shall not modify the way He asked you to act21 and the precepts which He commanded you, even though you do not know why the statutes and ordinances were given. Note, Then thou shalt live explains the term life (v. 15).
AND MULTIPLY. This explains and good (v. 15), for it refers to material increase,22 that is, in children and in wealth.
17. BUT IF THY HEART TURN AWAY. For the heart is most important.23
BUT SHALT BE DRAWN AWAY. I have previously explained the meaning of ve-niddachta (but shall be drawn away).24
18. THAT YE SHALL SURELY PERISH. This explains death and evil (v. 15), for they and their children and their wealth shall perish.
YE SHALL NOT PROLONG YOUR DAYS. The reverse of the Lord thy God shall bless thee in the land (v. 16).
19. HEAVEN AND EARTH. For they endure.25 Similarly with regard to this stone shall be a witness against us (Josh. 24:27) and Hear, O ye mountains, the Lord’s controversy (Micah 6:2).
LIFE AND DEATH. The reference is to the blessing and the curse.26 Observe, it is incumbent upon you to choose life.27
THAT THOU MAYEST LIVE. Physically or in memory. Scripture explains that life is to love.28

20. FOR THAT IS THY LIFE.29 According to the commentaries this refers to the voice of God. I believe that the reference is to God,30 as the poet says,31 the Lord is my salvation;32 The God of my mercy (Ps. 59:11); My shield (Ps. 18:3); and my sword.33
chapter.ftnote: 1 For a person living in the Land of Israel, the place of Israel’s exile appears to be at the uttermost parts of the heavens. However, in truth the heavens have no uttermost part for they are round.

2 I.E.’s paraphrase of I Sam. 2:3. In other words, God is the first cause who gave man the power to circumcise his heart. Since all things can be traced back to God, God can be said to “circumcise” man’s heart. And the Lord thy God will circumcise thy heart seems to indicate that man has no free will, for it implies that God will change man’s nature so that he will no longer sin. Hence I.E.’s comment.
3 I.E.’s paraphrase of the opening of verse 6.
4 I. E. renders ve-hotirekha as He will permit you to remain.
5 Which shall destroy them. However, you shall survive.
6 Hence Scripture mentions the written law and omits the oral law.
7 The oral tradition elaborates the laws which are found in the Torah.
8 The commandments.
9 Has total belief in God.
10 Belief must accompany observance. See I.E. on Ex. 31:18 (Vol. 2, p. 653).
11 See Rashi.
12 In other words, too hard.
13 The Atlantic Ocean.
14 That is, one cannot cross it.
15 A dark cloud covers it. I.E. like other medievalists believed that one cannot cross the “large sea.”
16 The commandments that pertain to the heart are the most important ones. Among the latter are the commandments to believe in God, to love God, etc.
17 We thus recite the shema to reinforce our belief.
18 Such as donning tefilin.

19 So that a person will remember to recall verbally the commandment tied to the ritual. However, not all commandments observed by deeds have this as their purpose. See I.E. on Ex. 31:18 (Vol. 2, p. 410) where he divides the positive commandments into three categories: those to be observed by the heart, those to be observed by speech, and those to be observed by action.
20 A person must ultimately die. Hence I.E.’s interpretation.
21 Literally, the way of His deeds.
22 Literally, an increase in bodies.
23 Hence it personifies the entire human being.
24 See I.E. on Deut. 4:19.
25 From generation to generation.
26 The blessing and the curse is not an addition to what precedes it but is synonymous with it.
27 I.E.’s interpretation of therefore choose life.
28 The object of life is to love God.
29 Hebrew, ki hu chayyyekha.
30 Literally, ki hu chayyyekha, which reads, for he is your life. Hence this interpretation.
31 We should not be surprised that the Torah refers to God by the term life. For Scripture terms God my sword, my shield, my mercy, my salvation.
32 Compare Ps. 18:47: The God of my salvation.
33 Compare, Deut. 33:29: The Lord is the sword of thy excellency.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 31
chapter.p: 1. AND MOSES WENT. Moses went to each tribe and tribe to inform them that he was about to die and that they should not fear.1 He strengthened them2 with his words to Joshua.3 Scripture therefore afterwards reads, and thou shalt cause them to inherit it (v. 7). I believe that he then4 blessed the tribes.5 This is so even though the blessings are recorded later.6

2. GO OUT AND COME IN. In war.7 Even if I did not die now, I would not have the ability to wage war. You have no need for any person to help you, for God will destroy the nations.8 Joshua will do the same.9 What you saw with your eyes in the war of Sihon and Og is proof.10
5. AND YE SHALL DO UNTO THEM. To break their pillars.11
6. BE STRONG AND OF GOOD COURAGE. Now that you know that God goes with you wherever you go to battle.
7. BE STRONG AND OF GOOD COURAGE. Moses also said this to Joshua12 whom he appointed over them.
FOR THOU SHALT GO WITH THIS PEOPLE. The word et means with.13
9. AND DELIVERED IT UNTO THE PRIESTS THE SONS OF LEVI. Who teach the Torah.
