AND UNTO ALL THE ELDERS OF ISRAEL. The Sanhedrin.14 Or its meaning is like And Moses and the elders of Israel commanded (Deut. 27:1).15
10. AT THE END OF EVERY SEVEN YEARS. At the beginning of the year.16
12. THAT THEY MAY LEARN. The entire year.17 Similarly on the Sabbath.18
AND THY STRANGER. Perhaps he will convert to Judaism.
[THAT THEY MAY HEAR, AND THAT THEY MAY LEARN.] When they hear19 they will ask. And he who is not wise and the children who are young will learn.
14. THY DAYS APPROACH THAT THOU MUST DIE. For there is a time set for each and everyone.20 I have previously explained this.21
AND MOSES…WENT. From the camp of Israel, for that is where he was.22 He then came to the camp where God’s presence rested.

15. AND THE LORD APPEARED IN THE TENT. The specified tent.23 The meaning of our verse is that the pillar of cloud was at the door of the tent and God was seen inside the tent. This24 is what the glory25 refers to.26

The statement that I may give him a charge (v. 14) refers to And he27 gave Joshua the son of Nun a charge (v. 23) by the command of God, may He be blessed. Scripture therefore reads, which I swore unto them (Ibid.).28 After this came the passage Behold, thou art about to sleep with thy fathers (v. 16).29 There is no chronological order in the Torah. The passage And it came to pass, when Moses had made an end of writing the words of this law (v. 24) is connected to30 And Moses wrote this law (v. 9).

16. AND THIS PEOPLE WILL RISE UP. It is not possible for this to be connected to what precedes it, for what reason is there to say,31 and this people will rise up, and go astray.32 The meaning of ve-zanah (and go astray) is, to leave God’s authority33 in one’s thought.

AFTER THE FOREIGN GODS OF THE LAND. We know that God is one.34 Change comes from the recepients.35 God does not change His works,36 for they are executed in wisdom. It is part of the service of God to harness one’s power to receive spiritual inspiration in accordance with the place.37 Scripture therefore reads, the manner of the God of the land (II Kings 17:26).38 Jacob therefore said,39 Put away the strange gods (Gen. 35:2).40 The place is unlike other places with regard to engaging in sexual intercourse with women whom Scripture deems as being of close flesh.41 The intelligent will understand.42

[AMONG THEM.] Be-kirbo (among them) refers to foreign.43 Scripture, as it were, states, and go astray after the gods of a foreign people,44 who are the gods of the land.45 However, it appears that be-kirbo refers to the word ha-aretz (of the land),46 for the word eretz is found in the masculine.47 Compare, And the land (ha-aretz) was not able to bear (nasa)48 them (Gen. 13:6); the land [is] burnt up (netam49 aretz) (Is. 9:18).
17. AND I WILL FORSAKE THEM. All of them.
AND THEY SHALL BE.50 Each one of them shall be food for the enemy.51

18. [AND I WILL SURELY HIDE.] The meaning of And I will surely hide is, if they call Me, I will not answer. Scripture compares God to a person who does not see or know what is happening. It is the custom of Scripture to employ two verbs.52 Those who know grammar understand this.53
IN THAT THEY ARE TURNED. This,54 as I previously explained,55 is the great evil. There is no evil which tops it.
19. NOW…WRITE THIS. A commandment that Moses, and all who know how to write,56 should write it.
AND TEACH THOU IT. Explain to them the difficult meanings.

PUT IT IN THEIR MOUTHS. That they should be able to recite it orally.57 The words ve-lammedah (and teach thou it) and also simah (put it) are irregular, for grammatically the heh of ve-lammedah should have been vocalized with a kamatz and the lamed with a segol.58

A WITNESS…AGAINST THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL. This meaning of our verse is tied to For when I shall have brought them (v. 20).59 It is also possible that our verse is independent,60 because Scripture states, ve-anetah (that…shall testify) (v. 21).61 Ve-anetah (that…shall testify) is similar to ta’aneh (bear)62 in thou shalt not bear…against thy neighbor (Ex. 20: 13). The song, as it were, will testify before those who ask, “Why did all this happen to us?”63
21. BEFORE THEM. Le-fanav means before them. It means that the witness will not be removed from before them but shall always be with them.64
FOR I KNOW THEIR IMAGINATION. For even if I did not know the future,65 I know what they have done until this day.66
22. THE SAME DAY. Moses did not tarry in doing this thing.67 It is possible that this took place on the day he died, which was after writing the words of the Torah, for Moses wrote the song with it.
24. UNTIL THEY WERE FINISHED. This is connected to the words.68
25. THAT MOSES COMMANDED THE LEVITES. Scripture is being brief.69 Our verse, as it were, says, the earlier-mentioned Levites who are kohanim, but not all the Levites, for they do not touch the ark.70
[THAT BORE THE ARK OF THE CONVENT OF THE LORD.] By command. There are many such instances.

26. IT MAY BE THERE FOR A WITNESS AGAINST THEE. Moses speaks to all of Israel. The kohanim are included when he speaks to Israel. However, when Moses addressed the Reubenites and the Gadites he spoke to them alone, as I previously explained.71

27. AND HOW MUCH MORE AFTER MY DEATH. In addition, I know that after my death…72 for God told me, and this people will rise up, and go astray (v. 16) after you sleep with your fathers. This is what after my death refers to.73
29. [BEFALL YOU.] The meaning of ve-karata (and…will befall you) is similar to ve-chatat (but the fault is) in but the fault is in thine people (Ex. 5:15).74 It is explained there.75
chapter.ftnote: 1 For they would not be left leaderless.
2 He encouraged them.
3 Be strong and of good courage; for thou shalt go with this people into the land, etc.,(vs. 7,8).
4 After charging Joshua in the sight of all of Israel (v. 7).
5 While they were assembled together.
6 In Deut. 33.
7 To lead you into battle.
8 I.E.’s paraphrase of the first part of verse 3.
9 I.E.’s interpretation of and Joshua, he shall go over before thee, as the Lord hath spoken (v. 3).
10 I.E.’s interpretation of verse 4.
11 See Deut. 7:5, which literally reads: But thus shall you do unto them…dash in pieces their pillars. Hence I.E.’s comment.
12 As he did to Israel (v. 6).
13 Thus et ha-am means with this people. The word et usually indicates the accusative and is not translated. Hence I.E.’s comment.
14 To interpret the Torah.
15 The meaning of which is that the elders assisted Moses in transmitting the word of God. Similarly, here too Moses commanded the elders to assist the kohanim in teaching the Torah.

16 According to I.E. the word mi-ketz (at the end) sometimes means at the beginning. See I.E. on Deut. 15:1. I.E. interprets thus because the seventh year was to be a year of Torah study. He felt that the public reading of the Torah was not the climax of this year but the initiation of a year of Torah study.
17 The year was to be devoted to Torah.
18 Is to be devoted to Torah study.
19 The Torah being read.
20 To pass away.
22 When he took leave of and blessed Israel.
23 The tent of meeting mentioned in the previous verse. Hence the word ohel (tent) has a heh ha-yedi’ah prefixed to it.
24 The pillar of cloud.
25 The glory of God.
26 When Scripture speaks of the glory of God appearing in the tent of meeting, the reference is to the pillar of cloud. See Ex. 16:10.
27 Moses.
28 Moses uses the term “I” because he was speaking for God by God’s command.

29 According to I.E. the sequence of events was as follows: Verses 14,15; 23; 16-22; 9. The reason for the aforementioned is purely exegetical. It allows for a logical, sequential unfolding of events.
30 It follows.
31 At this point.
32 Our verse does not logically follow God’s telling Moses that He is going to charge Joshua. Hence verses 16-22 follow what is recorded in verse 23.
33 Literally, to leave God’s domain, to believe in another god.
34 God is unchangeable. God remains the same at all times.

35 Of Divine beneficence. According to I.E. praying to God does not change God’s mind. It changes the petitioner. The person changes his fate because he becomes a different person. Thus God’s decrees remain unchangeable.
36 The laws of nature, or any of His actions.

37 The Land of Israel. According to I.E. if a person follows a certain way of life, i.e., following God’s commandments, certain things will follow automatically. He also believed that God’s influence varies in accordance with the place. Hence certain laws have to be followed in the Land of Israel if the land is to maintain its sanctity and receive the amount of divine influence allotted to it. See I.E. on Gen. 4:14; 28:16. Also see Ex. 15:17.

38 The reference is to the people whom the king of Assyria brought to Samaria. They wanted to learn the manner of the God of the land because they knew that if they wanted to remain in the Land of Israel, they would have to alter their ways to fit the religious requirements of the land.
39 To his sons.
40 According to I.E., Jacob told his sons, “Now that we are in the Land of Israel put away the images which you held on to while you were outside of the Land of Israel.”

41 A person is not allowed to marry a variety of close relatives. Among these are two sisters and an aunt. However, Jacob married two sisters and Amram married his aunt. According to I.E. they did so because they were outside of the Land of Israel. See I.E. on Lev. 18:26.
42 That the Land of Israel has special spiritual significance.

43 That is, foreign people. Our verse reads, and go astray after the foreign gods of the land, whither they go to he among them. I.E. does not believe that Scripture would use the term “among them” when referring to foreign gods, for such gods do not exist, and it is impossible to come among them. Hence his interpretation.
44 The Canaanite nations.
45 In other words, the foreign gods of the land is short for “the foreign people of the gods of the land.”
46 In this case be-kirbo should be translated as “in it” or “into the midst of it” and our verse rendered, and go astray after the foreign gods of the land into the midst of which they enter.
47 Hence the word be-kirbo which is masculine, can refer to eretz. Eretz is usually feminine. Hence I.E.’s comment.
48 Nasa is masculine.
49 Netam is masculine.
50 Hebrew, ve-hayah (literally, and he shall be).
51 Hence the combination of the plural and the singular.
52 Our verse reads, haster astir (I will surely hide). Literally, hide, I will hide.
53 That it is biblical style to employ an infinitive followed by a conjugated verb.
54 Idol worship.
55 See I.E. on verse 16.
56 Kitvu (write) is in the plural. Hence I.E.’s comment.
57 Literally, that they should be proficient in it.
58 Our word should have read ve-lamdeha rather than ve-lammedah. Similarly simah should have read simeha.

59 Our verse and the next one form one unit. The verses are to be read as follows: Now…write ye this song…that this song may be a witness for Me against the children of Israel (v. 19), For when I shall have brought them into the land… The song that is being discussed in these verses is the song in the following chapter.
60 In other words, our verse is not tied to the verse that follows.

61 In this case, verse 20 opens a new thought and is tied to verse 21. The verses are to be read: For when I shall have brought them into the land…(v. 20) that this song shall testify before them (v. 21).
62 That is, testify. In other words, ve-anetah does not mean will answer but rather will testify.
63 The song will explain to all why what occurred came to pass.
64 Israel shall always have a copy of the song with them.
65 Supernaturally.
66 And on this basis can surmise how they will act in the future.
67 In committing the song to writing.
68 Hence the plural “they were finished.”
69 The Levites is short for the kohanim, the Levites.
70 I.E.’s interpretation of that bore the ark of the covenant of the Lord.
71 See Deut. 3:18.
72 You will rebel. According to I.E., ve-af ki achare moti (and how much more after my death) means, and how much more after my death will you rebel.
73 After my death you will rebel.
74 Both words are perfects which become imperfects because of the conversive vav.
75 See I.E. on Ex. 5:16 (Vol. 2, p. 123).

chapter.title: CHAPTER 32
chapter.p: 1. GIVE EAR. I have previously explained in my book1 that the word ha’azinu (give ear) is related to the word ozen (ear). Scripture, as it were, says incline your ear.2 I have previously informed you3 that the Gaon4 says that the meaning of heavens is the angels and the meaning of the earth is the people of the earth.5 On the other hand, its meaning might be that the rain that comes down from heaven and the fruit which the earth produces are called to bear witness.6 I believe that the correct interpretation is that Moses called heaven and earth to witness because they last forever.7 Similarly Hear, O ye mountains (Micah 6:2) and also Joshua’s stone.8 Scripture there writes that the stone heard. I have hinted to you that man’s soul is intermediary between the upper and lower worlds.9 The soul compares all things to its body.10 It certainly does so when speaking to other human beings.11 It therefore elevates the low and lowers the high.12
2. SHALL DROP. The word ya’arof (shall drop) is related to the word ya’arof (he will break down) in He will break down their altars (Hos. 10:2). The meaning of ya’arof (shall drop) is will come down.
MY DOCTRINE. Likchi (My doctrine) refers to that which one will take away13 from him.14 It means a lesson. Compare, lekech (doctrine) in For I give you a good doctrine (Prov. 4:2).
AS THE SMALL RAIN. I believe that se’irim (small rain) refers to light rain.15
AND AS THE SHOWERS. The word revivim (showers) is related to the word rav (numerous). They16 are adjectives. The fact that esev (herb) is stronger than deshe (tender grass) is proof of this.17

Some say that se’irim (small rain) is related to sa’ar (hair).18 Others say that it is related to the word sa’arat (storm of)19 in storm of God (Jer. 30:23) even though se’irim is spelled with a sin.20 Similarly, the phrase ve-yista’er alav (shall come against him like a whirlwind) (Dan. 11:40), which is spelled with a sin, means the same as ve-yista’er alav spelled with a samekh.21 It is also possible that the word se’irim has no brother in Scripture.22
Our verse repeats itself23 for emphasis, as is the style in all prophecies.

The essence of our verse is that Moses prayed that his words be like dew and rain which, as it is written, do not return unfulfilled24 but water the earth.25 The meaning of the latter is that Moses’ words should enter the hearts of those who hear them in the same way that the rain affects the earth and fructifies it and causes it to produce plants.

3. ASCRIBE YE GREATNESS. This is addressed to the heavens and the earth, as Scripture states, The heavens declare the glory of God (Ps. 19:2), which is to be understood in accordance with my interpretation.26 Similarly Let the heavens and earth praise Him (Ps. 69:35).
4. [THE ROCK, HIS WORK IS PERFECT.] Moses opens with this phrase to make it known that all that befell Israel did so because of their evil deeds.

The meaning of The Rock is that God, like a rock, is everlasting. Do not be amazed at this,27 for Scripture similarly states, The Lord…shall roar like a lion (Hos. 11:10).28 Scripture does this because one who speaks cannot compare God’s work to anything but His works, for everything is His work. Rock, in But God is the rock of my heart (Ps. 73:26), similarly means a support, might, and permanence.

Others say that tzur (rock) is related to the word tzurah (image). Compare, tzuram (their form) in And their form shall be for the nether-world (Ps. 49:15). Its basic meaning is that God does not consist of matter,29 which can be molded into a form.30 On the contrary, He is Primary form.31 The first interpretation appears correct to me.

HIS WORK IS PERFECT. All the works of an artisan are incomplete32 because the artisan needs the assistance of one greater than he.33 The work of God alone is perfect. Everything is a duality34 except for the creator of all.35

FOR ALL HIS WAYS ARE JUSTICE. His ways do not change.36 On the contrary, they follow one law.37 This is the praise of God.38 All those who are created change their deeds in accordance with their needs.39 God’s works40 were done for His glory,41 with might42 and wisdom.43 The standing still of the sun (Josh. 10:12)44 is no argument to the contrary because, as I explained in its place,45 its secret is clear, from the clause And thou, Moon in the valley of Aijalon (Ibid.).46

A GOD OF FAITHFULNESS AND WITHOUT INIQUITY. God alone has true might,47 for all the might of the mighty is an “accident;”48 that is, it depends on outside sources.49 The meaning of our clause is, it is not possible that God does iniquity because He is a God of faithfulness.50 It is possible that ve-en avel (and without iniquity) means and without iniquity in His ways.51 On the other hand, it is possible that the word El (God) is to be read as if written twice.52

JUST AND RIGHT IS HE. Since Scripture states shichet lo (is corruption His) (v. 5),53 it says a perverse people corrupted God’s righteousness.54 Look, God alone is right.55 The rightness of the right is to fix that which is crooked.56 The word lo (v. 5) therefore refers to what He had at first.57

5. NO; HIS CHILDREN’S IS THE BLEMISH. Lo banav (no, his children’s) means those who say that they are not his children. Scripture similarly states, Children in whom is no faithfulness (v. 20). Its meaning is that they do not admit that God created them. Although they might profess their belief verbally, they do not believe it in their hearts. The fact that they do not fear God58 is proof of their lack of belief. The lamed of lo (his) serves itself and another word along with it. It is to be prefixed to the word mumam (the blemish).59 The meaning of lemumam is, because of their blemish, their blemish consisting in being A generation crooked and perverse.60

AND PERVERSE. The meaning of u-fetaltol (and perverse) is he grows strong and triumphant in his crookedness.61 Compare the word naftule (wrestlings)62 in with mighty wrestlings (Gen. 30:8). Some say that the meaning of shichet lo (is corruption His) is, they corrupted themselves; that is, they corrupted their souls. Do not wonder that the singular lo is employed,63 for this is the style of the language. Can you not see that Scripture reads, Remember (zekhor)64 the days of old, Consider (binu)65 the years of many generations (v. 7).

I believe that shichet lo (is corruption His) means they corrupted God;66 that is, they corrupted the ways of God, which are implanted in man’s mind,67 as well as the statutes which He commanded. Scripture, as it were, says the crooked generation that is not His children corrupted Him.68 This is their blemish. The verse that follows, namely, Do you thus requite the Lord, is proof that this is its interpretation.69 I have explained the meaning of the heh70 in the book entitled Moznayim.
6. FOOLISH. In their deeds.
AND UNWISE. In heart. Look, the entire people are totally deficient in thought and deed.
THY FATHER. Scripture states this because it earlier stated that they are not His children.
THAT HATH GOTTEN THEE. Kanekha (gotten thee) is similar to kanani (made me)71 in The Lord made me (Prov. 8:22).
HE…MADE THEE. Fully developed you.72
AND ESTABLISHED THEE.73 For full development.74
7. THE DAYS OF. Yemot (days of) and yeme (days of) are two forms.75 The same is the case with shenot (years of) and shene (years of).76
OF OLD. Olam (of old) means the time that has past.
ASK THY FATHER. Scripture states this because it earlier77 said Remember. If you forgot what your fathers told you, ask them.

AND HE WILL DECLARE UNTO THEE. Ve-yaggedekha means and he will declare unto thee.78 Compare, netattani (thou hast given to me)79 in for that thou hast given to me in the Southland80 (Josh. 15:19). And yetzauni (are gone forth of me) in My children are gone forth of me (Jer. 10:20).81
THINE ELDERS. Scripture repeats itself, for it is elegant to do so.82

8. WHEN THE MOST HIGH GAVE TO THE NATIONS THEIR INHERITANCE. The commentaries83 say that the reference is to “the generation of the dispersion”84 when all the earth became inhabited.85 God at that time decreed that the land of the seven nations should belong to Israel, as this land would be large enough for them. Scripture therefore reads, According to the number of the children of Israel.86

HE SET. Some say that yatzev (he set) is an infinitive.87 Compare the word dabber (speak)88 in behold, I cannot speak (Jer. 1:6). Others say that yatzev (he set) is a verb in the imperfect,89 employed as a perfect.90 It is like the word ya’asu (they made)91 in They made a calf in Horeb (Ps. 106:19). I believe that Ask thy father alludes to those “who understand.”92 The same applies to “thy elders.”
The meaning of the portion93 of the Lord is His people94 is similar to which the Lord thy God hath allotted95 (Deut. 4:19), for every portion96 below97 has a portion98 above.99

ACCORDING TO THE NUMBER OF THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL. The rabbis, of blessed memory, say that the image of our father Jacob is engraved on the throne of glory.100 The latter is a great secret.101 For the portion of the Lord is His people is proof of this.102 This is a very great status. God did not do this for any nation. Scripture therefore states, Do ye thus requite the Lord, O foolish people and unwise? (v. 6), that is, a people who have fallen from their status in their foolishness. Now, this God is your father, for he created you for His glory,103 and as Scripture goes on to explain,104 he taught you as a father teaches his son.
9. THE LOT. Chevel (lot) means a section.105 Compare, chavalim (the lines) (Ps. 16:6). A section is so called because land is measured with a cord.106
10. HE FOUND HIM. The reference is to thy father that hath gotten thee (v. 6).107

The meaning of He found him is that God’s glory entered into the desert with them. Furthermore, they were like a person wandering in the wilderness,108 a place where no man passes,109 for so Scripture states.110 The wilderness is a waste.
A HOWLING. A place where animals such as jackals and ostriches howl, and whoever hears their voices is astonished.111
HE COMPASSED HIM ABOUT. The reference is to the clouds.112
HE CARED FOR HIM. By giving him the Torah.
HE KEPT HIM. From the enemies.
AS THE APPLE OF HIS EYE. I have previously explained the meaning of ishon (apple).113
Scripture speaks as humans do when it says His eye.114 It means that God protected them from all enemies and all that lay in wait.115
11. AS AN EAGLE THAT STIRRETH UP HER NEST. Ya’ir (stirreth up) is a transitive verb.116 It means He leads them from place to place.117

HER YOUNG. Gozalav means her young. The word gozal (a young pigeon) in and a turtle-dove, and a young pigeon (Gen. 15:9) is similar. The word gozal, along with the term efrochim (young birds), is a general term.118 It is similar to the term tzippor (bird).119
HOVERETH. When they journey.120 Yerachef (hovereth) is related to the word merachefet (hovered) (Gen. 1:2). The cloud acted similarly when Israel journeyed.121

SPREADETH ABROAD HER WINGS, TAKETH THEM.122 As an eagle takes each and every chick and bears it123 on her wing, for the chick does not have the strength to fly. This is the meaning of our verse.124 However, the meaning of how I bore you on eagles’ wings (Ex. 19:4) is connected to and brought you unto Myself (Ibid.). It means that Israel went out with a high hand125 and came quickly to Mount Sinai.126 It is similar in meaning to Who are these that fly as a cloud (Is. 60:8).

12. THE LORD ALONE DID LEAD THEM. Adonai badad (the Lord alone) means only the Lord.127 Its meaning is128 similar to At the commandment of the Lord129 they encamped, and at the commandment of the Lord130 they journeyed (Num. 9:23). God had no associate. It is possible that the word badad (alone) refers to Israel.131 Compare, Lo, it is a people that shall dwell alone (Num. 23:9).
AND THERE WAS NO STRANGE GOD WITH HIM. With Israel.132 They roused Him to jealousy with strange gods (v. 16) is proof that this interpretation is correct.133
13. HE MADE HIM RIDE ON THE HIGH PLACES OF THE EARTH. The land of Canaan, which is in the center of the inhabited world. He made him ride is metaphorical.

The reading of the word bamote (high places) does not change because of the vav.134 It is related to the word bamotemo135 (their high places) (Deut. 33:29). The word bemotav136 (with…his tomb) in the wicked137…with…his tomb (Is. 53:9) is not related to our word.
FRUITAGE. The word tenuvot (fruitage) means fruit. It is related to the word yanuv (increase) in If riches increase (Ps. 62:11).

FIELD. Sadai (field) is an adjective.138 It follows the paradigm of chakham (wise).139 The yod of sadai is in place of a heh.140 It is similar to the vav of shalev141 (at ease) in I was at ease (Job 16:12). The clause ya’aloz sadai (let the field exult) (Ps. 96:12) wherein ya’aloz is in the singular proves this.142

AND HE MADE HIM TO SUCK HONEY OUT OF THE CRAG. This is a metaphor. It is like That the mountains shall drop down sweet wine143 (Joel 4:18). The reference is to the abundance of honey and oil which, as is clearly stated in Scripture,144 were exported from the land of Canaan

OUT OF THE FLINTY ROCK. The lamed in chalmish (flinty) has no dagesh145 because the word is in the construct. Me-chalmish tzur (out of the flinty rock) is the reverse of mi-tzur ha-challamish (out of the rock of flint) (Deut. 8:15).146 The same is true of charvot tzurim (knives of flint) and tzur charbo (his sword of flint)147 (Ps. 89:44).
14. CURD OF KINE. An abundance of meat.148

AND MILK OF SHEEP, WITH FAT OF LAMBS. Were it not for tradition149 then this verse150 would serve to support my opinion regarding the fat151 which I mentioned in its place.152 On the other hand, fat in with fat of lambs means the fleshy and the good.153 Compare, All the best (chelev)154 of the oil (Num. 18:12).155
OF THE BREED OF BASHAN. Who were raised in the mountain of the Bashan.
WITH THE KIDNEY-FAT OF WHEAT. This156 is metaphorical,157 for the fat lies on the kidneys.158 The kernel of wheat also159 looks like a kidney.

AND OF THE BLOOD OF THE GRAPE. The wine. The Land of Israel thus contains an abundance of honey, oil, meat, bread, wine, and all sorts of fruit. This is the meaning of the fruitage of the field (v. 13). Some say that honey refers to date honey.160
FOAMING WINE. The word chamer (foaming wine) means wine. Compare, kerem chemed (a vineyard of foaming wine) (Is. 27:2).

[THOU DRANKEST FOAMING WINE.]161 The tav of the word tishteh (thou drinkest) is a second person162 prefix. Our verse, as it were, speaks like a person who tells his friend the land has so much wine that you will drink it at all times.

Some say that enav (grape) is in the feminine.163 However, what they say is worthless, for the tav164 should have been vocalized with a pattach165 so that it would be a causative. Some say that tishteh166 speaks of the community,167 for the word Israel is sometimes in the masculine and sometimes in the feminine. This interpretation is a bit closer to the correct meaning.

[15.] BUT JESHURUN WAXED FAT. Jeshurun refers to Israel. It is possible that the name Jeshurun is related to the word yashar (upright). Its meaning is, the one who was upright became fat. Some say that the word Jeshurun is related to the word ashurennu168 (I behold him) (Num. 23:9).169 The first interpretation appears “upright” in my eyes. The fact that Jeshurun is in the singular170 is proof of this.171
AND KICKED. The word va-yivat (and kicked) is similar to tivatu (kick ye) in Wherefore kick ye (I Sam. 2:29). Its meaning is to be ascertained from its context.172
THOU DIDST WAX FAT. It did not enter their minds to take stock of themselves.173
THOU DIDST GROW THICK. The word avita (thou didst grow thick) is similar to the word avah (thicker) in My little finger is thicker (I Kings 12:10).

THOU DIDST BECOME GROSS. Some say that kasita174 (thou didst grow thick) is similar to kissah175 (he hath covered) in he hath covered his face with his fatness (Job 15:27),176 for the word is found in the kal conjugation.177 Others say that kasita is similar to ke-seh (like…a sheep) in I have gone astray like a lost sheep (Ps. 119:176).178 We do not find such a construction in any of the verbs.179 It appears to me the word kasita has no brother.180 Its meaning is, you kicked.
AND HE FORSOOK. The commandments of his God.

AND CONTEMNED. In mind and verbally. Its correct meaning is that Israel profaned the name of the Lord for not saving him. He caused this to be.181 Scripture therefore continues, the Rock of his salvation, which is to be understood as The Rock, His work is perfect (v. 4).182
16. THEY ROUSED HIM. In their thoughts.183 Compare, and now nothing will he withheld from them (Gen. 11:6).184
WITH STRANGE GODS. Be-zarim is to be interpreted as with strange gods.185
WITH ABOMINATIONS. The reference is to idols.

17. DEMONS. Shedim (demons) has the same meaning as se’irim (satyrs) in the satyrs after whom they go astray (Lev. 17:7).186 Therefore Rabbi Isaac the son of Saul187 who rests in Eden says that the word se’arum (dreaded) in Which your fathers dreaded not188 is related to the word se’irim.189

The lamed of la-shedim (unto demons) pertains to shedim and also to another word.190 La-shedim lo eloha (unto demons, no-gods) is to be read as if written la-shedim u-le-lo eloha (unto demons and unto no-gods).191 I believe that there is no need for this interpretation. On the contrary, the meaning of la-shedim lo eloha is clearly, unto demons who are no-gods. They are called shedim in the same way that the Emim are called Emim.192 They are called shedim because they destroy reason.193

GODS THAT THEY KNEW NOT. How could Israel think that these gods were deities when they did not know these gods by proof.194 This is the meaning of they knew not. Neither did they know them by tradition. This is what Which your fathers dreaded not refers to.
NEW GODS THAT CAME UP OF LATE. A few days ago. They are not ancient. Even their fathers did not know them.

DREADED. Se’arum means they were not in dread of them. Se’arum is related to the word ve-yista’er (shall come like a whirlwind) in shall come against him like a whirlwind (Dan. 11:40). It is similar in meaning to sa’ar in That made the hair (sa’arat)195 of my flesh to stand up (Job 4:15).196 However, it appears that se’arum is related to the word sa’arah (storm) even though the latter is spelled with a samekh.197

Se’arum is similar to yetza’uni (are gone forth of me)198 in My children are gone forth of me (Jer. 10:20) and in chazaktani199 (Thou hast overcome me) in Thou hast overcome me, and hast prevailed (Jer. 20:7); that is, you are more powerful than me.200 Look, the meaning of se’arum is, they were not afraid of them.

18. OF THE ROCK THAT BEGOT THEE THOU WAST UNMINDFUL. These are the words of the prophet.201 He wonders: How did you forget the One who begot you? You served new gods. Also, this clause,202 the rock that begot thee, is similar to Look unto the rock whence ye were hewn (Is. 51:1). Israel, as it were, came from God, for everything comes from God’s might.203 Compare, That spread the earth by Myself (Is. 44:24). One must be amazed by those who err in their hearts204 because Scripture states, This day have I begotten thee (Ps. 2:7).205 They have forgotten this verse.206

[THOU WAST UNMINDFUL.] The word teshi (thou wast unmindful) is related to the word tinnasheh (you will forget)207 in [the clause] you shall not forget.208 The missing silent letter following the tav209 is in place of the omitted dagesh which compensates for the first root letter, 210 and the yod is in place of the heh. Compare the word temchi (blot out)211 in Neither blot out their sin (Jer. 18:23). Both words212 are accented penultimately in order to show a difference between the masculine and the feminine in verbs whose last letter is a silent heh.213 However, it appears to me that the yod214 is superfluous.215 It follows the same rule as tet (decline)216 does in neither decline (Prov. 4:5).

THAT BORE THEE. Mecholelekha means that bore thee. Observe, God who is powerful and mighty as a rock [gave birth to you]. It is possible that the word mecholelekha is related to the word chil (pain), as in Like as a woman with child, that draweth near the time of her delivery, Is in pain (tachil) (Is. 26:17).
[19. AND SPURNED.]217 Scripture similarly writes, veyanetz ha-shaked (And the almond-tree shall blossom) (Eccles. 12:5).218 On the other hand, it might be an intransitive verb.219
HIS SONS AND HIS DAUGHTERS. Men and women, for they too 220 sacrificed to the idols.
20. AND HE SAID. God in His heart or to the angels.
I WILL HIDE MY FACE. Scripture speaks as people do.221 Similarly I will hide Mine eyes from you (Is. 1:15). It means222 that when they search for Me they will not find help.

I WILL SEE WHAT THEIR END WILL BE. Some say that our verse is to be interpreted, I will hide My face from them because I see what they will ultimately do.223 However, it is to be understood according to its literal meaning, that is, [so that] I will see what they will do when trouble comes upon them.224
FOR THEY ARE A VERY FROWARD GENERATION. This is connected to I will hide My face.225

FROWARD.226 They turned about and served gods besides Me. They were My children, for I gave birth to them. Look, there is no faithfulness in them. The word emun (faithfulness) is a noun. On the other hand, it might be an adjective227 meaning there is no faithful man among them, for we find for the faithful fail (Ps. 12:2)228 in which faithful is parallel to godly (Ibid.).229 We also find that keepeth faithfulness (emunim) (Is. 26:2).230
21. THEY HAVE ROUSED ME. The second root letter231 has no dagesh in order to simplify enunciation.
WITH A NO-GOD. Its meaning is, a god that has no power to deliver.232
WITH THEIR VANITIES. Rather than with something which truly exists.
I WILL ROUSE THEM. Akni’em (I will rouse them) is a hifil. It describes two actions.233

WITH A NO-PEOPLE. A nation who are not My people. Scripture describes how God shall anger them.234 He will bring upon Israel, upon Israel alone, unique troubles which surpass the adversity that he brought upon all others.
A VILE NATION. For a fool and a vile person lack understanding. He therefore kills and has no pity.

22. KINDLED. Their provocation, or that which they did,235 for we find the word kadechah (kindled) to be transitive, as in For ye have kindled (kedachtem) a fire in My nostril (Jer. 17:4). It is possible that kadechah means is kindled.236 It is like the word chaveru237 (came as allies) (Gen. 14:3), the meaning of which is gathered. All of this238 refers to God’s burning anger.
UNTO THE DEPTHS OF THE NETHER-WORLD. Its meaning is similar to that of and that the whole land thereof is brimstone, and salt, and a burning (Deut. 29:22).
AND DEVOURETH. Israel.
AND SETTETH ABLAZE. Va-telahet (and setteth ablaze)239 is related to the word lahat (flaming) in and the flaming sword (Gen. 3:24).
THE MOUNTAINS. The mountains of Israel.

23. I WILL HEAP. Some say that the word aspeh (I will heap) means I will add. However, it really means I will consume.240 Compare, tispeh (sweep away) in Wilt Thou indeed sweep away (Gen. 18:23). The aforementioned is so, even though aspeh and tispeh differ in conjugation.241 It means242 that there will be no evil that will not come upon them.243 Scripture244 compares the evils to arrows that suddenly appear and there is no way to guard oneself against them.245
24. THE WASTING OF HUNGER. Meze ra’av (the wasting of hunger) means burnt by hunger. Meze (wasting) is similar to le-meze (that they should heat) in that they should heat the furnace (Dan. 3:19).
AND THE DEVOURING OF THE FIERY BOLT. Le-chume reshef (the devouring of the fiery bolt) means consumed246 by birds.247 Compare, As the birds (bene reshef)248 fly upward (Job 5:7).249

It appears to me that Scripture mentions the four evil punishments. They are: starvation, which is what The wasting of hunger refers to; and the devouring of the fiery bolt, And bitter destruction refers to the plague; And the teeth of beasts will I send upon them refers to the beast: and finally [there is] the sword, as in Without shall the sword bereave (v. 25).
Reshef (the fiery bolt) is thus similar to reshfeha rishpe esh (The flashes thereof are flashes of fire) (Cant. 8:6).250 It means that the air will grow hot.251
AND …DESTRUCTION. Ketev means destruction.

BITTER. Meriri (bitter) refers to bitterness in the air. Compare, ke-meriri yom (like the bitterness of the day) (Job 3:5).252 Scripture similarly writes, Nor of the destruction (ketev) that wasteth at noonday (Ps. 91:6). The latter refers to the plague.
The word u-lechume in u-lechume reshef (and the devouring of the fiery bolt) means devoured by. There are many such instances.253
WITH THE VENOM OF CRAWLING THINGS OF THE DUST. The reference is to being bitten. Venom254 refers to being bitten.
[DUST.] This refers to fiery snakes.255

Zochale (crawling) is related to the word fear.256 They are called zochale because all who see them are afraid of them.257 It is similar to the term emim.258 This is so because there are adjectives [without nouns].259 Its counterpart260 is found in the speech of Elihu the son of Barachel (Job 32:6).

25. BOTH YOUNG MAN. This261 is connected to Without shall the sword bereave.262 Scripture reads gam (both)263 in accordance with the rules of the Hebrew language, as I have previously explained.264 Look, the Torah includes265 all: young men, virgins, old men, and youths.

[26.] I WOULD MAKE AN END OF THEM. Some say that the word afehem (I would make an end of them) is a combination of three words.266 Actually, it has no neighbor.267 Its meaning is, I will destroy them, for Scripture states afterwards, I would make their memory cease from among men. Look, all of them will die.268 If the grammarians269 who say that afehem means I will scatter them to all the corners are right,270 then the idea expressed by the first part of the verse is not to be connected to that of the second.271

Some say that the meaning of afehem is, I will destroy them in my anger.272 Behold, the meaning of afehem is,273 I will destroy them.274 Afehem is similar in meaning to ashbitah (I would make…cease). Scripture repeats itself.275 This interpretation276 would be correct were it not for the alef of afehem,277 for the word should have read anfehem,278 meaning I will be angry at them. The first interpretation279 is correct.
[I THOUGHT.] The meaning of amarti (I thought) is, I said to Myself. The Torah speaks as people do.

27. I DREADED. Agur means I dreaded. It is related to the word va-yagar (was sore afraid) in And Moab was sore afraid (Num. 22:3). The Aramaic translation connects it to the word agerah (gathereth) in And gatherest…in the harvest (Prov. 6:8).280 Actually it is related to the word tigrah (fight).281 Scripture speaks as people do so that those who hear will understand.282

SHOULD MISDEEM. Yenakkeru (misdeem)283 is the reverse of yakkiru284 (they shall recognize).285 Yenakkeru is similar286 to va-yitnakker287 (but made himself strange) in but made himself strange unto them (Gen. 42:7).
HATH WROUGHT ALL THIS. Upon the tribes.288
28. FOR THEY ARE A NATION VOID OF COUNSEL. The reference is to the enemies of Israel. This is its correct interpretation.289

The word ovad (void) is an adjective.290 It is in the construct.291 It is therefore vocalized with a pattach beneath the bet.292 It is known that the word ovad is an intransitive verb.293 The correct interpretation of ovad etzot is that etzot (counsel) reverts to ovad (void).294 It is similar to novelet aleha (whose leaf fadeth)295 (Is. 1:30). The same is true of ve-tovedu derekh (and ye perish in the way) (Ps. 2:12)296 wherein tovedu is connected to derekh. The Aramaic translator who rendered ovad etzot as me’abbede etzah (void of counsel) understood this.

29. IF THEY WERE WISE. If they were wise and understood that God did all of this to Israel because of all their sins, they would comprehend their eventual end, namely, that God would do so297 because of their sins.298

30. HOW SHOULD ONE CHASE. If Israel was wise299 they would understand how one of their enemies could pursue a thousand Israelites. This occurred only because their Rock has forsaken them. Others interpret our verse as how did Israel, who are now weak, at first pursue a thousand of their enemies.300

EXCEPT THEIR ROCK HAD GIVEN THEM OVER. Mekharam means had given them over.301 The same applies to yimkor (will give over) in for the Lord will give Sisera over (Jud. 4:9). Its meaning is that God, as it were, gave them over as in payment302 for their deeds. It is thus a literal sale.303

HAD DELIVERED THEM UP. Hisgiram (had delivered them up) is similar to yisgor (shutteth up) in, He shutteth up a man (Job 12:14).304 On the other hand, it might be similar to hasgiro (deliver him up) in and our part shall be to deliver him up (I Sam. 23:20).

31. FOR THEIR ROCK IS NOT AS OUR ROCK. These are the words of Moses.305 Moses explains for they306 are a nation void of counsel (v. 28). It means that our Rock307 has handed us over, and the nations have no rock like our Rock, and they are no better than we308 are.309 Scripture similarly states, and our enemies are not judges.310 Compare, And I have not learned wisdom (Prov. 30:3).311

Others say that the meaning of Even our enemies themselves being judges is as follows: our enemies admit this.312 It is therefore not connected to313 For their vine is of the vine of Sodom (v. 32).314
[32.] AND OF THE FIELDS OF GOMORRAH. Scripture repeats itself.315 The same is true of Their clusters are bitter.316
33. THE VENOM OF. Look, the wine317 is like the venom of angry serpents.318

AND THE CRUEL POISON OF ASPS. Petanim (asps) is similar to the word paten (asp) in on the hole of the asp (Is. 11:8). Even though rosh (poison) is spelled with an alef, it has the same meaning as its counterparts which are spelled with a vav.319
CRUEL. Akhzar (cruel) means mighty.320 The alef is superfluous,321 like the alef of etzba (finger)322 and ezro’a (arm).323

34. IS NOT THIS LAID UP IN STORE WITH ME. These are the words of God. Some say the reference is to the decrees.324 It appears to me that the reference is to their wine, which is the poison of asps. It is laid in store325 until they drink it.326
The meaning of the word kamus (laid up in store) is to be ascertained from its context, for it has no family.327
SEALED UP IN MY TREASURIES. So that no hand touches it. It is kept for them,328 for vengeance is to be exacted from them.

35. VENGEANCE IS MINE, AND RECOMPENSE. Shillem (recompense) is a noun.329 It is like the word kitter (offering)330 in The offering…did not (Jer. 44:21). It means331 that Vengeance is mine, and mine is the recompense to compensate them in accordance with their deeds.
AGAINST THE TIME WHEN THEIR FOOT SHALL SLIP. It means332 they will fall and be unable to stand.
The meaning of Against the time is similar to that of Yea, even the wicked for the day of evil (Prov. 16:4). It is a great secret.333
FOR THE DAY OF THEIR CALAMITY IS AT HAND. Let them not think that the vengeance will be exacted from their children.334

AND THE THINGS THAT ARE TO COME UPON THEM SHALL MAKE HASTE. Ve-chash atidot lamo (and the things that are to come upon them shall make haste) means each one of the future events that are to come upon them shall make haste.335 It is like Its branches (banot)336 run (tza’adah)337 over the wall (Gen. 49:22).338 Or the meaning of ve-chash atidot lamo is, the day (yom)339 when the future things that are to come upon them makes haste.340 The first interpretation is correct.
The word chash (make haste) comes from a root in which only two letters are present.341
The meaning of the things that are to come is, the evil things that are about to come.
36. FOR THE LORD WILL JUDGE HIS PEOPLE. God will exact judgment from Israel’s enemies on behalf of His people. It is like Be Thou my judge, O God, and plead my cause (Ps. 43:1).342
AND REPENT HIMSELF. I have previously explained this.343

THEIR STAY IS GONE. The stay of Israel. Yad (stay) means the strength. The tav of azelat is in place of a heh,344 for both the heh and the tav are signs of the feminine. The word ve-shavat345 (then it shall return) in then it shall return to the prince is similar (Ezek. 46:17).
AND THERE IS NONE REMAINING, SHUT UP OR LEFT AT LARGE. When the captives are numerous, the captors take some of them and leave others, but in this case almost all are lost.346
37. AND IT IS SAID.347 And the enemy shall say.
THE ROCK IN WHOM THEY TRUSTED. This is to be understood in accordance with my previous interpretation.348

38. WHO DID EAT. Scripture employs the language of the enemies349 who thought that the burnt offerings serve as food for God. Scripture employs the plural as they do.350 The Torah therefore states, I, only I, am He, And there is no god with Me (v. 39).

THE WINE OF THEIR DRINK-OFFERING. Yen nesikham351 (the wine of their drink-offering) is similar to venisko352 yayin (and the drink-offering thereof shall be of wine) (Lev. 23:13). They are two terms.353

Some say that yen nesikham (the wine of their drink-offering) means the wine of their king,354 for the kings used to donate the wine for the burnt offering. Compare, nesikhe midian (the princes of Midian) (Josh. 13:21).355 The first interpretation appears correct to me.
AND HELP YOU. Ve-yazrukhem (and help you) is similar to berakhnukhem (we bless you) (Ps. 119:26).356
If you357 say that the Lord alone is God358 then let Him359 protect you from the coming troubles.360

39. I, EVEN I.361 The word I is written twice.362 Compare, I, even I363 (Is. 51:12). On the other hand, its364 meaning might be, I am He, and I do not change.365 The latter is the correct interpretation, for God has no co-worker.366 I am He that put Israel to death, and I will bring them back to life. Look, they were not saved.367 There is none that can deliver you out of My hand, even you out of My hand,368 until I execute My judgment upon you.

Many say that we can derive the existence of life in the future world from this verse.369 They offer proof from the fact that Scripture first states, I kill and then, I make alive.370 It similarly reads, The Lord killeth, and maketh alive (I Sam. 2:6). He bringeth down to the grave, and bringeth up (Ibid.) is proof.371

Others offer proof372 from: And surely your blood of your lives (nafshotekhem)373 will I require (Gen. 9:5).374 Also from And it shall be righteousness unto us (Deut. 6:25);375 for that is thy life (Deut. 30:20) in the world to come,376 and the length of thy days (Ibid.) in this world;377 that it may go well with thee (Deut. 5:16).378
Rabbi Hai Gaon, of blessed memory, says that Scripture had no need to state clearly that a future world exists because it was known by tradition.

I believe that [Scripture does not speak of a future world] because the Torah was given to all. It was not given to an individual alone. The topic of the world to come is not comprehended by even one in a thousand, for it is very abstruse. The reward in the world to come is contingent on the nature of the soul.379 The reward380 is given for the service of the heart.381 The latter consists in comprehending the works of God,382 for they are the ladder whereon one ascends to the level of understanding the knowledge of God, which is what is most important. Observe, the Torah itself explains to the intelligent the topic of the tree of life.383 Behold, there is a power by which one can overcome the cherubim.384 The one who eats from the tree of life385 gains eternal life like the ministering angels.

The psalm of the sons of Korah similarly reads, Hear this, all ye peoples…(Ps. 49:2).386 The secret387 is But God will redeem my soul from the power of the nether-world; For He shall receive (take) me. Selah (Ps. 49:16).388 Scripture similarly states, And afterward receive (take) me with glory (Ps. 73:24). Both verses employ the word “taking” as Scripture does in the account of Enoch389 and Elijah.390 Now, since Scripture states, But God will redeem my soul [from the power of the netherworld] (Ps. 49:16), how could it say, For too costly is the redemption of their soul (Ps. 49:9)?391 The intelligent will understand.392
40. FOR I LIFT UP MY HAND TO HEAVEN. An oath taken over something which is everlasting.393

For I lift is similar to when he lifted up his right hand and his left hand unto heaven and swore by Him that liveth for ever (Dan. 12:7). The term I lift up is an anthropomorphism394 so those who hear will understand.
AS I LIVE FOR EVER. As I live so will I do this.

41. IF I WHET. Shannoti (I whet) comes from a double root.395 Compare, channoti396 (I am loathsome) in And I am loathsome to the children of my tribe (Job 19:17). Shannoti is related397 to the word shanun (sharp) in and a sharp arrow (Prov. 25:18).
AND MY HAND TAKE HOLD ON JUDGMENT. The sword is the instrument by which the warrior executes judgment.398
I WILL RENDER VENGEANCE TO MINE ADVERSARIES. The meaning of ashiv (I will render) is, I will do to Mine adversaries as they did to Israel. This is also the meaning of And will recompense (ashallem).
[42.] WITH THE BLOOD OF THE SLAIN. This explains I will make Mine arrows drunk.399
[THE CAPTIVES.] It means the wounded.400
FROM THE…HEADS. This explains shall devour flesh. It means that the head shall be chopped off.401
LONG-HAIRED. The word parot (long-haired) is similar to bi-fero’a pera’ot (When men let grow their hair) (Jud. 5:2).402 The rabbis also employ the term ha-nifra (one who collects).403

43. SING ALOUD, O YE NATIONS. Then, when God avenges Israel’s blood, the nations will praise Him.404 Some say that the meaning of harninu (sing aloud) is similar to the word rinnah (cry) in And there went a cry (I Kings 22:36). It means the herald.405 Proclaim about them in every place where they are.406

AND DOTH MAKE EXPIATION FOR THE LAND OF HIS PEOPLE. Some say that a vav407 is missing.408 Our verse should be interpreted as if written ve-khipper admato ve-ammo (and doth make expiation for His land and for His people). According to the midrash409 the meaning of ve-khipper admato ammo (and doth make expiation for His land of His people) is that the land makes expiation for His people.410 This interpretation is true in itself.411 However, it is not the meaning of the verse.412 Furthermore, the word adamah (land) is a feminine.413 The heh at its end414 is proof of this. The tav415 takes the place of the heh.416 Now, Scripture does not read vekhipperah (and doth make expiation).417

In my opinion the meaning of our clause is that the people will make expiation for the land,418 for we find Scripture stating, avanim shachaku mayim (The waters wear the stones) (Job 14:19).419 The word kippur (expiate) is also found without the word al (for),420 as in ve-khippartahu (and make atonement for it)421 in, thus shalt thou purify it and make atonement for it (Ezek. 43:20). The meaning of ve-khipper admato ammo is that Israel will execute vengeance upon the nations and they will make atonement for the Land of Israel because of the blood that was shed in it. Compare, and no expiation can be made for the land [for the blood that is shed therein, but by the blood of him that shed it] (Num. 35:33). This interpretation is in keeping with the meaning of the context.422 On the other hand, the meaning of ve-khipper (and doth make expiation) is, and will purify, as in ve-khippartahu (and make atonement for it) (Ezek. 43:20). Ezekiel similarly said, regarding the end of the wars,423 Thus shall they cleanse the land (Ezek. 39:16). Israel will thus purify the land.424

44. AND MOSES CAME. Our verse teaches that after Moses went to each one of the tribes and charged them,425 when he came to the tent of meeting and all of the children of Israel were gathered unto him, he spoke the words of this song.426

HE, AND HOSHEA THE SON OF NUN. This is similar to Then sang Moses and the children of Israel (Ex. 15:1).427 Also, this428 was done to exalt the status of Joshua in the eyes of all. Scripture refers to Joshua by the name of Hoshea because it was the name by which he was known to all of Israel, for who aside from the elect of the assembly knew that Moses referred to Hoshea by the name of Joshua. The approach of the midrash429 is known.430
47. BECAUSE IT IS YOUR LIFE. Its meaning is similar to that of The fear of the Lord prolongeth days (Prov. 10:27). Furthermore, you shall be in a good land and not in exile.
48. THAT SELFSAME DAY. The day that he delivered the song.431

50. AND DIE. To prepare himself for death, for Moses, as I will explain, was to bury himself.432 I have hinted earlier what one of the wise men of the generation said regarding the word va-ye’asef (and was gathered) (Gen. 25:8).433
51. BECAUSE YE SANCTIFIED ME NOT. I have previously explained this.434
[52.] THE LAND. This explains thither.435
chapter.ftnote: 1 The Moznayim (Weiser).
2 I.e., pay attention.
3 See I.E. on Deut. 3:24. However, I.E. does not there mention Rabbi Saadiah Gaon by name.
4 Rabbi Saadiah Gaon.
5 Rabbi Saadiah Gaon renders our verse: Give ear, O inhabitants of heaven, and I will speak, And let the people of the earth hear the words of my mouth.

6 See Rashi: “If Israel will act worthily, the witnesses will come and give them their reward…the ground will give its increase, the heavens will bestow its dew.” Rashi’s interpretation is based on the Sifre.
7 In other words, heaven and earth do not refer to angels and people, or rain and the produce of the earth.
8 See Josh. 24:27: And Joshua said…‘Behold, this stone shall be a witness…for it hath heard all the words of the Lord…’
9 Man’s soul comes from the middle world. See I.E. on Ex. 19:20 (Vol. 2, p. 338). For the upper, middle, and lower worlds, see I.E. on Ex. 3:15 (Vol. 2, pp. 86-90).
10 Literally, its palace. The body serves as a “palace” for the soul. The mind explains reality by employing figures of speech based on the body. For example, the earth opened her mouth, etc.
11 Literally, other inhabitants of the palace.

12 See I.E. on Gen. 1:26 (Vol. 1, p. 45). “Now a human being cannot speak of things above or below without employing human terminology. Hence Scripture uses such terms as the mouth of the earth (Num. 16:30), the hand of the Jordan (Num. 13:29).” Also see I.E. on Ex. 19:20 (Vol. 2, pp. 388,389).
13 The word lakach means took. The noun lekech thus means a taking.
14 Learn from Moses.
15 For it stands in contrast to revivim (showers), which refers to a heavy rain.
16 Se’irim (small rain) and revivim (showers).
17 That se’irim (small rain) refers to light rain and revivim (showers) to a heavy rain, for Scripture speaks of se’irim falling on deshe and revivim on esev.
18 It refers to raindrops as thin as hair.
19 In this case, se’irim (small rain) means a rainstorm.
20 And sa’arah (storm) with a samekh.
21 The word for storm is usually spelled with a samekh.
22 Its meaning is to be ascertained from its context.
23 My speech…repeats My doctrine…; As the small rain…repeats And the showers…
26 Those who study astronomy realize how great God is. It is in the latter sense that the heavens declare God’s glory. See I.E. on Ps. 19:2.
27 That Scripture compares God to a rock.
28 We thus see that Scripture compares God to mundane objects.
29 Hebrew, etzem.
30 According to medieval philosophy everything on earth consists of matter and form.
31 He does not consist of matter. According to this interpretation our clause should be rendered, The Primary form, for all His ways are justice.
32 A human being’s work is not perfect.
33 The work of an artisan or an author can always be improved upon. Furthermore, most artisans need assistance. Hence what they alone produce can never be perfect.
34 Matter and form. Some versions read, everything is in flux.
35 God does not consist of matter and form.
36 The laws of nature are unchangeable.
37 They are eternal.
38 That God’s works are unchangeable. This is what Moses means by ascribe ye greatness unto our God (v. 3).
39 People change their behavior in accordance with their needs. However, God is unchangeable.
40 The working of the universe. See Chapter 12 of the Yesod Mora.
41 The world reflects God’s glory. See Ps. 19:1, The heavens declare the glory of God.

42 Some editions read: God’s works alone were done in might. Creation was a mighty act. Compare the blessing recited upon hearing thunder: “Whose might and power fill the world.” Also see Ps. 29:1, Ascribe unto the Lord glory and strength.
43 Hence they are unchanging. See Job 12:13, With Him is wisdom and might. Some editions read: God’s works alone were done in might in accordance with wisdom.
44 Which appears to have entailed a suspension of the laws of nature.
45 I.E.’s commentary on the Book of Joshua is no longer extant.

46 See Ralbag on Josh. 10:12. Ralbag was bothered by the issue raised by I.E. According to Ralbag the meaning of Josh. 10:12 is, may Israel defeat its enemies while the sun is still over Gibeon and the moon over the valley of Aijalon. Perhaps I.E. interpreted similarly.
47 The term used for God in our clause is El. El means mighty. (See I.E. on Ex. 3:15). Hence I.E.’s comment on God’s might.
