382 The reference appears to be to the sciences. “Man’s soul is unique. When given by God, it is like a tablet set before a scribe. When God’s writing, which consists of the categorical knowledge of the things made out of the four elements, the knowledge of the spheres, the throne of glory, the secret of the chariot, and the knowledge of the Most High, is inscribed on this tablet the soul cleaves to God the Glorious while it is yet in man and also afterward when its power is removed from the body.” (Yesod Mora, Chapter 10, p. 143. See also Chapter 7, p. 107, “The intelligent person will…study the scienees…he will isolate himself for the purpose of studying and meditating upon God’s law and observing the Lord’s precepts…God’s right hand of bliss will be eternally upon his soul when it separates from the body.”
383 The tree of life alludes to eternal life. See I.E. on Gen. 3:24 (Vol. 1, p. 78). Also see previous note.
384 Which prevent man from reaching the tree of life. See Gen. 3:24. According to I.E. the cherubim symbolize the distractions (e.g., lust, materialism) which prevent man from developing His soul.
385 The person who acquires wisdom and develops his soul.
386 And goes on to speak of the future world.
387 To this psalm.
388 In other words, this psalm teaches that there is a future world. I.E. makes this same point in his commentary on Psalms.
389 See Gen. 5:24.
390 II Kings 2:2-10.
391 This verse implies that there is no future world.
392 That Ps. 49:9 applies to physical death and Ps. 49:16 to deliverance from spiritual extinction (Weiser). See I.E. on Ps. 49:16.
393 I lift my hand to heaven means I take an oath. See Nahmanides, “Whoever takes an oath, raises his hand and touches the object by which he swears” (Chevel translation).
394 For God has no hand.
395 Its root is shin, nun, nun.
396 From the root chet, nun, nun. Both words are similarly conjugated.
397 Has a similar meaning.
398 The meaning of our clause is, I will execute judgment with the sword which is in my hand.
399 With the blood of the slain is the conclusion of will make Mine arrows drunk even though it does not directly follow it.
400 The blood of the wounded captives.
401 From the…heads of the enemy concludes with And My sword shall devour flesh. In other words, And My sword shall devour flesh means my sword shall decapitate the enemy.

402 These words come from the same root, peh, resh, ayin. We do not have I.E.’s commentary on Judges so we do not know how I.E. rendered the verse quoted. However, Radak, who tends to follow I.E., renders it, to take revenge.
403 Or takes vengeance. Compare Bava Metziah 2:2, mi she-para (He who punished). See Jastrow, para: to tear, destroy, loosen, and disarrange.

404 When Israel suffered, the nations said, Where are their gods, The rock in whom they trusted (v. 37). However, now that God has revealed His might, they will praise Him. It should be noted that I.E. renders our clause, “Sing aloud, O ye nations,” because of what He did for His people.
405 According to I.E., I Kings 22:36 should be rendered, and there went a herald (proclaiming). See Radak.
406 That God avenges the blessed of His servants. According to I.E. our clause should be rendered: “Proclaim, O you nations,” concerning His people.
407 A connective vav.
408 From the word ammo (his people).
409 Ketuvot 111a. Rabbi Anan says: “Whoever is buried in the Land of Israel is considered to be buried beneath the altar.”
410 According to this interpretation ve-khipper does not refer to God but to admato (His land).

411 The Land of Israel will atone for Israel’s sins. See I.E. on Gen. 23:19 (Vol. 1, p. 232): “Scripture tells of the purchase of the field of Machpelah to teach us of the superiority of the Land of Israel over all the countries, both for the living and the dead.”
412 The verse serves as a means by which to transmit the idea. See I.E. on Gen. 1:26 (Vol. 1, p. 47).
413 Ve-khipper is a masculine. Hence it can not govern admato.
414 At the end of the word adamah. Adamah is the absolute form of the word admato.
415 In admato.
416 Of adamah.
417 A feminine. If ve-khipper governed admato as the midrash says, then our verse would read, ve-khipperah admato.
418 In other words, ve-khipper governs admato. Our verse should be interpreted as if written, ve-khipper ammo admato.

419 Avanim shachaku mayim (the waters wear the stones) literally reads, the stones wear the waters. This makes no sense. Hence we must rearrange the words in order to interpret the clause and interpret it as if written, mayim shachaku avanim. Similarly in our verse.

420 Our verse reads, ve-khipper admato. This literally means and doth make expiation His land. This makes no sense. Our clause should read, ve-khipper al admato (and make expiation for his land). Hence I.E.’s comment.

421 Ve-khippartahu is a combination of ve-khipparta oto (literally, and you shall make atonement it). Scripture should have read, ve-khipparta alav (and you shall make atonement for it). We thus see that Scripture sometimes leaves out the word al. It assumes that the reader will supply it.
422 Which speaks of executing justice upon the nations.
423 Waged by Gog against Israel.
424 From the impurities of the nations (Krinsky). Or purify it by avenging the innocent blood shed by the heathens (Cohen).
425 See Deut. 31:1.

426 In other words, and Moses came means and Moses came to the tent of meeting where all of Israel were gathered. This took place after he had visited each tribe separately and told them that he was about to die.
427 See I.E. on Ex. 15:1 (Vol. 2, p. 291): “Moses composed this song by himself. He then taught it to all of Israel, each of whom then sang.” Similarly here, Joshua repeated the words of Moses.
428 Like the laying of Moses’ hands upon Joshua. See Num. 27:18 and I.E.’s comment on verse 20 (Vol. 4, p. 228).
429 The Sifre.
430 See Rashi: “Why does Scripture refer to him as Hoshea? To teach us that Joshua did not become arrogant, for although greatness was given to him, he remained humble.”
432 See Deut. 34:6.
433 See I.E. on Gen. 25:8 (Vol. 1, p. 246).
435 Thither means into the land.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 33
chapter.p: 1. AND THIS IS THE BLESSING. This blessing is similar to the blessing of Jacob.1
THE MAN OF GOD. This teaches that Moses blessed them prophetically.
BEFORE HIS DEATH. Close to his death. This means on the day of his death.2

2. CAME FROM SINAI. The Gaon,3 of blessed memory, says that Mount Sinai, Seir, and Paran are close to each other.4 This verse speaks of the revelation at Sinai. Scripture reads mi-sinai (from Sinai), for mi-sinai has the same meaning as be-sinai (on Sinai).5 The same applies to the term mise’ir (from Seir).6
FROM THE MYRIADS HOLY. The reference is to the angels. Scripture speaks of the Divine presence, which descended.7
A FIERY LAW UNTO THEM. The Torah, which was given through fire and lightning.8

He9 says that the Lord came…is a prayer. It means, You who came to Sinai and bequeathed the Torah,10 Let Reuben live (v. 6). However, this interpretation is far-fetched, for Scripture should read, keep Reuben alive and do not put him to death.11

Those who lack faith say that from Seir refers to the religion of the Edomites,12 and Paran refers to the faith of the Ishmaelites.13 However, these err. Do they not see that Moses commenced at first to bless Israel alone. Scripture thus reads, wherewith Moses the man of God blessed the children of Israel (v. 1). Scripture goes on to say ve-zarach mi-se’ir lamo, the meaning of which is, And rose from Seir unto them.14 Compare, lamo (for them) in And there is no stumbling for them (Ps. 119:165).15

It appears to me that this chapter is a general blessing to all of Israel.16 Moses then goes on to address each tribe and tribe individually.17 Then Moses includes them all in the verse which reads, There is none unto God, O Jeshurun (v. 26).

Look,18 we find that Deborah said, Lord, when Thou didst go forth out of Seir, When Thou didst march out of the field of Edom, The earth trembled (Jud. 5:4). Clearly the field of Edom is not a mountain as the Gaon says,19 for the Gaon maintains that Sinai, Seir, and Paran are three mountains close to each other or facing each other. Also, the Book of Psalms states, O God, when Thou wentest forth before thy people, When Thou didst march through the wilderness (yeshimon); Selah (Ps. 68:8). Scripture then states, The earth trembled (Ps. 68:9).20 Now the Divine presence did not march through the wilderness (yeshimon) on the day that the Torah was given, for Israel came to the wilderness (yeshimon) after they had passed through the wilderness (midbar) of Paran.21 Furthermore, Habakkuk says, God cometh from Teman (Hab. 3:3). Teman was one of the sons of Edom, for we read, Teman, Omar (Gen. 36:11).22 From Teman means the same as from the field of Edom. Look, all the verses23 speak of war. Let God arise, let His enemies be scattered (Ps. 68:2) is proof of this. Scripture describes God’s saving of His servants in terms of help coming down from heaven, the earth melting, the mountains dissolving, and the heavens quaking. Then the earth did shake and quake (Ps. 18:8) in David’s song is proof of this. I have explained the meaning of even yon Sinai (Ps. 68:9) in its place.24

The following is the explanation of our verse. The Lord came refers to the glory that entered into Israel. It first entered Israel at Sinai. And rose from Seir means that God did not show His might among the nations all the years that Israel was in the wilderness until Israel came to the field of Edom. Scripture similarly states, in their mount Seir, unto El-paran (Gen. 14:6). Seir and Paran are thus close to each other.

The meaning of And rose from Se’ir is thus explained, for mi-seir means from the place of Seir; that is, when Israel came to Seir, God’s glory rose to Israel. He shined forth from mount Paran repeats the idea expressed by and rose from Seir. It means that God here25 showed His shining.

AND HE CAME FROM THE MYRIADS HOLY. I believe that this is connected to At His right hand. It means that fire came from the myriads holy at God’s right hand to surround Israel. It26 is similar to the horses and chariots of fire round about Elisha (II Kings 6:17).
[FIERY LAW.] The meaning of law27 is something constant.28

3. YEA, HE LOVETH THE PEOPLES. Hovev (loveth) comes from an Aramaic word. It29 has the meaning of then ye shall be Mine own treasure from among all peoples (Ex. 19:5). The peoples refers to Israel. Compare, After thee, Benjamin, among thy peoples (Jud. 5:14); They shall call peoples unto the mountain (v. 19).
[ALL HIS HOLY ONES.] This refers to the sons of Levi.
THEY ARE IN THY HAND. They are round about the ark.
AND THEY SIT DOWN AT THY FEET. This means they will walk in Your ways. The meaning of in Thy hand is, you will protect them.30
RECEIVING OF THY WORDS. They31 will teach Torah. They are the ones who transmit the oral Torah.

RECEIVING.32 Each and every one.33 This is so even though they are many.34 The meaning of Thy words35 is, that which You spoke they will bear,36 for they are the bearers of the Torah, and they also carry the ark.37 The word yissa (receiving) is similar to tissa (uttering) in Thou shalt not utter a false report (Ex. 23:1).

AND THEY SIT DOWN. Tukku (sit down) has no brother.38 Some say39 that it is related to the word mi-tokh (from the midst of).40 They, as it were, walk in the midst of Your feet. Others say that the tav41 is in place of a heh.42 It is like the tav of tirgalti (I taught)43 in I taught Ephraim (Hos. 11:3). The meaning of our verse is, even if they are beaten on Your account, they will not forsake Your words. However, this is farfetched. Actually it means are drawn;44 they go to the place of the ark which serves as the footstool for God’s feet.
This is the blessing:45 May God be a wall of fire round about Israel.46 May Israel be God’s treasure.47 May the Levites always teach the Torah.48

4. MOSES COMMANDED US A LAW. This is what they shall bear upon their lips and say from generation to generation: thus did we copy with our hands an inheritance from the mouth of Moses.49 The lamed of lanu (us) applies to itself and also to another word.50 Morashah kehillat ya’akov (an inheritance congregation of Jacob)51 should be read as if written morashah le-kehillat ya’akov (an inheritance of the congregation of Jacob). It is similar to ve-hanevu’ah oded ha-navi (even the prophecy Oded the prophet)52 (II Chronicles 15:8).53 Or54 morashah (an inheritance) should be read as if written twice. Our clause should be read as if written an inheritance, an inheritance of the congregation of Jacob.55

5. A KING. The reference is to Moses, from whose mouth the heads of the people clearly heard the words of the Torah. The meaning of our verse is that Moses was the equivalent of a king, and the heads of the tribes were gathered unto him.56 This interpretation is supported by Scripture’s statement that the Torah was given to the kohanim,57 who, in my opinion, are meant by All His holy ones-they are in Thy hand (v. 3), and to all the elders of Israel (Deut. 31:9). This is what When the heads of the people were gathered refers to. Scripture also writes there, Assemble unto me all the elders of your tribes (Deut. 31:28).
Rabbi Judah Ha-Levi, of blessed memory, says that the king alludes to the Torah. He similarly used to explain there was no king in Israel (Jud. 18:l).58

6. LET REUBEN LIVE. Moses starts with the first-born, for this is the proper practice. He does not mention Simeon because of the incident of Baal-peor,59 for those who served Baalpeor were from the tribe of Simeon.60 Their number61 proves this.62 Also, their prince was killed.63 It is also possible that Moses followed in the footsteps of Jacob,64 who did not bless Simeon and Levi. The tribe of Levi was blessed out of respect for Aaron. Simeon had no one as great as Aaron.65 Should one who disputes argue, “Why did Moses bless Reuben?”66 The answer is that Jacob blessed Reuben. The blessing was have not thou the excellency (Gen. 49:4).67 The meaning of the latter is that Reuben shall be like one of his brothers.

Moses mentions Judah after Reuben68 because he was in charge of a standard69 and he was the first to lead in battle. Next Levi and then Benjamin are mentioned70 because the Levites dwelled in Jerusalem, which was situated between Judah and Benjamin. Scripture clearly states this.71
Moses then mentions the tribe of Joseph so as not to delay naming him. He had already mentioned his younger brother.72 He next mentioned Zebulun because he waged war.73 He then mentioned Issachar.74

After Moses finished mentioning the children of the wives, he commenced with Gad,75 who camped among the standard of the children of the wives.76 Moses then mentions Dan, who was in charge of a standard.77 He then mentioned Naphtali because he was older than Asher.78
LET REUBEN LIVE. A prayer.
AND NOT DIE. For it is possible that he will be as a person who lives a certain number of years and then dies.79

IN THAT HIS MEN BECOME FEW.80 Ve-yehi metav mispar81 is to be rendered, and let his men not be numbered (few).82 It is similar to And I have not learned wisdom (Prov. 30:3)83 and to the bet of be-el shaddai (as God Almighty) (Ex. 6:3)84 as I have explained many times. Moses said this85 because it is possible for the tribe of Reuben to live forever but consist of few people. All things that are numbered are few. Compare, And I am men of number(Gen. 34:30).86
7. AND THIS FOR JUDAH. He similarly said to Judah,87 “Let Judah live and not die.” He also added, “Hear, Lord, the voice of Judah” when he goes to war, because Judah would go into battle first.88
AND BRING HIM IN UNTO HIS PEOPLE. To the camp, which was in Gilgal.89 On the other hand, it might be a prayer regarding those who go to do battle in the land of the enemy.90

HIS HAND SHALL CONTEND FOR HIM. Rav lo (contend for him) means shall be sufficient for him91 so that he has no need for anyone to help him but God’s help alone. Others say that the word rav is related to the word merivah (conflict). The meaning of yadav rav lo is that his hands shall fight for him. Others say that the word rav is like the word rav (shot forth) in and He shot forth lightnings (Ps. 18:15). It is related to va-robbu (and shot at him) (Gen. 49:23).92
8. AND OF LEVI. U-le-levi amar (and of Levi he said) is to be interpreted, And of Levi93 he said to God.94 Compare, say of me (li):95 He is my brother (Gen. 20:13).
WITH THY HOLY ONE. Le-ish chasidekha (with Thy holy one) means to the man who is Your holy one.96

WHOM THOU DIDST PROVE AT MASSAH. Massah is a noun. It means a test.97 The meaning of our clause is: Aaron was pious. Aside from the incident at Meribah,98 for which You already punished him,99 no unseemly thing was found in him.100 Also, this verse101 supports my interpretation regarding the incident of the calf, that is, that Aaron made the calf for God’s glory.102
[THY THUMMIM AND THY URIM.]103 This means may Thy Thummim and Thy Urim always be his104 and his seed’s.105
9. WHO SAID. Moses speaks of the tribe.106 Samuel who came to the house of God as soon as he was weaned,107 to be trained in God’s service, is an example.108
NOR KNEW HE HIS OWN CHILDREN. There were among them individuals who begot children for the service of God.109

FOR THEY HAVE OBSERVED110 THY WORD, AND KEEP THY COVENANT. Compare, They kept (shameru) His testimonies,111 and the statue that He gave them (Ps. 99:7) so that they would teach them to Israel. Some say that the reference112 is to Whoso is on the Lord’s side, let him come unto me (Ex. 32:26).
10. THEY SHALL PUT INCENSE. The reference is to those among them who are kohanim.
AND WHOLE BURNT-OFFERING. Kalil (whole burnt offering) refers to the olah (burnt offering).113
11. BLESS, LORD, HIS SUBSTANCE. The first-born and the tithe.
THE WORK OF HIS HANDS. The sacrifices.
SMITE THROUGH THE LOINS. Smite them that rise against him.
THAT THEY RISE NOT AGAIN. Min yekumun114 (that they rise not again) means of those that will rise against them.115 Compare, la-yam mekhassim (cover the sea) (Is. 11:9).116
12. OF BENJAMIN HE SAID. Le-vinyamin means of Benjamin.117 Moses said of Benjamin, who is the beloved of the Lord,118 Benjamin shall dwell in safety by God, and God shall dwell between his shoulders.
HE COVERETH HIM. The reference is to God’s glory which, as Scripture writes,119 dwelled in Benjamin’s portion, in Jerusalem.

The meaning of between his shoulders is, in the center of his inheritance. Or between his shoulders means that God’s glory was visible.120 Furthermore, between his shoulders is also connected to covereth.121
13. FOR THE PRECIOUS THINGS. Which the heavens will give.
14. THE FRUITS OF THE SUN. For the fruits of the seed and the vineyard are dependent upon the sun.

THE YIELD. Geresh (yield) is related to the word vayigreshu (cast up) in And its waters cast up (Is. 57:20). The moon does this122 via the moisture which is in the air,123 for its heat is unlike the power of the sun.124
Scripture reads moons125 because they renew themselves,126 and there are many of them in the year.127
15. AND FOR THE TOPS. This means and for the precious things that grow on the tops of the ancient hills.128
THE EVERLASTING HILLS. Scripture repeats itself.
16. AND FOR THE PRECIOUS THINGS OF THE EARTH. Scripture repeats itself. The earth refers to flat land.129
AND THE FULNESS THEREOF. From what it is full of.130
AND THE GOOD WILL OF HIM THAT DWELT IN THE BUSH. The reference is to heaven.131

LET THE BLESSING COME. Tavotah (let the blessing come)132 refers to this blessing.133 Two signs,134 the tav and the heh, are joined together.135 Compare, ezratah (help) (Ps. 44:27);136 yeshu’atah (salvation) (Ps. 3:3);137 ba-tzaratah (in…distress) (Ps. 120:1).138

Moses compared the tribe of Joseph to a bullock because he earlier spoke of produce.139 Moses referred to Joseph as His firstling bullock (v. 17) because a first-born bullock has great strength as it is the first of its father’s might.
17. MAJESTY IS HIS. His140 body is large. It means that the tribe of Joseph is large in number.
THE HORNS OF THE WILD-OX. In power.
THE TEN THOUSANDS OF EPHRAIM. As in the words of Jacob.141
18. REJOICE, ZEBULUN, IN THY GOING OUT. To war. Similarly Zebulun is a people that jeoparded their lives unto the death (Jud. 5:18).
IN THY TENTS. Compare, For he saw a resting-place that it was good (Gen. 49:15).142

19. THEY SHALL CALL PEOPLES UNTO THE MOUNTAIN. Zebulun shall possess great wealth because he dwells where ships dock. This is the meaning of they shall suck the abundance of the seas. The word shefa (abundance) is related to the word shifat (caravan) in The caravan of camels shall cover thee (Is. 60:6).

AND THE HIDDEN TREASURES OF THE SAND. The word sefune (hidden) has no brother.143 It has the same meaning as temune (treasures).144 Similarly admat afar (dust).145 The meaning of the hidden treasures of the sand is that Zebulun will have so much wealth that they [the tribe] will hide it in the sand. And because of their wealth, they will come in a multitude to the mountain of God to offer sacrifices of thanksgiving to the Lord.
20. ENLARGETH GAD. Moses compares Gad to a lion. All who see him will flee from him. No one shall torment him.
21. AND HE CHOSE A FIRST PART FOR HIMSELF.146 This means he looked out for himself and sought an inheritance before the other Israelites.147
FOR THERE A PORTION OF A RULER WAS RESERVED. The word chelkat (portion of) means a portion.
[A RULER.] Mechokek (ruler) refers to someone who is great and a ruler. Compare, My heart is toward the governors (le-chokeke) of Israel (Jud. 5:9).

[RESERVED.] The word safun (reserved) is similar to safun (ceiled) in and it is ceiled148 with cedar (Jer. 22:14); and sefunim (ceiled) in be-vattekhem sefunim (Haggai 1:4), which means your houses which are ceiled. The import of ki sham chelkak mechokek safun (for there a portion of a ruler was preserved)149 is that Gad saw the paneled palaces that were the portion of the nobles of the Amorites.
CAME. Va-yeta (came)150 is missing an alef.151 The meaning of our clause is that the heads of Gad came armed with the children of Israel.152 Moses prophetically saw this.

HE EXECUTED THE RIGHTEOUSNESS OF THE LORD. Gad fulfilled with his hands153 that which he spoke with his mouth, for the children of Gad vowed that they would go out with Israel to wage battle against their enemies.154 Moses did not mention Reuben.155 It is possible that he omitted Reuben because the tribe of Gad were greater warriors than the tribe of Reuben. The words of Chronicles, which states regarding the tribe of Gad, whose faces were like the faces of lions (I Chron. 12:9), is proof of this. We do not find this stated regarding the tribe of Reuben.
22. LEAPETH. The word yezannek (leapeth) has no companion in Scripture. Our clause is to be understood as follows: Moses compared Dan’s might to that of a lion’s whelp leaping from Mount Bashan.156
23. SATISFIED WITH FAVOR. Seva ratzon (satisfied) is an adjective. It means he will be sated with favor.157
THE SEA AND SOUTH. Yam158 ve-darom (the sea and south) means that Naphtali’s inheritance shall be in the southwest.159
24. THE FAVORED. Ratzuy (favored) means the beloved.
AND LET HIM DIP HIS FOOT IN OIL. Because of the abundance of oil. It is similar to He washeth his garments in wine (Gen. 49:11). Jacob similarly said,160 his bread shall be fat (Gen. 49:20).
25. IRON AND BRASS SHALL BE THY BARS.161 For mountains of iron and brass shall be in his portion.162

AND AS THY DAYS, SO SHALL THY STRENGTH BE. The word dovekha (thy strength) has no neighbor.163 The interpretation of the Aramaic translation164 is known, namely, that you will be strong all your days. Some say that the alef of dovekha is in place of the doubled letter.165 It is like the word baze’u (divide)166 in Whose land the rivers divide (Is. 18:2). They believe that dovekha is related to the word dovev (moving gently) in Moving gently the lips of those that are asleep (Cant. 7:10).167 This interpretation is not reasonable.168
26. THERE IS NONE LIKE UNTO GOD, O JESHURUN. Moses goes back to bless all of Israel.
WHO RIDETH UPON THE HEAVEN. That is, who is mighty. The fact that He rideth upon the heaven is proof of this.
[AND IN HIS EXCELLENCY ON THE SKIES.]169 It means, the heavens stand by God’s might.170

27. THE ETERNAL GOD IS A DWELLING-PLACE. Note that the word ma’on (dwelling-place) means a covering (i.e., a sukkah).171 In Salem also is set His covering172 (sukko), And His dwelling-place (me’onato) in Zion173 (Ps. 76:3) is proof of this. There are many such examples.174 The meaning of our verse is: The eternal God is your covering.175 Compare, Even the Most High, thy habitation (me’onekha)176 (Ps. 91:9) and Thou hast been our dwelling-place (ma’on) (Ps. 90:1). The ma’on (dwelling place) is always above the one who takes refuge in it.177 The “place”178 is below.179
AND UNDERNEATH ARE THE EVERLASTING ARMS. Which will support you.

Scripture reads everlasting to teach that it shall always be so. The hand will not weaken, and your covering (ma’on) will not be removed, for He is the eternal God. The meaning of kedem (everlasting) is that God has no beginning and no end. Scripture speaks in human terms when it speaks of beginning and end.180
The Gaon says that and underneath means and underneath God. He did not explain anything.
28. THE FOUNTAIN OF JACOB. All those who came forth out of the fountain of Jacob.181 Similarly And are come forth out of the fountain of Judah (Is. 48:1).
IN A LAND. El eretz is to be rendered, in a land.182 It is similar to if they pray in this place183 (el ha-makom ha-zeh)184 (I Kings 8:35).

YEA, HIS HEAVENS. The heavens of the earth or of Israel.185 The meaning of our verse is, it is the nature of the land186 to produce corn and oil. Also, the heavens shall always give their dew and there will be no need to water the ground.187
29. WHO IS LIKE UNTO THEE. Among the nations.
THE SHIELD OF THY HELP. No evil shall come upon you.
AND THAT IS THE SWORD. He is the sword by which you will exalt yourself over all your enemies.
SHALT TREAD. Tidrokh (shall tread) is similar to midrakh (to tread on) in for the sole of the foot to tread on (Deut. 2:5). The contents of our verse are similar to the account of Gideon.188
chapter.ftnote: 1 It speaks of the future. See I.E. on Gen. 49:1 (Vol. 1, p. 419).
2 Before his death is to be taken literally.
3 Rabbi Saadiah Gaon.
4 See Sefer Ha-Emunot Ve-Ha-De’ot 3:8. “These (Sinai, Seir, Paran) are three names for Mount Sinai.” The Gaon claims that the different names refer to different sides of the mountain.
5 That is, to Sinai. Thus the meaning of Adonai mi-sinai ba (the Lord came from Sinai) is, God came to Sinai.

6 It means to Seir. Saadiah Gaon is reacting to an interpretation offered by Jewish heretics or apostates. The apostates interpreted our verse as follows: God first revealed himself to Israel at Sinai. He then revealed himself to the Christians (Seir). He then revealed himself to the Arabs (Paran). This heretical interpretation is based on a midrash which identifies Seir with Christianity and Paran with the Arabs. See Sefer Ha-Emunot Ve-Ha-De’ot 3:8. Also see Mark Cohen, Under Crescent and Cross, p. 156, Princeton University Press, 1994.
7 On Mount Sinai.
9 The Gaon.
10 To Israel.

11 Verse 6 reads yechi re’uven ve-al yamut, the import of which is, may Reuben live, and not die. If Saadiah Gaon’s interpretation was correct the verse would read hachayeh et re’uven ve-al tamito (keep Reuben alive and do not put him to death). In other words, Scripture would have employed the imperative hachayeh (keep him alive) rather than the third person yechi (let him live). It similarly would have employed the second person tamito (you will put him to death) in place of the third person yamut (he will die).
12 Christianity.
13 See note 6.
14 Israel.
15 In other words, lamo means unto them.
16 Verses 2-5.
17 Verses 6-25.
18 I.E. goes on to explain our verse.
19 For a field is not a mountain. The field of Edom (sede edom) is parallel to Seir. If sede edom does not refer to a mountain neither does Seir.

20 We thus see that Jud. 5:4, which speaks of the earth trembling, does not refer to the revelation at Sinai for Ps. 68:8 indicates that the earth trembled in the yeshimon not at Sinai. I.E. comments thus because someone might still insist on identifying the field of Edom with Mount Sinai. It should be noted that I.E. insists that the clause “the earth trembled” in Jud. 5:4 and the similar clause in Ps. 68:9 refer to the same event. See I.E. on Ps. 68:8.
21 We thus see that Seir is to be identified with Sinai.
22 Are the sons of Eliphaz the son of Esau (Edom).
23 The verse quoted from Judges, Psalms, and Habbakuk.

24 See I.E. on Ps. 68:8. The meaning of Ps. 68:9 is that the earth trembled as Mount Sinai (zeh sinai) did. In other words, the phrase zeh sinai does not imply that what comes before (the earth trembled…) refers to the revelation at Sinai.
25 In Paran and Seir.
26 The statement that fire came from God’s hand to surround Israel.
27 Hebrew, dat. I.E. renders esh dat (a fiery law) as a constant fire.
28 I.E. interprets our verse as follows: a constant fire comes to them at His right hand.
29 Yea, He loveth the peoples.
30 I.E. earlier interpreted in Thy hand to mean that the Levites camp around the ark. His comment here is either another interpretation or it explains why Moses refers to the ark as Thy hand.
31 The Levites.
32 Hebrew yissa (literally, they will bear).
33 Of the Levites.
34 The verse opens with the plural (ve-hem). However, yissa (receiving) is singular. Hence I.E.’s comment.
35 That is, the meaning of yissa mi-dabberotekha (literally, they will bear your words).
36 Upon their lips.
37 Hence Scripture employs the term yissa, which means to bear upon the lips (to speak of, to teach) and to physically bear.
38 It does not appear elsewhere in Scripture.
39 See Rashi.
40 That is, to the word tokh.
41 Of tukku.
42 In other words, tukku is a variant of hukku (were beaten).
43 Tirgalti is a variant of hirgalti.
44 According to I.E. The literal meaning of tukku le-raglekha is, they are drawn to your feet.
45 With which Moses blessed Israel.
46 Verse 2.
47 Verse 3.
48 Verse 3.
49 In other words, Moses dictated to us and we transcribed the Torah.
50 It is to be placed before the word kehillat.
51 Morashah kehillat ya’akov literally means an inheritance congregation of Jacob. Hence I.E.’s comment.
52 Translated literally
53 Which is to be read as if written ve-hanevu’ah nevu’at oded ha-navi [even the prophecy (they), prophecy of Oded the prophet]. See I.E. on Gen. 2:9 (Vol. 1, p. 54).
54 I.E. is obviously offering another interpretation.
55 Our verse should be read as if written torah tzivvah lanu mosheh morashah, morashah kehillat ya’akov (Moses commanded us a law, an inheritance, an inheritance of the congregation of Jacob).
56 To study Torah.
58 He renders the verse, there was no Torah in Israel. That is, there was no rule of law.
60 See Num. 25:14.
61 Their drop in number.

62 When the tribe of Simeon was counted in the second year after the Exodus, they numbered 59,300. (Num. 1:23). When they were counted following the incident of Baal-peor, they numbered 22,200 (Num. 26:14). In other words, the number of the tribe was diminished by 37,100.
64 On his deathbed. See Gen. 49:5-7.
65 Hence they were not blessed.
66 When Jacob apparently did not bless him. See Gen. 49:3,4.
67 Of dignity and power.
68 Even though Levi was born before Judah.

69 For committing harlotry with a Midianite princess. The point is that the leader of the tribe of Simeon as well as a large proportion of the sinners at Baal-peor were Simeonites. Hence Moses did not bless them. See Num. 2:3-9.
70 After Judah.
71 See Josh. 15:8.
72 Benjamin.
73 Zebulun is a people that jeoparded their lives unto death (Jud. 5:18).
74 Who, like Zebulun, was a son of Leah.
75 That is, he commenced the listing of the children of the handmaids with Gad.
76 He camped under the banner of Reuben. See Num. 2:14.
77 See Num. 2:25.
79 In other words, Moses prayed that the tribe of Reuben exist forever and not disappear with the death of the present generation.
80 Literally, and let his men be numbered.
81 Ve-yehi metav mispar literally means and let his men be numbered (few).
82 For the word al (not) which precedes yamot is to be inserted after the vav of ve-yehi. Our clause is to be read as if written va-al yehi metav mispar.

83 Wherein the word lo (not, no) is to read as if written twice. Prov. 30:3 literally reads: I have not learned wisdom and I have knowledge of the Holy One. The verse should be read as if written: I have not learned wisdom and I have no knowledge of the Holy One.
84 Ex. 6:3 reads u-shemi. According to I.E. this is be interpreted as if written u-veshemi, for the bet of be-El also applies to the word u-shemi. See I.E. on Ex. 6:3 (Vol. 2, pp. 131,132.)
85 That Reuben’s men not be few.
86 Translated literally.
87 And this for Judah means he similarly said this to Judah.
88 When Israel conquered Canaan. See Jud. 1:1,2; 20:18.
89 Israel’s main camp was at Gilgal during the period of the conquest. See Chapters 9 and 10 of Joshua.
90 During the period of the monarchy. See Rashi.
91 The word rav means abundant. Hence rav lo literally means shall be abundant for him, that is, shall be more than enough for him to do what he has to do.

92 According to this interpretation our clause reads: his hands shall shoot for him; that is, he will be able to hold a bow and shoot at his enemies. See Ps. 18:35, so that mine arms do bend a bow of brass.
93 U-le-levi is to be rendered, and of Levi, not and to Levi.
94 He said, which is all the text provides, is short for he said to God.
95 Here too the word li is to be rendered of me, not to me. See I.E. on Gen. 20:13 (Vol. 1, p. 213).
96 Le-ish chasidekha (with Thy holy one) literally means to the man Your holy one. Hence I.E.’s comment.
97 According to I.E. our clause should be rendered, whom Thou didst prove with a test. Massah is also the name of a place. Hence I.E.’s comment.
99 I.E.’s interpretation of With whom Thou didst strive at the waters of Meribah.
100 Otherwise they would be mentioned here.
101 In additions to other proofs.

102 Our verse implies that the only sin that Aaron committed was the one at Meribah. Had Aaron sinned in making the golden calf, then that sin would have been mentioned. Furthermore, if Aaron had made an idol Moses would not have referred to him as ish chasidekha. See I.E. on Ex. 31:18 (Vol. 2, pp. 653-663).
103 That is the meaning of Thy Thummim and Thy Urim be with Thy holy one.
104 Aaron’s.
105 Aaron and his descendants.
106 Of Levi.
108 Who forsook his family to serve God.
109 They handed over their children to God’s service and did not ever see them again (Weiser).
110 Hebrew shameru (literally, kept).
111 They preserved the contents of God’s revelation in order to teach it to Israel. See I.E. on Ps. 99:7.
112 Of They have observed Thy word…
113 A sacrifice which is totally consumed by the fire on the altar. See Lev. 1:1-13.
114 Min yekumun literally means of them will arise against them.
115 In other words, min yekumun is short for min asher yekumun alehem, that is, of them that will arise against them. Yekumun is a variation of yakum (they shall arise).
116 La-yam mekhassim is to be read as if written asher la-yam mekhassim, i.e., that cover the sea.
117 Not to Benjamin. The lamed usually means to. Hence I.E.’s comment.
118 In other words, le-vinyamin amar yedid Adonai should be interpreted, le-vinyamin yedid Adonai amar.
120 Over the temple. See Rashi: The temple was built on the highest spot of Benjamin’s land.
121 He covereth him all the day, And He dwelleth beween his shoulders is to be interpreted, He covereth him, and dwelleth between his shoulders all the day (Krinsky).
122 Produces its yield.
123 The moon affects the moisture in the air. This results in “the yield of the moon.”

124 Which directly influences the growth of plants. The sun’s rays directly influence plant life. The moon has no rays. I.E. believed that the moon influences plant growth by its effect on the moisture in the air.
125 There is one moon. Hence I.E.’s comment.
126 The moon reappears each month.
127 There is thus a new moon each month. Hence one may speaks of “moons.”

128 In other words, the word meged from the previous verse also applies here. Thus u-merosh harere kedem (and for the tops of the ancient mountains) is to be read as if written u-mi-meged rosh ha-rere kedem (and for the precious things that grow on the tops of the ancient mountains).
129 For the earth is in contrast to the mountains and hills mentioned in the previous verse.
130 Not only the produce of the land but of all things that the earth is full of, i.e., gold, silver, etc. (Krinsky).
131 I.E. interprets the word seneh (bush) as meaning heaven. However, he rejects this interpretation in Ex. 3:2 (Vol. 2, pp. 52,53).
132 Tavotah is the elongated or poetic form of the word tavo.
133 The blessing mentioned in verses 13-16.
134 Two letters which are signs of the feminine.
135 The elongated form of tavo should have read tavo’ah or tavo’at. Tavotah is a combination of the two.
136 Ezratah is a combination of the two feminine forms ezrat and ezrah.
137 Yeshu’atah (salvation) is a combination of the two feminine forms yeshu’ah and yeshu’at.
138 Tzaratah is a combination of tzarah and tzarat.
139 Bulls are used in plowing and for pulling carts loaded with produce.
140 The bullock’s.
141 Who gave Joseph the blessing of many children. See Gen. 49:25.
142 Gen. 49:15 refers to the tribe of Issachar.
143 It is not found elsewhere in Scripture.
144 Our verse reads sefune temune. I.E. believes that Scripture employs two words back to back that have one meaning. It means hidden hidden [of the earth].
145 Dan. 12:2. Both words mean the same. Our text literally reads dust dust.

146 Literally, he saw a first (reshit) for himself. According to I.E. he saw is short for he sought an inheritance. First means before the other Israelites, and himself means he sought it for himself. Hence I.E.’s interpretation.
147 Received their inheritance. See Num. 32.
148 Ceilinged or paneled.
149 Which, according to I.E., means for there is the ceiled palace of the ruler.
150 Spelled vav, yod, tav, alef.
151 It should be spelled vav, yod, alef, tav, alef, for its root is alef, tav, alef.
152 To conquer Canaan. See Josh. 1:12-18; 22:1-9.
153 That is, Gad did in practice.

155 When he mentioned Gad’s keeping the oath which they made to join Israel in the conquest of Canaan. The same oath was made and observed by the tribe of Reuben. See Num. 32:16,17 and Josh. 1:12-18; 22:1-9.

156 In other words, yezannek means leap. According to I.E. our verse should be understood as follows: Dan is as powerful as a young lion leaping forth from Mount Bashan. Bashan is a district in Transjordan.
157 In other words, seva is not to be taken as an imperative with our verse meaning Naphtali be satisfied with God’s favor.
158 I.E. renders yam (sea) as west.
159 Of the tribe of Dan (Weiser).
160 Regarding the tribe of Dan.
161 Hebrew, minalekha. I.E. renders this, the place where you walk upon with your shoes (na’alkha). Hence I.E.’s interpretation.
162 Hence Asher will step upon iron and brass.
163 It is not found elsewhere in the Bible.
164 Onkelos renders u-kheyamekha dovekha (and as thy days, so shall thy strength be), and as thy youth so shall your strength be [all the days of your life].
165 In other words, dovekha comes from the root dalet, bet, bet.
166 Which is a variant of bazezu, for the alef in baze’u takes the place of a zayin.
167 They interpret u-kheyamekha dovekha to mean: as in your youth so shall you speak [all the days of your life]; i.e., you shall always speak happily as young people are wont to do (Weiser).
168 It does not fit the context.
169 Literally, and in His excellency the skies.

170 I.E. renders be-gavato (in His excellency) by His might. Therefore And in His might the skies is short for and by His might the heavens stand. I.E. renders our verse as follows: He who rides upon the heavens is your help, and He [so too is] by whose might the heavens stand.
171 Literally, booth. According to I.E. a sukkah is so called because it has a covering over it.
172 Translated literally.
173 For sukko is parallel to me’onato.
174 Where the word sukkah is used in the sense of protection.
175 That is, your protection.
176 I.E. renders this as even the Most High, your protection.
177 According to I.E., ma’on means a protective covering. God serves as a protective covering above us.
178 The rabbis refer to God as “The Place (makom).”

179 Either beneath the protective covering or beneath the person being protected. In other words, ma’on refers to “up above” and makom to below. God is referred to as “The Place” because He is present in all places on the earth. See I.E.’s introduction to Esther, “God is not referred to as ‘The Place (makom)’ in any of the books of Scripture. On the contrary, He is referred to as ‘dwelling place (ma’on),’ for the ma’on which is always on high. However, the ancients, of blessed memory, called God ‘The Place’ because all places are full of His glory.”
180 In reference to God.
181 The meaning of The fountain of Jacob is, All those who came forth out of the fountain of Jacob, i.e., all those descended from Jacob.
182 Reading be-eretz as in Vat. Ebr. 38.
183 Translated according to I.E.
184 El ha-makom ha-zeh (to this place) is to be interpreted as if written bamakom ha-zeh.
185 The heavens over the Land of Israel.
186 Of the land in Israel.
187 The meaning of our verse is, God brought Israel into a land which produces corn and oil and whose heavens shall always give dew, and there will be no need to irrigate the ground.

188 Whose men shouted, “The sword for the Lord and for Gideon.” See Jud. 7:20. Vat. Ebr. 38 reads: As in the account of Gibeon. See Josh. 10:24, Come near, put your feet upon the necks of these kings. And they came near, and put their feet upon the necks of them.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 34
chapter.p: 1. AND MOSES WENT UP. I believe that Joshua wrote from this verse onward,1 for Moses did not write2 after he ascended.3 Joshua wrote prophetically.4 And the Lord showed him; And the Lord said unto him (v. 4); and also, And he was buried (v. 6) are proof.5
5. SO MOSES THE SERVANT OF THE LORD DIED THERE. Even in his death Moses, like a servant, did what God commanded him.

ACCORDING TO THE WORD OF THE LORD.6 For God told him, Get thee up (Deut. 32:49) and die (Deut. 32:50). Scripture similarly writes with regard to the death of Aaron, at the commandment of the Lord7 (Num. 33:38). It similarly states, At the commandment of the Lord8 they encamped (Num. 9:23).

6. AND HE WAS BURIED.9 Moses buried himself.10 He entered a cave in the valley. The same is true of but the shepherds fed them (otam),11 and fed not My sheep (Ezek. 34:8) and, And the officers of the children of Israel did see them12 (otam)13 (Ex. 5:19).

Note,14 Mount Abarim is also known as Mount Nebo.15 Nebo is in the image of Mercury.16 Mount Abarim is also known as “the valley which is the top of Pisgah which is over against Beth-peor.”17 The fact that Scripture tells us that Israel journeyed from Bamoth to the valley that is in the field of Moab, by the top of Pisgah (Num. 21:20) is proof of this.18 Furthermore, Scripture writes, And Moses went up from the plains of Moab unto mount Nebo, to the top of Pisgah (v. 1).19 Moses died there20 and his grave is there.21

Scripture states,22 So we abode in the valley over against Beth-peor (Deut. 3:29). Now, Scripture tells us that after Israel dwelt in the valley…the children of Israel journeyed, and pitched in the plains of Moab (Num. 22:1). Another verse states, And [Israel] pitched in the mountains of Abarim, in front of Nebo. And they journeyed from the mountains of Abarim, and pitched in the plains of Moab (Num. 33:47,48). Look, it is clear that Moses’ burial place was in the place where he died.23
UNTO THIS DAY. These are the words of Joshua.24 He probably wrote this at the end of his days.25

7. HIS NATURAL FORCE. The heh of lechoh (his natural force) is in place of a vav.26 It is like the heh of oholoh (his tent) (Gen. 9:21).27 Lechoh is related to the word lach (moist, fresh).28 Scripture notes this29 because old people are overtaken by dryness. The word nas (abated) is the reverse of diffused.30
8. THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL. However, when Aaron died, even all the house of Israel (Num. 20:29) mourned out of respect for Moses.31
SO…WERE ENDED. When the days of weeping in the mourning of Moses were ended there,32 the children of Israel hearkened unto Joshua.

9. WAS FULL OF THE SPIRIT OF WISDOM. The reference is to the spirit of the Lord.33 For Moses had laid his hands upon him is proof of this,34 for there was not found in Israel one such as Joshua for Moses to lean on.35
AND DID AS THE LORD COMMANDED MOSES. That they hearken unto Joshua.
10. FACE TO FACE. I have previously explained this.36
12. THE MIGHTY HAND. The wonders at the sea.37
THE GREAT TERROR. When Israel stood before Mount Sinai.38
chapter.ftnote: 1 In other words, Joshua composed Chapter 34.
2 Anything.
3 Mount Nebo. Hence he could not have composed this chapter.
4 Chapter 34 was written under Divine inspiration. Hence it could be appended to the Torah.
5 That Chapter 34 was written prophetically, for otherwise how would Joshua know these things.
6 Hebrew, al pi Adonai (literally, by God’s mouth). Hence I.E.’s comment.
7 Hebrew, al pi Adonai.

8 Hebrew, al pi Adonai. We thus see that al pi Adonai is not to be taken literally but is to be interpreted according to God’s command. I.E. comments thus because there is a midrash which takes al pi Adonai literally and tells us that Moses died by God’s kiss. See Mo’ed Katan 28a; Bava Batra 17a. Also see Rashi.
9 Hebrew, va-yikbor oto (literally, and he buried him).
10 Va-yikbor oto (and he buried him) is to be rendered, and he buried himself. I.E.’s point is that the pronoun oto (him) or otam (them) sometimes has the meaning of himself or themselves.
11 Otam (them) is to be rendered themselves. Our clause thus reads, but the shepherds fed themselves.
12 Translated literally.
13 Which is to be rendered, and the officers of the children of Israel did see themselves (otam).

14 Scripture refers to Moses’ burial place by the following names: Mount Abarim (Deut. 32:49); Mount Nebo (Deut. 34:1); the top of Pisgah (Ibid.); the valley (gai) which is over against Beth-peor (Deut. 34:6). I.E. goes on to explain that all of these terms refer to one and the same place.
15 See Deut. 32:39.

16 Nebo is the name of an idol in the image of Mercury (Krinsky). See I. E. on Is. 46:1, Bel boweth down, Nebo stoopeth. According to I.E. the idol Nebo stood and was worshipped on Mount Abarim. Hence Mount Abarim was also known as Mount Nebo.
17 In other words, Mount Abarim, Mount Nebo, the valley which is the top of Pisgah which is over against Beth-peor all refer to one place.
18 That the valley (gai) is to be identified with the top of Pisgah.
19 We thus see that Pisgah and Mount Nebo refer to the same place.
20 On Mount Nebo.
21 On Mount Nebo.
22 Additional proof that the valley and Mount Abarim are one and the same.

23 I.E. takes issue with the midrash that states that Moses died in the land of the tribe of Reuben (the location of Mount Nebo) but was buried in the land belonging to the tribe of Gad. See Sifre and Sotah 13b.
24 Contrary to the opinion of Rabbi Meir in the Talmud that Moses also wrote this verse. See Bava Batra 15a: “The Holy One, blessed be He, dictated, and Moses wrote in tears.”
25 Unto this day indicates that some time had passed since the death of Moses.
26 The pronoun “his” is usually indicated by a vav. Here it is indicated by a heh. Hence I.E.’s comment.
27 Which is in place of a vav.
28 Thus lechoh means his moistness.
29 That Moses’ moisture did not abate.
30 Moisture is diffused throughout the skin of a young person. However, it is removed from the skin of an old man. See Filwarg.

31 The word “all” does not appear before the children of Israel. I.E. believes that Moses did not leave any survivors of such importance that out of respect for them all of Israel would participate in the public mourning for him. It should be noted that the midrash offers a different interpretation for the difference in mourning for Moses and Aaron. See Rashi: “The children of Israel wept,” i.e., the men; but regarding Aaron, because he pursued peace, and made peace between a man and his fellow, and between a woman and her husband, it is stated, “The whole house of Israel wept [for him] the men and the women” (Rosenbaum and Silberman translation). See Pirke De Rabbi Eliezer, Chapter 17.
32 In the plains of Moab.

33 Scripture states, And the spirit of the Lord shall rest upon him (Is. 11:2). It then goes on to explain that the spirit of the Lord is the spirit of wisdom and understanding (Ibid.). See I.E. on Ex. 31:3 (Vol. 2, pp. 645,646).
34 That Joshua was full of the spirit of wisdom.

35 Another term for “place his hands on him.” It is possible that I.E. interprets Moses had laid his hands upon him to mean relied on him, i.e., took him for a disciple. Be that as it may, according to I.E, For Moses had laid his hands upon him does not mean that the placing of Moses’ hand on Joshua caused Joshua to be full of the spirit of wisdom but rather that Moses placed his hands on Joshua because Joshua was full of the spirit of God.
36 See I.E. on Deut. 3:5.
37 See Ex. 14:31: And Israel saw the mighty hand of God (literal translation).
